EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level disturbance moved across southern New England bringing cold air in at the upper levels and producing showers and thunderstorms.  The cold air at the upper levels created conditions conducive to the production of large hail.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Penny to quarter size hail fell in Canton.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several trees were downed by thunderstorm winds, including one that blocked Torrington Avenue.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Penny size hail fell in a swath from Avon to downtown Hartford.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trees on Lasalle Road were downed by thunderstorm winds.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Large tree limbs were downed by thunderstorm winds.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Multiple trees were downed by thunderstorm winds.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trees on Ashford and Westford Roads were downed by thunderstorm winds.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A tree on Bedlam Road was downed by thunderstorm winds.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A weak cold front moved through Southern New England, coupling with a warm, tropical airmass to produce showers and thunderstorms.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Large limbs were downed by thunderstorm winds.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A weak cold front moved through Southern New England, coupling with a warm, tropical airmass to produce showers and thunderstorms.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trees on Avon Road were downed by thunderstorm winds.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A weak cold front moved through Southern New England, coupling with a warm, tropical airmass to produce showers and thunderstorms.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trees on Mountain Road were downed by thunderstorm winds.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A weak cold front moved through Southern New England, coupling with a warm, tropical airmass to produce showers and thunderstorms.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trees were downed by thunderstorm winds.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Substantial low level moisture combined with an upper level disturbance to produce showers and thunderstorms across Southern New England.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A tree was downed by thunderstorm winds.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An approaching cold front, tropical moisture, and diurnal heating produced showers and thunderstorms across portions of Southern New England, some of which were severe.
An approaching cold front, tropical moisture, and diurnal heating produced showers and thunderstorms across portions of Southern New England, some of which were severe.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trees along the southbound lane of Route 32 near the intersection with Route 275 were downed by thunderstorm winds.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Following the passage of a strong cold front, strong west winds developed.  Peak gusts ranged from around 40 to 50 mph and caused scattered power outages.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Strong winds downed tree limbs in Fairfield.||The ASOS at Sikorsky Airport in Bridgeport measured a peak gust to 46 mph at 1:39 pm EDT.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Moderate tidal flooding was caused by a strong pressure gradient between high pressure to the north and a coastal storm passing south of Long Island October 17th and 18th.||A prolonged period of strong northeast winds across coastal waters coupled with astronomically high tides caused water to build along the coast followed by tidal piling.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Bayview section of Milford, and New Haven Avenue were flooded around the time of high tide.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system developed over the lower Mississippi Valley during Tuesday January 27th. The low then strengthened, and tracked northeast from the lower Ohio Valley Wednesday morning on January 28th, into Pennsylvania during Wednesday afternoon, and into northern New England by Thursday morning January 29th. ||This storm spread a mixture of snow, sleet and freezing rain across northwest Connecticut, beginning early Wednesday morning, and ending Wednesday evening.||Snow and sleet amounts ranged from 3 to 6 inches, with the greatest amounts occurring across the higher elevations within northeast Litchfield County. In addition, ice accretion from freezing rain generally was under one tenth of an inch.

A low pressure system developed over the lower Mississippi Valley during Tuesday January 27th. The low then strengthened, and tracked northeast from the lower Ohio Valley Wednesday morning on January 28th, into Pennsylvania during Wednesday afternoon, and into northern New England by Thursday morning January 29th. ||This storm spread a mixture of snow, sleet and freezing rain across northwest Connecticut, beginning early Wednesday morning, and ending Wednesday evening.||Snow and sleet amounts ranged from 3 to 6 inches, with the greatest amounts occurring across the higher elevations within northeast Litchfield County. In addition, ice accretion from freezing rain generally was under one tenth of an inch.
Strong low pressure moving through New York State coupled with a vigorous low level jet resulted in periods of damaging wind across Southern New England.  Rain and occasional thunder also occurred.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Automated Surface Observing System at Windham Airport in Willimantic, CT (KIJD) recorded sustained wind speeds of 37 mph and gusts to 56 mph.  In addition, reports were received of large tree limbs blown down onto wires, bringing the wires down as well.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Following the passage of a strong cold front, strong west winds developed.  Peak gusts ranged from around 40 to 50 mph and caused scattered power outages.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Strong winds downed tree limbs that caused power outages in Naugatuck, Middlebury, and Woodbury.  About 6,700 customers in Naugatuck were without power.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Following the passage of a strong cold front, strong west winds developed.  Peak gusts ranged from around 40 to 50 mph and caused scattered power outages.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Strong winds downed a tree onto a house and cars on Springside Avenue in New Haven.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong upper level system initiated a line of hail producing thunderstorms across the New York Metropolitan area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Law Enforcement reported nickel size hail and large downed trees in Redding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An intense area of low pressure over the Eastern Great Lakes on the morning of February 12, tracked northeast and up into the Canadian Maritimes by evening. High winds developed near daybreak, right behind the cold front, and continued through the day. The strongest winds occurred during the morning and appeared to be associated with sharp pressure rises right behind the cold front. There were numerous trees and power lines down from the event, with several thousand power outages across southern Connecticut.||The following are some peak wind gusts across southern Connecticut: Fairfield County, New Canaan 51 mph; New Haven County, Hamden and Oxford at 54 mph; Middlesex County, 48 mph at Durham; and New London County, 51 mph at Groton.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Connecticut Light and Power reported several thousand power outages with the city of Danbury hit the hardest, with over 2000 customers without power in the morning. Downed power lines and trees across the area resulted in numerous road closures across the area.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An intense area of low pressure over the Eastern Great Lakes on the morning of February 12, tracked northeast and up into the Canadian Maritimes by evening. High winds developed near daybreak, right behind the cold front, and continued through the day. The strongest winds occurred during the morning and appeared to be associated with sharp pressure rises right behind the cold front. There were numerous trees and power lines down from the event, with several thousand power outages across southern Connecticut.||The following are some peak wind gusts across southern Connecticut: Fairfield County, New Canaan 51 mph; New Haven County, Hamden and Oxford at 54 mph; Middlesex County, 48 mph at Durham; and New London County, 51 mph at Groton.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Numerous trees and power lines reported down across the county, resulting in power outages and road closures.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An intense area of low pressure over the Eastern Great Lakes on the morning of February 12, tracked northeast and up into the Canadian Maritimes by evening. High winds developed near daybreak, right behind the cold front, and continued through the day. The strongest winds occurred during the morning and appeared to be associated with sharp pressure rises right behind the cold front. There were numerous trees and power lines down from the event, with several thousand power outages across southern Connecticut.||The following are some peak wind gusts across southern Connecticut: Fairfield County, New Canaan 51 mph; New Haven County, Hamden and Oxford at 54 mph; Middlesex County, 48 mph at Durham; and New London County, 51 mph at Groton.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Numerous trees and power lines reported down across the county, resulting in power outages and road closures.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strengthening low pressure system tracked northeast from the mid Mississippi Valley Wednesday February 18th, into the lower Saint Lawrence Valley by Thursday morning February 19th. An occluded front associated with this low pressure system swept northeast across western New England early Thursday morning, preceded and accompanied by moderate wet snow, along with some rain in the lower elevations. ||Snowfall amounts ranged from 3 to 6 inches across the higher elevations within northern Litchfield County, with generally 1 to 3 inches across lower elevations.||The snow began late Wednesday afternoon, and tapered off early Thursday morning.

A bitterly cold air mass spread across much of east central New York and adjacent western New England during Friday January 16th. ||Widespread subzero temperatures occurred across northwest Connecticut Friday morning, with temperatures as low as -13 F recorded at Colebrook Lake, and -8 F recorded in Litchfield.||In addition, some wind added to the extreme cold, with wind chills of |-15 to -24 F.

A low pressure system tracked east from the eastern Great Lakes Sunday morning January 18th, across northern New England Sunday afternoon and evening, to a position off the northern New England coast by Monday morning January 19th. ||An area of light to moderate snowfall accompanied the passage of this system across much of east central New York and adjacent western New England from Sunday morning, into early Monday morning. ||Snowfall amounts generally ranged from 3 to 6 inches. ||The steadiest snowfall occurred during Sunday morning, before tapering to snow showers and flurries Sunday afternoon and evening. The snow then ended by Monday morning.

A strong low pressure system moved through southern New England from the southwest spreading snow across the area. This was followed by strong warm advection resulting in a precipitation change to freezing rain.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: An eighth of an inch of ice accumulated on power lines and wires in the Hartford area, downing these lines.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system moved across the Ohio Valley and into southern New England. This low developed a secondary low off the coast of New Jersey. These two low pressure systems resulted in precipitation overspreading the area while warm air moved in aloft. This made precipitation type a challenge with snow, freezing rain, and sleet occurring across southern New England.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Wires in Vernon were downed by one quarter to one third of an inch of ice accumulation.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front triggered scattered afternoon and early evening severe thunderstorms across southern Connecticut. In addition to the afternoon storms, three people were struck by lightning while camping in early morning convection.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A tree fell on a house at 115 River Trail Road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front triggered scattered afternoon and early evening severe thunderstorms across southern Connecticut. In addition to the afternoon storms, three people were struck by lightning while camping in early morning convection.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Nickel size hail was reported by law enforcement between Route 121 and Butternut Court.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front triggered scattered afternoon and early evening severe thunderstorms across southern Connecticut. In addition to the afternoon storms, three people were struck by lightning while camping in early morning convection.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Nickel size hail was reported by a trained spotter.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front triggered scattered afternoon and early evening severe thunderstorms across southern Connecticut. In addition to the afternoon storms, three people were struck by lightning while camping in early morning convection.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Multiple arm size tree branches were downed on Main Street.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front triggered scattered afternoon and early evening severe thunderstorms across southern Connecticut. In addition to the afternoon storms, three people were struck by lightning while camping in early morning convection.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A tree was downed on Jacksons Cove Road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front triggered scattered afternoon and early evening severe thunderstorms across southern Connecticut. In addition to the afternoon storms, three people were struck by lightning while camping in early morning convection.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trees fell on wires on Sugar Hill Road.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A tree fell on a house at 138 Floodbridge Road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front triggered scattered afternoon and early evening severe thunderstorms across southern Connecticut. In addition to the afternoon storms, three people were struck by lightning while camping in early morning convection.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A tree fell on a house at 125 River Trail Road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level disturbance, in combination with a sea breeze boundary, allowed for the development of an isolated, slow moving severe thunderstorm over New London county.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Nickel size hail was reported by a trained spotter.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front triggered scattered afternoon and early evening severe thunderstorms across southern Connecticut. In addition to the afternoon storms, three people were struck by lightning while camping in early morning convection.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Penny size hail was reported by law enforcement.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front triggered scattered afternoon and early evening severe thunderstorms across southern Connecticut. In addition to the afternoon storms, three people were struck by lightning while camping in early morning convection.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Penny size hail was reported by a trained spotter.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front approached from the west Sunday afternoon and evening on May 24th, preceded and accompanied by scattered thunderstorms, some of which contained large hail.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Nickel size hail was reported near Cornwall during a thunderstorm.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level trough and associated surface low pressure system slowly advanced towards the local area from the Ohio Valley triggering scattered thunderstorms with heavy rain which caused flash flooding in Greenwich.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain caused many flooded basements and some sewage backups in the Havemeyer Park area of Greenwich.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The combination of an approaching cold front from the west, and strong upper level dynamics in association with a developing upper level low over the Great Lakes, created scattered to numerous thunderstorms across northwest Connecticut during the afternoon hours of Friday, June 26th, some of which became severe.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trees and powerlines were reported down in Harwinton due to strong thunderstorm winds. In addition, penny size hail also occurred during this thunderstorm.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The combination of an approaching cold front from the west, and strong upper level dynamics in association with a developing upper level low over the Great Lakes, created scattered to numerous thunderstorms across northwest Connecticut during the afternoon hours of Friday, June 26th, some of which became severe.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trees and wires were reported down in Torrington due to strong thunderstorm winds.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The combination of an approaching cold front from the west, and strong upper level dynamics in association with a developing upper level low over the Great Lakes, created scattered to numerous thunderstorms across northwest Connecticut during the afternoon hours of Friday, June 26th, some of which became severe.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Two trees were reported down in Washington due to strong thunderstorm winds. A measured peak wind gust of 62 mph was also reported by a trained spotter.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The combination of an approaching cold front from the west, and strong upper level dynamics in association with a developing upper level low over the Great Lakes, created scattered to numerous thunderstorms across northwest Connecticut during the afternoon hours of Friday, June 26th, some of which became severe.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Quarter size hail was reported in Oakville during a thunderstorm.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The combination of an unseasonably cool air mass in place, clear skies and light winds resulted in frost across northern portions of Litchfield County during the early morning hours of Monday June 1st.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Areas of frost occurred during the early morning hours.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A very moist environment with dewpoints in the low 70s and plenty of sunshine combined to produce showers and thunderstorms, some of which became severe and produced damaging winds.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trees and wires on Lyons Road, Upson Street, and Blaine Lane were downed by thunderstorm winds.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A very moist environment with dewpoints in the low 70s and plenty of sunshine combined to produce showers and thunderstorms, some of which became severe and produced damaging winds.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Numerous trees along Route 179 were downed by thunderstorm winds.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A very moist environment with dewpoints in the low 70s and plenty of sunshine combined to produce showers and thunderstorms, some of which became severe and produced damaging winds.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Multiple trees on Forest Road were downed by thunderstorm winds, including at least one that blocked the road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A very moist environment with dewpoints in the low 70s and plenty of sunshine combined to produce showers and thunderstorms, some of which became severe and produced damaging winds.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trees on Penny Road were downed by thunderstorm winds.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A very moist environment with dewpoints in the low 70s and plenty of sunshine combined to produce showers and thunderstorms, some of which became severe and produced damaging winds.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trees along Route 75 were downed by thunderstorm winds.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Showers and thunderstorms formed along a warm front moving northward through Connecticut.  One of these storms became severe and produced damaging wind gusts.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Large tree branches were downed by thunderstorm winds.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front triggered scattered afternoon and early evening severe thunderstorms across southern Connecticut. In addition to the afternoon storms, three people were struck by lightning while camping in early morning convection.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A tree fell on a building at 323 Kruger Circle.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front triggered scattered afternoon and early evening severe thunderstorms across southern Connecticut. In addition to the afternoon storms, three people were struck by lightning while camping in early morning convection.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A tree fell on wires at 4 Nelson Lane.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The passage of a strong upper level atmospheric disturbance, combined with low level moisture led to the development of locally intense snow squalls across portions of Litchfield County during the afternoon and evening hours of Thursday February 19th.||Snowfall rates of 1 to 2 inches per hour were reported within the most intense snow squalls. Total accumulations of 2 to 4 inches fell within these squalls, although isolated higher amounts of 4 to 7 inches were reported. The most intense snow squalls occurred across southeast Litchfield County.

The passage of a strong upper level atmospheric disturbance, combined with low level moisture led to the development of locally intense snow squalls across portions of Litchfield County during the afternoon and evening hours of Thursday February 19th.||Snowfall rates of 1 to 2 inches per hour were reported within the most intense snow squalls. Total accumulations of 2 to 4 inches fell within these squalls, although isolated higher amounts of 4 to 7 inches were reported. The most intense snow squalls occurred across southeast Litchfield County.

The remnants of Ida produced heavy rain across Southwest Connecticut on 11/13/09, causing vehicles to hydroplane, producing 2 accidents with injuries. The heavy rain combined with gusty winds also downed a tree as well.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain caused a vehicle to hydroplane on Piedmont Street, causing it to lose control and crash into two parked cars. The driver was taken to Saint Mary's Hospital to treat head injuries.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong winds developed between a deep low pressure system northeast of Maine and a strong high pressure system over the Southeast United States.  Peak wind gusts ranged from 40 mph to 55 mph. They downed tree limbs and caused scattered power outages across Southern Connecticut.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A wind gust of 51 mph was measured by the Automated Surface Observing System at Meriden Markham Airport at 10:30 am.  A strong wind gust knocked a tree down onto a moving vehicle and injured a 44 year old woman on Saturday morning, November 28, 2009.  The vehicle was traveling along Kensington Avenue near the Westfield Meriden Mall.  The tree landed between the dash board and front seat.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A thunderstorm developed ahead of a cold front as it moved over Waterbury and produced lightning.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Lightning struck a large tree in the back yard of 92 Grassy Hill Road around 4:30 am EST.  It traveled through the ground, blasted a hole through the basement wall, and displaced wooden panels in the interior portions of the house.  The sound was so loud that it damaged the hearing of a woman living in the house.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The remnants of Ida produced heavy rain across Southwest Connecticut on 11/13/09, causing vehicles to hydroplane, producing 2 accidents with injuries. The heavy rain combined with gusty winds also downed a tree as well.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain caused a vehicle to hydroplane on a road bank on Brushy Ridge in New Canaan, CT.  The vehicle over turned, and the driver was taken to Norwalk Hospital for treatment. ||A large tree fell down in Waveny Park in New Canaan due to a combination of heavy rain and gusty winds.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Moderate tidal flooding was caused by a strong pressure gradient between high pressure to the north and a coastal storm passing south of Long Island October 17th and 18th.||A prolonged period of strong northeast winds across coastal waters coupled with astronomically high tides caused water to build along the coast followed by tidal piling.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Overwash flooding was reported at Campo Beach Road and Soundview Drive during high tide.|Water Street in Norwalk was closed from 10 am (EDT) until 3 pm (EDT) due to coastal flooding, with at least one vehicle being stranded.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A combination of a passing pre-frontal trough and an approaching cold front spawned an isolated severe thunderstorm in Fairfield County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Lightning strikes resulted in two fires in Greenwich. The fires were quickly put out.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A combination of a passing pre-frontal trough and an approaching cold front spawned an isolated severe thunderstorm in Fairfield County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: An estimated wind gust of 65 mph was reported by a trained spotter in Greenwich.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Following the passage of a strong cold front, strong west winds developed.  Peak gusts ranged from around 40 to 50 mph and caused scattered power outages.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Strong winds downed trees and tree limbs, that downed power lines in Danbury and Ridgefield.||Strong winds downed a tree, which knocked down wires onto and around a house at 88 Drum Hill Road in Wilton.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A deep upper low tracking northeast through the Central United States was responsible for a rapidly intensifying low pressure system tracking into the Great Lakes. A strong upper level jet rounding up the East Coast induced secondary low pressure along an associated warm front off the Mid-Atlantic Coast. This low tracked northeast along the coast...producing a 6 to 8 hr period of heavy precipitation across the region. A marginally cold thermal profile and strong dynamics allowed for a 2 to 4 hr period of moderate to heavy snow across interior zones...with snowfall rates of 1 inch per hour. Snowfall amounts ranged from 6.8 at Seymour and Southbury, 6.0 at Bethany, and 6.0 at Waterbury.

Coastal low pressure rapidly intensified Saturday night as it tracked northeast from off the Delmarva Coast...just southeast of the 40N/70W benchmark���and to southeast of Cape Cod by Sunday morning. This was in response to a powerful upper low approaching and then crossing south of the area. The track of low pressure to the southeast of the region and stubborn placement of arctic high pressure over the Northern US Plains and Southern Canadian Plains...ridging eastward...made for the ideal setup for heavy snow across most of the region. The rapid intensification of low pressure created near blizzard conditions along Southeastern Coastal Connecticut for several hours with northeast winds of 15 to 25 mph and gusts 35 to 40 mph���and visibilities occasionally below �� mile.  Snowfall rates of 2 to 4 inches per hour occurred with an intense mesoscale band that developed S of the region���pivoted north into Southeastern Connecticut���and then slowly pulled east through the overnight. Snow totals increased rapidly from northwest to southeast across the region...with 6 to 8 inches across Northern Fairfield���to around 2 ft across far Southeastern Connecticut.

Snow totals increased rapidly from northwest to southeast across the region...with 6 to 8 inches across Northern Fairfield���to around 2 ft across far Southeastern Connecticut.

Low pressure slowly tracked east across the United States and Canadian border from December 13th 2009 through December 14th 2009, with its trailing cold front slowly pushing through the region. Well below freezing temperatures in the preceding 48 hours and temperatures just below freezing during the onset of precipitation created a 2 to 4 hour period of light freezing rain that resulted in severe road icing across the region Sunday morning into early Sunday afternoon. Up to a quarter of an inch of freezing rain was reported across portions of the area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Forty six people were injured in a 50 car pile up near the corner of route 110 and Indian Well Road around noon when freezing rain began. None of the injuries were life threatening.

Snowfall rates of 2 to 4 inches per hour occurred with an intense mesoscale band that developed S of the region���pivoted north into Southeastern Connecticut���and then slowly pulled east through the overnight. Snow totals increased rapidly from northwest to southeast across the region...with 6 to 8 inches across Northern Fairfield���to around 2 ft across far Southeastern Connecticut.

Coastal low pressure rapidly intensified Saturday night as it tracked northeast from off the Delmarva Coast...just southeast of the 40N/70W benchmark���and to southeast of Cape Cod by Sunday morning. This was in response to a powerful upper low approaching and then crossing south of the area. Snow totals increased rapidly from northwest to southeast across the region...with 6 to 8 inches across Northern Fairfield���to around 2 ft across far Southeastern Connecticut.
A powerful cold front produced numerous severe thunderstorms across Connecticut, Long Island and the Lower Hudson Valley of New York.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Lightning struck an apartment complex which started a fire lasting about one hour. No injuries were reported.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A powerful cold front produced numerous severe thunderstorms across Connecticut, Long Island and the Lower Hudson Valley of New York.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Penny size hail was reported by a trained spotter.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A powerful cold front produced numerous severe thunderstorms across Connecticut, Long Island and the Lower Hudson Valley of New York.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Nickel size hail was reported by a trained spotter.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A powerful cold front produced numerous severe thunderstorms across Connecticut, Long Island and the Lower Hudson Valley of New York.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Penny to nickel size hail was reported by a trained spotter.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A pre-frontal trough brought a round of severe weather to Fairfield County in the afternoon.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Quarter size hail was reported in Ridgebury.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A powerful cold front produced numerous severe thunderstorms across Connecticut, Long Island and the Lower Hudson Valley of New York.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Nickel size hail was reported.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A powerful cold front produced numerous severe thunderstorms across Connecticut, Long Island and the Lower Hudson Valley of New York.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorm winds knocked down a tree which damaged a mobile home.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A pre-frontal trough brought a round of severe weather to Fairfield County in the afternoon.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Nickel size hail was reported in Bethel.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A pre-frontal trough brought a round of severe weather to Fairfield County in the afternoon.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Dozens of trees and large limbs were reported down from Salem Road north of Ridgfield down into the town of Ridgefield.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A large and powerful low pressure system over the upper midwest moved slowly northeastward as it weakened on Saturday, December 26th. In the meantime, a secondary low had formed over the mid atlantic region and moved gradually northeast. A light wintry mix of precipitation overspread northwestern Connecticut |Christmas night and continued through much of Saturday morning, causing dangerous travel.  ||Snow and sleet accumulations of up to an inch occurred, along with ice accretions of one tenth of an inch.

A large and powerful low pressure system over the upper midwest moved slowly northeastward as it weakened on Saturday, December 26th. In the meantime, a secondary low had formed over the mid atlantic region and moved gradually northeast. A light wintry mix of precipitation overspread northwestern Connecticut |Christmas night and continued through much of Saturday morning, causing dangerous travel.  ||Snow and sleet accumulations of up to an inch occurred, along with ice accretions of one tenth of an inch.

A tight pressure gradient developed across the region Tuesday morning, December 29th. This was the result of strengthening low pressure heading northeast into the Canadian Maritimes as high pressure built in from the west.  Northwest winds gusted to around 55 mph.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Tree fell on a postal vehicle on Weekeepeemee Road in Bethlehem Connecticut killing the driver.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The combination of gusty winds, and low temperatures produced wind chills of -20 to -24 F across the higher elevations of northwest Connecticut early Thursday morning on January 1st.

The combination of a weak high retreating over the northeast and deepening low pressure over the Great Lakes resulted in a significant accumulation of ice across interior portions of southern Connecticut from the evening of January 6 into the afternoon of January 7. A warm front extending east from the developing low worked northward from the Mid Atlantic states with overrunning precipitation well out ahead of it.||Ice amounts averaged around one-half inch across northern portions of New Haven and New London counties, with up to almost an inch in spots. The following are ice accumulation ranges across the area: New Haven County, 0.30 inches in New Haven to 0.80 inches in Waterbury; and in New London County, 0.30 inches in Groton to 0.50 inches in Norwich. Across Fairfield County, reported amounts were generally between 0.30 and 0.40 inches, but damage across the region suggested higher amounts.||Numerous power lines and large tree limbs were reported down across the region on January 7, especially in and around the Danbury area. Power outages exceeded 20 percent in some towns. In Waterbury, Connecticut, a large tree limb fell on power lines, bringing a utility pole down on a 21-year-old woman's head in front of her home at approximately 1600EST.  The woman died later that evening at around 2100EST.

The woman died later that evening at around 2100EST.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Ice accumulation appears to have been the cause of a tree falling on a car traveling on the Merritt Parkway near the North Street Ramp, exit 31, around 9 a.m in Greenwich.  A 30-year-old female suffered minor injuries.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system moved across the Ohio Valley and into southern New England. This low developed a secondary low off the coast of New Jersey. These two low pressure systems resulted in precipitation overspreading the area while warm air moved in aloft. This made precipitation type a challenge with snow, freezing rain, and sleet occurring across southern New England.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trees and wires in Bloomfield, West Hartford, Enfield, and Windsor were downed by one quarter to one third of an inch of ice accumulation.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low pressure off the mid-Atlantic coast intensified dramatically resulting in widespread snowfall along the northeast corridor of the U.S. While the mid-Atlantic received much of the snow and wind from this storm, snow spread across much of Southern New England and blizzard conditions occurred in Newport, Rhode Island and Marshfield, Massachusetts. Snowfall totals ranged from 1 to 3 inches in northwestern Massachusetts and southern New Hampshire to 18 to 20 inches across Rhode Island and southeastern Massachusetts.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Five to fifteen inches of snow fell across Tolland County.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong area of low pressure tracked across the Great Lakes and passed to our north producing high winds across the local area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The ASOS at Bridgeport Connecticut reported a wind gust of 50 mph. Strong winds also resulted in widespread downed trees in Greenwich and Stamford, closing roads including Riversville, Glenville and Indian Head Roads. These high winds also downed a tree onto a Connecticut transit bus outside of Springdale School, closing Hope Street and injuring the driver.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low pressure off the mid-Atlantic coast intensified dramatically resulting in widespread snowfall along the northeast corridor of the U.S. While the mid-Atlantic received much of the snow and wind from this storm, snow spread across much of Southern New England and blizzard conditions occurred in Newport, Rhode Island and Marshfield, Massachusetts. Snowfall totals ranged from 1 to 3 inches in northwestern Massachusetts and southern New Hampshire to 18 to 20 inches across Rhode Island and southeastern Massachusetts.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Nine to twenty inches of snow fell across Windham County.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong pressure gradient between strong low pressure to the north and high pressure building from the west resulted in strong northwestery winds across the area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The ASOS's at Meriden and New Haven airports measured wind gusts of 56 mph and 52 mph respectively. In Waterbury, there was a partial roof collapse of an apartment building at 121 Lounsbury Street due to the winds.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong pressure gradient between strong low pressure to the north and high pressure building from the west resulted in strong northwester winds across the area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A 51 mph gust was reported at Groton/New London Airport. These strong winds also knocked a 75 foot tall Spruce tree onto a house at 147 Shore Road in Waterford which produced damage to the roof and front porch.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A developing low pressure system tracked northeast from the lower Ohio Valley on Saturday January 10th, into central Pennsylvania Saturday night, and then east to a position off the New England coast by Sunday morning, January 11th.||This low pressure system spread moderate snowfall across much of northwest Connecticut, beginning late Saturday afternoon, and ending Sunday morning.||Snowfall amounts generally ranged from 3 to 6 inches.

A developing low pressure system tracked northeast from the lower Ohio Valley on Saturday January 10th, into central Pennsylvania Saturday night, and then east to a position off the New England coast by Sunday morning, January 11th.||This low pressure system spread moderate snowfall across much of northwest Connecticut, beginning late Saturday afternoon, and ending Sunday morning.||Snowfall amounts generally ranged from 3 to 6 inches.

A coastal low pressure system moved southeast of Nantucket, spreading snow across Southern New England. Snowfall amounts ranged from three inches on Cape Cod to almost twelve inches in southern New Hampshire. This late season storm affected most of the east coast and resulted in hundreds of flight cancellations at Boston's Logan Airport and many car accidents. In northern Connecticut, snowfall amounts were closer to eight inches.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Five to eleven inches of snow fell across Hartford County.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A coastal low pressure system moved southeast of Nantucket, spreading snow across Southern New England. Snowfall amounts ranged from three inches on Cape Cod to almost twelve inches in southern New Hampshire. This late season storm affected most of the east coast and resulted in hundreds of flight cancellations at Boston's Logan Airport and many car accidents. In northern Connecticut, snowfall amounts were closer to eight inches.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Seven to ten inches of snow fell across Tolland County.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A coastal low pressure system moved southeast of Nantucket, spreading snow across Southern New England. Snowfall amounts ranged from three inches on Cape Cod to almost twelve inches in southern New Hampshire. This late season storm affected most of the east coast and resulted in hundreds of flight cancellations at Boston's Logan Airport and many car accidents. In northern Connecticut, snowfall amounts were closer to eight inches.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Eight to twelve inches of snow fell across Windham County.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An unseasonably cold air mass produced freezing temperatures across northern Litchfield County during the early morning hours of Tuesday May 19th. The growing season already started in this area after a stretch of unusually warm temperatures during April.

A strengthening low pressure system tracked northeast from the southeast coast on Sunday morning, March 1st, to just southeast of Long Island by Monday morning March 2nd. The low then headed northeast into the Canadian maritimes by Tuesday March 3rd.||This storm system spread a swath of heavy snow across Litchfield County in northwest Connecticut, beginning early Monday morning, and ending by late Monday afternoon.||Total snowfall accumulations ranged from 6 to 12 inches across Litchfield County. This heavy snowfall resulted in either closures, or delayed openings of numerous schools and businesses Monday morning, and also created treacherous travel conditions for the Monday morning commute.

A strengthening low pressure system tracked northeast from the southeast coast on Sunday morning, March 1st, to just southeast of Long Island by Monday morning March 2nd. The low then headed northeast into the Canadian maritimes by Tuesday March 3rd.||This storm system spread a swath of heavy snow across Litchfield County in northwest Connecticut, beginning early Monday morning, and ending by late Monday afternoon.||Total snowfall accumulations ranged from 6 to 12 inches across Litchfield County. This heavy snowfall resulted in either closures, or delayed openings of numerous schools and businesses Monday morning, and also created treacherous travel conditions for the Monday morning commute.

A coastal low pressure system along the Outer Banks of North Carolina Sunday evening, March 1, tracked northeast, to east of Long Island by Monday afternoon, March 2.  At the same time, arctic high pressure, from the upper midwest to James Bay, was gradually building east.  The two combined to produce a heavy snowfall event across the tri-state area with snowfall rates of 2 to 3 inches an hour during the pre-dawn hours of March 2. This was the biggest snowfall event of the winter season.||Snowfall amounts across southern Connecticut ranged from 8 to 14 inches, with the highest amounts occurring across Middlesex County. The following are snowfall ranges across the area: Fairfield County, 7.6 inches in Monroe to 10.0 inches in Norwalk; New Haven County, 8.0 inches in New Haven to 11.3 inches in North Haven; Middlesex County, 8.0 inches in Essex to 14.3 inches in Old Saybrook; and New London County, 7.5 inches in Norwich to 10.5 inches in Lisbon.

A cold front moved across Southern New England, triggering showers and thunderstorms.  Warm, moist air and a strong low level jet aided in the development of these storms and several storms became severe, producing hail up to two inches in diameter.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Penny sized hail fell on Willard Avenue.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Penny sized hail fell on the Monson/Stafford line.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A tree and wires on Abbott Road were downed by thunderstorm winds.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A tree and wires were downed onto a house by thunderstorm winds.  The roof sustained minor damage.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A tree on Brennan Street was downed onto wires by thunderstorm winds.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trees and wires on Benedict and Kelley Roads were downed by thunderstorm winds.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Quarter to half dollar size hail fell in Vernon, covering the ground.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A large tree, limbs and wires were downed by thunderstorm winds.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front moved across Southern New England, triggering showers and thunderstorms.  Warm, moist air and a strong low level jet aided in the development of these storms and several storms became severe, producing hail up to two inches in diameter.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trees and wires were downed by thunderstorm winds.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A shortwave rotating around a deep upper trough over New England acted on warm humid air in place at the surface to allow for supercell thunderstorms to form and track across CT.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Tree limbs and wires were reported down in Trumball.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A shortwave rotating around a deep upper trough over New England acted on warm humid air in place at the surface to allow for supercell thunderstorms to form and track across CT.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trees and power lines were reported down in Fairfield.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A shortwave rotating around a deep upper trough over New England acted on warm humid air in place at the surface to allow for supercell thunderstorms to form and track across CT.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Cars were stuck in water near the intersections of Elm St. and South State St. as well as E. Main St. and Crystal St. in Stamford.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A shortwave rotating around a deep upper trough over New England acted on warm humid air in place at the surface to allow for supercell thunderstorms to form and track across CT.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Nickle size hail was reported in Milldale.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A shortwave rotating around a deep upper trough over New England acted on warm humid air in place at the surface to allow for supercell thunderstorms to form and track across CT.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Penny size hail was reported in Lisbon.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A shortwave rotating around a deep upper trough over New England acted on warm humid air in place at the surface to allow for supercell thunderstorms to form and track across CT.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A tree was reported down across Baldwin Street.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A shortwave rotating around a deep upper trough over New England acted on warm humid air in place at the surface to allow for supercell thunderstorms to form and track across CT.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Lightning struck a tree at 387 Robinwood Road, causing a large limb to fall on a car.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front triggered scattered afternoon and early evening severe thunderstorms across southern Connecticut. In addition to the afternoon storms, three people were struck by lightning while camping in early morning convection.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Three people were struck by lightning while in their tents camping at Webb Mountain Park.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front triggered scattered afternoon and early evening severe thunderstorms across southern Connecticut. In addition to the afternoon storms, three people were struck by lightning while camping in early morning convection.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A tree fell on a house at 195 Floodbridge Road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The combination of an approaching cold front from the west, and strong upper level dynamics in association with a developing upper level low over the Great Lakes, created scattered to numerous thunderstorms across northwest Connecticut during the afternoon hours of Friday, June 26th, some of which became severe.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Quarter size hail was reported in Watertown during a thunderstorm.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The combination of an approaching cold front from the west, and strong upper level dynamics in association with a developing upper level low over the Great Lakes, created scattered to numerous thunderstorms across northwest Connecticut during the afternoon hours of Friday, June 26th, some of which became severe.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Penny size hail was reported in Harwinton during a thunderstorm. In addition, trees and power lines were also reported down due to strong thunderstorm winds.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The combination of an approaching cold front from the west, and strong upper level dynamics in association with a developing upper level low over the Great Lakes, created scattered to numerous thunderstorms across northwest Connecticut during the afternoon hours of Friday, June 26th, some of which became severe.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flash flooding from heavy rainfall during several thunderstorms resulted in three feet of standing water on Summer Street in Torrington, with vehicles reportedly becoming stuck in the water.||A spotter measured 1.50 inches of rainfall within one hour from these thunderstorms.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Showers and thunderstorms developed across Southern New England as an upper level low moved across the area.  Weak low level winds resulted in these storms moving very slowly, if at all.  Rainfall rates of up to four inches per hour produced flash flooding, resulting in street closures and basement flooding at several locations.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Many roads were impassable across Mansfield and Willimantic.  A store on Storrs Road in Mansfield was flooded and a house on Jackson Street in Willimantic was flooded.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A closed upper low centered over central New England resulted in isolated thunderstorm development during the early evening hours. The storms produced hail and flash flooding on small streams.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Nickel size hail was reported by the Connecticut State Police.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front moved across Southern New England providing lift for showers and thunderstorms to develop across the area.  Strong instability across the state of Connecticut as well as deep layer shear resulted in many of these storms to become severe.  One of these storms produced a weak tornado (EF1) that moved across the community of Wethersfield.  Numerous trees were downed, including one that split a house in half when it fell.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trees were downed by thunderstorm winds, some of them are blocking a road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front moved across Southern New England providing lift for showers and thunderstorms to develop across the area.  Strong instability across the state of Connecticut as well as deep layer shear resulted in many of these storms to become severe.  One of these storms produced a weak tornado (EF1) that moved across the community of Wethersfield.  Numerous trees were downed, including one that split a house in half when it fell.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A narrow tornado moved through Wethersfield.  The NWS storm survey team found damage beginning near the intersection of Nott Street and Park Avenue and continuing southeast into a cornfield along Elm Street, between Maple Street and Interstate 91.  ||Along this track, numerous trees were downed.  One of these trees fell onto a car on Park Avenue, trapping a person.  Another fallen tree blocked the exit ramp of Exit 24  on Interstate 91.  Many of these trees were large, healthy oak trees that were sliced in half, sheared off at their bases, or uprooted.  One tree fell onto a house with such force it split the house in half.  Two of the residents were inside the house at the time, but escaped without injury.  One injury indirectly occurred as a result of this tornado, when a split branch high up in a tree fell the following day, striking a person.||In the cornfield at the end of the tornado track, cornstalks were found flattened in a criss-cross pattern.  Farther into the cornfield, cornstalks were found to have not been impacted at all by the winds.  ||At a sporting goods store along the tornado track, a kayak inside the store was sucked out onto the road through a front window.

An occluded front coupled with shortwave energy moving through associated with a vigorous upper low over the Great Lakes, combined to produce an isolated severe thunderstorm over New London County, CT.  Training of cells also caused severe flash flooding.  Mesonet sites at Cutler Middle School in Mystic and Wheeler Middle/High School in North Stonington reported 6 1/2 inches and 5 3/4 inches of rainfall respectively.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Penny size hail was reported in Lyme.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Five to seven inches of rain fell across southeast New London County from late morning into the early afternoon on July 1, 2009.  Very wet conditions also preceded this event with rainfall 2 1/2 to 3 inches above normal in Connecticut during the month of June. All of this rain caused Sylvias Pond Dam to overtop and prompted an unscheduled release at the Mystic Reservoir Dam leading to downstream flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The town of Stonington received 6.5 inches of rain over 4 hours from late morning into the early afternoon hours. ||Around 7:30 pm, the Mystic South Reservoir Dam (also known as the Palmer Dam) in Stonington breached and eroded the banks at the edges of the dam causing overtopping.  An unscheduled release of water was performed to protect the integrity of the dam.  However, it was later determined that the berm wall was not returned to its normal postition after a release was done the previous week during low flow.  This caused more water to be released than anticipated with soil eroding near roads and bridges on S. Broad St. (Rt. 1) downstream.  Rt. 1 was closed and several roads such as the intersection of Mistuxet Ave. and Jerry Brown Rd., were damaged.  In addition, approximately 50 cars were trapped in several feet of water in the Mystic Aquarium parking lot.  Numerous streets were impassable and closed of by local authorities.||Around 10 pm, Silvia's Pond Dam, also in Stonington, overtopped causing flooding downstream, resulting in significant damage to a home on Briar Patch Rd. and the need for local authorities to rescue the family inside. This also prompted evacuations to 2 other homes on this street.  A bridge on Collins Road was also damaged from the flood waters.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A wave of low pressure and its attending warm front lifted north from the Delmarva Penisula and triggered scattered showers and thunderstorms which resulted in isolated flash flooding in New Haven and New London counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several roads in Norwichtown were flooded due to heavy rain. Specifically, a low-lying underpass beneath a railroad bridge on Wawecus St. was closed for much of the day.  Mediterranean Ln. was also closed due to flooding.  Fire crews were also dispatched to assist residents with pumping water out of their basements in areas that typically experience flooding, including Bliss Pl. off Washington St.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An occluded front coupled with shortwave energy moving through associated with a vigorous upper low over the Great Lakes, combined to produce an isolated severe thunderstorm over New London County, CT.  Training of cells also caused severe flash flooding.  Mesonet sites at Cutler Middle School in Mystic and Wheeler Middle/High School in North Stonington reported 6 1/2 inches and 5 3/4 inches of rainfall respectively.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A farm dam overtopped, flooded and closed Route 1 near Angola Brook in Pawcatuck.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An occluded front coupled with shortwave energy moving through associated with a vigorous upper low over the Great Lakes, combined to produce an isolated severe thunderstorm over New London County, CT.  Training of cells also caused severe flash flooding.  Mesonet sites at Cutler Middle School in Mystic and Wheeler Middle/High School in North Stonington reported 6 1/2 inches and 5 3/4 inches of rainfall respectively.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: In Mystic, High St. near Cow Hill Rd. was closed due to flooding.  Water was also pumped out of basements on Sandy Hollow Road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An occluded front coupled with shortwave energy moving through associated with a vigorous upper low over the Great Lakes, combined to produce an isolated severe thunderstorm over New London County, CT.  Training of cells also caused severe flash flooding.  Mesonet sites at Cutler Middle School in Mystic and Wheeler Middle/High School in North Stonington reported 6 1/2 inches and 5 3/4 inches of rainfall respectively.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A river bridge on Collins Rd. in North Stonington was flooded, which resulted in damage to the bridge and the road being closed.  Noank Rd. in Mystic was closed due to flooding.  A river bridge on North Stonington Rd. near Shewville Rd. in North  Stonington was flooded and resulted in the road being closed.  Approximately 50-60 cars were inundated with water and trapped in the Mystic Aquarium parking lot. Several vehicles were also stuck in high water on Coogan Blvd. near the Mystic Aquarium.  A portion of Rt. 1 in Mystic was closed due to flooding.  Emergency responders in Stonington pulled an occupied vehicle out of the water in the area of Washington St. and Broadway Ave.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A tropical and very unstable airmass was in place across the area. An upper level disturbance moved over the region ahead of a slow moving cold front Friday afternoon on August 21st, triggering widespread severe thunderstorms across Litchfield County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Numerous trees were reported down in Litchfield due to strong thunderstorm winds.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Numerous trees were reported down in Morris due to strong thunderstorm winds. The southbound lane of Route 61, South Street, was closed due to numerous downed trees and branches. East Shore Road was closed due to downed trees. Motorists were reported stranded and rescued by state police on Alaine White Road near East Shore Road.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A house on Milton Road in Litchfield was struck by lightning.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A tropical and very unstable airmass was in place across the area. An upper level disturbance moved over the region ahead of a slow moving cold front Friday afternoon on August 21st, triggering widespread severe thunderstorms across Litchfield County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A tree fell on wires and caught fire on Torringford West Street near Dibble Street in Torrington due to strong thunderstorm winds.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A deep upper level low allowed for the development of scattered afternoon thunderstorms across portions of eastern Connecticut. Hail, severe winds and very heavy rain were produced by these storms.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Penny size hail stripped the leaves off of trees at the intersection of Mountain Road and Route 68.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front transiting the Tri-State formed a squall line with multiple bow echoes, producing two tornadoes, and widespread damage from straight line winds.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The tornado cut a narrow, discontinuous swath of damage nearly 3 miles long from near Copse Trail east-southeast to Hull Road between Acorn and Saxon Roads. Downed trees on Wellsweep Drive were strewn in multiple directions in a pattern indicative of a tornado. Snapped and uprooted hardwood trees were also indicative of maximum wind speeds around 100 mph, or EF1 on the Enhanced Fujita Scale.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front transiting the Tri-State formed a squall line with multiple bow echoes, producing two tornadoes, and widespread damage from straight line winds.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several trees were reported down in Pine Rock Park.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front transiting the Tri-State formed a squall line with multiple bow echoes, producing two tornadoes, and widespread damage from straight line winds.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Wires were reported down at 177 Randolph Road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A powerful cold front produced numerous severe thunderstorms across Connecticut, Long Island and the Lower Hudson Valley of New York.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Numerous trees were downed in Naugatuck. These trees fell on cars, power lines and houses. Power was lost for over eight hours in some locations.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front transiting the Tri-State formed a squall line with multiple bow echoes, producing two tornadoes, and widespread damage from straight line winds.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Spotter reports indicate downed trees near the off/on ramps of exit 25 on Route 8 North, extending east for about 200 yards to near a commuter parking lot on Cross Street and onto Andrasko Road. Downed trees near the Route 8 ramps were facing toward the north and northwest, while those near the parking lot and on Andrasko Road were oriented east and southeast. Some healthy trees in the damage area were snapped about one-third of the way down from the top. This damage is indicative of a microburst with estimated maximum winds of about 95 mph.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front transiting the Tri-State formed a squall line with multiple bow echoes, producing two tornadoes, and widespread damage from straight line winds.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A boat was reported overturned at Eastern Point Beach, with minor damage.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front transiting the Tri-State formed a squall line with multiple bow echoes, producing two tornadoes, and widespread damage from straight line winds.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Many tree branches were reported down near 50 Thompson Avenue.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front transiting the Tri-State formed a squall line with multiple bow echoes, producing two tornadoes, and widespread damage from straight line winds.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Minor damage was reported to 15-20 condominiums.  Trees and power lines were also reported to be intertwined.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front transiting the Tri-State formed a squall line with multiple bow echoes, producing two tornadoes, and widespread damage from straight line winds.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Multiple trees and wires were reported down throughout the town.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front transiting the Tri-State formed a squall line with multiple bow echoes, producing two tornadoes, and widespread damage from straight line winds.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A large limb fell into a house, injuring an occupant.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front transiting the Tri-State formed a squall line with multiple bow echoes, producing two tornadoes, and widespread damage from straight line winds.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Main Street was closed due to multiple trees down across the road.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Numerous trees were reported down in Guilford, including one which fell on a car.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Numerous trees were reported down.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A tree and power lines fell across High Rock Road in the town of Sandy Hook, closing the road for a few hours.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front transiting the Tri-State formed a squall line with multiple bow echoes, producing two tornadoes, and widespread damage from straight line winds.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A narrow path of wind damage extended along the Yutaka Trail near Kanungum Trail and Agawam trail to Long Hill Avenue near Pochong Trail. The most concentrated wind damage was along Oronogue trail, where many trees were downed.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A deep upper level low allowed for the development of scattered afternoon thunderstorms across portions of eastern Connecticut. Hail, severe winds and very heavy rain were produced by these storms.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorm winds downed a tree in Durham.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A deep upper level low allowed for the development of scattered afternoon thunderstorms across portions of eastern Connecticut. Hail, severe winds and very heavy rain were produced by these storms.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Nickel size hail was reported on Cimarron Road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A weak cold front moved through Southern New England, coupling with a warm, tropical airmass to produce showers and thunderstorms.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trees were downed by thunderstorm winds, including one that fell on a house on North Main Street.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A pre-frontal trough spawned an isolated severe thunderstorm which impacted northern portions of  New Haven and Middlesex Counties.  The storm produced very heavy rain and resulted in isolated flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several trees and power lines were reported down in Naugatuck.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A pre-frontal trough spawned an isolated severe thunderstorm which impacted northern portions of  New Haven and Middlesex Counties.  The storm produced very heavy rain and resulted in isolated flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A large tree and powerlines were reported down on Trees Road near the Prospect Town line.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A pre-frontal trough spawned an isolated severe thunderstorm which impacted northern portions of  New Haven and Middlesex Counties.  The storm produced very heavy rain and resulted in isolated flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Downed wires were reported across State Route 82 near State Route 156.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A pre-frontal trough spawned an isolated severe thunderstorm which impacted northern portions of  New Haven and Middlesex Counties.  The storm produced very heavy rain and resulted in isolated flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: In Waterbury, the intersection of Long Hill Rd. and Wolcott St. was closed due to flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front transiting the Tri-State formed a squall line with multiple bow echoes, producing two tornadoes, and widespread damage from straight line winds.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Numerous trees were brought down across the Merritt Parkway between exits 55 and 56 closing the road for a few hours and causing multiple accidents.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front transiting the Tri-State formed a squall line with multiple bow echoes, producing two tornadoes, and widespread damage from straight line winds.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A 15 inch diameter branch fell into a roof on a house on Greenport Lane, causing minor injuries to the occupant.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front transiting the Tri-State formed a squall line with multiple bow echoes, producing two tornadoes, and widespread damage from straight line winds.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Dozens of trees were reported uprooted and snapped, mainly along Woodruff Road and Ardmore Road near the Milford/Orange Town Line.  This caused minor property damage to fences, roofs, and windows.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front transiting the Tri-State formed a squall line with multiple bow echoes, producing two tornadoes, and widespread damage from straight line winds.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Multiple trees fell across the Merritt Parkway between exits 52 and 53 closing the road for 3 hours, and causing multiple accidents.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A wave of low pressure and its attending warm front lifted north from the Delmarva Penisula and triggered scattered showers and thunderstorms which resulted in isolated flash flooding in New Haven and New London counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Many roads were flooded in the Wolcott Township.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A wave of low pressure and its attending warm front lifted north from the Delmarva Penisula and triggered scattered showers and thunderstorms which resulted in isolated flash flooding in New Haven and New London counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: In Waterbury, 4 to 5 inches of rainfall fell over a 3 hour period. Many cars were stranded in high water approximately 3 ft. deep on Wolcott St. and at the Route 8 underpass on Watertown Ave. Portions of Freight St. was under 4 ft. of water and the intersection of Woodtick Rd. at Upson Rd. was closed due to flooding.  Large chunks of pavement were torn up on Wall St. and the House of Joy and Praise sustained water damage in the basement from ravaging runoff from a hill nearby.  A section of Long Hill Rd. near Wolcott St. was also closed from damage to the street from flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong area of low pressure and its associated cold front moved across the area Wednesday afternoon, October 7th, producing strong and gusty west to northwest winds.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A few trees were reported down due to strong winds in New Milford.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An approaching pre-frontal trough along with a passing upper level disturbance caused a squall line to form and move across Southwestern Connecticut. The line caused wind damage in Fairfield County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A tree and several wires were reported down near the intersection of Route 37 and Wakeman Hill Road north of Danbury.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A combination of a passing pre-frontal trough and an approaching cold front spawned an isolated severe thunderstorm in Fairfield County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: At least 42 trees and large branches were downed in Greenwich.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Slow moving thunderstorms developed in a tropical airmass, which resulted in very heavy rain and flash flooding across portions of Southwest Connecticut.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Route 172 in Southbury was closed due to flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Slow moving thunderstorms developed in a tropical airmass, which resulted in very heavy rain and flash flooding across portions of Southwest Connecticut.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: In Fairfield, Saw Mill Rd. was closed near Rt. 39 due to flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Scattered thunderstorms occurred during the afternoon of the 2nd ahead of a pre-frontal trough. One storm's lightning struck a house in Waterbury.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Lightning struck a tree at 84 Greystone Road, passed through rock and stone retaining wall, then struck the home at 92 Greystone Road in Waterbury, causing a minor fire, electrical damage, and some cosmetic damage to the exterior.  The force of the strike also caused the dishes to come out of a cabinet at 85 Greystone Road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A slow moving cold front triggered numerous thunderstorms in a tropical airmass which produced very heavy rain and flash flooding in Fairfield County Connecticut.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: In Danbury, 3 ft. of standing water accumulated on White St. at the intersection of Meadow Street.  Six to eight inches of standing water also accumluated on roads near the Bethel town line.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A slow moving cold front interacted with a tropical airmass as it moved across the Tri-State area.  Scattered thunderstorms developed as a result which produced very heavy rain and flash flooding in Fairfield County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: In Wilton, 1 to 1.5 ft. of running water accumulated at the intersection of Newtown Tpke. and Weston Road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A tropical and very unstable airmass was in place across the area. An upper level disturbance moved over the region ahead of a slow moving cold front Friday afternoon on August 21st, triggering widespread severe thunderstorms across Litchfield County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Measured quarter size hail was reported in Morris during a thunderstorm.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A deep upper level low allowed for the development of scattered afternoon thunderstorms across portions of eastern Connecticut. Hail, severe winds and very heavy rain were produced by these storms.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: In Middletown, Poplar Rd. and Rt. 66 between Old Mill St and West St. were closed due to flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A shortwave rotating around a deep upper trough over New England acted on warm humid air in place at the surface to allow for supercell thunderstorms to form and track across CT.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Dime to penny size hail was reported.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A closed upper level low and pool of unusually cold air in the mid and upper levels of the atmosphere moved over the region Tuesday, July 7th, leading to the development of thunderstorms across northwest Connecticut. Severe thunderstorms developed during the early afternoon.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Nickel size hail was reported in New Hartford during a thunderstorm.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A closed upper level low and pool of unusually cold air in the mid and upper levels of the atmosphere moved over the region Tuesday, July 7th, leading to the development of thunderstorms across northwest Connecticut. Severe thunderstorms developed during the early afternoon.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Quarter size hail was reported in New Hartford during a thunderstorm.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A closed upper level low and pool of unusually cold air in the mid and upper levels of the atmosphere moved over the region Tuesday, July 7th, leading to the development of thunderstorms across northwest Connecticut. Severe thunderstorms developed during the early afternoon.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Penny size hail was reported in Litchfield during a thunderstorm.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A closed upper level low and pool of unusually cold air in the mid and upper levels of the atmosphere moved over the region Tuesday, July 7th, leading to the development of thunderstorms across northwest Connecticut. Severe thunderstorms developed during the early afternoon.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Golf ball size hail was reported in Bakersville during a thunderstorm.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A closed upper level low and pool of unusually cold air in the mid and upper levels of the atmosphere moved over the region Tuesday, July 7th, leading to the development of thunderstorms across northwest Connecticut. Severe thunderstorms developed during the early afternoon.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Nickel size hail was reported in Northville during a thunderstorm. Also, several small tree limbs were downed.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The cold front which triggered widespread severe weather across eastern New York into western New England Thursday the 16th stalled along the eastern seaboard from New England southward to the mid Atlantic Region on Friday, July 17th. A wave of low pressure developed along the boundary and headed northward Friday night triggering a line of thunderstorms which moved northward across Dutchess and Litchfield counties late in the evening.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A tree was reported down on a rural road in Sharon due to strong thunderstorm winds.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The cold front which triggered widespread severe weather across eastern New York into western New England Thursday the 16th stalled along the eastern seaboard from New England southward to the mid Atlantic Region on Friday, July 17th. A wave of low pressure developed along the boundary and headed northward Friday night triggering a line of thunderstorms which moved northward across Dutchess and Litchfield counties late in the evening.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A tree was reported down on a rural road to the east of Lakeville due to strong thunderstorm winds.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A warm, humid and unstable airmass was in place within the warm sector of a low pressure system. Aloft, an upper level low was over the Great Lakes region with disturbances rotating about it. Thunderstorms occurred across Litchfield County during the evening hours with some storms becoming severe.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Nickel to ping pong ball size hail was reported in New Milford during a thunderstorm.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A house was struck by lightning in Bantam.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system approached the region Thursday, July 16th. A warm front associated with the system moved to the northeast by early afternoon placing the local area in a very unstable airmass. A cold front then moved across the area Thursday night. In addition, an upper level low was approaching the Great Lakes Region. Severe thunderstorms moved across Litchfield County Thursday evening.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trees were reported down along Route 41 and Route 44 in Salisbury due to strong thunderstorm winds.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A warm, humid and unstable airmass was in place within the warm sector of a low pressure system. Aloft, an upper level low was over the Great Lakes region with disturbances rotating about it. Thunderstorms occurred across Litchfield County during the evening hours with some storms becoming severe.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Wires were reported down in Mitcheltown due to strong thunderstorm winds.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong cold front brought rain and high winds to northern Connecticut.  Winds knocked numerous trees and wires down in Hartford and Tolland counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trees and wires were downed in portions of Tolland County, including Columbia, Ellington, Tolland, and Somers.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong cold front brought rain and high winds to northern Connecticut.  Winds knocked numerous trees and wires down in Hartford and Tolland counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Numerous trees and wires were downed throughout Hartford County.  This included trees in Glastonbury, Manchester, West Hartford, Berlin, Suffield, Farmington, East Hartford, Granby, Windsor, Wethersfield, Southington, Simsbury, and South Windsor.  Trees fell on houses on Lincoln Street in Berlin, on Evergreen Lane in Glastonbury, and on Grennan Road in West Hartford.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Unseasonably warm temperatures moved into southern New England ahead of a cold front which allowed for excellent atmospheric mixing. This resulted in strong to damaging winds across much of eastern Massachusetts and Rhode Island as well as portions of northern Connecticut.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A weather station at an amateur radio operator's home in New Britain recorded a wind gust of 47 mph.  Trees and branches were downed in Granby, South Windsor, Suffield, East Hartford, Newington, Farmington, and Glastonbury.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Rapidly deepening low pressure tracked slowly northeast from the North Carolina coast during the day Wednesday to southeast of Long Island by Wednesday evening. This brought periods of heavy snow to the region late Tuesday night into Wednesday evening. In addition, strong northeasterly winds occurred during the peak of the event Wednesday afternoon. Between six to twelve inches of snow fell across extreme Southwestern Connecticut, with four to eight inches across Southeastern Connecticut.

Low pressure developing along the Delmarva coast tracked northeast Monday Night, passing just south of Long Island on Tuesday. This surface low in combination with a strong upper level disturbance brought a heavy snowfall to Northern New Haven County Monday night into Tuesday, with between seven to twelve inches of snow.
Low pressure moved northeastward from the New Jersey coast, southeast of Nantucket, and into the Gulf of Maine. This spread three to six inches of snow across much of Southern New England.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Four to eight inches of snow fell across Tolland County.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A backdoor cold front combined with a sea breeze front, warm temperatures, and plenty of instability to produce showers and thunderstorms across much of southern New England.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trees and wires on Main Street were downed by thunderstorm winds.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A backdoor cold front combined with a sea breeze front, warm temperatures, and plenty of instability to produce showers and thunderstorms across much of southern New England.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A tree on Silver Lane was downed by thunderstorm winds.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A backdoor cold front combined with a sea breeze front, warm temperatures, and plenty of instability to produce showers and thunderstorms across much of southern New England.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A tree on Capen Street was downed by thunderstorm winds.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A weak frontal boundary dropped south through the area, resulting in a few thunderstorms that produced quarter size hail in Massachusetts and Connecticut.
A weak frontal boundary dropped south through the area, resulting in a few thunderstorms that produced quarter size hail in Massachusetts and Connecticut.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A tree on Route 315 was downed by thunderstorm winds.
