EVENT_NARRATIVE: Quarter to golfball size hail fell on Ridge Road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A backdoor cold front combined with a sea breeze front, warm temperatures, and plenty of instability to produce showers and thunderstorms across much of southern New England.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A tree on Wright Road was downed by thunderstorm winds.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A backdoor cold front combined with a sea breeze front, warm temperatures, and plenty of instability to produce showers and thunderstorms across much of southern New England.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A tree on River Road was downed by thunderstorm winds.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A backdoor cold front combined with a sea breeze front, warm temperatures, and plenty of instability to produce showers and thunderstorms across much of southern New England.
A backdoor cold front combined with a sea breeze front, warm temperatures, and plenty of instability to produce showers and thunderstorms across much of southern New England.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A large tree on Mountain Road was downed by thunderstorm winds.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low pressure over the Canadian Maritimes produced winds gusts of 40 to 50 mph throughout southern New England, resulting in scattered wind damage.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Winds gusting as high as 56 mph at Bradley International Airport in Windsor Locks produced wind damage throughout Hartford County, most notably in the higher elevations. There were many reports of downed trees, large limbs, and wires from Southington, Farmington, Avon, and Simsbury through the greater Hartford area.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An intensifying area of low pressure and a strong cold front led to showers and thunderstorms as well as gradient winds across much of Southern New England.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Numerous trees and wires were downed across Hartford County.  Trees were downed in Bloomfield on Terry Plains Road, in Manchester on Porter Street, in Suffield on Bridge and Thrall Streets, and in Enfield on Dover Road and South River Street.  In West Hartford, a tree fell on a car at the intersection of Mountain Road and Albany Avenue.  A tree fell on a car near Prospect Street in Manchester.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level disturbance combined with a weakening cold front to initiate showers and thunderstorms across southern New England. These storms produced damaging winds, downing trees, wires, and power poles throughout the area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Large trees were downed onto power lines by thunderstorm winds.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level disturbance combined with a weakening cold front to initiate showers and thunderstorms across southern New England. These storms produced damaging winds, downing trees, wires, and power poles throughout the area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trees were downed by thunderstorm winds, blocking a road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level disturbance combined with a weakening cold front to initiate showers and thunderstorms across southern New England. These storms produced damaging winds, downing trees, wires, and power poles throughout the area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Five inch diameter tree limbs were downed by thunderstorm winds.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level disturbance combined with a weakening cold front to initiate showers and thunderstorms across southern New England. These storms produced damaging winds, downing trees, wires, and power poles throughout the area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Wires on Arch Road were downed by thunderstorm winds.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level disturbance combined with a weakening cold front to initiate showers and thunderstorms across southern New England. These storms produced damaging winds, downing trees, wires, and power poles throughout the area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Two trees on Lake Street were downed by thunderstorm winds.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A wave of low pressure moving along a stationary front in place across Southern New England produced showers and thunderstorms across much of the region.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Many trees were downed by thunderstorm winds.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A wave of low pressure moving along a stationary front in place across Southern New England produced showers and thunderstorms across much of the region.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Numerous trees and wires were downed throughout Suffield and Windsor Locks.  Several trees were downed onto houses on School Street and North Street in Windsor Locks.  The Automated Surface Observing Station at Bradley International Airport (KBDL) recorded a wind gust of 60 mph.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front moved across Southern New England, bringing showers and thunderstorms to the region.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trees, wires, and large tree limbs were downed by thunderstorm winds in East Hartford and West Hartford.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low pressure tracked up the east coast and interacted with a stalled frontal boundary and approaching upper level low pressure system.  Strong southerly flow allowed for the transport of tropical moisture, including the remnants of Tropical Storm Nicole, up the coast which resulted in heavy rain and flooding in portions of Fairfield and New Haven Counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Riverside Ave. was closed due to flooding in Greenwich.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low pressure tracked up the east coast and interacted with a stalled frontal boundary and approaching upper level low pressure system.  Strong southerly flow allowed for the transport of tropical moisture, including the remnants of Tropical Storm Nicole, up the coast which resulted in heavy rain and flooding in portions of Fairfield and New Haven Counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Ponding of water six inches deep accumulated alongside a major swamp located near the intersection of Boggs Hill Rd. and Palestine Rd in Newtown.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low pressure tracked up the east coast and interacted with a stalled frontal boundary and approaching upper level low pressure system.  Strong southerly flow allowed for the transport of tropical moisture, including the remnants of Tropical Storm Nicole, up the coast which resulted in heavy rain and flooding in portions of Fairfield and New Haven Counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Sections of Route 25 in Monroe and off Exit 33 of Interstate 95 in Stratford were closed due to flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low pressure tracked up the east coast and interacted with a stalled frontal boundary and approaching upper level low pressure system.  Strong southerly flow allowed for the transport of tropical moisture, including the remnants of Tropical Storm Nicole, up the coast which resulted in heavy rain and flooding in portions of Fairfield and New Haven Counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The intersection of Route 136 and South Main Street in Norwalk was under several feet of water.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An approaching cold front sparked scattered thunderstorms across portions of Connecticut. One of the storms became briefly severe.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Nickel size hail was reported in Wilton.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Severe thunderstorms produced damaging winds in parts of nothern Connecticut.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorm winds brought down wires on Washington Avenue in East Hartford. Trees were brought down on Griswold Street in Wethersfield. In Rocky Hill, trees were downed on Walnut Road, and wires were downed on Riverview Road and West Street.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Severe thunderstorms produced damaging winds in parts of nothern Connecticut.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorm winds brought down wires in Bolton.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Several waves of low pressure moved across Southern New England bringing unseasonably warm air into the area. This allowed for good mixing which brought strong winds from a strong low level jet to the surface.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Automated Surface Observing System at Bradley International Airport (KBDL) recorded sustained wind speeds of 32 mph.  Several reports of trees and wires downed were received throughout Hartford County.  In addition a utility pole on Burnside Avenue in East Hartford was downed by the wind.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong ridge built into Southern New England resulting in temperatures nearing 100 with high humidity.  Heat index values ranged from 100 to 106 for most of Southern New England on the 6th and again on the 7th in a more limited area, generally the Connecticut River Valley.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heat index values at the Bradley International Airport (KBDL) and Hartford Brainard Airport (KHFD) Automated Surface Observing Systems reached 105-106 degrees.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong ridge built into Southern New England resulting in temperatures nearing 100 with high humidity.  Heat index values ranged from 100 to 106 for most of Southern New England on the 6th and again on the 7th in a more limited area, generally the Connecticut River Valley.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heat index values at the Windham Airport (KIJD) Automated Surface Observing System in Willimantic reached 100 to 104 degrees.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong ridge built into Southern New England resulting in temperatures nearing 100 with high humidity.  Heat index values ranged from 100 to 106 for most of Southern New England on the 6th and again on the 7th in a more limited area, generally the Connecticut River Valley.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heat index values at the Windham Airport (KIJD) Automated Surface Observing System in Willimantic reached 105 to 106 degrees.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level disturbance combined with a strong jet to produce showers and thunderstorms across portions of Massachusetts and Connecticut.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trees along Route 171 were downed by thunderstorm winds.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level disturbance combined with a strong jet to produce showers and thunderstorms across portions of Massachusetts and Connecticut.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trees and power lines were downed by thunderstorm winds.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front brought showers and thunderstorms in southern New England. Some of the storms became severe and produced damaging winds. One report of large hail was received from north central Massachusetts.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A house was struck by lightning in Vernon which ignited a fire.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front brought showers and thunderstorms in southern New England. Some of the storms became severe and produced damaging winds. One report of large hail was received from north central Massachusetts.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A tree was downed onto wires on Hillsdale Road in Ellington. Trees and wires were downed by thunderstorm winds in Vernon.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A wave of low pressure moving along a stationary front in place across Southern New England produced showers and thunderstorms across much of the region.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Numerous trees, wires, and large branches were downed by thunderstorm winds, including along Connecticut Route 191.  One tree was downed onto a car.

A wave of low pressure moving along a stationary front in place across Southern New England produced showers and thunderstorms across much of the region.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A large tree on Rice Street was blown onto a car by thunderstorm winds.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A wave of low pressure moving along a stationary front in place across Southern New England produced showers and thunderstorms across much of the region.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trees and wires on Orchard and Davis Streets and Route 74 were downed by thunderstorm winds.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A wave of low pressure moving along a stationary front in place across Southern New England produced showers and thunderstorms across much of the region.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A tree and utility pole on Route 83 were downed by thunderstorm winds.  In addition, wires were downed in parts of town.  An amateur radio operator recorded a wind gust of 58 mph on their home weather station.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A wave of low pressure moving along a stationary front in place across Southern New England produced showers and thunderstorms across much of the region.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A large tree downed by thunderstorm winds blocked Frog Hollow Road at its intersection with Route 140.  Trees and wires on West Road were downed as well.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A wave of low pressure moving along a stationary front in place across Southern New England produced showers and thunderstorms across much of the region.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Large branches were downed by thunderstorm winds.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front moved through southern New England, returning as a warm front the following day. Storms fired along the warm front, producing significant wind damage and localized flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Wires on Center Street were downed by thunderstorm winds.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front moved through southern New England, returning as a warm front the following day. Storms fired along the warm front, producing significant wind damage and localized flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trees on Cottage Road were downed by thunderstorm winds.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An isolated severe thunderstorm produced wind damage in Windham County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A house was struck by lightning on Valentine Road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An isolated severe thunderstorm produced wind damage in Windham County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorm winds downed a tree and wires on Pomfret Street.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong ridge built into Southern New England resulting in temperatures nearing 100 with high humidity.  Heat index values ranged from 100 to 106 for most of Southern New England on the 6th and again on the 7th in a more limited area, generally the Connecticut River Valley.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heat index values at the Bradley International Airport (KBDL) and Hartford Brainard Airport (KHFD) Automated Surface Observing Stations reached 100 to 104 degrees.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Wires on Brook and Atwood Streets were downed by thunderstorm winds.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trees on Burnham Road were downed by thunderstorm winds.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front moved through southern New England, returning as a warm front the following day. Storms fired along the warm front, producing significant wind damage and localized flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Golfball sized hail fell east of Interstate 91.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong northwest to north winds occurred in the wake of a cold front during Wednesday morning, November 24th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A tree was reported down on a home due to strong winds. A 51 MPH wind gust was reported at that time.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A major nor'easter brought significant snows and blizzard conditions to Litchfield County Sunday, December 26th into Monday, December 27th. ||Low pressure initially developed along the Gulf Coast on Christmas. Once the low reached the southeast coast Christmas night, it strengthened and headed northeastward along the east coast Sunday. Explosive deepening, cyclogenesis, occurred Sunday night as the low moved northward toward Long Island with the low eventually passing directly over Cape Cod early Monday morning. The low then proceeded up the New England coast during the day. ||Bands of heavy snow with snowfall rates of 1 to 3 inches an hour occurred across Litchfield County resulting in snowfall accumulations of 9 to 17 inches. ||In addition, strong and gusty winds of 35 to 45 mph caused significant blowing and drifting of the snow.

A strong cold front swept across northwestern Connecticut Wednesday, December 1st, bringing strong and gusty winds and heavy rains to the area. With the passage of the cold front winds quickly shifted from the south-southeast to the west and temperatures rapidly dropped. ||Ahead of the cold front, a very strong south to southeast low level jet resulted in wind gusts up to 55 mph, and with the passage of the front there were wind gusts up to around 50 mph. These strong wind gusts downed trees and power lines, resulting in power outages. ||Generally, 1  1/2 to 3 inches of rain fell across the area, resulting in some urban and small stream flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Power lines were reported down on Route 341 in Kent due to strong and gusty winds and temporarily blocked the road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong cold front swept across northwestern Connecticut Wednesday, December 1st, bringing strong and gusty winds and heavy rains to the area. With the passage of the cold front winds quickly shifted from the south-southeast to the west and temperatures rapidly dropped. ||Ahead of the cold front, a very strong south to southeast low level jet resulted in wind gusts up to 55 mph, and with the passage of the front there were wind gusts up to around 50 mph. These strong wind gusts downed trees and power lines, resulting in power outages. ||Generally, 1  1/2 to 3 inches of rain fell across the area, resulting in some urban and small stream flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Power lines were reported down on Essex and Saxony Roads in New Milford due to strong and gusty winds. Power lines were also reported downed in Woodbury.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A major nor'easter brought significant snows and blizzard conditions to Litchfield County Sunday, December 26th into Monday, December 27th. ||Low pressure initially developed along the Gulf Coast on Christmas. Once the low reached the southeast coast Christmas night, it strengthened and headed northeastward along the east coast Sunday. Explosive deepening, cyclogenesis, occurred Sunday night as the low moved northward toward Long Island with the low eventually passing directly over Cape Cod early Monday morning. The low then proceeded up the New England coast during the day. ||Bands of heavy snow with snowfall rates of 1 to 3 inches an hour occurred across Litchfield County resulting in snowfall accumulations of 9 to 17 inches. ||In addition, strong and gusty winds of 35 to 45 mph caused significant blowing and drifting of the snow.
A tight pressure gradient ahead of a cold front produced strong southerly winds.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Tree and power lines were downed onto a driveway.  A car was damaged.  The location was Greenwood Ave. in Waterbury CT.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A tight pressure gradient ahead of a cold front produced strong southerly winds.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Strong winds knocked down numerous power lines and trees across the area.  In Griswold CT, many roads including Route 14 were closed because of fallen trees and power lines.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The combination of strong low pressure, a slow moving cold front, warm temperatures and deep moisture produced a period of heavy rainfall Monday, January 25th across Litchfield County. In addition, the warm temperatures caused some melting of the snow pack, adding to the runoff. Widespread flash flooding occurred as the heavy rain fell on frozen ground. In addition, some mud and rock slides were reported. One and a half to 2 1/2 inches of rain were reported across Litchfield County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Route 44 in Norfolk was reported closed due to a mudslide.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A tight pressure gradient ahead of a cold front produced strong southerly winds.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: In Stamford, 1178 homes were without power due to downed trees and power lines. In Shippan, live wires were down on Harvard Avenue.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A tight pressure gradient ahead of a cold front produced strong and gusty winds.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Strong winds blew a piece of metal flashing the size of a car or about 5 feet by 20 feet off the steeple on St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church.  The church is located on Hillhouse Avenue and Temple Street, and the damage occurred around 7 pm.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A powerful storm formed in the Gulf of Maine on Saturday, January 2nd, and moved gradually westward toward the northern New England coast Saturday night into Sunday, January 3rd, bringing a moderate snowfall to northern Litchfield County along with blustery conditions resulting in blowing and drifting of the snow. Generally 4 to 7 inches of snow fell, with the greatest accumulations occurring across the higher terrain.

The combination of strong low pressure, a slow moving cold front, warm temperatures and deep moisture produced a period of heavy rainfall Monday, January 25th across Litchfield County. In addition, the warm temperatures caused some melting of the snow pack, adding to the runoff. Widespread flash flooding occurred as the heavy rain fell on frozen ground. In addition, some mud and rock slides were reported. One and a half to 2 1/2 inches of rain were reported across Litchfield County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Portions of several roads in Torrington were reported closed due flooding: East Main Street between East Elm Street to New Harwinton Road, Riverside Avenue and South Main Street.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A tight pressure gradient ahead of a cold front produced strong southerly winds.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Numerous trees and power lines were downed in West Haven, Cheshire, and Guilford.  A downed tree blocked Treadwell Street in Hamden, and 1200 customers were without power.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strengthening winter storm passed southeast of Nantucket and brought heavy snow and strong winds to northern Connecticut, resulting in near blizzard conditions at times.  More than 2000 flights were cancelled along the east coast due to the storm and Amtrak service between New York and Boston was suspended during the storm.  Despite numerous cancellations, Bradley International Airport remained open during the storm, except for a 1-2 hour period early Monday morning which they used to clear snowfall from runways and taxiways.  Snowfall totals of 6 to 12 inches were widely observed.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snowfall totals of 6 to 12 inches were widely observed in Hartford County. In addition, high winds brought down two trees in Simsbury, one of which fell through the roof of a house. Trees and wires were downed on Sunset Lane in Bloomfield. At Bradley International Airport in Windsor Locks, the official snowfall total was 13.9 inches. Sustained winds reached 41 mph with a peak gust of 56 mph.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strengthening winter storm passed southeast of Nantucket and brought heavy snow and strong winds to northern Connecticut, resulting in near blizzard conditions at times.  More than 2000 flights were cancelled along the east coast due to the storm and Amtrak service between New York and Boston was suspended during the storm.  Despite numerous cancellations, Bradley International Airport remained open during the storm, except for a 1-2 hour period early Monday morning which they used to clear snowfall from runways and taxiways.  Snowfall totals of 6 to 12 inches were widely observed.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snowfall totals averaged 4 to 8 inches in Windham County. In addition, strong winds produced near blizzard conditions at times.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strengthening winter storm passed southeast of Nantucket and brought heavy snow and strong winds to northern Connecticut, resulting in near blizzard conditions at times.  More than 2000 flights were cancelled along the east coast due to the storm and Amtrak service between New York and Boston was suspended during the storm.  Despite numerous cancellations, Bradley International Airport remained open during the storm, except for a 1-2 hour period early Monday morning which they used to clear snowfall from runways and taxiways.  Snowfall totals of 6 to 12 inches were widely observed.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snowfall totals of 6 to 10 inches were observed in Tolland County. In addition, strong winds produced near blizzard conditions at times.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A rapidly intensifying low pressure system tracked from off the Southeast US coast on Christmas Day and then past the Mid Atlantic Coast on Sunday December 26th to just east of Long Island by early Monday morning December 27th. This intense low pressure system spread snowfall into the region Sunday morning, with bands of heavy snow plus embedded thunderstorms and very strong winds affecting the region Sunday afternoon through Sunday night. The powerful blizzard (defined when sustained winds or frequent gusts greater than or equal to 35 mph accompanied by falling and/or blowing snow, frequently reducing visibility to less than 1/4 mile for three hours or more) brought a widespread area of 10 to 18 inches of snow across Southwest Connecticut and 5 to 10 inches across Southeast Connecticut. The heavy snow was accompanied by area wide winds of 25 to 40 mph and gusts in excess of 60 mph Sunday afternoon into Sunday night, resulting in near whiteout conditions with blowing and drifting snow and making all forms of travel extremely difficult to nearly impossible. In fact, several Metro North lines as well as Amtrak was suspended Sunday night into Monday morning due to high snow drifts. In addition, over 10000 customers lost power during the height of the storm.

Low pressure developed along the mid Atlantic coast Tuesday, February 23rd, then gradually moved northward toward southern New England Tuesday night and Wednesday. ||This system blanketed the area in a heavy wet snow that resulted in treacherous|travel conditions and numerous power outages. Four to 10 inches of snow accumulated across northern Litchfield County with the higher amounts above 1000 feet.
Strong winds associated with a low pressure system and a low level jet affected portions of Connecticut, resulting in numerous downed trees and wires.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trees, branches, and wires were downed in Tolland, Vernon, Bolton, and Willington.  In Bolton, one of the downed trees landed on a house.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A powerful storm impacted the region, the second in just a couple of days bringing heavy rainfall and a heavy wet snow to the local area. The heavy wet snow resulted in additional and continued widespread power outages across northwest Connecticut, downed trees and power lines and treacherous travel. ||An area of low pressure developed south of Long Island Thursday, February 25th, and rapidly deepened Thursday night as it drifted northwestward into southern New England. The low began to weaken on Friday moving little, then moved gradually eastward Friday night and Saturday. ||During the day Thursday precipitation overspread the area. The rain snow line set up just to the west of the Hudson River Valley in New York State. Colder air eventually worked into northwestern Connecticut Thursday night, changing the precipitation to all snow. By the time the snow came to an end, snowfall totals of 4 to 8 inches occurred with the greatest amounts across the higher terrain. The liquid equivalent  totals from the storm were 2 to 3 inches.

Low pressure rapidly deepened as it tracked north from the North Carolina coast Thursday morning the 25th of February to over the Tri-State area by Thursday evening. This was in response to a powerful upper level disturbance approaching the Eastern U.S coast. The low presure area then rotated over the region through Friday afternoon before finally lifting out on Saturday. This low brought a combination of heavy snow, heavy rain, coastal flooding and strong winds to the region Wednesday Night through Friday. Up to 1 foot of snow fell across far western portions of Southern Connecticut, 4 to 6 inches across Central Southern Connecticut, with less than an inch across far southeastern portions.

This was in response to a powerful upper level disturbance approaching the Eastern U.S coast. The low presure area then rotated over the region through Friday afternoon before finally lifting out on Saturday. This low brought a combination of heavy snow, heavy rain, coastal flooding and strong winds to the region Wednesday Night through Friday. Up to 1 foot of snow fell across far western portions of Southern Connecticut, 4 to 6 inches across Central Southern Connecticut, with less than an inch across far southeastern portions.

Rapidly deepening low pressure tracked slowly northeast from the North Carolina coast during the day Wednesday to southeast of Long Island by Wednesday evening. This brought periods of heavy snow to the region late Tuesday night into Wednesday evening. In addition, strong northeasterly winds occurred during the peak of the event Wednesday afternoon. Between six to twelve inches of snow fell across extreme Southwestern Connecticut, with four to eight inches across Southeastern Connecticut.

Low pressure developed off the mid Atlantic coast Monday evening, February 15th. This low strengthened as it moved rapidly northeast reaching southern New England by Tuesday evening. Eight to 10 inches of snow accumulated across northern Litchfield County and 5 to 8 inches across the southern portion of the county.

Low pressure developed off the mid Atlantic coast Monday evening, February 15th. This low strengthened as it moved rapidly northeast reaching southern New England by Tuesday evening. Eight to 10 inches of snow accumulated across northern Litchfield County and 5 to 8 inches across the southern portion of the county.

The rain snow line set up just to the west of the Hudson River Valley in New York State. Colder air eventually worked into northwestern Connecticut Thursday night, changing the precipitation to all snow. By the time the snow came to an end, snowfall totals of 4 to 8 inches occurred with the greatest amounts across the higher terrain. The liquid equivalent  totals from the storm were 2 to 3 inches.

Rapidly deepening low pressure tracked slowly northeast from the North Carolina coast during the day Wednesday to southeast of Long Island by Wednesday evening. This brought periods of heavy snow to the region late Tuesday night into Wednesday evening. In addition, strong northeasterly winds occurred during the peak of the event Wednesday afternoon. Between six to twelve inches of snow fell across extreme Southwestern Connecticut, with four to eight inches across Southeastern Connecticut.

A rapidly intensifying low pressure system tracked from off the Southeast US coast on Christmas Day and then past the Mid Atlantic Coast on Sunday December 26th to just east of Long Island by early Monday morning December 27th. This intense low pressure system spread snowfall into the region Sunday morning, with bands of heavy snow plus embedded thunderstorms and very strong winds affecting the region Sunday afternoon through Sunday night. The powerful blizzard (defined when sustained winds or frequent gusts greater than or equal to 35 mph accompanied by falling and/or blowing snow, frequently reducing visibility to less than 1/4 mile for three hours or more) brought a widespread area of 10 to 18 inches of snow across Southwest Connecticut and 5 to 10 inches across Southeast Connecticut. The heavy snow was accompanied by area wide winds of 25 to 40 mph and gusts in excess of 60 mph Sunday afternoon into Sunday night, resulting in near whiteout conditions with blowing and drifting snow and making all forms of travel extremely difficult to nearly impossible. In fact, several Metro North lines as well as Amtrak was suspended Sunday night into Monday morning due to high snow drifts. In addition, over 10000 customers lost power during the height of the storm.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Downed trees on power lines caused a major power outage Tuesday morning, December 28th, in Stonington, with 2745 customers without power for a while as a result.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A 3 to 5 hour period of moderate snowfall occurred over the region Thursday morning as an Alberta clipper system moved across the area. The timing and intensity of the event during the morning rush hour caused numerous traffic accidents.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: More than 150 traffic accidents occurred across Bridgeport, Norwalk, and Stamford Connecticut due to icy road conditions.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A 3 to 5 hour period of moderate snowfall occurred over the region Thursday morning as an Alberta clipper system moved across the area. The timing and intensity of the event during the morning rush hour caused numerous traffic accidents.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Route 107 was completely impassable Thursday morning.  Dozens of traffic accidents occurred in Ridgefield, with a five car crash on Turney Rd. at 730 am.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A 3 to 5 hour period of moderate snowfall occurred over the region Thursday morning as an Alberta clipper system moved across the area. The timing and intensity of the event during the morning rush hour caused numerous traffic accidents.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Dozens of traffic accidents occurred due to slippery roads and several schools closed in Waterbury.

This intense low pressure system spread snowfall into the region Sunday morning, with bands of heavy snow plus embedded thunderstorms and very strong winds affecting the region Sunday afternoon through Sunday night. The powerful blizzard (defined when sustained winds or frequent gusts greater than or equal to 35 mph accompanied by falling and/or blowing snow, frequently reducing visibility to less than 1/4 mile for three hours or more) brought a widespread area of 10 to 18 inches of snow across Southwest Connecticut and 5 to 10 inches across Southeast Connecticut. The heavy snow was accompanied by area wide winds of 25 to 40 mph and gusts in excess of 60 mph Sunday afternoon into Sunday night, resulting in near whiteout conditions with blowing and drifting snow and making all forms of travel extremely difficult to nearly impossible. In fact, several Metro North lines as well as Amtrak was suspended Sunday night into Monday morning due to high snow drifts. In addition, over 10000 customers lost power during the height of the storm.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Approximately 15 road closures were reported Sunday night into Monday, December 27th, due to downed trees and power lines fully or partially blocking the roadways around Wilton, with over 1100 people without power in the town. Tuesday afternoon a 20 foot section of roof collapsed at Lawn Doctor's production facility on Viaduct Road in Stamford, but no one was injured.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A rapidly intensifying low pressure system tracked from off the Southeast US coast on Christmas Day and then past the Mid Atlantic Coast on Sunday December 26th to just east of Long Island by early Monday morning December 27th. This intense low pressure system spread snowfall into the region Sunday morning, with bands of heavy snow plus embedded thunderstorms and very strong winds affecting the region Sunday afternoon through Sunday night. The powerful blizzard (defined when sustained winds or frequent gusts greater than or equal to 35 mph accompanied by falling and/or blowing snow, frequently reducing visibility to less than 1/4 mile for three hours or more) brought a widespread area of 10 to 18 inches of snow across Southwest Connecticut and 5 to 10 inches across Southeast Connecticut. The heavy snow was accompanied by area wide winds of 25 to 40 mph and gusts in excess of 60 mph Sunday afternoon into Sunday night, resulting in near whiteout conditions with blowing and drifting snow and making all forms of travel extremely difficult to nearly impossible. In fact, several Metro North lines as well as Amtrak was suspended Sunday night into Monday morning due to high snow drifts. In addition, over 10000 customers lost power during the height of the storm.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The strong winds caused a large gas station canopy to collapse on Washington Avenue in North Haven and a tree to fall in Hamden between midnight and 1 am EST Sunday night, December 27th. Meanwhile in Wallingford, an 80 foot spruce tree was toppled onto a house on Pond Hill Road Sunday night.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: High winds occurred across the area as deep low pressure settled just south and strong high pressure remained to the north.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A wind gust to 58 mph was reported in Westport at 320 pm. At Bridgeport Sikorsky Airport, a wind gust of 60 mph was reported at 430 pm.  The public reported a wind gust to 65 mph in Norwalk at 515 pm. There was widespread trees downed by the storm. Some towns that reported many trees down were Darien and Norwalk. There were 2 deaths due to fallen trees. One woman from Westport was killed. Another woman from Greenwich was killed by a fallen tree.

An area of low pressure developed along the southeast coast Monday, March 29th, and strengthened as it moved gradually northward. The storm reached its peak intensity Tuesday morning and stalled just south of Long Island. During the day Tuesday the low began to weaken and move very slowly eastward. The storm tapped into abundant moisture which resulted in a heavy rainfall of 2 to 4 inches across Litchfield County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A one lane bridge on Carpenter Road near Route 202 in New Hartford was reported closed due to water flowing over the bridge.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system sat just south of Long Island for two days, bringing heavy rain to much of Southern New England during that time.  A persistent southerly low level jet brought very moist air into the area, which resulted in high rainfall rates.  A coastal front enhanced rainfall along the Interstate 95 corridor.  This event followed a heavy rainfall and record flooding event in mid-March as well as a second lesser rain event about a week prior.  Rivers across much of Massachusetts and Rhode Island were still high from those events and warm temperatures in northern Vermont and New Hampshire resulted in a period of snowmelt, causing rises on both the mainstem Connecticut and Merrimack Rivers.  All of these factors led to a second record rainfall and flooding event.  ||Two day rainfall totals across Southern New England ranged from an inch to ten inches.  Though concentrated in Rhode Island and southeastern Massachusetts, all of Southern New England was affected by the flooding.  In Connecticut, two day rainfall totals ranged from three inches in Hartford County to eight inches in Windham County.  Providence, Boston, and Blue Hill Observatory in Milton, MA set record monthly precipitation totals during the month of March.  Providence also set the record for the wettest month ever in the period of record.  Both the Pawtuxet River in Rhode Island and the Sudbury River in Massachusetts set floods of record.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Four to eight inches of rain fell across Windham County resulting in several small streams rising above flood stage, including the Mount Hope River at Warrenville and the Quinebaug River at Quinebaug.  Wappoquia Brook ran over its banks at Route 169 in Pomfret, resulting in flooding near the Connecticut Audubon Society.  Also in Pomfret, Mashamoquet Brook flooded.  The Moosup River overflowed its banks in Plainfield, closing South Main Street.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A Nor'easter centered off the Delmarva coast produced an extended period of heavy rainfall across the area as it tracked very slowly to the northeast. This caused widespread flooding across portions of Southern Connecticut.  Major flooding occurred in New London County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Old Saybrook Police Department on Main St. suffered severe flood damage to the building, stored equipment and records after 8 inches of water accumulated in the basement.  The Parks and Recreation Department building also in Old Saybrook and the Senior Center in Westbrook also suffered from minor flood damage.  In Clinton, widespread damage to houses from flooding was reported across town.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The combination of strong high pressure over Southeastern Canada and intensifying low pressure tracking slowly northeast from the Mid-Atlantic States created a prolonged period of strong east winds across the region March 12th through the 14th. The highest winds and resultant tidal rises occurred on March 13th with widespread moderate flooding occurring.  Positive tidal departures of 3 to 5 feet were recorded, with many places seeing water levels reaching their highest levels in almost 20 years.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Water rose to 10.4 ft. MLLW at 924 pm EST at the NOS tidal gage at Bridgeport CT. This is right at the moderate flooding benchmark.  In addition, numerous roads were closed near the shore in Bridgeport on the evening of March 13th.  Paylifters had to remove sand and debris from residences and streets in this area.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Water rose to 10.4 ft. MLLW at 924 pm EDT at the NOS tidal gage at Bridgeport CT. This is right at the moderate flooding benchmark.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Total rainfall recorded at Sikorsky Memorial Airport in Bridgeport was 3.84 inches. In addition, total precipitation for the month of March was 10.19 inches which broke the old record of 9.40 inches set in 1953.

The sewer system backed up into the Bethel Police Dept. on Plumtrees Rd. and was inundated by a mix of rain water and raw sewage.

An upper level disturbance combined with a weakening cold front to initiate showers and thunderstorms across southern New England. These storms produced damaging winds, downing trees, wires, and power poles throughout the area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trees on Maple Street were downed onto wires by thunderstorm winds.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low pressure tracked up the east coast and interacted with a stalled frontal boundary and approaching upper level low pressure system.  Strong southerly flow allowed for the transport of tropical moisture, including the remnants of Tropical Storm Nicole, up the coast which resulted in heavy rain and flooding in portions of Fairfield and New Haven Counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Numerous roads were closed due to flooding in the towns of New Haven and West Haven.  A school bus loaded with children became stuck in high water at the intersection of Washington Ave. and Wood St. in West Haven.  The water was so high that the children had to stand on the seats to avoid getting wet.  The local fire department rescued the children on board.  The basement of Seth Haley School on South St. in West Haven filled with two to three feet of water in approximately ten minutes and caused the school to be closed for the day.  Rainfall totals ranged from 1.73 inches at New Haven/Tweed Airport to 3.05 inches in Hamden.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Significant tree damage was reported throughout the Town of Easton, with some falling on houses.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Two trees were reported down on a house located on Bond Street in Bridgeport.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A large tree was reported down on Housatonic Drive in Devon.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A hot and humid airmass allowed for isolated severe thunderstorm development during the evening hours on the 26th. A strong backdoor cold front then sparked numerous severe thunderstorms across the area through the overnight hours.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A large tree branch was downed on the Wilbur Cross Parkway.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A hot and humid airmass allowed for isolated severe thunderstorm development during the evening hours on the 26th. A strong backdoor cold front then sparked numerous severe thunderstorms across the area through the overnight hours.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Three large trees were downed by strong winds.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A hot and humid airmass allowed for isolated severe thunderstorm development during the evening hours on the 26th. A strong backdoor cold front then sparked numerous severe thunderstorms across the area through the overnight hours.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A tree was downed by strong winds.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front and strong upper level trough moved across the Tri-State, triggering severe thunderstorms across Southwest Connecticut during the afternoon.  This included both supercells and squall lines, producing an EF-1 Tornado in Bridgeport, and severe winds and hail across the remainder of the region.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Straight line winds in Bridgeport, in addition to the small EF1 Tornado, caused the collapse of 5 complete buildings, including one on Knowlton Street, with damage to 9 other buildings. The winds, estimated at 100 mph also blew a billboard off an apartment building, blew out windows and off bricks from buildings, flipped over a tractor trailer on I-95 between exits 27 and 28, flipped over cars on Route 25 between exits 3 and 4, and tore some siding of off the City Hall Annex. It also tore down radio towers, brought down hundreds of trees, including 2 on a house on Bond Street, and across Route 25 between exits 3 and 4. 57 streets were at least partially closed due to the wind damage. Around two dozen people were displaced by the storm.  Note damage estimate includes damage from the tornado, as the total is hard to separate.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front and strong upper level trough moved across the Tri-State, triggering severe thunderstorms across Southwest Connecticut during the afternoon.  This included both supercells and squall lines, producing an EF-1 Tornado in Bridgeport, and severe winds and hail across the remainder of the region.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Numerous trees and wires were reported down throughout Waterbury, damaging at least one car, and several fences. In addition there was some minor roof damage reported in the area around Dallas and Monroe Avenues and Newbury and Gates Streets.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Four oak trees fell on a home in Wolcott, resulting in extensive damage to the home but no injuries.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front and strong upper level trough moved across the Tri-State, triggering severe thunderstorms across Southwest Connecticut during the afternoon.  This included both supercells and squall lines, producing an EF-1 Tornado in Bridgeport, and severe winds and hail across the remainder of the region.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: At the time of the wind gust, a roof was lifted off a hangar at the airport, shattering windows, and cracking its foundation. The winds also detached two corner walls from the top story of the old terminal building at the airport. A couple of airplanes suffered minor damage. Debris from the damaged hangar and terminal building caused minor damage to an adjacent bar.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front and strong upper level trough moved across the Tri-State, triggering severe thunderstorms across Southwest Connecticut during the afternoon.  This included both supercells and squall lines, producing an EF-1 Tornado in Bridgeport, and severe winds and hail across the remainder of the region.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Hundreds of trees were reported down in Stratford, with the Lordship section hardest hit, with the Paradise Green section a close second. Several structures as well as a few cars were reported to have trees fall on them. One person was injured when a tree branch fell on the car they were in, and a police car had its windshield blown out by the winds.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong cold frontal passage produced numerous thunderstorms across western Connecticut.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trees were snapped off 15 feet above the ground on Oak Drive, and several trees were downed on Beechwood Drive.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A backdoor cold front combined with a sea breeze front, warm temperatures, and plenty of instability to produce showers and thunderstorms across much of southern New England.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several large trees were downed by thunderstorm winds, including one on Birch Street and one on exit 46 on Interstate 91 Southbound.  Wires were also downed.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several large trees were downed by thunderstorm winds, including ones on Scantic Road in East Windsor and along Felt Road in South Windsor.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong cold frontal passage produced numerous thunderstorms across western Connecticut.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trees and power lines were downed on Scudder Road in Newtown.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong cold frontal passage produced numerous thunderstorms across western Connecticut.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Numerous trees and wires were downed in Newtown. The areas impacted most heavily ranged from the center of town to the Route 302 and Route 6 areas.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong cold frontal passage produced numerous thunderstorms across western Connecticut.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Numerous trees and power lines were downed throughout Newtown. Over 11,000 customers lost power in the region. Over 25 roads were closed due to the damage.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An area of low pressure moved to the north dragging a cold front through on May 8th 2010. The pressure gradient tightened considerably behind this front as the low moved to the northeast of the area. A fatal lightning strike also occurred with the system.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Strong winds resulted in downed trees across the town of Newtown. A large branch fell onto a motorist, damaging the car. The motorist was not injured. Otherwise, numerous trees were downed along with power lines cutting power to several hundred customers. Trees were also reported down in Trumbull.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A Nor'easter centered off the Delmarva coast produced an extended period of heavy rainfall across the area as it tracked very slowly to the northeast. This caused widespread flooding across portions of Southern Connecticut.  Major flooding occurred in New London County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: In Groton, many streams were above bankfull and numerous homes experienced basement flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An area of low pressure moved to the north dragging a cold front through on May 8th 2010. The pressure gradient tightened considerably behind this front as the low moved to the northeast of the area. A fatal lightning strike also occurred with the system.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Lighning struck 3 men fishing on a jetty at Seaside Park in Bridgeport.  A 29 year old man was filled and 2 other men were injured.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Lightning struck a transformer in Norwich. Five thousand people lost power as a result.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An approaching cold front and upper level trough spawned an isolated severe thunderstorm in New London County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A tree was reported down across Route 97 in Sprague.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system moved eastward across the region on Wednesday, July 21st. The system's warm front lifted to the north during the morning ushering in a moist and unstable airmass. A cold front moved across the area during the evening. In addition, a vigorous disturbance in the upper levels of the atmosphere, along with strong winds, led to the development of multiple lines and clusters of strong to severe thunderstorms during the afternoon and evening hours. ||A supercell moved across Litchfield County during the afternoon and produced intermittent damage along a track from Sharon to Litchfield with brief tornadic touchdowns confirmed in East Litchfield, Thomaston and Terryville.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A supercell that moved across Litchfield County during the afternoon hours produced  a tornado that made brief touchdowns in East Litchfield, Thomaston and Terryville with damage mainly to hardwood and softwood trees. There was little evidence of direct structural damage.||In Terryville, tornadic damage occurred along Prospect Street and Route 6. Damage was reported to a gas station awning on Route 6.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A stationary front, coupled with an approaching upper level trough caused severe thunderstorms, including isolated supercells, across Southern Connecticut.  One supercell was responsible for a microburst in Middlesex County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A National Weather Service Storm Survey team, along with officials from Portland Emergency Management, found damage consistent with microburst winds up to 110 mph along a swath approximately 2 miles long. The damage swath began near the intersection of State Route 66 and Middle Haddam Road in Portland and ended about 2 miles to the east at Keighly Pond Road in the town of East Hampton. The damage path was approximately 0.5 miles wide at its eastern edge and 1.5 miles wide at its western edge, indicative of divergent winds.||Significant damage to many large, mainly hardwood, trees was observed throughout the damage path, with trees averaging 80 feet in height and up to 2 feet in diameter snapped, in almost all cases, 20 to 30 feet above the ground. This is indicative of wind speeds of 90 to 110 mph.||Most of the damage was observed generally along Middle Haddam Road, with trees mostly oriented directly east or east-southeast. To the north, along Breezy Corners Road and Jobs Pond Road, tree damage was oriented east or east-northeast. To the south, along Lyman Lane and Wellwyn Road, trees were oriented to the southeast. This pattern also indicated diverging winds.||Damage to structures was confined to those in open areas away from trees. One such building, a Farm Center on Middle Haddam Road had a large section of roof ripped off that was carried by the wind for about 100 yards. Other buildings in open areas received minor damage to windows and screens.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Two house fires were caused by lightning strikes.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A supercell that moved across Litchfield County during the afternoon hours produced  a tornado that made brief touchdowns in East Litchfield, Thomaston and Terryville with damage mainly to hardwood and softwood trees. There was little evidence of direct structural damage.||In Thomaston, tornadic damage occurred just west of Fenn Road.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorm winds downed numerous large trees and wires in Windsor Locks. Several large trees and limbs were downed in Windsor, including one tree on a house. Large limbs were downed in the Hazardville section of Enfield.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A warm front edging into the southern portions of Southern New England, followed by a cold front moving eastward across the area resulted in severe thunderstorms across much of the area. Many of these produced substantial straight line wind damage and one storm produced a track of intermittent F1 tornado damage that moved through northwestern Connecticut.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A tree on West Chippens Hill Road was downed by thunderstorm winds.

In addition, a vigorous disturbance in the upper levels of the atmosphere, along with strong winds, led to the development of multiple lines and clusters of strong to severe thunderstorms during the afternoon and evening hours. ||A supercell moved across Litchfield County during the afternoon and produced intermittent damage along a track from Sharon to Litchfield with brief tornadic touchdowns confirmed in East Litchfield, Thomaston and Terryville.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Wires were reported down on a car in East Litchfield due to strong thunderstorm winds.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A pre-frontal boundary and upper level disturbance moved across the region during the late afternoon and evening hours of Saturday, July 17th. With an unstable airmass in place, a cluster of strong to severe thunderstorms developed and moved across northwestern Connecticut.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Numerous trees were reported down on Route 44 in Lakeville due to strong thunderstorm winds.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A warm front edging into the southern portions of Southern New England, followed by a cold front moving eastward across the area resulted in severe thunderstorms across much of the area. Many of these produced substantial straight line wind damage and one storm produced a track of intermittent F1 tornado damage that moved through northwestern Connecticut.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A brief tornado touchdown occurred on the east side of Rockwell Park and had an intermittent damage path, mostly at the tree top level, to the end of High Street.  Straight line winds appeared to be the main cause of damage in Bristol, however, damage from a small, brief tornado was also evident.  Trees felled in different directions, tree tops twisted off, and shearing off of tree tops were the nature of tree damage viewed by NWS Storm Survey team members in the area of High and Blakeslee Streets.  This is consistent with low end EF1 tornado damage.  Damage was consistent with a maximum wind speed of about 90 mph.  Numerous trees were downed, bringing down wires and power lines, as well as moving a garage off its foundation, blowing lawn furniture several houses down the street, and crushing an above ground pool.  The Imagine Nation Museum which was very near the damage path recorded a wind gust of 67 mph on their anemometer.

Many of these produced substantial straight line wind damage and one storm produced a track of intermittent F1 tornado damage that moved through northwestern Connecticut.
