Many of these produced substantial straight line wind damage and one storm produced a track of intermittent F1 tornado damage that moved through northwestern Connecticut.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Twelve to eighteen inches of water moved over Corbin Avenue.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A warm front edging into the southern portions of Southern New England, followed by a cold front moving eastward across the area resulted in severe thunderstorms across much of the area. Many of these produced substantial straight line wind damage and one storm produced a track of intermittent F1 tornado damage that moved through northwestern Connecticut.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several trees were downed by thunderstorm winds, including one on Pompeo Road and another on Bully Hill Road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A warm front edging into the southern portions of Southern New England, followed by a cold front moving eastward across the area resulted in severe thunderstorms across much of the area. Many of these produced substantial straight line wind damage and one storm produced a track of intermittent F1 tornado damage that moved through northwestern Connecticut.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Numerous trees were downed throughout Plainville by straight line winds.  Many of these were downed on Northwest Drive, another onto a car on Cooke Street, and another into a condo unit.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A prefrontal trough developed over the area, which became the focus for thunderstorms that produced heavy rain and flash flooding in Fairfield County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: In Danbury, vehicles became stuck in high water on Main Street near Elmwood Park, one of which had water over its hood.  Beaver Brook Rd. and Commerce Dr. were also under a few feet of water.  The ASOS at Danbury Airport reported a daily total rainfall amount of 1.20 inches while a cooperative observer in Danbury recorded a daily total of 3.21 inches.  A meteorologist at the Connecticut Weather Center reported 2 inches of rain had fallen in 33 minutes.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong high pressure, at the surface and aloft, established itself across the eastern United States early in July. Temperatures across northwestern Connecticut warmed into the 90s with a few locations reaching the century mark. Colebrook Lake reported 100 degrees on both the 6th and 7th. Heat index values ranged from the upper 90s up to 104 degrees during the peak heating of the day.

A strong ridge built into Southern New England resulting in temperatures nearing 100 with high humidity.  Heat index values ranged from 100 to 106 for most of Southern New England on the 6th and again on the 7th in a more limited area, generally the Connecticut River Valley.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heat index values at the Bradley International Airport (KBDL) and Hartford Brainard Airport (KHFD) Automated Surface Observing Systems reached 100 to 103 degrees.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong ridge built into Southern New England resulting in temperatures nearing 100 with high humidity.  Heat index values ranged from 100 to 106 for most of Southern New England on the 6th and again on the 7th in a more limited area, generally the Connecticut River Valley.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heat index values at the Windham Airport (KIJD) Automated Surface Observing Systems in Willimantic reached 100 to 102 degrees.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A warm front edging into the southern portions of Southern New England, followed by a cold front moving eastward across the area resulted in severe thunderstorms across much of the area. Many of these produced substantial straight line wind damage and one storm produced a track of intermittent F1 tornado damage that moved through northwestern Connecticut.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A tree on Stanley Street was downed by thunderstorm winds as well as two eight to ten inch diameter branches that were downed on Kenyon Circle.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong high pressure, at the surface and aloft, established itself across the eastern United States early in July. Temperatures across northwestern Connecticut warmed into the 90s with a few locations reaching the century mark. Colebrook Lake reported 100 degrees on both the 6th and 7th. Heat index values ranged from the upper 90s up to 104 degrees during the peak heating of the day.

A cold front approached the region from the west during the day Monday, September 13th, while a disturbance in the upper levels of the atmosphere moved over the region. Isolated thunderstorms occurred across Litchfield County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Penny size hail was reported in Taconic during a thunderstorm.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An approaching pre-frontal trough triggered an isolated severe thunderstorm, that impacted coastal New London County from New London to Mystic.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A funnel cloud was spotted near the General Dynamics Electric Boat Division, in Groton.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A developing coastal storm off of Long Island created strong winds and heavy rains, which were sufficient to bring down trees in Southern Fairfield and New Haven Counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A combination of heavy rains and strong winds brought down a combined total of around 20 trees and large branches in the town of Greenwich from Sunday Night into Monday Morning.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A developing coastal storm off of Long Island created strong winds and heavy rains, which were sufficient to bring down trees in Southern Fairfield and New Haven Counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A combination of strong winds and heavy rains brought down trees and power lines across New Haven Monday morning.  A gust of 50 mph was measured by WTNH-TV in New Haven.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An approaching pre-frontal trough triggered an isolated severe thunderstorm, that impacted coastal New London County from New London to Mystic.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Numerous buildings throughout town were struck by lightning.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An approaching pre-frontal trough triggered an isolated severe thunderstorm, that impacted coastal New London County from New London to Mystic.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A few small trees were reported down throughout the town of Groton, including one tree being blown down along Poplar Street, bringing down wires with it.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An approaching cold front triggered isolated severe thunderstorms across Fairfield County Connecticut.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Multiple trees were reported down throughout the Town of Greenwich.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An approaching cold front triggered isolated severe thunderstorms across Fairfield County Connecticut.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Small to large tree limbs, as well as power lines, were reported down throughout the Town of Westport.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A warm front in conjunction with strong upper level winds produced numerous severe thunderstorms, including tornadic cells, across the New York City Metropolitan Area. These cells impacted portions of New Haven County, Connecticut in a weakened state.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trees were downed on Race Hill Road in Madison.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front and strong upper level trough moved across the Tri-State, triggering severe thunderstorms across Southwest Connecticut during the afternoon.  This included both supercells and squall lines, producing an EF-1 Tornado in Bridgeport, and severe winds and hail across the remainder of the region.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: An NWS Storm Survey determined that an EF-1 Tornado, with maximum winds of 110 mph, impacted a small portion of Bridgeport. The survey found many signs of wind rotation in a highly localized area just north of Interstate 95. The area was bounded by the Interstate 95 northbound connector on the west and Pembroke Street on the east. The most severe damage was concentrated along East Main Street between Nichols Street on the south and Cedar Street on the North. In this area, windows were blown in, the facade of a building was stripped off, tree tops were sheared off, and large pieces of metal blown off from surrounding structures were wrapped around a fire hydrant. Eyewitness reports described a rain wrapped tornado with visibility near zero in swirling heavy rain and debris. Note the damage estimate is just a portion of the total damage to Bridgeport.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An approaching cold front triggered an isolated severe thunderstorm, which impacted far northern Fairfield County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trees, poles and wires were reported down at the intersection of Route 39 and Church Road in the town of Sherman.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong low pressure system approached from the south.  A warm front passed to the north of the area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Strong winds downed a tree that fell on wires on Sudbury Street at 8:30 pm.  In addition, a tree fell on an unoccupied car near 213 Walnut street around 7 pm. Several additional trees were downed across the city of Waterbury. A tree was blown over due to strong winds. The tree fell onto a house at 62 Cedar Lane in Beacon Falls.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The combination of an intensifying low pressure system moving northward along the east coast and high pressure off the New England and mid Atlantic Coast created a very strong pressure gradient across the region. Strong and gusty southerly winds developed as the low approached during Thursday September 30th. Winds gusts of up to 50 to 60 mph occurred across Litchfield County. ||This event continued through October 1st, 2010 bringing very heavy rainfall to the area. Storm total rainfall of 4 to almost 9 inches occurred across Litchfield County resulting in widespread urban and small stream flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Power outages were reported in Cornwall due to high winds.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low pressure tracked up the east coast and interacted with a stalled frontal boundary and approaching upper level low pressure system.  Strong southerly flow allowed for the transport of tropical moisture, including the remnants of Tropical Storm Nicole, up the coast which resulted in heavy rain and flooding in portions of Fairfield and New Haven Counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Multiple roads were closed in Waterford due to flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low pressure tracked up the east coast and interacted with a stalled frontal boundary and approaching upper level low pressure system.  Strong southerly flow allowed for the transport of tropical moisture, including the remnants of Tropical Storm Nicole, up the coast which resulted in heavy rain and flooding in portions of Fairfield and New Haven Counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: In Wilton, a man and a woman drowned shortly after launching their 2-person kayak into the swollen Norwalk River in the early evening hours after the heavy rain had ceased.  Neither of them were wearing a life preserver, and the river was moving quickly at the time of the accident.  Rainfall totals ranged from 1.59 inches in Bridgeport to 5.54 inches in Danbury.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low pressure offshore, in conjunction with a strong upper level low, produced isolated large hail producing thunderstorms across portions of southwest Connecticut.
Low pressure offshore, in conjunction with a strong upper level low, produced isolated large hail producing thunderstorms across portions of southwest Connecticut.
An early season noreaster moved across eastern Massachusetts bringing strong winds and rain to much of southern New England.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Automated Surface Observing System at Bradley International Airport (KBDL) recorded a sustained wind speed of 31 mph.  A tree was downed onto a house on Canterbury Street in Hartford.  In addition, a large branch fell onto the bleachers at a baseball field at Elizabeth Park, injuring a woman and her 6 and 8 year old nieces.  Both the young girls sustained head injuries.  The branch was large enough that it took 10 people to move the branch off the injured girls, however once it fell it appeared that the inside of the breanch was rotted away.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The combination of an intensifying low pressure system, the remnants of Tropical Storm Nicole, and high pressure off the New England coast created a very strong pressure gradient across the region. Strong and gusty southerly winds occurred across Litchfield County as the low approached with wind gusts up to 50 to 60 mph. ||In addition, heavy rains occurred with storm total rainfall of 4 to 8 1/2 inches across Litchfield County, resulting in some minor small stream and urban flooding. Prior to this event, rainfall deficits were running around 6 to 9 inches.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Ninety-eight power outages were reported in Litchfield due to high winds.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong low pressure system approached from the south and caused strong wind gusts ranging from around 40 to 46 mph across the area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The ASOS at Danbury Airport measured a wind gust of 46 mph at 558 am.  There were numerous power outages in Newtown and Shelton due to strong winds.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong low pressure system approached from the south and caused strong wind gusts ranging from around 40 to 46 mph across the area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trees were downed on to railroad tracks in Waterbury.  Downed wires occurred in Wallingford.  In Meriden, a tree fell on the corner of 19 Quinlan Ave., striking a roof of the front porch.  The house was located at 19 Quinlan Avenue.  Thousands of customers were without power across the area due to strong winds.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong low pressure system approached from the south and caused strong wind gusts ranging from around 40 to 46 mph across the area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Around 2000 customers lost power due to the strong winds in Milford.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong low pressure system approached from the south and caused strong wind gusts ranging from around 40 to 46 mph across the area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thousands of customers lost power due to strong winds in Greenwich, Westport, Fairfield and Darien.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong low pressure system moved across the region and passed to the northeast.  It produced wind gusts from around 40 to 45 mph.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Strong winds downed trees which fell onto and knocked down power lines in Norwich.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong low pressure system moved across the region and passed to the northeast.  It produced wind gusts from around 40 to 45 mph.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A tree fell onto Ocean Avenue in New London during the afternoon.  The tree struck a passing car, but there were no injuries.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A Nor'easter centered off the Delmarva coast produced an extended period of heavy rainfall across the area as it tracked very slowly to the northeast. This caused widespread flooding across portions of Southern Connecticut.  Major flooding occurred in New London County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A bridge on Shewville Rd. in Groton was washed out.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A Nor'easter centered off the Delmarva coast produced an extended period of heavy rainfall across the area as it tracked very slowly to the northeast. This caused widespread flooding across portions of Southern Connecticut.  Major flooding occurred in New London County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Major flooding occurred on the Quinnebaug River at Jewett City.  The river crested at 23.26 ft. at 0630 EST on March 31, 2010 and remained above flood stage until the morning of April 1.  As a result, roads were damaged by flood waters including, South Main St. A retaining wall was also damaged on School St.  A woman nearly electrocuted herself while attempting to unplug a clothes dryer.  Water inside the walls of her 24 Wedgewood Dr. apartment caused the wire to become live and she was badly shocked and taken to the hospital.  Coincidentally, 13 other apartments were evacuated after the ceilings collapsed inside the first and second-floor apartments.  The Jewett City sewage treatment plant also located on Wedgewood Dr. suffered severe flooding and the National Guard was called in to assist in the efforts to keep raw sewage from backing into homes and into the Quinebaug River.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A Nor'easter centered off the Delmarva coast produced an extended period of heavy rainfall across the area as it tracked very slowly to the northeast. This caused widespread flooding across portions of Southern Connecticut.  Major flooding occurred in New London County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: In the Griswold neighborhood of Jewett City, many roads were damaged by flood waters, including Sheldon Rd., Campbell Rd., Bitgood Rd., Coal Pit Hill Rd., Popple Bridge Rd., Colonel Brown Rd. and Geer Rd.  A house sustained damage on Pachaug Pond. and a bridge on Sheldon Rd. was closed because of damage.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A pre-frontal boundary and upper level disturbance moved across the region during the late afternoon and evening hours of Saturday, July 17th. With an unstable airmass in place, a cluster of strong to severe thunderstorms developed and moved across northwestern Connecticut.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A roof was reported blown off a house on Factory-Washinee Road in Salisbury due to strong thunderstorm winds.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A pre-frontal boundary and upper level disturbance moved across the region during the late afternoon and evening hours of Saturday, July 17th. With an unstable airmass in place, a cluster of strong to severe thunderstorms developed and moved across northwestern Connecticut.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trees and wires were reported down along Routes 44 and 41 in Salisbury due to strong thunderstorm winds.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A Nor'easter centered off the Delmarva coast produced an extended period of heavy rainfall across the area as it tracked very slowly to the northeast. This caused widespread flooding across portions of Southern Connecticut.  Major flooding occurred in New London County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Major flooding occurred on the Yantic River at Yantic.  The river crested at 13.23 ft. on March 30, 2010 at 1600 EST.  As a result, West Town St. was closed at several intersections, including Case St., Sholes Ave. and at I-395. Sections of the New London Turnpike were closed as was the Canada Bridge on Sherman Rd.  The Yantic Voulnteer Fire Dept. on Yantic Rd. sustained damage due to flood waters.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A Nor'easter centered off the Delmarva coast produced an extended period of heavy rainfall across the area as it tracked very slowly to the northeast. This caused widespread flooding across portions of Southern Connecticut.  Major flooding occurred in New London County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: In Stamford, many basements were flooded on Cedar Heights Rd. and in the Shippan Point area.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A Nor'easter centered off the Delmarva coast produced an extended period of heavy rainfall across the area as it tracked very slowly to the northeast. This caused widespread flooding across portions of Southern Connecticut.  Major flooding occurred in New London County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Widespread basement flooding occurred throughout New Canaan and extending into the Old Bridgeport area.  This was exacerbated by storm surge in the Old Bridgeport area, which caused the closing of Sound Beach Ave. between Lincoln Ave. and Vista Avenue.  Widespread small stream flooding was also reported in New Canaan.||Total rainfall amounts received across Fairfield County ranged from 3.84 inches at Sikorsky Memorial Airport in Bridgeport to 4.78 inches in Shelton.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A Nor'easter centered off the Delmarva coast produced an extended period of heavy rainfall across the area as it tracked very slowly to the northeast. This caused widespread flooding across portions of Southern Connecticut.  Major flooding occurred in New London County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: In Stonington and N. Stonington, numerous roads were closed and reports of numerous houses with serious basement flooding, up to 3 ft. high, was received.  The intersection of Montauk Ave. and Mistuxet Ave. just outside of Mystic was also closed due to flooding.  Several basement offices in Stonington Town Hall on Elm St. were flooded.  Floodwaters also caused extensive damage to the bridge over Shunock Brook on Wyassup Rd. between Avery Ln. and Main St., and a historic 150 year old building that houses the Watermark Cafe and the Village Hardware Store.  Lantern Hill Rd, Grindstone Hill Rd., Loin Hill Rd. and Pinewoods Rd. were completely washed out and in need of major repairs.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A Nor'easter developed off the Delmarva peninsula which produced an extended period of heavy rainfall across the area as it tracked very slowly to the northeast. This caused widespread flooding across portions of New London County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A resident of 22 Oak St. in Lyme suffered from a heart attack and drowned after trying to move structures in his pond because of high water. He was pronounced dead at Lawrence and Memorial Hospital at 1610 EST.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A Nor'easter centered off the Delmarva coast produced an extended period of heavy rainfall across the area as it tracked very slowly to the northeast. This caused widespread flooding across portions of Southern Connecticut.  Major flooding occurred in New London County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Numerous roads were closed in Mystic and Pawcatuck due to flooding. In the Birdland neighborhood of Pawcatuck, Route 1 was closed from Spellman Dr. to S. Anguilla Rd.  Residents on Milan Terrance experienced basement flooding.  In Mystic, Route 1 was closed near Bishop's Cove. Portions of Pequot Trail, Jerry Brown Rd. near the Aquarion Water Co. and Coogan Blvd were also closed.  A small bridge on Collins Rd. was also badly damaged from flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A Nor'easter centered off the Delmarva coast produced an extended period of heavy rainfall across the area as it tracked very slowly to the northeast. This caused widespread flooding across portions of Southern Connecticut.  Major flooding occurred in New London County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: In Stonington, a bridge on Greenhaven Rd. between Palmer Neck Rd. and Route 1 that spans over what is usually a small creek that flows into the Wequetequock Cove was destroyed by flood waters.  A large section of the road was also washed away and several nearby homes were flooded.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A Nor'easter centered off the Delmarva coast produced an extended period of heavy rainfall across the area as it tracked very slowly to the northeast. This caused widespread flooding across portions of Southern Connecticut.  Major flooding occurred in New London County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Pawcatuck River Bridge located on W. Broad St. and the Stillman Ave. Bridge over the Pawcatuck River were closed due to the concern that debris in the raging waters pounding the side of the roadways were damaging the integity and stability of the bridges.  Several businesses along the river experienced damage due to flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A Nor'easter developed off the Delmarva peninsula which produced an extended period of heavy rainfall across the area as it tracked very slowly to the northeast. This caused widespread flooding across portions of New London County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Automated Surface Observing System at Sikorsky Airport recorded 3.31 inches of rainfall on March 13.  This was the greatest 24-hour rainfall total for March 2010.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system moved eastward across the region on Wednesday, July 21st. The system's warm front lifted to the north during the morning ushering in a moist and unstable airmass. A cold front moved across the area during the evening. In addition, a vigorous disturbance in the upper levels of the atmosphere, along with strong winds, led to the development of multiple lines and clusters of strong to severe thunderstorms during the afternoon and evening hours. ||A supercell moved across Litchfield County during the afternoon and produced intermittent damage along a track from Sharon to Litchfield with brief tornadic touchdowns confirmed in East Litchfield, Thomaston and Terryville.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Golf ball size hail was reported during a thunderstorm in East Litchfield.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front and strong upper level trough moved across the Tri-State, triggering severe thunderstorms across Southwest Connecticut during the afternoon.  This included both supercells and squall lines, producing an EF-1 Tornado in Bridgeport, and severe winds and hail across the remainder of the region.

A low pressure system moved eastward across the region on Wednesday, July 21st. The system's warm front lifted to the north during the morning ushering in a moist and unstable airmass. A cold front moved across the area during the evening. In addition, a vigorous disturbance in the upper levels of the atmosphere, along with strong winds, led to the development of multiple lines and clusters of strong to severe thunderstorms during the afternoon and evening hours. ||A supercell moved across Litchfield County during the afternoon and produced intermittent damage along a track from Sharon to Litchfield with brief tornadic touchdowns confirmed in East Litchfield, Thomaston and Terryville.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A supercell that moved across Litchfield County during the afternoon hours produced  a tornado that made brief touchdowns in East Litchfield, Thomaston and Terryville with damage mainly to hardwood and softwood trees. There was little evidence of direct structural damage.||In East Litchfield, tornadic damage occurred in a line across East Litchfield Road and East Litchfield Road South.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system moved eastward across the region on Wednesday, July 21st. The system's warm front lifted to the north during the morning ushering in a moist and unstable airmass. A cold front moved across the area during the evening. In addition, a vigorous disturbance in the upper levels of the atmosphere, along with strong winds, led to the development of multiple lines and clusters of strong to severe thunderstorms during the afternoon and evening hours. ||A supercell moved across Litchfield County during the afternoon and produced intermittent damage along a track from Sharon to Litchfield with brief tornadic touchdowns confirmed in East Litchfield, Thomaston and Terryville.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Penny to nickel size hail was reported during a thunderstorm in Harwinton.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system moved eastward across the region on Wednesday, July 21st. The system's warm front lifted to the north during the morning ushering in a moist and unstable airmass. A cold front moved across the area during the evening. In addition, a vigorous disturbance in the upper levels of the atmosphere, along with strong winds, led to the development of multiple lines and clusters of strong to severe thunderstorms during the afternoon and evening hours. ||A supercell moved across Litchfield County during the afternoon and produced intermittent damage along a track from Sharon to Litchfield with brief tornadic touchdowns confirmed in East Litchfield, Thomaston and Terryville.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Multiple trees were reported down in Cornwall, including a large tree on Route 7, due to strong thunderstorm winds.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A slow moving cold front to the west sparked scattered thunderstorms across the region.  A lightning strike produced damage at the Stratfield School in Fairfield.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A lightning strike struck Stratfield Elementary School in Farifield. The lightning strike knocked out a 10-by-3-foot chunck of the chimney.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An area of low pressure lifted northeast through the Western Atlantic and passed offshore of the Southeastern New England Shoreline. Snow accumulations on the order of 3 to 8 inches, with lighter amounts out on the Cape and Islands, were attributable with this storm. The light and fluffy nature of the snow combined with strong winds associated with the storm resulted in blowing and drifing, as well as visibility restrictions.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Between 3 to 6 inches of snow fell across Tolland County.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An area of low pressure lifted northeast through the Western Atlantic and passed offshore of the Southeastern New England Shoreline. Snow accumulations on the order of 3 to 8 inches, with lighter amounts out on the Cape and Islands, were attributable with this storm. The light and fluffy nature of the snow combined with strong winds associated with the storm resulted in blowing and drifing, as well as visibility restrictions.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Between 4 to 6 inches of snow fell across Windham County.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An inverted trough set up across New England...producing snow across much of Connecticut and western Massachusetts.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Three to nine inches of snow fell across Hartford County.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front pressed eastward through the region during the afternoon and evening hours on February 18th along and ahead of which a very mild and moist airmass existed. Showers and thunderstorms developed ahead of the cold front resulting in isolated sub-severe hail reports through Southeast New England. In wake of the cold front, strong winds gusted upwards of 60 mph causing minor damage with downed trees throughout the aforementioned region.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Nickel sized hail was reported at 7:49 pm EST in Enfield, CT.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong upper level ridge brought very hot temperatures to Southern New England. A moist southwest low level flow increased humidity levels such that heat index values rose above 105 degrees for a period of a few hours.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Automated Surface Observing System at Hartford-Brainard Airport (KHFD) recorded heat indexes of 105 to 107 over an eight hour period.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong upper level ridge brought very hot temperatures to Southern New England. A moist southwest low level flow increased humidity levels such that heat index values rose above 105 degrees for a period of a few hours.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Automated Surface Observing System at Windham Airport (KIJD) near Willimantic recorded heat indexes of 105 to 108 over a seven hour period.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A lingering surface trough and an approaching cold front resulted in showers and thunderstorms developing across western Massachusetts. These thunderstorms produced damaging winds.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Large limbs on Firetown Road were downed onto wires by thunderstorm winds.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong cold front moved across Southern New England, providing enough lift for showers and thunderstorms to develop. A large area of instability ahead of the front was enough for these storms to become severe, producing large hail and damaging winds.

A strong cold front moved across Southern New England, providing enough lift for showers and thunderstorms to develop. A large area of instability ahead of the front was enough for these storms to become severe, producing large hail and damaging winds.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Large branches and wires on Taylor Road were downed by thunderstorm winds.  The Automated Surface Observing System at nearby Bradley International Airport (KBDL) recorded sustained wind speeds of 41 mph.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong cold front moved across Southern New England, providing enough lift for showers and thunderstorms to develop. A large area of instability ahead of the front was enough for these storms to become severe, producing large hail and damaging winds.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Many wires were downed by thunderstorm winds.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong cold front moved across Southern New England, providing enough lift for showers and thunderstorms to develop. A large area of instability ahead of the front was enough for these storms to become severe, producing large hail and damaging winds.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A tree on Route 66 was downed by thunderstorm winds.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong cold front moved across Southern New England, providing enough lift for showers and thunderstorms to develop. A large area of instability ahead of the front was enough for these storms to become severe, producing large hail and damaging winds.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Many trees in South Windham were downed by thunderstorm winds.  Also, a large branch was downed onto the steps of town hall.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong upper level ridge brought very hot temperatures to Southern New England. A moist southwest low level flow increased humidity levels such that heat index values rose above 105 degrees for a period of a few hours.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Automated Surface Observing System at Bradley International Airport (KBDL) near Hartford, recorded heat indexes of 105 to 107 over a three hour period. The Automated Surface Observing System at Hartford-Brainard Airport (KBAF) also recorded heat indexes of 105 over a three hour period.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A warm front moved through Southern New England resulting in increased moisture and lift.  This produced thunderstorms across the area, including northern Connecticut, Rhode Island, and the coastal waters.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A utility pole, wires, and tree limbs along Bailey Road and Parsonage Street were downed by thunderstorm winds.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A warm front moved through Southern New England resulting in increased moisture and lift.  This produced thunderstorms across the area, including northern Connecticut, Rhode Island, and the coastal waters.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trees and wires at Birch and Hunting Lodge Roads were downed by thunderstorm winds.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A warm front moved through Southern New England resulting in increased moisture and lift.  This produced thunderstorms across the area, including northern Connecticut, Rhode Island, and the coastal waters.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trees and wires on Route 74 and Graham Road were downed by thunderstorm winds.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A warm front moved through Southern New England resulting in increased moisture and lift.  This produced thunderstorms across the area, including northern Connecticut, Rhode Island, and the coastal waters.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trees and wires along Gibson Hill Road were downed by thunderstorm winds.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong low pressure system moved up the coast and southeast of Nantucket producing up to a foot and a half of snow across Connecticut.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Six to seventeen inches of snow fell across Hartford County.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong low pressure system moved up the coast and southeast of Nantucket producing up to a foot and a half of snow across Connecticut.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thirteen to nineteen inches of snow fell across Tolland County.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong low pressure system moved up the coast and southeast of Nantucket producing up to a foot and a half of snow across Connecticut.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thirteen to eighteen inches of snow fell across Windham County.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The excessive weight from snow and ice caused numerous roof collapses across Southern Connecticut during the first week of February.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A vacant Willard Road building in Norwalk experienced a partial roof collapse due to heavy snow and ice Thursday afternoon February 3rd.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An area of low pressure lifting through the eastern Mid-Atlantic and deepening through southeast New England into the Gulf of Maine resulted in an area of heavy rains with amounts ranging 2 to 5 inches across coastal and interior New England on top of melting snows. This large amount of water into various basins resulted in flooding of tributaries and major rivers, inundating local neighborhoods and roadways.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Willimantic River at Coventry went above flood cresting above the moderate flood stage of 11 feet.  In Ellington, Route 140 was closed near its intersection with Route 30 because of flooding.  Portions of Routes 6 and 66 in Columbia were also closed due to flooding.  Portions of Freshwater Boulevard in Enfield were flooded.  In Somers, portions of Durkee, Four Bridges, and King Roads adjacent to the Scantic River flooded.  Two cars got stuck on Flanders River Road in Coventry after it was closed due to flooding and had to be towed out by the fire department.  The drivers of both cars and a passenger were taken to Windham Community Memorial Hospital after showing signs of hypothermia.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The excessive weight from snow and ice caused numerous roof collapses across Southern Connecticut during the second week of February.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The weight of heavy snow and ice caused about 200 feet of a wall to collapse at the state armory building in New Haven, Monday Night February 7th.  The incident occurred around 6:30 pm.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The excessive weight from snow and ice caused numerous roof collapses across Southern Connecticut during the second week of February.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Around 8:50 pm Monday night February 7th, the roof of Nutmeg Utility Products at 1755 Highland Avenue in Cheshire collapsed due to the weight of heavy snow and ice.  This forced the closing of Route 10 between West Johnson Avenue and School House Road until the following morning.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The excessive weight from snow and ice caused numerous roof collapses across Southern Connecticut during the first week of February.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A barn roof collapsed in Bethany at around 4 pm Wednesday afternoon February 2nd at the end of a cul-de-sac on Hunter Trail.  The weight of the snow and ice caused the roof to pancake and trap between 12 and 15 horses.  Rescue operations took 3 1/2 hours.  Also in Bethany, about 13 people escaped injury Wednesday afternoon when half of the roof collapsed at Fairfield County Millwork Inc., at 20 Sargent Drive. ||In Naugatuck, part of the roof at Thurston Energy at 410 Rubber Avenue, collapsed Thursday morning February 3rd under the weight of snow and ice.  The garage of a vacant house on the corner of Arch and Scott streets collapsed as well on Thursday. Mayor Robert A. Mezzo of Naugatuck declared a state of emergency Friday February 4th as a result of widespread structural damage to buildings across the borough due to heavy snow and ice loads.||In Wolcott, a garage at 1615 Meriden Road, used as storage for several aging school buses collapsed on Thursday around 1:30 pm.||In Meriden, the roof of a detached 3 car garage on 599 North Colony Street collapsed under the weight of snow and ice on Friday evening.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The excessive weight from snow and ice caused numerous roof collapses across Southern Connecticut during the second week of February.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A real estate agency collapsed Tuesday morning, February 8th on Route 101 in Norwich due to the heavy weight of snow and ice.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An elderly woman was found dead of exposure in Westport Connecticut on Thursday morning.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Eighty four year old Ada Eads was found dead of hypothermia or exposure to the cold weather on High Point Road in Westport Connecticut on Thursday morning around 8:00 am by trash collectors.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A complex low pressure system tracked northeast from the Lower Mississippi River Valley into the Ohio Valley Tuesday, February 1st into Tuesday Night , with a secondary low pressure developing over the Delmarva region and tracking southeast of Long Island on Wednesday February 2nd.  With a polar high locked in place across Ontario and Quebec, this slow moving storm system brought a mixture of snow, sleet and freezing rain to the region.  A bought of light snow, sleet and freezing rain occurred early Tuesday morning into Tuesday afternoon ahead of an approaching warm front, with a second heavier round of freezing rain and sleet for the region Tuesday Night into early Wednesday afternoon. This later episode caused numerous road closure and roof collapses across the region.||Generally 3 to 5 inches of snow and sleet fell across interior portions of Southern Connecticut during this 2 day storm, with 2 to 3 inches across southern portions. Between 1/4 and 3/4 of an inch of ice accreted across Southern Connecticut, with the highest amounts across far Southwestern Connecticut and interior Northeastern Connecticut.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Tennis Club of Trumbull on Monroe Turnpike collapsed Tuesday evening beneath the mass of snow and ice on its sloped roof about 7:30 pm.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A complex low pressure system tracked northeast from the Lower Mississippi River Valley into the Ohio Valley Tuesday, February 1st into Tuesday Night , with a secondary low pressure developing over the Delmarva region and tracking southeast of Long Island on Wednesday February 2nd.  With a polar high locked in place across Ontario and Quebec, this slow moving storm system brought a mixture of snow, sleet and freezing rain to the region.  A bought of light snow, sleet and freezing rain occurred early Tuesday morning into Tuesday afternoon ahead of an approaching warm front, with a second heavier round of freezing rain and sleet for the region Tuesday Night into early Wednesday afternoon. This later episode caused numerous road closure and roof collapses across the region.||Generally 3 to 5 inches of snow and sleet fell across interior portions of Southern Connecticut during this 2 day storm, with 2 to 3 inches across southern portions. Between 1/4 and 3/4 of an inch of ice accreted across Southern Connecticut, with the highest amounts across far Southwestern Connecticut and interior Northeastern Connecticut.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: In Cheshire, the 174 East Johnson Street Church roof collapsed Wednesday February 2nd, causing a back wall to cave in and two other walls to bulge out.  In addition, a partial collapse to a roof of a building at 1701 Highland Ave. and the rear of a 136 yr. old George Keeler Stove Shop at 166 S. Main Street occurred Wednesday morning.||A building at 505 Main St. in Middletown collapsed on the morning of February 2nd after the roof and 3rd floor caved in due the excessive weight of snow and ice.||A storage barn at 91 Library Road in Southbury came crashing down early Wednesday afternoon under the weight of snow and ice.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A complex low pressure system tracked northeast from the Lower Mississippi River Valley into the Ohio Valley Tuesday, February 1st into Tuesday Night , with a secondary low pressure developing over the Delmarva region and tracking southeast of Long Island on Wednesday February 2nd.  With a polar high locked in place across Ontario and Quebec, this slow moving storm system brought a mixture of snow, sleet and freezing rain to the region.  A bought of light snow, sleet and freezing rain occurred early Tuesday morning into Tuesday afternoon ahead of an approaching warm front, with a second heavier round of freezing rain and sleet for the region Tuesday Night into early Wednesday afternoon. This later episode caused numerous road closure and roof collapses across the region.||Generally 3 to 5 inches of snow and sleet fell across interior portions of Southern Connecticut during this 2 day storm, with 2 to 3 inches across southern portions. Between 1/4 and 3/4 of an inch of ice accreted across Southern Connecticut, with the highest amounts across far Southwestern Connecticut and interior Northeastern Connecticut.

A slow moving frontal boundary gradually moved eastward across northwest Connecticut between Monday September 5th, and Tuesday September 6th, as waves of low pressure traveled northeast along the boundary. The front then moved south and east of the state by late Tuesday, as waves of low pressure continued to travel northeast along the boundary. In addition, copious amounts of moisture from the remnants of Tropical Storm Lee, which made landfall along the Gulf coast, interacted with the frontal system from Wednesday into Thursday September 8th, producing additional heavy rainfall. Total rainfall amounts across northwest Connecticut for the period from Monday into Thursday ranged from 3 to 6 inches. ||This heavy rainfall, combined with saturated soil from the excessive rains which fell in late August associated with the passage of Irene, led to widespread minor to moderate flooding on rivers, as well as small streams and creeks across northwest Connecticut. Some major flooding did occur across portions of the Housatonic River. Flash flooding also occurred in the vicinity of Woodbury.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: In Woodbury Center Route 317, Route 47 and Judson Avenue were closed due to flooding. Major flooding occurred on the Pomperaug River at Southbury New Haven County. The river gage located near Poverty Road in Southbury exceeded its 9 foot flood stage around 6:45 am EST, its 10 foot moderate flood stage around 7:45 am, its 12 foot major flood stage around 8:45 am, it crested at 15.64 feet around 11 am and fell below flood stage by 5:30 pm September 8th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A manufacturing building on Woodmont Road in Milford was destroyed Wednesday morning around 1105 am, when wooden support trusses under the flat roof failed under the weight of heavy snow and ice.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A complex low pressure system tracked northeast from the Lower Mississippi River Valley into the Ohio Valley Tuesday, February 1st into Tuesday Night , with a secondary low pressure developing over the Delmarva region and tracking southeast of Long Island on Wednesday February 2nd. EVENT_NARRATIVE: In Hebron, the roof of a ranch style house on West Street collapsed on Wednesday morning pushing out the structures walls and crushing a car in the garage.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A series of low pressure centers impacted the Southern New England Region with a combination of heavy snows and ice.  The first area of low pressure on February 1st lifted northeastward offshore of the Southeastern New England shoreline ushering heavy snows across the interior portions of New England, especially north and west.  A second area of low pressure deepened through the Ohio River Valley, redeveloping over the Southeastern New England shoreline bringing a combination of heavy snows, sleet and freezing rain over much of the region February 2nd, before changing back to all snow into the end of the event.||A series of significant heavy snow events occurred between December 26, 2010 and February 2, 2011.  Snow for the winter season totaled 86.4 inches, most of which fell during this period.  Across Connecticut, numerous roof collapses due to heavy snow load occurred following the February 2nd storm, including 75 structures in Hartford County, 28 structures in Windham County, and 31 structures in Tolland County.  Damage amounts for this storm include these roof collapses.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A total of 6-11 inches of snow fell across Hartford County over the two day period, with upwards of a quarter inch of ice accumulation for isolated locations falling during the morning perod on the 2nd.  Damage amounts are for the roof collapses of some 75 structures that occurred following heavy snowfall that totaled 86.4 inches by the end of the snow season.  Most of this snow fell from December 26 through February 2 and most roof collapses occurred during or shortly after the February 1 and 2 snow storm.

Damage amounts are for the roof collapses of some 31 structures that occurred following heavy snowfall that totaled 86.4 inches by the end of the snow season.  Most of this snow fell from December 26 through February 2 and most roof collapses occurred during or shortly after the February 1 and 2 snow storm.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A historic and unprecedented early-season winter storm impacted the area on Saturday, October 29, with more than one foot of heavy wet snow falling on interior portions of Southern Connecticut.  This is the first time a winter storm of this magnitude has ever occurred in October.||Late Friday night, October 28, an area of low pressure emerged from the South Carolina coastal plain into the western Atlantic Ocean.  The low moved up the coast late Friday night into Saturday morning.  The low began to rapidly strengthen late Saturday morning when it was east of the Delmarva coast, and continued to strengthen as it passed south of Long Island Saturday night.  With water temperatures in the lower 60s, extreme southeast coastal Connecticut received mainly rainfall and up to 3 inches of rain during the event.  Areas just to the north and west, however, were just cold enough to support a heavy wet snow.  The heaviest snow fell along a corridor through interior southwest Connecticut, with up to a foot of snow in the highest elevations.  In addition to the heavy rain and snow, strong winds were experienced along the immediate coastline. ||Hundreds of thousands of people across southern Connecticut lost power during this event as heavy snow accumulated on trees that still had partial to full foliage during mid-autumn.  This caused extensive felling of trees and limbs across the region and damage to power lines.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Widespread tree damage and power outages occurred due to 3 to 8 inches of heavy wet snow and 15 to 20 mph winds. ||In Stamford, trees and branches and power lines were reported down throughout the town around 1230 pm EST.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A passing cold front triggered isolated severe thunderstorms in New London County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A tree was reported down at the intersection of Harland and Cuprack Roads in the town of Norwich.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A passing cold front triggered isolated severe thunderstorms in New London County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A tree was reported down on power lines on Lantern Hill Road in Stonington.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The combination of showers and thunderstorms in association with a slow moving cold front and deep tropical moisture moving up the east coast from the remnants of Tropical Storm Lee, produced a prolonged period of rainfall, which led to river flooding in Fairfield and New Haven Counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: In Southbury, two feet of water infiltrated the first floor of 15 homes along the Pomperaug River.  The river gage on the Pomperaug River at Southbury exceeded its flood stage of 9.0 ft. on 9/8/2011 at 7:45am EDT, crested at 14.78 ft. at 1:15pm EDT and fell back within its banks at 6:30 pm EDT.  River Rd., River Trail and East Flat Hill Rd. also in Southbury, were closed due to following. Total rainfall amounts across New Haven County ranged from 3.04 in Oxford to 5.60 in Wallingford.

In Danbury, 2 homes were damaged by falling trees by around 330 pm EST. In Sherman, lanes were blocked on Route 39 near Hubble Mountain Road due to downed trees and power lines around 4pm EST.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A complex low pressure system originating from the deep south brought heavy snow and sleet to Litchfield County Connecticut. Initially light snow overspread the area as a result of a weak area of low pressure moving northeastward off the mid Atlantic and northeast coasts on Tuesday, February 1st. A much stronger low approached from the Ohio Valley Tuesday night and crossed the region on Wednesday, February 2nd. ||Snowfall reports across Litchfield County ranged from 8 to 11 inches across the northern portion of the county, with 5 to 7 inches across the southern portion.

A complex low pressure system originating from the deep south brought heavy snow and sleet to Litchfield County Connecticut. Initially light snow overspread the area as a result of a weak area of low pressure moving northeastward off the mid Atlantic and northeast coasts on Tuesday, February 1st. A much stronger low approached from the Ohio Valley Tuesday night and crossed the region on Wednesday, February 2nd. ||Snowfall reports across Litchfield County ranged from 8 to 11 inches across the northern portion of the county, with 5 to 7 inches across the southern portion.

A low pressure system approached from the Great Lakes region Friday night, January 7th, while a secondary area of low pressure formed along the mid Atlantic coast. These lows moved slowly eastward Friday night into Saturday, eventually consolidating into one low during the day Saturday, January 8th. Four to 10 inches of snow fell across Litchfield County.

A low pressure system approached from the Great Lakes region Friday night, January 7th, while a secondary area of low pressure formed along the mid Atlantic coast. These lows moved slowly eastward Friday night into Saturday, eventually consolidating into one low during the day Saturday, January 8th. Four to 10 inches of snow fell across Litchfield County.

Low pressure developed along mid Atlantic coast Tuesday, January 18th, and strengthened as it moved northeastward passing over Cape Cod Tuesday night around midnight. This storm brought a wintry mix of snow, sleet and freezing rain to the area. ||Snow and sleet accumulations across Litchfield County varied from 3 to 6 inches, with ice accumulations up to a quarter of an inch.

Low pressure developed along mid Atlantic coast Tuesday, January 18th, and strengthened as it moved northeastward passing over Cape Cod Tuesday night around midnight. This storm brought a wintry mix of snow, sleet and freezing rain to the area. ||Snow and sleet accumulations across Litchfield County varied from 3 to 6 inches, with ice accumulations up to a quarter of an inch.

Bitterly cold air settled into the region as Canadian high pressure built in Sunday night January 23rd, into early Monday morning on January 24th. Temperatures plummeted to 5 to 15 degrees below zero across Litchfield County. Brisk westerly winds diminished during the evening, becoming light and variable to calm after midnight. The winds resulted in wind chill readings of 15 to 25 degrees below zero.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low pressure developed along the southeast coast Tuesday, January 11th, and explosive deepening, cyclogenesis, occurred Tuesday night as the low tracked northeastward. The storm passed over eastern Long Island and Cape Cod Wednesday morning, January 12th, and then continued to strengthen during the day as it gradually moved up the New England coast.||Heavy snow fell across Litchfield County with snowfall accumulations ranging from 17 to 28 inches. Mesoscale snowbands moved across Litchfield County resulting in snowfall rates of 2 to 4 inches an hour.

Low pressure developed along the southeast coast Tuesday, January 11th, and explosive deepening, cyclogenesis, occurred Tuesday night as the low tracked northeastward. The storm passed over eastern Long Island and Cape Cod Wednesday morning, January 12th, and then continued to strengthen during the day as it gradually moved up the New England coast.||Heavy snow fell across Litchfield County with snowfall accumulations ranging from 17 to 28 inches. Mesoscale snowbands moved across Litchfield County resulting in snowfall rates of 2 to 4 inches an hour.

The combination of showers and thunderstorms in association with a slow moving cold front and deep tropical moisture moving up the east coast from the remnants of Tropical Storm Lee, produced a prolonged period of rainfall, which led to river flooding in Fairfield and New Haven Counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Pembroke Elementary School in Danbury was closed for the day due to flooding in the building.  The back parking lot at Danbury Police Headquarters on Main St. was completely flooded with several cars submerged in water up to the bottom of the windows.  In Ridgefield, a portion of George Washington Hwy., as well as Shadow Lake Rd. were closed due to flooding. Total rainfall amounts across Fairfield County ranged from 2.99 inches in Success Hill to 6.39 inches in Danbury.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong low pressure system moved up the east coast bringing heavy rain and strong to damaging winds to Southern New England.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A spotter reported a wind gust of 61 mph.  A tree on English Neighborhood Road in Woodstock was downed.

With water temperatures in the lower 60s, extreme southeast coastal Connecticut received mainly rainfall and up to 3 inches of rain during the event.  Areas just to the north and west, however, were just cold enough to support a heavy wet snow.  The heaviest snow fell along a corridor through interior southwest Connecticut, with up to a foot of snow in the highest elevations.  In addition to the heavy rain and snow, strong winds were experienced along the immediate coastline. ||Hundreds of thousands of people across southern Connecticut lost power during this event as heavy snow accumulated on trees that still had partial to full foliage during mid-autumn.  This caused extensive felling of trees and limbs across the region and damage to power lines.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Widespread tree damage and power outages occurred due to 3 to 8 inches of heavy wet snow. The heavier amounts fell in the higher elevations.||In Colchester, numerous trees and wires were reported down on Route 16 between Bigilow and Waterhole Roads by 530 pm EST.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The combination of a strong upper level disturbance and a slow moving inverted surface trough extending back over the region from offshore low pressure brought an unusual snow event to the region on Friday, January seventh. Light snow developed across southwest Connecticut during the morning, with a narrow band of heavy snow developing by early Friday afternoon. This band of heavy snow, with snowfall rates of 2 to 4 inches per hour, then slowly translated east across Southern Connecticut  Friday afternoon through Friday evening. Snow totals ranged from 6 to 15 inches across northwestern portions of Southern Connecticut, with 4 to 8 inches across the remainder of this region.

Southern Connecticut received a heavy snowfall on the 11th and 12th of January from surface low pressure tracking up the Atlantic seaboard and then rapidly intensifying as it tracked just southeast of Long Island in response to an intense upper level disturbance. ||Light snow overspread the region Tuesday evening ahead of low pressure and then became heavier Tuesday night as low pressure rapidly intensified. As the upper level disturbance worked over the region late Tuesday night a semi-stationary north to south band of very heavy snow developed just east of the Hudson River, gradually pivoting northeast Wednesday morning through early Wednesday afternoon. This band was responsible for snowfall rates of 3 to 4 inches per hour, and snow totals of between 15 and 30 inches across Southern CT by Wednesday afternoon.||The highest snowfall totals were observed across northern portions of Fairfield and New Haven Counties. The Governor of CT, Daniel P. Malloy, was cited as saying, ���that the season's second major storm was a record-breaker, dumping more snow on Connecticut in 12 hours than the state had ever seen in a full day, up to 30 inches.

Weak low pressure tracked up the coast Tuesday and then just southeast of Long Island Tuesday night, bringing a wintry mix of snow, sleet, freezing rain and rain to the region. With cold air in place initially, light snow overspread the region Tuesday evening. Then as warmer air began to work into the region aloft late Tuesday night into early Wednesday morning, the precipitation changed to sleet and eventually freezing rain, before ending as a mix of freezing rain and rain Wednesday afternoon. Between 2 and 3 inches of snow and sleet fell across the region Tuesday night, with one quarter to one half of an inch of ice accumulation on top of that. This made for dangerous road conditions for the Wednesday morning commute.

Southern Connecticut received a heavy snowfall on the 11th and 12th of January from surface low pressure tracking up the Atlantic seaboard and then rapidly intensifying as it tracked just southeast of Long Island in response to an intense upper level disturbance. ||Light snow overspread the region Tuesday evening ahead of low pressure and then became heavier Tuesday night as low pressure rapidly intensified. As the upper level disturbance worked over the region late Tuesday night a semi-stationary north to south band of very heavy snow developed just east of the Hudson River, gradually pivoting northeast Wednesday morning through early Wednesday afternoon. This band was responsible for snowfall rates of 3 to 4 inches per hour, and snow totals of between 15 and 30 inches across Southern CT by Wednesday afternoon.||The highest snowfall totals were observed across northern portions of Fairfield and New Haven Counties. The Governor of CT, Daniel P. Malloy, was cited as saying, ���that the season's second major storm was a record-breaker, dumping more snow on Connecticut in 12 hours than the state had ever seen in a full day, up to 30 inches.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A partial roof collapse occurred at a multi-unit apartment building at 92 Washington Street in Norwich, CT at 10:53 am on Wednesday. No one was injured, but 10 people were displaced. The collapse was due to roof rafters on the nearly flat roof giving out under the weight of heavy snow and ice. The roof partially collapsed, causing the rear wall to bulge and for the building's chimney to lean towards an adjacent building.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A period of moderate to heavy snow overspread the region Wednesday morning into Wednesday afternoon on January 26th in response to a subtropical moisture feed ahead of a Mid Atlantic low pressure system. This bout of snow produced 2 to 5 inches across the region. The snow tapered to a light wintry mix late Wednesday afternoon into early evening, before a second heavier round of precipitation with convection worked into the region Wednesday evening. This was in response to a strong upper level disturbance working towards the region and rapidly intensifying coastal low pressure southeast of the region throwing moisture back over the area. A very heavy snow band developed over Southwest Connecticut Wednesday evening, that gradually moved northeast late Wednesday night. This band was responsible for snowfall rates of 3 to 4 inches per hour over a 4 to 6 hr period that raised snow totals to 12-20 inches across most of the region.

Weak low pressure tracked up the coast Tuesday and then just southeast of Long Island Tuesday night, bringing a wintry mix of snow, sleet, freezing rain and rain to the region. With cold air in place initially, light snow overspread the region Tuesday evening. Then as warmer air began to work into the region aloft late Tuesday night into early Wednesday morning, the precipitation changed to sleet and eventually freezing rain, before ending as a mix of freezing rain and rain Wednesday afternoon. Between 2 and 3 inches of snow and sleet fell across the region Tuesday night, with one quarter to one half of an inch of ice accumulation on top of that. This made for dangerous road conditions for the Wednesday morning commute.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Approximately 3000 customers lost power Tuesday night on January 18 and a section of Route 10 was shut down for about 2 hours in Cheshire due to snow and ice. About 26 percent of Cheshire was without power.

A heavy snowpack after multiple snowstorms since the end of December caused multiple roof collapse events across Southern Connecticut during the month of January.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The roof of a vacant building at 1198 New Haven Road in Naugatuck collapsed under the weight of heavy accumulated snow.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The northbound stretch of I-95  in Westport was shutdown Wednesday morning for nearly 6 hours by snow related crashes. This stranded dozens of truckers and motorists with some motorists driving southbound in the northbound lane.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A period of moderate to heavy snow overspread the region Wednesday morning into Wednesday afternoon on January 26th in response to a subtropical moisture feed ahead of a Mid Atlantic low pressure system. The snow tapered to a light wintry mix late Wednesday afternoon into early evening, before a second heavier round of precipitation with convection worked into the region Wednesday evening. This was in response to a strong upper level disturbance working towards the region and rapidly intensifying coastal low pressure southeast of the region throwing moisture back over the area. A very heavy snow band developed over Southwest Connecticut Wednesday evening, that gradually moved northeast late Wednesday night. This band was responsible for snowfall rates of 3 to 4 inches per hour over a 4 to 6 hr period that raised snow totals to 12-20 inches across most of the region.

A developing nor'easter coastal storm dumped up to two and a half feet of snow across Connecticut in a 24 hour period.  Twenty-two and a half inches fell at Bradley International Airport setting a one day snowfall record for that location.||This was the second major storm of an above average winter of snowfall.  The first occurred December 26 and 27, with several other relatively minor snowfalls in the month of January, and a third major storm February 1 and 2.  With only a brief thaw in between the December storm and the January storm, snow piled up across southern New England resulting in numerous roof collapses, towns seeking permission to dump excess snow in area rivers and bays, and numerous disruptions to transportation.  Federal assistance was sought by Governor Malloy for costs associated with the January 12 winter storm and its cleanup.  It was granted by President Obama for Hartford and Tolland counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Seventeen to twenty-nine inches of snow fell across Tolland County.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Interstate 84 westbound was closed between exits 17 and 11 from around 5:30 pm January seventh until around 2:00 am on January eighth. This was due to the road becoming impassable from  numerous accidents and cars and trucks becoming stuck in the deep snow.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Three barns collapsed on the morning of January 19th in Newtown due to the weight of accumulated heavy snow. A barn on 57 West Street in Newtown collapsed at around 9:49 am. Another barn collapsed around 8:30 am that morning at the intersection of Currituck Road and Hedge Meadow Lane, while a third barn collapsed around the same time on the intersection of Currituck Road and Butterfield Road.

A vertically stacked upper level low moved slowly over eastern Pennsylvania, New Jersey and southern New York on Friday, May 20th. The surface low moved to near Long Island by the early afternoon. Showers and thunderstorms developed in a moist and unstable airmass across the region. Storms ���trained��� or repeatedly moved over the same areas across a portion of Litchfield County resulting in flash flooding in the Waterbury area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flooding was reported northwest of Waterbury in Litchfield County at the intersection of Route 6 and Route 63, on Route 63 between Echo Lake Road and Woodruff Avenue and on portions of Woodruff Avenue and Scott Avenue.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A nearly stationary low pressure system over the Mid-Atlantic States produced heavy showers and thunderstorms that resulted in isolated flooding across part of New Haven County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Numerous cars were under water at the on ramp of Interstates 91 and 95.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Several waves of low pressure tracked north along a slow moving cold front that extended from the Gulf Coast to Maine.  The combination of this slow moving boundary and a sub-tropical moisture feed aided in the production of heavy rainfall that resulted in moderate to major flooding across portions of Southern Connecticut.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The West Branch of the Saugatuck River exceeded bankfull causing basement flooding in the town of Westport.  Easton Road, Lyons Plains Road, and Highway 136 were closed and evacuations were performed on Saugatuck Ave. due to flooding of the Saugatuck River, also in Westport.  The intersection of Federal Rd. and Rt. 7 in Brookfield was flooded with approximately two to four inches of standing water forcing car dealerships to evacuate.  The Still River exceeded bankfull causing Rt. 6 and Newtown Rd. to be closed.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Several waves of low pressure tracked north along a slow moving cold front that extended from the Gulf Coast to Maine.  The combination of this slow moving boundary and a sub-tropical moisture feed aided in the production of heavy rainfall that resulted in moderate to major flooding across portions of Southern Connecticut.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Three vehicles and two structures were seen floating down the Housatonic River in Oxford.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low pressure continued to deepen across the Southeastern Canadian Maritimes as high pressure pressed eastward through the Central Plains and the Great Lakes Region into the Ohio River Valley. The interaction of the two systems resulted in a tight pressure gradient across New England to continue with strong north-northwest winds.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: An amateur radio operator in Tolland, CT recorded a wind gust of 59 mph on their home weather station at 11:13 am EST.  In addition, a large tree and utility pole were downed in Vernon, CT.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low pressure continued to deepen across the Southeastern Canadian Maritimes as high pressure pressed eastward through the Central Plains and the Great Lakes Region into the Ohio River Valley. The interaction of the two systems resulted in a tight pressure gradient across New England to continue with strong north-northwest winds.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Automated Surface Observing System at Bradley International Airport (KBDL) recorded a sustained wind of 44 mph at 1:33 pm EST.  In addition, multiple trees were downed across Hartford County, including one that was downed onto a garage on Halwood Drive in Granby, another on a garage in East Hartford, and two on April Drive and Indian Hill Road in Glastonbury.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front moved gradually southeastward across the region during the day Monday, March 7th, as a wave of low pressure moved northeastward along the boundary. To the south of the boundary, it was mild as the area was in the warm sector of the low pressure system. The storm tapped into both Atlantic and Gulf moisture, resulting in heavy rainfall of 3 to 4 inches across Litchfield County Sunday, March 6th, into Monday, March 7th. The heavy rainfall, combined with runoff from snowmelt due to the mild temperatures, resulted in widespread flooding of rivers, streams, creeks, roads, and basements. Evacuations occurred in some communities as flood waters cut residences off from main roads.||Damage estimates are unknown.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Sections of Route 7 were closed due to flooding from heavy rainfall and from the Housatonic River overflowing its banks from Kent to just south of the Veterans Bridge, Route 202, in New Milford. Widespread street and basement flooding was reported New Milford. A mudslide occurred on Grove Street in New Milford which prompted the evacuation of several families on Monday, March 7th. It was reported about 40 families were evacuated in Kent due to flood waters.  ||Moderate flooding occurred along the Housatonic River through Litchfield County. The river gauge at Falls Village crested at 11.6 feet, 4.6 feet above flood stage and the gauge at Gaylordsville crested at 13.8 feet, 5.8 feet above flood stage. Farther downstream the river gauge at Stevenson Dam experienced major flooding with a crest of 21.7 feet, 10.7 feet above flood stage.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An area of low pressure lifting through the eastern Mid-Atlantic and deepening through southeast New England into the Gulf of Maine resulted in an area of heavy rains with amounts ranging 2 to 5 inches across coastal and interior New England on top of melting snows. This large amount of water into various basins resulted in flooding of tributaries and major rivers, inundating local neighborhoods and roadways.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several mainstem rivers and small streams in Hartford County went into flood.  These include the Farmington River at Tariffville, Unionville, and Simsbury, the Bunnell Brook at Burlington, and the Quinnipiac River at Southington.  In addition, basements were flooded in Berlin and Avon.  Several intersections were flooded, including the intersection of Old Farms and Tillotson Roads in Avon and the intersection of Wolcott and Wescott Roads in Simsbury.  In New Britain, sewers backed up on Pierremount Avenue, flooding numerous houses.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An area of low pressure lifting through the eastern Mid-Atlantic and deepening through southeast New England into the Gulf of Maine resulted in an area of heavy rains with amounts ranging 2 to 5 inches across coastal and interior New England on top of melting snows. This large amount of water into various basins resulted in flooding of tributaries and major rivers, inundating local neighborhoods and roadways.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several mainstem rivers and small streams in Hartford County went into flood.  These include, the Hockanum River at East Hartford and the Connecticut River at Hartford.  Several basements flooded in Windsor and Windsor Locks, including one on Gaylord Road in Windsor Locks.  Bloomfield Avenue was closed near the Bloomfield/Windsor line because a nearby pond overflowed its banks.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front moved through Southern New England creating enough lift to produce showers and thunderstorms.  A cold pool aloft increased instability and the probability of large hail.  Hail up to the size of ping pong balls was reported with these storms.

An area of low pressure developed along the mid Atlantic coast during the day Wednesday, January 26th. The low strengthened as it moved northeastward, passing just south and east of Cape Cod early Thursday morning, January 27th. Seven to nearly 11 inches of snow accumulated across southern Litchfield County, with lesser amounts of 5 to 7 inches across the northern portion of the county.

The low strengthened as it moved northeastward, passing just south and east of Cape Cod early Thursday morning, January 27th. Seven to nearly 11 inches of snow accumulated across southern Litchfield County, with lesser amounts of 5 to 7 inches across the northern portion of the county.

Irene made landfall locally as a tropical storm around 900 am EDT on August 28, 2011 over New York City.  Irene then moved across Southeast New York and Western Connecticut before dissipating over Northern New England near the Canadian Border later that evening. Copious amounts of tropical moisture within the storm produced extended periods of heavy rainfall, which resulted in widespread moderate to major flooding across the area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Multiple sections of White St. were closed with several feet of water on it in Danbury.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Irene made landfall locally as a tropical storm around 900 am EDT on August 28, 2011 over New York City.  Irene then moved across Southeast New York and Western Connecticut before dissipating over Northern New England near the Canadian Border later that evening. Copious amounts of tropical moisture within the storm produced extended periods of heavy rainfall, which resulted in widespread moderate to major flooding across the area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Interstate 95 was closed at Exit 30 in Bridgeport due to flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Irene made landfall locally as a tropical storm around 900 am EDT on August 28, 2011 over New York City.  Irene then moved across Southeast New York and Western Connecticut before dissipating over Northern New England near the Canadian Border later that evening. Copious amounts of tropical moisture within the storm produced extended periods of heavy rainfall, which resulted in widespread moderate to major flooding across the area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Naugatuck River overflowed its banks resulting in flooding in downtown Seymour.  Water breached the bridge on Rt. 67 and evacuations were performed on Derby Ave. in Derby.  Center St. in Shelton was also flooded. The Naugatuck River at Beacon Falls and Waterbury exceeded their respective flood stages of 12.0 ft and 12.8 ft and crested at 14.36 ft. and 15.77 ft.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A slow moving cold front moved across Southern New England and stalled just south of the area.  This front was instrumental in bringing tropical moisture from the remnants of Tropical Storm Lee into New England.  A series of shortwaves moved through the northeast during this time period bringing several periods of showers and steady rainfall to parts of Southern New England.  Rainfall totals throughout the region over the four days totaled anywhere from two to eight inches, with most areas receiving four to six inches.  This resulted in flooding both on the rivers and small streams and in urban areas.  The bulk of the flooding in urban areas occurred on Sept. 8 as a band of very heavy rain moved through, dumping up to two inches of rain in an hour to hour and a half in some locations.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Numerous roads were closed throughout Bloomfield because of water one to two feet deep over the roads.  In addition, a ten foot section of Bloomfield Avenue was washed out near the intersection of Bloomfield Avenue and Route 218.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: As an intensifying low pressure system moved northeast, its cold front swept east across the region and produced high winds.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A wind gust to 61 mph was measured at Groton New London Airport at 10:21 pm.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: As an intensifying low pressure system moved northeast, its cold front swept east across the region and produced high winds.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A wind gust to 63 mph was measured at New Haven Airport at 9:25 pm.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Increasing cyclonic flow aloft, a shortwave rotating through the upper level trough and a cold front moving across the Southern New England region created enough instability and lift to produce isolated thunderstorms across northern Connecticut. One of these storms produced severe thunderstorm winds that resulted in tree damage in Hartford, Connecticut.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A large tree on Pliny Street was downed by thunderstorm winds, landing on a house.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A significant severe weather event occurred across east central New York and adjacent western New England, including Litchfield County on Thursday June 9th. A very warm and humid air mass was in place across the region on the morning of June 9th. A cold front was positioned well to the north and west of the region, toward the Upper Great Lakes. However, a well-defined pre-frontal trough marched across Litchfield County late in the afternoon. This pre-frontal trough showed up well in observational data, with an abrupt wind shift to the northwest and a sharp drop in dew points. The pre-frontal trough triggered convection, first as a series of discrete storms developing into a broken line, which eventually evolved into an organized line of severe storms known as a severe quasi-linear-convective-system, QLCS. Initially when the storms were discrete, hail was the main threat. Once the QLCS developed, damaging winds were the main threat. The severe storms resulted in numerous power outages with the large hail denting vehicles.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Quarter size hail was reported during a thunderstorm in Canaan.
