EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An unusual cutoff low pressure system for June, resulted in a period of strong northeast  winds across the region June 4 into June 5.  The combination of the resultant surge and astronomically high spring tides, created widespread minor and localized moderate  coastal flooding during the time of high tide the night of June 4.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The NOS tidal gauge at New Haven recorded a water level of 9.5 ft. MLLW during the high tide cycle of the night of June 4, 2012.  This is .3 ft. above the threshold for moderate coastal flooding at this location established by the National Weather Service. Media reported 30 homes were surrounded by water for a period around midnight in East Haven, CT.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A weak upper level short wave trough moved through the area during the morning hours producing showers and thunderstorms.  This resulted in heavy rainfall and isolated flash flooding in New London County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Route 12 at Stoddards Wharf Rd. in Massapeag was closed due to flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front moved through a hot and humid southern New England producing showers and thunderstorms.  Many of these storms became severe, resulting in damaging winds, large hail, and some flash flooding.

A cold front moved through a hot and humid southern New England producing showers and thunderstorms.  Many of these storms became severe, resulting in damaging winds, large hail, and some flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Collins and Gardner Streets in Hartford were flooded and impassable.  Several streets were flooded in the area of the Manchester Mall in Manchester.  Peldon Street in East Hartford was closed due to flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Tropical Storm Sandy formed in the Caribbean Sea on October 22. After drifting slowly southwest on October 23, Sandy turned to the north and intensified to a hurricane on October 24, just before making landfall in Jamaica. Hurricane Sandy continued to the north and intensified to a strong category two hurricane before making landfall again in Cuba shortly after Midnight EDT on the 25th. Hurricane Sandy emerged on the other side of Cuba during the morning of the 25th and proceeded to drift northwest as a category one or two hurricane as it moved through the Bahamas on the 25th and 26th. Overnight on the 26th, Hurricane Sandy (Category 1) started to move toward the north northeast, a motion that continued into the evening of the 28th. From there, Sandy���s motion became driven by two factors. An anomalously strong blocking ridge over the Canadian Maritimes prevented Sandy from escaping to the east. Simultaneously, an approaching and deepening extratropical trough was about to capture Sandy. The combination of the two, turned Sandy to the north overnight on the 28th and then to the northwest on the 29th.||As Sandy continued to move northwest and interact with the mid latitude trough, its interaction continued to make it less tropical, but did not weaken it much. Sandy continued to make a harder turn to the left (west) and made landfall in Atlantic County as a post tropical storm in Brigantine City just north of Atlantic City at 7:30 p.m. EDT on the 29th. The estimated minimum central pressure was 945 millibars. The lowest recorded central pressure was 945.6 millibars at the Atlantic City Marina at 7:34 p.m. EDT.||Record breaking high tides and wave action was combined with sustained winds of 40 to 60 mph and wind gusts of 80 to 90 mph.||These extreme conditions resulted in at least 5 deaths and widespread property damage of at least 360 million dollars.||Emergency managers recommended mandatory evacuations of 362,000 people that lived in low lying areas. Widespread significant statewide power outages of 667,598 lasted up to 8 days.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Coastal communities along Southern New Haven County experienced two successive tidal cycles with at least moderate coastal flooding on Monday October 29th. The peak of this surge occurred Monday Night as Sandy made landfall in Southern New Jersey, with widespread major coastal flooding occurring along the Southern New Haven coast. ||Peak storm tides surpassed water levels from Hurricane Irene in 2011. The record storm tide levels along Western Long Island Sound resulted from a peak storm surge of about 7 to 9 feet that coincided with normal high tides. These storm tides resulted in up to 2 to 5 feet of inundation several blocks inland along Long Island Sound, with a few feet of inundation working north of I-95 in several spots along waterways such as the Housantonic River in Milford, the West River and Quinnipiac River in New Haven, Branford River in Branford, and East River in Guilford.||The most widespread major damage occurred along soundfront communities in Milford and East Haven. Several soundfront homes were completely destroyed in Momaguin in East Haven and Milford Lawn, Morningside, and Silver Beach in Milford. Smaller pockets of major damage also occurred in coastal areas of Guilford and Branford.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Tropical Storm Sandy formed in the Caribbean Sea on October 22. After drifting slowly southwest on October 23, Sandy turned to the north and intensified to a hurricane on October 24, just before making landfall in Jamaica. Hurricane Sandy continued to the north and intensified to a strong category two hurricane before making landfall again in Cuba shortly after Midnight EDT on the 25th. Hurricane Sandy emerged on the other side of Cuba during the morning of the 25th and proceeded to drift northwest as a category one or two hurricane as it moved through the Bahamas on the 25th and 26th. Overnight on the 26th, Hurricane Sandy (Category 1) started to move toward the north northeast, a motion that continued into the evening of the 28th. From there, Sandy���s motion became driven by two factors. An anomalously strong blocking ridge over the Canadian Maritimes prevented Sandy from escaping to the east. Simultaneously, an approaching and deepening extratropical trough was about to capture Sandy. The combination of the two, turned Sandy to the north overnight on the 28th and then to the northwest on the 29th.||As Sandy continued to move northwest and interact with the mid latitude trough, its interaction continued to make it less tropical, but did not weaken it much. Sandy continued to make a harder turn to the left (west) and made landfall in Atlantic County as a post tropical storm in Brigantine City just north of Atlantic City at 7:30 p.m. EDT on the 29th. The estimated minimum central pressure was 945 millibars. The lowest recorded central pressure was 945.6 millibars at the Atlantic City Marina at 7:34 p.m. EDT.||Record breaking high tides and wave action was combined with sustained winds of 40 to 60 mph and wind gusts of 80 to 90 mph.||These extreme conditions resulted in at least 5 deaths and widespread property damage of at least 360 million dollars.||Emergency managers recommended mandatory evacuations of 362,000 people that lived in low lying areas. Widespread significant statewide power outages of 667,598 lasted up to 8 days.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Coastal communities along Southern Middlesex County experienced two successive tidal cycles with at least moderate coastal flooding on Monday October 29th. The peak of this surge occurred Monday Night as Sandy made landfall in Southern New Jersey, with widespread major coastal flooding occurring along the Southern Middlesex coast. ||Peak storm tides surpassed water levels from Hurricane Irene in 2011. The record storm tide levels along Eastern Long Island Sound resulted from a peak storm surge of about 6 to 8 feet that coincided with normal high tides. These storm tides resulted in up to 2 to 3 feet of inundation several blocks inland along Long Island Sound, with 1 to 2 feet of inundation working north of I-95 in several spots along waterways such as the Hammonassett River in Clinton, and almost 15 miles inland along the Connecticut River.||The most widespread major damage occurred along soundfront communities in Westford and Saybrook Harbor. Smaller pockets of major damage also occurred in coastal areas of Clinton and Fenwick.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Tropical Storm Sandy formed in the Caribbean Sea on October 22. After drifting slowly southwest on October 23, Sandy turned to the north and intensified to a hurricane on October 24, just before making landfall in Jamaica. Hurricane Sandy continued to the north and intensified to a strong category two hurricane before making landfall again in Cuba shortly after Midnight EDT on the 25th. Hurricane Sandy emerged on the other side of Cuba during the morning of the 25th and proceeded to drift northwest as a category one or two hurricane as it moved through the Bahamas on the 25th and 26th. Overnight on the 26th, Hurricane Sandy (Category 1) started to move toward the north northeast, a motion that continued into the evening of the 28th. From there, Sandy���s motion became driven by two factors. An anomalously strong blocking ridge over the Canadian Maritimes prevented Sandy from escaping to the east. Simultaneously, an approaching and deepening extratropical trough was about to capture Sandy. The combination of the two, turned Sandy to the north overnight on the 28th and then to the northwest on the 29th.||As Sandy continued to move northwest and interact with the mid latitude trough, its interaction continued to make it less tropical, but did not weaken it much. Sandy continued to make a harder turn to the left (west) and made landfall in Atlantic County as a post tropical storm in Brigantine City just north of Atlantic City at 7:30 p.m. EDT on the 29th. The estimated minimum central pressure was 945 millibars. The lowest recorded central pressure was 945.6 millibars at the Atlantic City Marina at 7:34 p.m. EDT.||Record breaking high tides and wave action was combined with sustained winds of 40 to 60 mph and wind gusts of 80 to 90 mph.||These extreme conditions resulted in at least 5 deaths and widespread property damage of at least 360 million dollars.||Emergency managers recommended mandatory evacuations of 362,000 people that lived in low lying areas. Widespread significant statewide power outages of 667,598 lasted up to 8 days.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Coastal communities along Southern New London County experienced two successive tidal cycles with at least moderate coastal flooding on Monday October 29th. The peak of this surge occurred Monday Night as Sandy made landfall in Southern New Jersey, with widespread major coastal flooding occurring along the Southern New London coast. ||Peak storm tides surpassed water levels from Hurricane Irene in 2011, only being topped by Hurricane Carol in 1954 and the 1938 Hurricane. The record storm tide levels along Eastern Long Island Sound resulted from a peak storm surge of about 5 to 7 feet that coincided with normal high tides. These storm tides resulted in up to 2 to 3 feet of inundation a few blocks inland along low lying portions of Long Island Sound, with 1 to 2 feet of inundation working north of I-95 in several low spots along waterways such as the Niantic River in Niantic, Mystic River in Mystic, and almost 15 miles inland along the Connecticut and Thames Rivers.||Pockets of major damage occurred in Old Lyme.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Tropical Storm Sandy formed in the Caribbean Sea on October 22. After drifting slowly southwest on October 23, Sandy turned to the north and intensified to a hurricane on October 24, just before making landfall in Jamaica. Hurricane Sandy continued to the north and intensified to a strong category two hurricane before making landfall again in Cuba shortly after Midnight EDT on the 25th. Hurricane Sandy emerged on the other side of Cuba during the morning of the 25th and proceeded to drift northwest as a category one or two hurricane as it moved through the Bahamas on the 25th and 26th. Overnight on the 26th, Hurricane Sandy (Category 1) started to move toward the north northeast, a motion that continued into the evening of the 28th. From there, Sandy���s motion became driven by two factors. An anomalously strong blocking ridge over the Canadian Maritimes prevented Sandy from escaping to the east. Simultaneously, an approaching and deepening extratropical trough was about to capture Sandy. The combination of the two, turned Sandy to the north overnight on the 28th and then to the northwest on the 29th.||As Sandy continued to move northwest and interact with the mid latitude trough, its interaction continued to make it less tropical, but did not weaken it much. Sandy continued to make a harder turn to the left (west) and made landfall in Atlantic County as a post tropical storm in Brigantine City just north of Atlantic City at 7:30 p.m. EDT on the 29th. The estimated minimum central pressure was 945 millibars. The lowest recorded central pressure was 945.6 millibars at the Atlantic City Marina at 7:34 p.m. EDT.||Record breaking high tides and wave action was combined with sustained winds of 40 to 60 mph and wind gusts of 80 to 90 mph.||These extreme conditions resulted in at least 5 deaths and widespread property damage of at least 360 million dollars.||Emergency managers recommended mandatory evacuations of 362,000 people that lived in low lying areas. Widespread significant statewide power outages of 667,598 lasted up to 8 days.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Widespread record coastal flooding occurred along Western Long Island Sound. Along the Southern Fairfield coast, peak storm tides surpassed water levels from the October 31, 1991 and December 11, 1992 nor'easters and the recorded peaks from Hurricane Irene in 2011 and the 1938 Hurricane. ||The record storm tide levels along Western Long Island Sound resulted from a peak storm surge of about 8 to 9 feet that coincided with normal high tides. These storm tides resulted in up to 2 to 5 feet of inundation several blocks inland along Long Island Sound, with a few feet of inundation working north of I-95 in several spots along waterways such as the Pequonnock River in Bridgeport, Ash Creek and Mill River in Fairfield, Saugatuck River in Westport, and Norwalk River in Norwalk.||The most widespread major damage occurred in Bridgeport and Fairfield townships, with isolated pockets of heavy damage, such as in Greenwich. In addition, Igor Sikorsky Airport experienced inundation of both runways by a few feet of water with inundation reaching the terminal building.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low pressure moved up the east coast spreading snow, rain, and wind across southern New England.  Cloudy skies coupled with evaporational cooling to keep temperatures cooler than expected which resulted in snow spread across all but the south coasts of RI and MA as well as portions of southeastern MA.  This in turn resulted in higher snow accumulations across much of southern New England.  In Connecticut, accumulations ranged from two to nine inches.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Anywhere from two to nine inches of snow fell across Hartford County.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A wind gust to 76 mph was reported at Bridgeport Airport at 549 pm. Wind gusts of 70 mph were reported at Greenwich, with gusts up to 69 and 68 mph in Norwalk and Trumbull respectively.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low pressure tracked from the Tennesse Valley to Mid-Altantic coast Friday night into early Saturday morning, and then just south of Long Island on Saturday.  A band of moderate to heavy snow to the north of the low brought 6 to 12 inches of snow across most of Southern Connecticut.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Between 6 to 11 inches of snow fell across Northern Middlesex County by Saturday afternoon. The heaviest amounts fell across southern portions of this area with Haddam reporting 11 inches.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A deep area of low pressure approached from the southeast, and passed just south of Long Island. High winds from this Nor'Easter resulted in scattered damage.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: In Colchester, trees and power lines were reported down from the high winds. This report came from amateur radio and this occurred at 1209 am on the 27th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A complex low pressure system entering the Ohio Valley on December 28th transferred its energy to a secondary low along the North Carolina coast on the 29th. The secondary low intensifed into a nor'easter off the Mid Atlantic and New England coasts later on the 29th, and brought heavy snow to most of southern Connecticut.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Spotters and state DOT reported snowfall of 3 to 6 inches. The highest snowfall amount of 6.3 inches was at Shelton.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A complex low pressure system entering the Ohio Valley on December 28th transferred its energy to a secondary low along the North Carolina coast on the 29th. EVENT_NARRATIVE: Spotters and state DOT reported 10 to 12 inches of snowfall.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Spotters and state DOT reported 9 to 12 inches of snowfall.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A complex multi-part long duration (24 to 36 hour) storm blanketed northern Litchfield County with 4 to 8 inches of snow and sleet on Wednesday, February 29th and Thursday, March 1st. ||A large low pressure system approached from the upper mid west and Great Lakes region Wednesday. In association with the system's warm front, snow initially overspread the area. As warmer air worked its way into the area Wednesday night, the snow transitioned to a wintry mix. A secondary low began to form in the mid-Atlantic region early Thursday morning. This resulted in a double-barrelled low pressure system which moved eastward during the day Thursday. The wintry mix transitioned back to snow which persisted most of the day. However, the snow had trouble accumulating as temperatures warmed and this limited additional significant accumulations.

The secondary low intensifed into a nor'easter off the Mid Atlantic and New England coasts later on the 29th, and brought heavy snow to most of southern Connecticut.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Spotters and state DOT measured 8 to 9 inches of snowfall.

A cold front moved across southern New England into a warm moist airmass with plenty of instability. This resulted in severe thunderstorms and in some cases training of storms that resulted in flash flooding across some of the more urban areas. A microburst occurred in Arlington, knocking down numerous trees and damaging a roof.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Dime to golfball size hail fell in Eastford.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front approaching from the west provided enough lift for showers and thunderstorms. As this front was approaching the atmosphere was sufficiently unstable across western Massachusetts, southwestern New Hampshire and western Connecticut for storms to become severe. Most damage was the result of strong to damaging winds.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A tree was downed by thunderstorm winds blocking the road.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Lightning struck at the intersection of the two main runways at Bradley International Airport, damaging the runway surface.  The runways were closed for about an hour while debris was cleared and the runway was patched.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A warm and moist southerly flow of air moved into the region in advance of a powerful cold front. The combination of partial sunshine, increasing amounts of instability and strong wind dynamics with this system placed the region into a rare Moderate Risk by the Storm Prediction Center. Several supercell thunderstorms developed earlier in the day in advance of the main squall line associated with the cold front with the potential for tornadoes, although none developed across the region. The main hazard was straight line damaging wind gusts from a squall line during the afternoon and early evening hours that resulted in numerous power outages and trees down across the area. The squall line moved east of the area later in the evening, ending the threat for severe weather.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trees were reported to be down and on wires due to thunderstorm winds in Northfield.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Showers and thunderstorms developed in a warm, moist atmosphere. Cold air aloft contributed to an unstable environment resulting in severe thunderstorms. Moisture was such that rainfall rates were high enough to result in flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A man was struck by lightning inside his house.  He is expected to be alright.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A passing cold front and upper level shortwave triggered multiple severe thunderstorms across Southern Connecticut. Large hail, up to hen-egg in size, was the main feature with these storms.

The combination of an upper level shortwave trough and a surface trough produced scattered showers and thunderstorms across the area.  Some thunderstorms produced torrential rainfall which resulted in flash flooding in Fairfield County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: In Norwalk, a car was stranded in high water from flash flooding at the intersection of Connecticut and Fairfield Avenues. Multiple cars were also stuck in high water on Merrill Rd. as well as on Interstate 95 southbound, which was closed.  Water from flash flooding also entered homes on Glenndenning St. and Hunters Lane.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A combination of a pre-frontal trough and a passing cold front triggered multiple severe thunderstorms across Southern Connecticut.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A two- ton air conditioning unit on top of Roger Park Middle School was torn loose and fell through the roof into the building.  The town engineer estimated the wind at 100 mph.  Many large trees were uprooted nearby.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A lingering surface trough and an approaching upper level disturbance triggered isolated severe thunderstorms across Fairfield County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trees were reported down on wires at the intersection of Old Stamford and Talmadge Hill Roads.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A lingering surface trough and an approaching upper level disturbance triggered isolated severe thunderstorms across Fairfield County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A tree was reported down on Merritt Parkway just east of Exit 37 near the Service Area.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A lingering surface trough and an approaching upper level disturbance triggered isolated severe thunderstorms across Fairfield County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A Condominium on East Hayestown Road was struck by lightning and caught fire.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A complex and powerful low pressure system moved across the region bringing damaging winds and widespread heavy rainfall. A low pressure system originating in the Deep South approached the region from the southwest during the day as a strong cold front approached from the Great Lakes region. These systems merged and moved across the northeastern United States. Moisture was transported into the region on a very strong low level jet. Rainfall totals ranged from just over an inch up to around 3 inches. Despite instability being very limited, the winds field was so strong aloft that showers and low-topped thunderstorms were able to transport strong, damaging winds to the surface, producing damage to trees and power lines.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trees were reported down in Torrington due to non-thunderstorm winds.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A passing cold front triggered isolated severe thunderstorms in Fairfield and New Haven Counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Multiple large branches were reported down.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A passing cold front triggered isolated severe thunderstorms in Fairfield and New Haven Counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A large tree snapped off halfway up the trunk on Pine Rock Avenue at Saint Ann���s Park.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front moved across southern New England into a warm moist airmass with plenty of instability. This resulted in severe thunderstorms and in some cases training of storms that resulted in flash flooding across some of the more urban areas. A microburst occurred in Arlington, knocking down numerous trees and damaging a roof.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several trees and branches were downed by thunderstorm winds, including one on New Britain Road.  Part of a screen was blown off a screen door.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Dozens of trees were reported down throughout the town of Greenwich, including several into homes. A combination of the downed trees and associated power lines down closed all or parts of 62 roads in the town, including 2 southbound lanes of I-95 between exits 2 and 3. One of the uprooted trees broke a gas line at the intersection of Shore Road and Nawthorne Road.  Some of these trees fell across the tracks for the New Haven Line for Metro-North, resulting in the suspension of service along this line in both directions between Stamford, CT and Harrison NY.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The combination of an upper level short wave and a surface trough triggered scattered showers and thunderstorms across the area.  Some thunderstorms produced very heavy rainfall that resulted in localized flash flooding in New Haven county.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: In Naugatuck, the underpass to the Salem Bridge at Rt. 63 was closed due to flooding.  There was also at least six inches of flowing water on South Main St.  In addition, apartment units on Prospect St., Trowbridge Pl., and Highland Ave. were evacuated due to flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The combination of an upper level short wave and a surface trough triggered scattered showers and thunderstorms across the area.  Some thunderstorms produced very heavy rainfall that resulted in localized flash flooding in New Haven county.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: There were numerous road closures and impassable roads throughout Naugatuck due to flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A passing warm front and upper level short wave triggered scattered showers and thunderstorms in south central Connecticut.  A tropical air mass in place across the region resulted in torrential downpours and flash flooding in New Haven and Middlesex Counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several railroad underpasses were closed in West Haven due to flooding.  In Hamden, a vehicle was stuck in approximately eight inches of flowing water on Morse Street.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong winds developed between a retreating offshore high pressure system and an approaching cold front.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Numerous trees were knocked down in Seymour due to the strong winds. A trained spotter measured a wind gust to 54 mph in East Haven at 7:22 pm.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Showers and thunderstorms associated with a cold front passage produced heavy rainfall that resulted in flash flooding in Fairfield and New Haven Counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Cars were stranded in flood waters at the intersection of Old Town Rd. and Main St. in Ox Hill.  In Norwalk, Interstate 95 southbound was closed near exit 16 with a vehicle also stranded in flood waters.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Sandy, a hybrid storm with both tropical and extra-tropical characteristics, brought high winds and coastal flooding to southern New England.  Easterly winds gusted to 50 to 60 mph for interior southern New England; 55 to 65 mph along the eastern Massachusetts coast and along the I-95 corridor in southeast Massachusetts and Rhode Island; and 70 to 80 mph along the southeast Massachusetts and Rhode Island coasts.  A few higher higher gusts occurred along the Rhode Island coast.  A severe thunderstorm embedded in an outer band associated with Sandy produced wind gusts to 90 mph and concentrated damage in Wareham early Tuesday evening, |a day after the center of Sandy had moved into New Jersey.  In general, moderate coastal flooding occurred along the Massachusetts coastline, and major coastal flooding impacted the Rhode Island coastline.  The storm surge was generally 2.5 to 4.5 feet along the east coast of Massachusetts, but peaked late Monday afternoon in between high tide cycles.  Seas built to between 20 and 25 feet Monday afternoon and evening just off the Massachusetts east coast.  Along the south coast, the storm surge was 4 to 6 feet and seas from 30 to a little over 35 feet were observed in the outer coastal waters.  The very large waves on top of the storm surge caused destructive coastal flooding along stretches of the Rhode Island exposed south coast.  ||Sandy grew into a hurricane over the southwest Caribbean and then headed north across Jamaica, Cuba, and the Bahamas.  As Sandy headed north of the Bahamas, the storm interacted with a vigorous weather system moving west to east across the United States and began to take on a hybrid structure.  Strong high pressure over southeast Canada helped with the expansion of the strong winds well north of the center of Sandy.  In essence, Sandy retained the structure of a hurricane near its center (until shortly before landfall) while taking on more of an extra-tropical cyclone configuration well away from the center.  Sandy���s track was unusual.  The storm headed northeast and then north across the western Atlantic and then sharply turned to the west to make landfall near Atlantic City, NJ during Monday evening.  Sandy subsequently weakened and moved west across southern Pennsylvania on Tuesday before turning north and heading across western New York state into Quebec during Tuesday night and Wednesday.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: In Coventry, numerous roads were blocked by downed trees.  In Mansfield, a 90 year old woman was killed when a tree fell on her and two of her family members on West Highland Road.  They were walking to a neighbor's house who still had electricity after they lost power.  The other two victims (a male and a female) were seriously injured.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: An amateur radio operator recorded a wind gust of 61 mph on their home weather station in Thompson.  The Automated Surface Observing System at Windham Airport in Willimantic (KIJD) recorded sustained wind speeds of 38 mph and gusts to 53 mph.  A 32 inch diameter tree was downed in Pomfret, blocking a road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An area of low pressure moved across the area producing periods of heavy rainfall.  One round of heavy rainfall coincided with high tide on Long Island Sound.  The tides were astronomically high with a full moon predicted on September 29.  This exacerbated the flash flooding situation in Fairfield and New Haven Counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Vehicles were trapped with water up to the windows at the railroad underpass on East Main St. and up to the roofs further south on Main St. in Stratford.  In Mill Hill, Interstate 95 southbound was closed at exit 30 due to flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An area of low pressure moved across the area producing periods of heavy rainfall.  One round of heavy rainfall coincided with high tide on Long Island Sound.  The tides were astronomically high with a full moon predicted on September 29.  This exacerbated the flash flooding situation in Fairfield and New Haven Counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A car was stranded in flood waters on Interstate 95 in Milford.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Automated Surface Observing System at Bradley International Airport in Windsor Locks, CT (KBDL) recorded sustained wind speeds of 40 mph and gusts to 71 mph.  In South Windsor, a tree was downed along Route 5, blocking Nutmeg Road.  In West Hartford, a tree was downed onto power lines.  In Hartford, trees were downed onto houses on Auburn Street and Bristol Street.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An early season nor'easter storm impacted the region about a week after Hurricane Sandy. Upper level energy from both the northern and southern portions of the jetstream merged over the mid-Atlantic region during the morning of November 7th.  This helped develop a strong area of low pressure at the surface.  This storm slowly moved towards the Jersey Shore on the evening of November 7th to just off Long Island by the morning of the November 8th.  The storm moved towards Cape Cod by late in the day on November 8th.  The precipitation fell nearly entirely in the form of snow across western New England.  The result was a widespread 4 to 8 inches of snow across Litchfield County. In addition, strong and  gusty winds to 35 mph caused for some blowing of the snow, making travel difficult.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trained spotters reported 7.0 inches of snow in New Milford, 6.5 inches in New Hartford and 5.0 inches in Thomaston.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A passing cold front triggered isolated late day severe storms across Southern Connecticut.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Northbound Interstate 95 was closed due to a downed tree near Exit 4.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A passing cold front triggered isolated late day severe storms across Southern Connecticut.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A tree and wires were reported down on Main Street.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An early season nor'easter storm impacted the region about a week after Hurricane Sandy. This storm slowly moved towards the Jersey Shore on the evening of November 7th to just off Long Island by the morning of the November 8th. The result was a widespread 4 to 8 inches of snow across Litchfield County. In addition, strong and  gusty winds to 35 mph caused for some blowing of the snow, making travel difficult.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trained spotters reported 6.0 inches of snow in Bakersville,  5.0 inches in Torrington and 4.8 inches in Norfolk.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong winds developed between a retreating offshore high pressure system and an approaching cold front.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Numerous trees were knocked down in Greenwich due to the strong winds. A skywarn spotter in Greenwich reported a wind gust to 50 mph at 6:15 pm.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A passing cold front triggered isolated late day severe storms across Southern Connecticut.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A tree was reported down and power pole snapped on High Ridge Road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A passing cold front triggered isolated late day severe storms across Southern Connecticut.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Multiple trees were reported down across the town of East Hampton.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Hurricane Sandy moved northward off the eastern seaboard of the United States during the last week of October 2012. Due to a very strong blocking ridge of high pressure situated over the Atlantic Ocean, the storm turned back to the northwest and rapidly strengthened as it moved toward the mid-Atlantic coast. Although the storm began transitioning into a non-tropical nor'easter storm, it remained an extremely powerful cyclone. As the storm made landfall in southern New Jersey during the evening of October 29th, bands of rain moved across western New England. The rainfall was not excessively heavy and did not cause any flooding, thanks to dry antecedent conditions. Rainfall amounts were generally around an inch with the highest amount being reported 1.63 inches in New Milford.||However, strong and gusty winds in association with the storm caused damage to trees and power lines across the region. Although not quite as widespread as areas across southeastern New York and New Jersey, power outages occurred throughout the region. Across the entire state of Connecticut 640,000 people lost power.  Wind gusts of 40 to 70 mph were common from the afternoon of the 29th until the early morning hours of the 30th. The highest wind gust in Litchfield County was 70 mph at a location 5 miles west of Bristol.  Also, gusts to 57 mph occurred just outside Torrington and a gust to 47 mph occurred near New Hartford.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: At 4:23 pm EST, a 70 mph wind gust was measured by a mesonet observation station 5 miles west of Bristol in Terryville at an elevation of 814 feet. In addition, trees and wires were reported down in Preston Hill.  In Northville, the front end of a house was reportedly blown down from high wind.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Showers and thunderstorms associated with a cold front passage produced heavy rainfall that resulted in flash flooding in Fairfield and New Haven Counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: In Ansonia, Wakelee Ave. near Clarkson St. was closed due to flooding.  Beaver St. was also closed due to flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An area of low pressure moved across the area producing periods of heavy rainfall.  One round of heavy rainfall coincided with high tide on Long Island Sound.  The tides were astronomically high with a full moon predicted on September 29.  This exacerbated the flash flooding situation in Fairfield and New Haven Counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The intersection of Fairfield Ave. and Railroad Ave. in Bridgeport was flooded with a car stranded in the water.

Due to a very strong blocking ridge of high pressure situated over the Atlantic Ocean, the storm turned back to the northwest and rapidly strengthened as it moved toward the mid-Atlantic coast. Although the storm began transitioning into a non-tropical nor'easter storm, it remained an extremely powerful cyclone. As the storm made landfall in southern New Jersey during the evening of October 29th, bands of rain moved across western New England. EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trees were reported down in the town of Warren due to high winds.  Numerous trees and wires were also reported down due to high winds along Dairy Hill Road in Salisbury. A wind gust to 57 mph was measured at 3:37 pm EST in Torrington at an elevation of 967 feet. A wind gust to 47 mph was measured at 6:04 pm EST 2 west-southwest of New Hartford at an elevation of 1043 feet.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An approaching cold front produced a few severe storms in the afternoon across Southwest Connecticut.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Tree limbs were reported down on both Nob Hill and Cheshire Roads.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An area of low pressure moved across the area producing periods of heavy rainfall.  One round of heavy rainfall coincided with high tide on Long Island Sound.  The tides were astronomically high with a full moon predicted on September 29.  This exacerbated the flash flooding situation in Fairfield and New Haven Counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: In Saugatuck, Interstate 95 southbound was closed due to flooding before the ramp to Saugatuck Avenue.  In Bridgeport, severe flooding occurred on Iranistan Ave. with water up to car doors. Several streets were also flooded in the vicinity of Seaside Park.  In Stratford, runoff from the heavy rain entered a building.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An area of low pressure moved across the area producing periods of heavy rainfall.  One round of heavy rainfall coincided with high tide on Long Island Sound.  The tides were astronomically high with a full moon predicted on September 29.  This exacerbated the flash flooding situation in Fairfield and New Haven Counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flood waters entered the first floor of the Milford Mall in Milford.  Twenty five homes and businesses, including City Hall, were also flooded.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The West Haven fire department was dispatched to rescue stranded motorists in flood waters on Painter Ave. and also at the intersection of Cambell Ave. and Clark Street.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An approaching cold front produced a few severe storms in the afternoon across Southwest Connecticut.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A wire was reported down across King Lane, which caught fire.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An approaching trough of low pressure at the surface and a passing upper level disturbance triggered an isolated strong thunderstorm, producing a funnel cloud over New London County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A funnel cloud was reported.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A passing cold front triggered a thunderstorm causing a lightning strike in New London County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Ten people were taken to the hospital after lightning struck the restroom they were in, between holes 4 and 13, at Lake of Isles Golf Course in North Stonington.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A passing cold front and upper level shortwave triggered multiple severe thunderstorms across Southern Connecticut. Large hail, up to hen-egg in size, was the main feature with these storms.
A passing cold front and upper level shortwave triggered multiple severe thunderstorms across Southern Connecticut. Large hail, up to hen-egg in size, was the main feature with these storms.
A passing cold front and upper level shortwave triggered multiple severe thunderstorms across Southern Connecticut. Large hail, up to hen-egg in size, was the main feature with these storms.
A passing cold front and upper level shortwave triggered multiple severe thunderstorms across Southern Connecticut. Large hail, up to hen-egg in size, was the main feature with these storms.
A passing cold front and upper level shortwave triggered multiple severe thunderstorms across Southern Connecticut. Large hail, up to hen-egg in size, was the main feature with these storms.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Hail around golf-ball in size damaged cars on Wilbur Cross parkway near Wallingford.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A passing cold front and upper level shortwave triggered multiple severe thunderstorms across Southern Connecticut. Large hail, up to hen-egg in size, was the main feature with these storms.
A passing cold front produced an isolated severe thunderstorm in New Haven County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A tree and large branches were reported down in Naugatuck.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A passing cold front and upper level shortwave triggered multiple severe thunderstorms across Southern Connecticut. Large hail, up to hen-egg in size, was the main feature with these storms.
High pressure remained over the western Atlantic as a cold front approached from the west.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The heat index reached or exceeded 106 degrees at Meriden Markham Municipal airport.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The combination of an upper level shortwave trough and a surface trough produced scattered showers and thunderstorms across the area.  Some thunderstorms produced torrential rainfall which resulted in flash flooding in Fairfield County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flash flooding caused 4 feet of water to accumulate in a garage on Hoyt St. in Northfield.  Water also accumulated in basements on Lincoln Ave. in Glenbrook and on Ledge Ln. in Belltown.  In addition, a resident was stranded in their home from the high water levels on Research Dr. also in Belltown.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A series of upper level disturbances rotated around a vertically stacked low pressure system in the Great Lakes.  These provided a focus for showers and thunderstorms to develop across southern New England.  Southerly winds drew tropical moisture over the area, resulting in very heavy rain in showers and thunderstorms that developed.  In addition, strong winds in the upper levels and 30-40 knots of deep layer shear resulted in wind damage with the strongest of these storms.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trees and wires on Routes 2 and 83 were downed by thunderstorm winds.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A storm system moved from the Great Lakes and into the Northeastern United States.  The storm's warm front was draped across the region.  As skies cleared out in the late morning hours, the atmosphere became increasingly unstable.  Warm and moist air set the stage for the potential for strong to severe thunderstorms.  With lots of wind shear present, there was the potential for damaging wind gusts and even tornadoes as well. ||A strong squall line develop across western New York and western Pennsylvania and moved eastward, producing significant damage along its path.  As the line of storms reached western New England, it clipped portions of Litchfield County, producing widespread wind damage during the evening hours.  The line quickly advanced eastward into central and eastern New England, ending the threat for severe weather.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Widespread damage to trees was reported due to thunderstorm winds in New Milford.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A weak cold front produced showers and thunderstorms, a few of which became severe producing both large hail and gusty winds.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trees were downed by thunderstorm winds.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A very warm and humid air mass was in place across the region.  At the surface, a frontal boundary was draped just south of the area across the northern Mid-Atlantic states.   As a shortwave trough moved across upstate New York, severe thunderstorms broke out across Connecticut during the early to mid afternoon hours.  Some of these thunderstorms contained hail as large as golf-ball size.  Thunderstorms ended by the late afternoon, as a secondary cold front moved across the area, bringing drier and less humid air into the region.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Quarter size (measured) hail was reported during a thunderstorm in Warren.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A combination of a pre-frontal trough and a passing cold front triggered multiple severe thunderstorms across Southern Connecticut.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Numerous trees were reported down along Keeny Road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A complex and powerful low pressure system moved across the region bringing damaging winds and widespread heavy rainfall. A low pressure system originating in the Deep South approached the region from the southwest during the day as a strong cold front approached from the Great Lakes region. These systems merged and moved across the northeastern United States. Moisture was transported into the region on a very strong low level jet. Rainfall totals ranged from just over an inch up to around 3 inches. Despite instability being very limited, the winds field was so strong aloft that showers and low-topped thunderstorms were able to transport strong, damaging winds to the surface, producing damage to trees and power lines.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trees were reported down due to thunderstorm winds in Torrington.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An approaching cold front produced a few severe storms in the afternoon across Southwest Connecticut.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A tree was reported down on power lines on Cognewaugh Road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A passing cold front triggered isolated severe thunderstorms in Fairfield County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Both lanes of the Merritt Parkway  between exits 31 and 33 were blocked by fallen trees.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A very warm and humid air mass was in place across the region.  At the surface, a frontal boundary was draped just south of the area across the northern Mid-Atlantic states.   As a shortwave trough moved across upstate New York, severe thunderstorms broke out across Connecticut during the early to mid afternoon hours.  Some of these thunderstorms contained hail as large as golf-ball size.  Thunderstorms ended by the late afternoon, as a secondary cold front moved across the area, bringing drier and less humid air into the region.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Golf-ball size (measured) hail was reported during a thunderstorm in Oakville.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A passing warm front and upper level short wave triggered scattered showers and thunderstorms in south central Connecticut.  A tropical air mass in place across the region resulted in torrential downpours and flash flooding in New Haven and Middlesex Counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Torrential rain resulted in six inches of flowing water on Rt. 66 in Middletown.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low pressure moved from the Great Lakes across southern New England bringing showers and thunderstorms to the region.  Most of these storms produced heavy rain, but at least one produced damaging winds in Connecticut.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms produced strong winds that downed several trees and snapped tree branches.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A warm and humid air mass was in place across the region on Sunday, June 2nd with temperatures well into the 80s.  A cold front and associated pre-frontal surface trough was moving towards the area during the afternoon hours.  With plenty of moisture and instability in place, showers and thunderstorms developed across the region.  These thunderstorms were aided by very strong winds aloft and a few storms became severe across northwestern Connecticut, producing large hail.  The thunderstorms weakened by evening as the cold front moved across the area, ending the threat for severe weather.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Quarter size hail was reported during a thunderstorm in Barkhampsted Center.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A large ridge of high pressure was situated along the eastern seaboard for the week of July 15th through July 19th. The flow around this high pressure ridge brought a very warm and humid air mass into Connecticut for much of the week, along with plenty of sunshine.||The result was high temperatures each day exceeding 90 degrees. When combined with the humidity, heat index values exceeded 100 degrees at times during the afternoon and evening hours. The hottest days were July 18th-19th, when high temperatures reached the mid to upper 90s in many locations. On the 19th, heat index values were between 105 and 110 degrees across southern portions of Litchfield County, with heat index values of 100 to 105 degrees across northern parts of Litchfield County. ||By the weekend, an approaching cold front brought somewhat cooler and less humid air into the region, which allowed heat index values to be lower.

An upper level disturbance pushed a cold front through southern New England, resulting in showers and thunderstorms. With plenty of instability available, some of the storms became severe, producing damaging winds.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A large tree was uprooted and downed by thunderstorm winds.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level disturbance pushed a cold front through southern New England, resulting in showers and thunderstorms. With plenty of instability available, some of the storms became severe, producing damaging winds.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A utility pole was downed by thunderstorm winds.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level disturbance pushed a cold front through southern New England, resulting in showers and thunderstorms. With plenty of instability available, some of the storms became severe, producing damaging winds.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trees and wires along Route 6 were downed by thunderstorm winds.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level disturbance pushed a cold front through southern New England, resulting in showers and thunderstorms. With plenty of instability available, some of the storms became severe, producing damaging winds.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trees were downed by thunderstorm winds.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front moved across southern New England, igniting showers and thunderstorms in the warm, unstable airmass ahead of the front. With plenty of instability and steep mid level lapse rates, some of these storms became severe, producing large hail and damaging winds.  Anomalous precipitable water values allowed for heavy rain with these storms, which resulted in flash flooding across parts of the region.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A house on Spring Hill Road has eighteen inches of water in the basement with water still rising.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A large ridge of high pressure was situated along the eastern seaboard for the week of July 15th through July 19th. The flow around this high pressure ridge brought a very warm and humid air mass into Connecticut for much of the week, along with plenty of sunshine.||The result was high temperatures each day exceeding 90 degrees. When combined with the humidity, heat index values exceeded 100 degrees at times during the afternoon and evening hours. The hottest days were July 18th-19th, when high temperatures reached the mid to upper 90s in many locations. On the 19th, heat index values were between 105 and 110 degrees across southern portions of Litchfield County, with heat index values of 100 to 105 degrees across northern parts of Litchfield County. ||By the weekend, an approaching cold front brought somewhat cooler and less humid air into the region, which allowed heat index values to be lower.
Low pressure moved out of the midwest, off the mid-Atlantic coast and northeastward across Nantucket and the outer arm of Cape Cod bringing accumulating snow to much of southern New England.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Three to eight inches of snow fell across Hartford County.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low pressure moved out of the midwest, off the mid-Atlantic coast and northeastward across Nantucket and the outer arm of Cape Cod bringing accumulating snow to much of southern New England.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Four to seven inches of snow fell across Tolland County.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front moved across southern New England, igniting showers and thunderstorms in the warm, unstable airmass ahead of the front. With plenty of instability and steep mid level lapse rates, some of these storms became severe, producing large hail and damaging winds.  Anomalous precipitable water values allowed for heavy rain with these storms, which resulted in flash flooding across parts of the region.

An upper level disturbance moved over southern New England, igniting showers and thunderstorms.  With plenty of instability, but little shear, the main threat with these storms was heavy rain.  However, one of the storms did become severe producing damaging winds in Tolland County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A tree and wires on Mountain Spring Road were downed by thunderstorm winds.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level disturbance moved over southern New England, igniting showers and thunderstorms.  With plenty of instability, but little shear, the main threat with these storms was heavy rain.  However, one of the storms did become severe producing damaging winds in Tolland County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A tree and wires were downed by thunderstorm winds at the intersection of Routes 74 and 320 and on Fisher Hill Road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A warm front moved northward across southern New England.  This brought a period of mainly rain and warm temperatures.  In addition, a strong low level jet (up to 80 kts) resulted in high winds across much of southern New England.  There was some tree damage and downed power lines with winds gusting to 60 to 70 mph.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Automated Surface Observing Stations at Hartford Brainard Airport (KHFD) and at Bradley International Airport (KBDL) recorded wind gusts to 54 and 55 mph, respectively.  An amateur radio operator in Berlin recorded a 53 mph wind gust on their home weather station.  In addition, a tree was downed onto a house in Manchester and wires were downed onto a school bus in East Hartford.  In Hartford, a tree was downed onto two cars.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A warm front moved northward across southern New England.  This brought a period of mainly rain and warm temperatures.  In addition, a strong low level jet (up to 80 kts) resulted in high winds across much of southern New England.  There was some tree damage and downed power lines with winds gusting to 60 to 70 mph.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: No wind speed observations were reported from Tolland County, however reports from surrounding counties and damage reports indicate that winds likely reached high wind criteria.  In Columbia, a tree was downed onto wires on Basket Shop Road.  A tree and wires were downed in Stafford.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A warm front moved northward across southern New England.  This brought a period of mainly rain and warm temperatures.  In addition, a strong low level jet (up to 80 kts) resulted in high winds across much of southern New England.  There was some tree damage and downed power lines with winds gusting to 60 to 70 mph.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Automated Surface Observing System at Windham Airport in Willimantic (KIJD) recorded a wind gust to 58 mph.  In addition, mesonet and amateur radio operators reported gusts to 60 mph in Thompson and North Grosvenor Dale.  Several trees were downed onto wires in Woodstock.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A large ridge of high pressure was situated along the eastern seaboard for the week of July 15th through July 19th. The flow around this high pressure ridge brought a very warm and humid air mass into Connecticut for much of the week, along with plenty of sunshine.||The result was high temperatures each day exceeding 90 degrees. When combined with the humidity, heat index values exceeded 100 degrees at times during the afternoon and evening hours. The hottest days were July 18th-19th, when high temperatures reached the mid to upper 90s in many locations. On the 19th, heat index values were between 105 and 110 degrees across southern portions of Litchfield County, with heat index values of 100 to 105 degrees across northern parts of Litchfield County. ||By the weekend, an approaching cold front brought somewhat cooler and less humid air into the region, which allowed heat index values to be lower.

A warm and moist air mass remained in place over the region on June 30th. At the surface, a weak stationary front was draped across the area. During the afternoon hours, a weak upper level disturbance moved across the region. This allowed some showers and thunderstorms to develop in the vicinity of the surface front. With the moist air mass in place, these showers and thunderstorms produced locally heavy rainfall. With the ground already saturated due to several weeks of wet weather, this led to flash flooding in northwestern parts of Litchfield County.  Showers and thunderstorms waned by evening as the disturbance moved east.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rainfall led to flash flooding in Sharon.  The basement of the Sharon Hospital flooded.  A total of six roads were closed throughout the town, as well as one bridge.  A supermarket also was impacted by the flood waters.

On the 19th, heat index values were between 105 and 110 degrees across southern portions of Litchfield County, with heat index values of 100 to 105 degrees across northern parts of Litchfield County. ||By the weekend, an approaching cold front brought somewhat cooler and less humid air into the region, which allowed heat index values to be lower.

A moist and humid air mass was in place across the region on Sunday, September 1st. A surface frontal boundary was situated across southern New York into southern New England during the morning hours.  During the day, the frontal boundary slowly lifted northward.  With enough instability in place due to daytime heating, some showers and thunderstorms developed along this frontal boundary.  The showers and thunderstorms tracked over the same locations during the early afternoon hours across Litchfield County.  As a result of the persistent heavy rain, flash flooding occurred, causing a street to be flooded in the Winsted area.  ||By later in the afternoon, the heaviest showers and thunderstorms were located north of the region, and the threat for flash flooding ended.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: One street in Winsted was flooded due to a blocked catch basin as a result of heavy rainfall.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A large ridge of high pressure was situated along the eastern seaboard for the week of July 15th through July 19th. The flow around this high pressure ridge brought a very warm and humid air mass into Connecticut for much of the week, along with plenty of sunshine.||The result was high temperatures each day exceeding 90 degrees. When combined with the humidity, heat index values exceeded 100 degrees at times during the afternoon and evening hours. The hottest days were July 18th-19th, when high temperatures reached the mid to upper 90s in many locations. On the 19th, heat index values were between 105 and 110 degrees across southern portions of Litchfield County, with heat index values of 100 to 105 degrees across northern parts of Litchfield County. ||By the weekend, an approaching cold front brought somewhat cooler and less humid air into the region, which allowed heat index values to be lower.

On July 20th, 2013, a very warm and humid air mass was in place over Connecticut, allowing for a rather unstable atmosphere.  A cold front, with somewhat cooler and less humid air in its wake, was approaching the region from the Great Lakes.  Ahead of this boundary, isolated to scattered showers and thunderstorms developed during the afternoon hours.  One of these thunderstorms became severe across Litchfield County, producing wind damage.  ||With the passage of the cold front, thunderstorm activity diminished by the late afternoon and the threat for severe weather ended.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Powers lines were reported down and burning as a result of thunderstorm winds in East Canaan.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: During the day on May 29th, a warm front lifted northward across northwestern Connecticut. Although the day began cloudy, some breaks of sun started to occur by early afternoon. At the same time, a potent upper level disturbance over Ontario started to approach the region and a strong jet streak was located just to the north. With a moist southerly flow moving into the region at the surface, it became rather humid as well.||With all these ingredients coming together, thunderstorms developed across upstate New York by mid afternoon and they began to spread eastward.  The thunderstorms eventually organized into a few distinct squall lines.  The lines of storms reached northwestern Connecticut by the evening hours and moved northwest to southeast across Litchfield County.  Many of these storms produced wind damage, mainly to trees and power lines.  In addition, these thunderstorms produced a significant amount of lightning, which in combination with the wind damage, led to some power outages across the area.  One of the lightning strikes also caused a brief fire to a barn in Torringford.||Thunderstorms pushed east of the area by around midnight, ending the threat of severe weather.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Multiple trees, limbs and power lines were reported down in North Canaan as a result of thunderstorm winds.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: On July 20th, 2013, a very warm and humid air mass was in place over Connecticut, allowing for a rather unstable atmosphere.  A cold front, with somewhat cooler and less humid air in its wake, was approaching the region from the Great Lakes.  Ahead of this boundary, isolated to scattered showers and thunderstorms developed during the afternoon hours.  One of these thunderstorms became severe across Litchfield County, producing wind damage.  ||With the passage of the cold front, thunderstorm activity diminished by the late afternoon and the threat for severe weather ended.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A tree was reported down and on wires as a result of thunderstorm winds in North Canaan.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A warm front moved through during the early morning hours on Tuesday, July 23rd, ushering in warm and moist air from the south.  With some breaks in the clouds for the afternoon hours ahead of an approaching cold front, the atmosphere became unstable.  As a result of the unstable atmosphere, scattered showers and thunderstorms developed across Connecticut, with a few of these becoming strong.  One storm grew tall enough in the Torrington area to produce wind damage to trees.  ||The cold front moved through the area during the overnight hours, ending the threat for showers and thunderstorms.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several trees were reported down in Torrington as a result of thunderstorm winds.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: During the day on May 29th, a warm front lifted northward across northwestern Connecticut. Although the day began cloudy, some breaks of sun started to occur by early afternoon. At the same time, a potent upper level disturbance over Ontario started to approach the region and a strong jet streak was located just to the north. With a moist southerly flow moving into the region at the surface, it became rather humid as well.||With all these ingredients coming together, thunderstorms developed across upstate New York by mid afternoon and they began to spread eastward.  The thunderstorms eventually organized into a few distinct squall lines.  The lines of storms reached northwestern Connecticut by the evening hours and moved northwest to southeast across Litchfield County.  Many of these storms produced wind damage, mainly to trees and power lines.  In addition, these thunderstorms produced a significant amount of lightning, which in combination with the wind damage, led to some power outages across the area.  One of the lightning strikes also caused a brief fire to a barn in Torringford.||Thunderstorms pushed east of the area by around midnight, ending the threat of severe weather.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Multiple trees and wires were reported down as a result of thunderstorm winds in Salisbury.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: During the day on May 29th, a warm front lifted northward across northwestern Connecticut. Although the day began cloudy, some breaks of sun started to occur by early afternoon. At the same time, a potent upper level disturbance over Ontario started to approach the region and a strong jet streak was located just to the north. With a moist southerly flow moving into the region at the surface, it became rather humid as well.||With all these ingredients coming together, thunderstorms developed across upstate New York by mid afternoon and they began to spread eastward.  The thunderstorms eventually organized into a few distinct squall lines.  The lines of storms reached northwestern Connecticut by the evening hours and moved northwest to southeast across Litchfield County.  Many of these storms produced wind damage, mainly to trees and power lines.  In addition, these thunderstorms produced a significant amount of lightning, which in combination with the wind damage, led to some power outages across the area.  One of the lightning strikes also caused a brief fire to a barn in Torringford.||Thunderstorms pushed east of the area by around midnight, ending the threat of severe weather.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trees were reported down and blocking Bricklemaier Road in Colebrook as a result of thunderstorm winds.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A warm front moved northward across southern New England Sunday night (Oct 6) into Monday (Oct 7) creating a warm, moist, unstable atmosphere over the region.  Monday afternoon and evening (Oct 7) a strong cold front brought a line of strong to severe showers and storms through southern New England.  Strong, damaging winds occurred both with the storms and in the tight pressure gradient ahead of the front.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A tree on Martin Road was downed by thunderstorm winds, blocking the whole road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A nearly stationary warm front draped across southern New England, coupled with a very moist atmosphere, resulted in showers and thunderstorms across the area for the third day in a row.  Heavy rain fell within these showers and storms and flash flooding occurred, particularly over portions of Rhode Island.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several streets were flooded with four to eight inches of water.  A car was stuck in flood waters on Golden Hill Street.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: During the day on May 29th, a warm front lifted northward across northwestern Connecticut. Although the day began cloudy, some breaks of sun started to occur by early afternoon. At the same time, a potent upper level disturbance over Ontario started to approach the region and a strong jet streak was located just to the north. With a moist southerly flow moving into the region at the surface, it became rather humid as well.||With all these ingredients coming together, thunderstorms developed across upstate New York by mid afternoon and they began to spread eastward.  The thunderstorms eventually organized into a few distinct squall lines.  The lines of storms reached northwestern Connecticut by the evening hours and moved northwest to southeast across Litchfield County.  Many of these storms produced wind damage, mainly to trees and power lines.  In addition, these thunderstorms produced a significant amount of lightning, which in combination with the wind damage, led to some power outages across the area.  One of the lightning strikes also caused a brief fire to a barn in Torringford.||Thunderstorms pushed east of the area by around midnight, ending the threat of severe weather.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Multiple trees and wires were reported down as a result of thunderstorm winds in Norfolk.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level disturbance moved across Pennsylvania and New Jersey during the day on Wednesday, August 28th.  With instability in place due to daytime heating and above normal amounts of moisture present, showers and thunderstorms developed across the mid Atlantic states, eastern New York and southern New England during the afternoon and evening hours.  Winds aloft were very light, which kept these showers and thunderstorms from moving very quickly.  As a slow moving thunderstorm moved across Torrington in Litchfield County, flash flooding occurred.  This caused several roads to be closed due to flooding.  The thunderstorm activity waned later in the evening as the disturbance moved away from the region.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rainfall caused flash flooding on Tioga Street in Torrington.  A home was inundated with water and the fire department was dispatched to respond.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms developed during the evening in warm and humid air behind a warm front over central New England.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trees were downed in Suffield on Hill Street and a few other locations.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An arctic airmass settled in over the region on January 22nd and remained in place for a few days as cold fronts moved across the region ushering in reinforcing surges of cold air. In addition to the cold air, winds remained rather brisk for much of the time resulting in dangerously cold wind chill values. Minimum temperatures dropped into the single digits and below across the Litchfield County each night and during the day temperatures only warmed into the teens and lower 20s.
A passing cold front triggered a line of severe thunderstorms that moved through Southern Connecticut.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A large tree was reported down on a pickup truck on Sherwood Avenue near the James J. Curiale School.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An arctic airmass settled in over the region on January 22nd and remained in place for a few days as cold fronts moved across the region ushering in reinforcing surges of cold air. In addition to the cold air, winds remained rather brisk for much of the time resulting in dangerously cold wind chill values. Minimum temperatures dropped into the single digits and below across the Litchfield County each night and during the day temperatures only warmed into the teens and lower 20s.

An upper level disturbance moved across southern New England igniting showers and thunderstorms.  A cold pool aloft allowed for steep mid level lapse rates as well as temperatures cold enough for large hail.  Storms were isolated but produced damaging winds in northern Connecticut and up to half dollar size hail in southwestern Massachusetts.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A tree and wires along Grant Hill Road in Tolland were downed by thunderstorm winds.  Three inch diameter branches also were downed by thunderstorm winds in nearby Ellington.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Tropical moisture in place across southern New England ahead of a cold front resulted in precipitable water values increasing to 2-2.5 inches (2 to 3 times normal). The cold front provided enough lift for widespread rain with embedded thunderstorms across all of southern New England. The high moisture content of the atmosphere resulted in torrential downpours across much of the region, which led to flash flooding in some areas.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Route 10 and Route 189 in Granby were flooded with cars stuck on both roads.  In Windsor Locks, the Farmington River overflowed its banks near the junction of Interstate 91 and Route 159.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A pre-frontal trough moved into southern New England, providing lift for showers and thunderstorms to develop in a hot and humid atmosphere.  In addition, CAPE up to 2000 J/kg and 30-40 kts of shear provided enough instability and shear for thunderstorms to become severe.  Because of warm air aloft, these thunderstorms mostly produced strong to damaging winds and not large hail.

A pre-frontal trough moved into southern New England, providing lift for showers and thunderstorms to develop in a hot and humid atmosphere.  In addition, CAPE up to 2000 J/kg and 30-40 kts of shear provided enough instability and shear for thunderstorms to become severe.  Because of warm air aloft, these thunderstorms mostly produced strong to damaging winds and not large hail.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trees and wires on Mashamoquet and Hampton Roads were downed by thunderstorm winds.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A pre-frontal trough moved into southern New England, providing lift for showers and thunderstorms to develop in a hot and humid atmosphere.  In addition, CAPE up to 2000 J/kg and 30-40 kts of shear provided enough instability and shear for thunderstorms to become severe.  Because of warm air aloft, these thunderstorms mostly produced strong to damaging winds and not large hail.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trees and wires on Putnam Pike and Lake Road were downed by thunderstorm winds.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An area of low pressure moved across the Ohio Valley towards western New York on Saturday, December 14th. At the same time, another area of low pressure began to develop over the mid-Atlantic coast late in the day and rapidly strengthened overnight as it moved up the eastern seaboard. This storm was located off the coast of New England during the day on Sunday, December 15th. ||As a result, snow slowly spread from southwest to northeast during the morning hours on December 14th. With a cold and dry airmass in place, the snow was initially light in intensity and little accumulation occurred during the day. ||However, as the secondary low began to rapidly develop, a steadier and heavier snowfall moved across the region during the evening hours.  Snow fell at rates in excess of one inch per hour at times.  During the late evening and into the overnight hours, the snow began to mix with and eventually change over to sleet and freezing rain, which ultimately cut down on snow accumulations.  Precipitation tapered off by shortly before sunrise.  Snow accmulation was generally about 6 to 8 inches across Litchfield County.

A light to moderate snowfall occurred during the daytime hours on Tuesday, December 17th. Snowfall began during the morning hours as a weak upper level disturbance passed south of the region. This upper level disturbance caused a surface low to develop off the coast of New Jersey during the afternoon hours, which helped produce some additional snowfall into the afternoon hours. This low headed eastward out to sea through the afternoon. By the time snow ended in the late afternoon or early evening hours, about 2 to 6 inches of snow fell across much of the region. ||Temperatures during the snowfall were very cold, with many areas only in the single digits. This allowed for very slick driving conditions during the busy holiday shopping season. Numerous traffic accidents were reported as a result of the snowfall.
A passing cold front triggered a line of severe thunderstorms that moved through Southern Connecticut.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trees were reported down in town.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A passing cold front triggered a line of severe thunderstorms that moved through Southern Connecticut.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Wires were reported down along Route 68 at Pent Road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A passing cold front triggered a line of severe thunderstorms that moved through Southern Connecticut.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: There were branches and wires reported down in East Hampton.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A passing cold front triggered a line of severe thunderstorms that moved through Southern Connecticut.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: There was a report of branches and wires down in Middle Haddam.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An anomalously strong low level jet coupled with strong pressure falls associated with a low pressure region approaching southern New England resulted in strong to damaging winds across southern New England.  Damage was largely to trees.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Numerous trees were downed across the town of Tolland.  Some of these trees were downed onto wires.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An anomalously strong low pressure region (976mb) moved from Ontario into southern Quebec.  Southern New England was sandwiched in between this and high pressure off the coast to the southeast, creating a very tight pressure gradient over the region.  This resulted in strong gusty winds which caused some damage, especially to areas where the trees were still fully leaved.  In addition, a convective line formed along and just ahead of the cold front, moving through northern Connecticut.  Winds associated with this convective line also resulted in tree damage.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A tree was downed onto wires on Loehr Road by thunderstorm winds.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A light to moderate snowfall occurred during the daytime hours on Tuesday, December 17th. Snowfall began during the morning hours as a weak upper level disturbance passed south of the region. This upper level disturbance caused a surface low to develop off the coast of New Jersey during the afternoon hours, which helped produce some additional snowfall into the afternoon hours. This low headed eastward out to sea through the afternoon. By the time snow ended in the late afternoon or early evening hours, about 2 to 6 inches of snow fell across much of the region. ||Temperatures during the snowfall were very cold, with many areas only in the single digits. This allowed for very slick driving conditions during the busy holiday shopping season. Numerous traffic accidents were reported as a result of the snowfall.

A series of shortwaves moved along a stationary boundary to the west of Southern New England, igniting showers and thunderstorms.  An atmosphere characterized by low CAPE and decent deep layer shear resulted in showers and thunderstorms producing heavy rain and rotating thunderstorms.  One of these storms produced two short-lived tornadoes.  The first was an EF-1 in the Windsor Locks area of Hartford County and the second was an EF-0 in Enfield, CT.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: An EF-0 tornado briefly touched down in Enfield.  This tornado was associated with the same storm that produced the EF-1 tornado in Windsor earlier in the day.  There was scattered tree damage that began on Glen Arden Lane, then crossed Hazard Avenue and continued northeast to Heron Road, ending at Taylor Road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Showers and thunderstorms developed over New York and moved into western Massachusetts. With plenty of diurnal heating resulting in instability, damaging winds occurred with a few of these thunderstorms.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A tree on Ledyard Road and two trees on Albany Avenue were downed by thunderstorm winds.  A telephone pole on Albany Avenue also was downed by the thunderstorm winds.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A pre-frontal trough moved into southern New England, providing lift for showers and thunderstorms to develop in a hot and humid atmosphere.  In addition, CAPE up to 2000 J/kg and 30-40 kts of shear provided enough instability and shear for thunderstorms to become severe.  Because of warm air aloft, these thunderstorms mostly produced strong to damaging winds and not large hail.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Wires on South Street were downed by thunderstorm winds.
