In addition, CAPE up to 2000 J/kg and 30-40 kts of shear provided enough instability and shear for thunderstorms to become severe.  Because of warm air aloft, these thunderstorms mostly produced strong to damaging winds and not large hail.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trees and wires on Mashentuck Road were downed by thunderstorm winds.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An anomalously strong low pressure region (976mb) moved from Ontario into southern Quebec.  Southern New England was sandwiched in between this and high pressure off the coast to the southeast, creating a very tight pressure gradient over the region.  This resulted in strong gusty winds which caused some damage, especially to areas where the trees were still fully leaved.  In addition, a convective line formed along and just ahead of the cold front, moving through northern Connecticut.  Winds associated with this convective line also resulted in tree damage.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A large tree in Canton, a tree and wires on Lovely Street in Avon, and numerous power lines across southern Hartford were all downed by thunderstorm winds.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A warm front lifted northward through Southern New England, igniting showers and thunderstorms across much of the area.  While the main threat with many of these storms was flash flooding with precipitable water values above 2 inches, a few of the storms started rotating with plenty of instability and low level shear in the atmosphere.  An EF-1 tornado developed from one of these storms, resulting in damage across parts of the towns of Andover, Coventry, and Mansfield.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The NWS survey team found a discontinuous damage path approximately eleven miles long and 100 yards wide that extended from Andover to Mansfield, Connecticut.  Most of the damage was to trees.  Trees were both uprooted and in other parts of the path tops were snapped off the trees.  The only structural damage was to a sheet metal barn that was torn apart.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A warm front lifted northward through Southern New England, igniting showers and thunderstorms across much of the area.  While the main threat with many of these storms was flash flooding with precipitable water values above 2 inches, a few of the storms started rotating with plenty of instability and low level shear in the atmosphere.  An EF-1 tornado developed from one of these storms, resulting in damage across parts of the towns of Andover, Coventry, and Mansfield.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Three feet of water flooded Love Lane in Hartford.  A car was stuck in flood waters on Lyme and Palm Streets.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: This storm brought heavy snow and significant coastal flooding to the forecast area. This was an unusual synoptic set-up, with low pressure lingering off the coast of southern New England for several days. Snowfall was difficult to forecast due to concerns about precipitation type and boundary layer temperature. In the end, precipitation type turned out to be all snow for much of the area, with most locations receiving 1 to 2 feet of snow.  In addition, the Massachusetts east coast was hit by widespread moderate and pockets of major coastal flooding for two high tide cycles and beach erosion for at least 5 high tide cycles.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Fifteen to twenty-three inches of snow fell across Tolland County.

In the end, precipitation type turned out to be all snow for much of the area, with most locations receiving 1 to 2 feet of snow.  In addition, the Massachusetts east coast was hit by widespread moderate and pockets of major coastal flooding for two high tide cycles and beach erosion for at least 5 high tide cycles.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Five to eighteen inches of snow fell across Windham County.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A coastal storm moved across the southern New England coastline, spreading a wintry mix of precipitation across much of the area.  While the precipitation started as snow for most locations, snow quickly transitioned to sleet and freezing rain across portions of Connecticut, Rhode Island, and southeastern Massachusetts.  Areas of northern Massachusetts and southwestern New Hampshire remained all snow and received around a foot of snow.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Two to five inches of snow fell across Hartford County.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Three to four inches of snow fell across Windham County.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An approaching pre-frontal trough, ahead of a cold front, triggered isolated severe thunderstorms over Fairfield and New Haven Counties during the afternoon.  These storms also produced heavy rain, which resulted in isolated flash flooding in Fairfield County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A large tree limb was reported down next to a house on Diamond Hill Road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An approaching pre-frontal trough, ahead of a cold front, triggered isolated severe thunderstorms over Fairfield and New Haven Counties during the afternoon.  These storms also produced heavy rain, which resulted in isolated flash flooding in Fairfield County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several trees were reported down on wires along Hamilton Avenue.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An approaching pre-frontal trough, ahead of a cold front, triggered isolated severe thunderstorms over Fairfield and New Haven Counties during the afternoon.  These storms also produced heavy rain, which resulted in isolated flash flooding in Fairfield County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: In Danbury, Main St. was closed near Wooster St. due to flooding.  Rogers Park Rd. was also closed due to flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A backdoor cold front pushing south through New England produced isolated severe thunderstorms in north central Connecticut during the afternoon and evening.
A backdoor cold front pushing south through New England produced isolated severe thunderstorms in north central Connecticut during the afternoon and evening.
A backdoor cold front pushing south through New England produced isolated severe thunderstorms in north central Connecticut during the afternoon and evening.

A warm and humid air mass was in place across the region on Sunday, June 2nd with temperatures well into the 80s.  A cold front and associated pre-frontal surface trough was moving towards the area during the afternoon hours.  With plenty of moisture and instability in place, showers and thunderstorms developed across the region.  These thunderstorms were aided by very strong winds aloft and a few storms became severe across northwestern Connecticut, producing large hail.  The thunderstorms weakened by evening as the cold front moved across the area, ending the threat for severe weather.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Quarter size hail was reported during a thunderstorm in Falls Village.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A line of showers and thunderstorms, with isolated severe thunderstorms embedded, formed along a slow moving cold front pushing through the Tri-State area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Lightning struck a house, causing the house to fill with smoke.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A line of showers and thunderstorms, with isolated severe thunderstorms embedded, formed along a slow moving cold front pushing through the Tri-State area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Lightning struck a tree in the parking lot of the Bridgeport zoo, causing it to splinter up to 200 yards away across the parking lot.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A line of showers and thunderstorms, with isolated severe thunderstorms embedded, formed along a slow moving cold front pushing through the Tri-State area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Lightning struck a house, causing two small fires.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A line of showers and thunderstorms, with isolated severe thunderstorms embedded, formed along a slow moving cold front pushing through the Tri-State area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A tree was reported down across Interstate 95 at Exit 5, resulting in heavy delays.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A line of showers and thunderstorms, with isolated severe thunderstorms embedded, formed along a slow moving cold front pushing through the Tri-State area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Multiple trees and wires were reported down blocking Bonnie Brook Lane.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A line of showers and thunderstorms, with isolated severe thunderstorms embedded, formed along a slow moving cold front pushing through the Tri-State area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A tree was reported down, blocking the intersection of Scofieldtown Road and Old Logging Road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A large upper level low encompassing the Mississippi Valley resulted in a moisture feed up the east coast from the Gulf of Mexico. A stationary boundary just to the west of New York City was the focus for training showers and thunderstorms that resulted in heavy rain and flash flooding in Fairfield County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The intersection of Taconic Rd. and Stanwich Rd. in North Stamford was closed due to flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A large upper level low encompassing the Mississippi Valley resulted in a moisture feed up the east coast from the Gulf of Mexico. A stationary boundary just to the west of New York City was the focus for training showers and thunderstorms that resulted in heavy rain and flash flooding in Fairfield County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The intersection of Danbury Rd. and Farmingville Rd. in Ridgefield was closed due to flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A coastal trough served as the trigger for scattered thunderstorms and embedded severe thunderstorms with increasing moisture and instability ahead of an approaching cold front.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Multiple trees and wires were reported down along River Road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A coastal trough served as the trigger for scattered thunderstorms and embedded severe thunderstorms with increasing moisture and instability ahead of an approaching cold front.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Multiple trees and wires were reported down along Route 81.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A coastal trough served as the trigger for scattered thunderstorms and embedded severe thunderstorms with increasing moisture and instability ahead of an approaching cold front.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Multiple trees and wires were reported down along Route 9 at Exit 5.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Ahead of a storm system, a southerly flow allowed for very warm and humid air to move into the region. Temperatures were quite warm, especially considering that it was mid-September. Under plenty of sunshine, temperatures warmed into the lower to middle 90s throughout northwestern Connecticut, along with dewpoint values in the lower to middle 70s. The allowed for heat index values to reach between 100 and 105 degrees. The heat index values were highest between 2 pm and 5 pm. Heat index values lowered by the evening hours as temperatures cooled.

Heat index values lowered by the evening hours as temperatures cooled.

An upper level shortwave trough moved across the area on July 9 with a nearly stationary front stretched from Connecticut through the Mid-Hudson Valley and into the Great Lakes.  This caused scattered afternoon showers and thunderstorms, which produced heavy rainfall and resulted in isolated flash flooding in New Haven County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Rt. 42, North Brooksvale Rd., near Rt. 10, South Main St. in Cheshire was closed due to flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A coastal trough served as the trigger for scattered thunderstorms and embedded severe thunderstorms with increasing moisture and instability ahead of an approaching cold front.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trees and wires were reported down along Route 9 between Exits 6 and 7.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A coastal trough served as the trigger for scattered thunderstorms and embedded severe thunderstorms with increasing moisture and instability ahead of an approaching cold front.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Multiple trees and wires were reported down along Route 148.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A coastal trough served as the trigger for scattered thunderstorms and embedded severe thunderstorms with increasing moisture and instability ahead of an approaching cold front.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Multiple trees and wires were reported down on Schnoor Road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A coastal trough served as the trigger for scattered thunderstorms and embedded severe thunderstorms with increasing moisture and instability ahead of an approaching cold front.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Multiple trees and wires were reported down along Wig Hill Road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level impulse triggered an area of strong to severe thunderstorms along a stationary front situated just west of the Tri-State area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Multiple trees and power lines down along Sherman Turnpike, resulting in widespread power outages.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level impulse triggered an area of strong to severe thunderstorms along a stationary front situated just west of the Tri-State area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The National Weather Service in New York, NY confirmed an EF0 tornado with maximum winds of 80 mph in the towns of Greenwich and Stamford in Fairfield County Connecticut. The tornado touched down in the town of Greenwich on North Street just north of the Merritt Parkway. It continued east-northeast into the town of Stamford and lifted on Janes Lane approximately a half mile west of Scofieldtown Road.||Extensive tree damage was observed along the tornado path starting on Taconic Road and continuing onto Skyridge Road. The most significant tree damage was observed just south of the intersection of Stag Lane and Stanwich Road, where numerous large trees and power lines were downed. Tree damage continued on Carrington Drive and at the Mead House Farm. It reached its maximum width of 150 yards along River Bank Rd. immediately east of Newman Mills Park. The only structural damage was also reported at this point with the door to a barn being blown off.  |The tornado started to weaken as it moved into the town of Stamford just south of Web Hills Road and Lynam Road. Trees were last noted down at the far western end of Janes Lane.|||No fatalities or injuries were reported.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level impulse triggered an area of strong to severe thunderstorms along a stationary front situated just west of the Tri-State area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Road closure due to many trees and power lines down along Drum Hill Road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A large area of high pressure remained nearly stationary to the south resulting in excessive heat across the area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The combination of high heat and humidity resulted in a heat index of 105 degrees at Meriden Airport late in the afternoon.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A large area of high pressure remained nearly stationary to the south resulting in excessive heat across the area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The combination of high heat and humidity resulted in a heat index of 106 degrees at Bridgeport Airport.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Increasing moisture and instability in the wake of a warm front provided the ingredients for a line of thunderstorms to form along a surface trough extending through the Tri-State area.  Embedded strong thunderstorms developed within this line that impacted Southern Connecticut.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Numerous trees were reported down along Neck Road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A stalled front in the vicinity coupled with a passing upper level disturbance produced an isolated severe thunderstorm in New London County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Wires were reported down on Route 85.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The combination of a trough of low pressure stalled over the region and a passing upper level disturbance triggered an isolated severe thunderstorm in New Haven County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A tree was reported down on wires in Wallingford.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The remnants of Tropical Storm Andrea tracked up the eastern seaboard in early June resulting in a prolonged period of heavy rain, which caused flash flooding in portions of Fairfield and New London Counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: In Groton, South Rd. was closed at the railroad underpass due to flooding.  Total reported rainfall amounts in New London County ranged from 4.12 inches in Yantic to 6.64 inches in Gales Ferry.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The remnants of Tropical Storm Andrea tracked up the eastern seaboard in early June resulting in a prolonged period of heavy rain, which caused flash flooding in portions of Fairfield and New London Counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: In Bridgeport, the intersections of Iranistan Ave. and State St., and Fairfield Ave. and Railroad Ave., as well as Bishop Ave., River St., Savoy St. and Amsterdam Ave. were all closed due to flooding.  Total reported rainfall amounts in Fairfield County ranged from 3.34 inches in Stamford to 4.60 inches at Sikorsky Airport in Bridgeport.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An unusually moist atmosphere, even for early August standards, was in place across Connecticut on Friday, August 9th. A cold front, aided by strong upper level dynamics, was approaching the region from the Great Lakes.||Ahead of this front, a large area of heavy rainfall and embedded thunderstorms moved across the region during the morning and afternoon hours. Areas of heavy rainfall repeatedly moved across the same portions of Litchfield County. This heavy rainfall of more than five inches in spots caused streams and creeks to overflow their banks, resulting in flash flooding. Roads were closed as a result of the flooding and people had to be rescued due to water stranding vehicles. ||By the evening hours, the heavy rain had ended and the water begun to recede. Much less humid air moved into the region by that night as the cold front swept through the area, ending the threat for severe weather and flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flash flooding occurred in the Torringford section of Torrington from heavy rainfall.  Two women had to be rescued from their vehicle on Torringford Street by Fire Department personnel due to being trapped by flood waters.  The Fire Department received 25 calls within a hour requesting assistance and had to pump water out of 10 homes in Torrington.  In addition, roads were temporarily closed, including Albrecht Road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An approaching cold front and passing shortwave triggered severe thunderstorms in Fairfield and New Haven Counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A tree was reported down on wires on Scribner Avenue.  Wires were also reported down in two other places in Norwalk.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An approaching cold front and passing shortwave triggered severe thunderstorms in Fairfield and New Haven Counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A large tree was reported down at Calf Pasture Beach.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An approaching cold front and passing shortwave triggered severe thunderstorms in Fairfield and New Haven Counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Limbs and branches were reported down across town.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An approaching cold front and passing shortwave triggered severe thunderstorms in Fairfield and New Haven Counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A gust of 51 knots was measured at Norwalk Light.

Much less humid air moved into the region by that night as the cold front swept through the area, ending the threat for severe weather and flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flash flooding was reported on Highland Avenue in Torrington due to heavy rainfall.  The road was washed out as a result of the flooding. Flooding also occurred on Riverside Avenue at the intersection with Route 4.   Some manhole covers were blown off the roadways from the force of the flooding.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flash flooding was reported throughout Torrington as a result of heavy rainfall.  Flood waters reached against the side of parked car on Main Street across from the Warner Theatre.  Water was also covering Riverside Avenue, Franklin Drive and Brook Street.||Some homes were also affected by flood waters. It was reported that the Torrington Fire Department helped pump out about 10 homes. A home on Brook Street had heavy flooding, with water nearly reaching up to the top of an above ground pool in the backyard.  There was significant garage flooding at the home as well.

A cold front, aided by strong upper level dynamics, was approaching the region from the Great Lakes.||Ahead of this front, a large area of heavy rainfall and embedded thunderstorms moved across the region during the morning and afternoon hours. Areas of heavy rainfall repeatedly moved across the same portions of Litchfield County. This heavy rainfall of more than five inches in spots caused streams and creeks to overflow their banks, resulting in flash flooding. Much less humid air moved into the region by that night as the cold front swept through the area, ending the threat for severe weather and flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flash flooding was reported on Steele Road in New Hartford due to heavy rainfall.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A warm front lifted northward through Southern New England, igniting showers and thunderstorms across much of the area.  While the main threat with many of these storms was flash flooding with precipitable water values above 2 inches, a few of the storms started rotating with plenty of instability and low level shear in the atmosphere.  An EF-1 tornado developed from one of these storms, resulting in damage across parts of the towns of Andover, Coventry, and Mansfield.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A severe thunderstorm downed several trees and large branches on Mountain Spring Road in Tolland.  While several eyewitnesses reported seeing a funnel cloud, the survey team found no evidence of a tornado touching down.  All of the downed trees were blown down in the same direction indicating straight line winds.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A series of shortwaves moved along a stationary boundary to the west of Southern New England, igniting showers and thunderstorms.  An atmosphere characterized by low CAPE and decent deep layer shear resulted in showers and thunderstorms producing heavy rain and rotating thunderstorms.  One of these storms produced two short-lived tornadoes.  The first was an EF-1 in the Windsor Locks area of Hartford County and the second was an EF-0 in Enfield, CT.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: An EF1 tornado touched down on Hayden Station Road in Windsor and continued moving northeastward through portions of Windsor Locks and across the Connecticut River, ending in the 200 block of Main Street in East Windsor.  ||The roof was blown off a warehouse on Hayden Station Road in Windsor.  Numerous trees were downed near Raymond Road and Alicia Terrace, including some that were downed onto cars and houses.  Shingles were blown off houses on Preston Road and Gaylord Road.  As the tornado traveled northeastward, tobacco tents were ripped off the tobacco fields and some tobacco was flattened.  This can be seen from Interstate 91.  Several eyewitnesses reported debris being lofted into the air and noise that sounded like a freight train as the tornado moved through.  While much of the damage was rated EF-0, there were several small areas of EF-1 damage.  EF-1 damage included a sports bubble collapsing at Sports World in East Windsor and blowing onto Interstate 91, blocking two lanes on the southbound side.  Additionally, reports were received of a semi truck that was blown over on Interstate 91 south at exit 44 in East Windsor.

This heavy rainfall of more than five inches in spots caused streams and creeks to overflow their banks, resulting in flash flooding. Much less humid air moved into the region by that night as the cold front swept through the area, ending the threat for severe weather and flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several streets in Winsted were closed as a result of flash flooding from heavy rainfall.

This heavy rainfall of more than five inches in spots caused streams and creeks to overflow their banks, resulting in flash flooding. Roads were closed as a result of the flooding and people had to be rescued due to water stranding vehicles. ||By the evening hours, the heavy rain had ended and the water begun to recede. Much less humid air moved into the region by that night as the cold front swept through the area, ending the threat for severe weather and flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A vehicle was stranded on Townhill Road in Salisbury as a result of flash flooding from heavy rainfall.  Fire Department personnel were dispatched to rescue a motorist from the vehicle.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An unusually moist atmosphere, even for early August standards, was in place across Connecticut on Friday, August 9th. A cold front, aided by strong upper level dynamics, was approaching the region from the Great Lakes.||Ahead of this front, a large area of heavy rainfall and embedded thunderstorms moved across the region during the morning and afternoon hours. Areas of heavy rainfall repeatedly moved across the same portions of Litchfield County. This heavy rainfall of more than five inches in spots caused streams and creeks to overflow their banks, resulting in flash flooding. Roads were closed as a result of the flooding and people had to be rescued due to water stranding vehicles. ||By the evening hours, the heavy rain had ended and the water begun to recede. Much less humid air moved into the region by that night as the cold front swept through the area, ending the threat for severe weather and flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flash flooding was reported from heavy rainfall in Riverton.  Six to ten inches of water was flowing across Route 20.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong area of low pressure moved from the Great Lakes on the afternoon of Wednesday, January 30th towards the St. Lawrence Valley during the morning of Thursday, January 31st. A strong cold front was associated with this area of low pressure. Ahead of the storm, southerly winds allowed warm and moist air to move into the region. While it took some time for the warmer air to overtake the cold, dense air in place, temperatures warmed into the 40s and 50s during the early morning hours of January 31st.||Just ahead of the cold front, a line of heavy rain showers developed around sunrise. Strong wind gusts up to 60 mph accompanied some of this rainfall as it moved across northwestern Connecticut. This caused damage to some trees and power lines, causing power outages throughout the region. ||With the rainfall falling heavy in intensity and warmer temperatures allowing for some snow melt, some ponding of water on roadways caused some isolated urban and street flooding, but no widespread flooding occurring. ||Behind the cold front, winds switched to a westerly direction and continued to be gusty throughout the day on Thursday, as colder temperatures moved into the region. Additional wind gusts of 35 to 55 mph occurred during the daytime hours on Thursday, January 31st with some additional damage to trees and power lines. Winds diminished by late Thursday afternoon as the pressure gradient began to relax over the area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trees and wires were reported down as a result of high winds in Winchester Center.

A strong cold front was associated with this area of low pressure. Ahead of the storm, southerly winds allowed warm and moist air to move into the region. While it took some time for the warmer air to overtake the cold, dense air in place, temperatures warmed into the 40s and 50s during the early morning hours of January 31st.||Just ahead of the cold front, a line of heavy rain showers developed around sunrise. Strong wind gusts up to 60 mph accompanied some of this rainfall as it moved across northwestern Connecticut. Additional wind gusts of 35 to 55 mph occurred during the daytime hours on Thursday, January 31st with some additional damage to trees and power lines. Winds diminished by late Thursday afternoon as the pressure gradient began to relax over the area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trees and wires were reported down as a result of high winds in Woodbury and New Milford.  Power outages were reported throughout southern Litchfield County.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An intensifying low pressure system taking shape over the lower Mississippi Valley the morning of Saturday the 14th moved to a position south of Long Island by the morning of the 15th, bringing heavy snow and some freezing rain to most of southern Connecticut.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The CT Department of Transportation (DOT), spotters and cooperative observers reported widespread snowfall of 5 to 7 inches.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An intensifying low pressure system taking shape over the lower Mississippi Valley the morning of Saturday the 14th moved to a position south of Long Island by the morning of the 15th, bringing heavy snow and some freezing rain to most of southern Connecticut.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Spotters reported snowfall totals of 7.2 inches in Weston, 6 inches in Danbury, and 5.3 inches in Brookfield.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An intensifying low pressure system taking shape over the lower Mississippi Valley the morning of Saturday the 14th moved to a position south of Long Island by the morning of the 15th, bringing heavy snow and some freezing rain to most of southern Connecticut.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Spotters and the CT DOT reported widespread snowfall of 5 to 7.2 inches.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An intensifying low pressure system taking shape over the lower Mississippi Valley the morning of Saturday the 14th moved to a position south of Long Island by the morning of the 15th, bringing heavy snow and some freezing rain to most of southern Connecticut.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The CT DOT, trained spotters and the public reported widespread snowfall of 5.5 to 7 inches.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An intensifying low pressure system taking shape over the lower Mississippi Valley the morning of Saturday the 14th moved to a position south of Long Island by the morning of the 15th, bringing heavy snow and some freezing rain to most of southern Connecticut.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The CT DOT reported snowfall of 7.3 inches in Haddam.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An intensifying low pressure system taking shape over the lower Mississippi Valley the morning of Saturday the 14th moved to a position south of Long Island by the morning of the 15th, bringing heavy snow and some freezing rain to most of southern Connecticut.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The CT DOT reported snowfall of 6.5 inches in Old Saybrook.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Deep low pressure approached the area, then slowly moved to the east. Strong gusty winds occurred as this low approached.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Strong winds downed a tree in Silvermine. The tree blocked the right lane of the southbound Merritt Parkway, near exit 38.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A complex low pressure system tracking northeast through the Ohio Valley and Northeast United States produced strong onshore winds across the region Tuesday Night into Wednesday morning on February 27th. These onshore winds piled 2 to 3 feet of surge along the southwest CT coast during the Wednesday morning high tide cycle, with widespread minor to locally moderate coastal flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The NOS tidal gauge in New Haven recorded a water level of 9.22 feet MLLW during the morning high tide cycle on February 27th. This is .02 foot above the threshold for moderate coastal flooding established by the National Weather Service.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A complex low pressure system tracking northeast through the Ohio Valley and Northeast United States produced strong onshore winds across the region Tuesday Night into Wednesday morning on February 27th. These onshore winds piled 2 to 3 feet of surge along the southwest CT coast during the Wednesday morning high tide cycle, with widespread minor to locally moderate coastal flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Two to three feet of inundation was experienced in the parking lot of the Birdseye Marina in Stratford, along the Housatonic River on the morning of February 27th. In the same area, a car became stranded on the exit 30 on ramp to I-95, due to 2 to 3 feet of inundation. Additionally, the storm tide reached 10.7 feet MLLW at the Stamford Hurricane Barrier, which is .6 ft over the start of damages for the immediate protect area of the East Branch of the Stamford Harbor.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong storm system moved off the mid-Atlantic coast during the early morning of Thursday, March 7th. Although this storm system was far south of the region, it moved very slowly and help produced a strong easterly flow, which transported moisture off the Atlantic Ocean into the region.||As an upper level shortwave moved from the Great Lakes region towards the Northeast coast, it interacted with the moisture, allowing snowfall to develop over the area. Initially, the snowfall was rather spotty in nature and temperatures just above freezing prevented much accumulation from occurring during the morning and afternoon hours of March 7th. However, a steadier, accumulating snow developed across the entire region by the evening hours as the shortwave moved just south of the region across Pennsylvania and New Jersey and temperatures began to cool.||Steady snowfall, moderate in intensity at times, occurred during the overnight hours and into the morning of Friday, March 8th, as the upper level shortwave became absorbed by the much larger storm off the coast. Snowfall tapered off to snow showers around midday on Friday, March 8th. By that point, storm total snowfall range from 6.5 inches to 10.5 inches across Litchfield County.

Surface low pressure moved off the southern Mid Atlantic coast the morning of March 6th, and continued moving slowly east into the north Atlantic through March 9th while intensifying. The low produced sustained northeast winds of 30 to 39 mph and wind gusts of 40 to 55 mph during the day on March 6th, then produced some light snow the night of the 6th. An upper level low moving southeast from the upper Great Lakes region interacted with the offshore surface low to produce more significant snowfall on March 7th and 8th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Widespread snowfall of over 7 inches fell, with as much as 14 inches in Middletown.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Surface low pressure moved off the southern Mid Atlantic coast the morning of March 6th, and continued moving slowly east into the north Atlantic through March 9th while intensifying. The low produced sustained northeast winds of 30 to 39 mph and wind gusts of 40 to 55 mph during the day on March 6th, then produced some light snow the night of the 6th. An upper level low moving southeast from the upper Great Lakes region interacted with the offshore surface low to produce more significant snowfall on March 7th and 8th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Connecticut Department of Transportation reported 7.3 inches of snowfall in Old Saybrook.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Surface low pressure moved off the southern Mid Atlantic coast the morning of March 6th, and continued moving slowly east into the north Atlantic through March 9th while intensifying. An upper level low moving southeast from the upper Great Lakes region interacted with the offshore surface low to produce more significant snowfall on March 7th and 8th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Spotters and the Connecticut Department of Transportation reported from 6 to 15 inches of snowfall.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low pressure that formed along the northern Gulf coast by the morning of Thursday, February 7, 2013 moved northeast to near Cape Hatteras by the morning of Friday, February 8, 2013 . The low then rapidly intensified while moving northeast to a position east of Cape Cod by the morning of Saturday, February 9, 2013, producing blizzard conditions and very heavy snowfall across southern Connecticut on February 8th and 9th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Spotters reported snowfall ranging from 12 inches in Ridgefield to as much as 30 inches in Monroe. Winds also gusted as high as 40 mph at Danbury Airport.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low pressure that formed along the northern Gulf coast by the morning of Thursday, February 7, 2013 moved northeast to near Cape Hatteras by the morning of Friday, February 8, 2013 . The low then rapidly intensified while moving northeast to a position east of Cape Cod by the morning of Saturday, February 9, 2013, producing blizzard conditions and very heavy snowfall across southern Connecticut on February 8th and 9th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Nearby ASOS stations reported at least 3 hours of consecutive blizzard conditions. Snow began at 8:05 am on February 8. Spotters reported an average snowfall of 6 inches by 6:10 pm. Snowfall totals ranged from 22 inches in Ledyard Center to as much as 31 inches in Colchester.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low pressure that formed along the northern Gulf coast by the morning of Thursday, February 7, 2013 moved northeast to near Cape Hatteras by the morning of Friday, February 8, 2013 . The low then rapidly intensified while moving northeast to a position east of Cape Cod by the morning of Saturday, February 9, 2013, producing blizzard conditions and very heavy snowfall across southern Connecticut on February 8th and 9th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Groton Airport ASOS (KGON) reported at least 3 consecutive hours of blizzard conditions. Snowfall began at 7:40 am on February 8.  Spotters reported an average snowfall of 6 inches by 7:50 pm.  Total snowfall ranged from 15 inches in Stonington to as much as 23.6 inches in Old Lyme. Winds also gusted as high as 60 mph at Groton Airport.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An historic winter storm deposited tremendous amounts of snow over all of southern New England, mainly from the mid-afternoon on Friday, February 8 and lasting into the daylight hours of Saturday, February 9. What made this an amazing storm was the widespread coverage of heavy snowfall.  Most locations received 2 to 2.5 feet of snow!  A stationary band of even heavier snowfall persisted from southwest NH through central MA and on to the southwest across central and western CT. In those areas, reports averaged closer to 2.5 to 3 feet! Isolated thunderstorms were common across the entire region during the height of the storm.||A low pressure system advancing from the Great Lakes region combined forces with a very moist low pressure system moving northeast from the Gulf Coast states. Explosive deepening took place Friday evening, February 8, as a low center moved from the North Carolina coast to south of Nantucket.  Strong high pressure to the north of New England helped ensure that cold air remained in place over the area. Snowfall gained intensity during the afternoon, but during the night, 2 to 3 inch per hour amounts were common throughout the region. The band of heaviest snowfall, with 3 to 5 inches per hour for several hours, extended from southwest NH to central and western CT.  Snow ended in the morning in western and central MA, southwest NH, most of CT and RI, and in the early afternoon across eastern MA.||The Connecticut Department of Agriculture reported that more than 140 agricultural structures were damaged or destroyed throughout the state because of the weight of the snow.  Many of these were hoop houses, but a few greenhouses and barns were destroyed as well.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Twenty to thirty-three inches of snow fell across Hartford County.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Blizzard conditions were observed on the Automated Surface Observing System at Hartford-Brainard Airport (KHFD) for a total of three hours.  The highest wind gust observed at Bradley International Airport (KBDL) was 60 mph.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Weak low pressure moved from the Tennessee Valley on the morning of the 18th to just south of Long Island on the morning of the 19th. Snow began during the evening of the 18th, and changed to freezing rain across interior southern Connecticut during the pre-dawn and early daylight hours of the 19th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A Skywarn spotter in Danbury reported 5.4 inches of snow. The nearby Automated Surface Observing System at Danbury Airport (KDXR) measured 0.11 inches of freezing rain.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low pressure that formed along the northern Gulf coast by the morning of Thursday, February 7, 2013 moved northeast to near Cape Hatteras by the morning of Friday, February 8, 2013 . The low then rapidly intensified while moving northeast to a position east of Cape Cod by the morning of Saturday, February 9, 2013, producing blizzard conditions and very heavy snowfall across southern Connecticut on February 8th and 9th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Oxford ASOS (KOXC) reported at least 3 consecutive hours of blizzard conditions. Snow began at 8:15 am on February 8. Spotters reported an average snowfall of 6 inches by 5:00 pm. Total snowfall ranged from 26 inches in Southbury to as much as 40 inches in Ansonia. Winds also gusted as high as 48 mph in Waterbury.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: During the afternoon of Monday, March 18th, an area of low pressure moved towards the eastern Ohio Valley.  Precipitation well out ahead of the storm's warm front moved from southwest to northeast across the region.  With enough cold air in place, the precipitation fell in the form of snow during the evening hours. By just after midnight on Tuesday, March 19th, the steady precipitation ended or changed to patchy areas of freezing drizzle or sleet.||At the same time, another storm system began to develop along the mid-Atlantic coast.  This low pressure took a track just off the Northeast coast.  The track of this storm allowed some additional moisture off the Atlantic Ocean to be drawn into the region.  During the daylight hours on Tuesday, March 19th, an additional batch of steady snowfall developed across the entire region, as an upper level shortwave moved overhead.  While some additional snow accumulated, the strength of the March sun helped limit the amount of the accumulations, especially on paved surfaces.  Some additional snow showers and squalls lingered into the evening hours, before tapering off for Tuesday night.||At the end of the storm, snowfall amounts ranged from 4 to 6 inches across northwestern Connecticut.

Low pressure that formed along the northern Gulf coast by the morning of Thursday, February 7, 2013 moved northeast to near Cape Hatteras by the morning of Friday, February 8, 2013 . The low then rapidly intensified while moving northeast to a position east of Cape Cod by the morning of Saturday, February 9, 2013, producing blizzard conditions and very heavy snowfall across southern Connecticut on February 8th and 9th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Bridgeport ASOS (KBDR) reported at least 3 consecutive hours of blizzard conditions. Snow began at 7:20 am on February 8. Spotters reported an average snowfall of 6 inches by 5:40 pm. Total snowfall ranged from 19 inches in Stamford to as much as 33 inches in Stratford. Winds also gusted as high as 82 mph near Westport.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: This storm brought heavy snow and significant coastal flooding to the forecast area. This was an unusual synoptic set-up, with low pressure lingering off the coast of southern New England for several days. Snowfall was difficult to forecast due to concerns about precipitation type and boundary layer temperature. In the end, precipitation type turned out to be all snow for much of the area, with most locations receiving 1 to 2 feet of snow.  In addition, the Massachusetts east coast was hit by widespread moderate and pockets of major coastal flooding for two high tide cycles and beach erosion for at least 5 high tide cycles.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Three to almost nineteen inches of snow fell across Hartford County.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A very warm and humid air mass was in place across northwestern Connecticut on Tuesday, May 21st. A slow moving frontal boundary was situated just north of the area across the Saint Lawrence River Valley along the United States-Canadian border. During the day, a wave of low pressure moved along this boundary, allowing the boundary to slowly push southward towards the area. With strong wind shear aloft and plenty of low level moisture in place, thunderstorms developed during the afternoon hours across eastern New York and moved towards western Connecticut by the early evening hours .||Thunderstorms initially formed as single cells and supercells, but eventually organized into several broken lines, which moved from west to east across the area. Many of these storms produced wind damage to trees and power lines. In addition, some thunderstorms produced hail, with hailstones as large as golf ball size.||As the surface wave of low pressure moved away and with the loss of daytime heating, thunderstorms eventually ended during the late evening hours.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trees and wires were reported down due to thunderstorm winds in Lakeville.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A very warm and humid air mass was in place across northwestern Connecticut on Tuesday, May 21st. A slow moving frontal boundary was situated just north of the area across the Saint Lawrence River Valley along the United States-Canadian border. With strong wind shear aloft and plenty of low level moisture in place, thunderstorms developed during the afternoon hours across eastern New York and moved towards western Connecticut by the early evening hours .||Thunderstorms initially formed as single cells and supercells, but eventually organized into several broken lines, which moved from west to east across the area. Many of these storms produced wind damage to trees and power lines. In addition, some thunderstorms produced hail, with hailstones as large as golf ball size.||As the surface wave of low pressure moved away and with the loss of daytime heating, thunderstorms eventually ended during the late evening hours.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The public reported golf ball size hail from a thunderstorm in Lakeville.

With strong wind shear aloft and plenty of low level moisture in place, thunderstorms developed during the afternoon hours across eastern New York and moved towards western Connecticut by the early evening hours .||Thunderstorms initially formed as single cells and supercells, but eventually organized into several broken lines, which moved from west to east across the area. Many of these storms produced wind damage to trees and power lines. In addition, some thunderstorms produced hail, with hailstones as large as golf ball size.||As the surface wave of low pressure moved away and with the loss of daytime heating, thunderstorms eventually ended during the late evening hours.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Amateur radio reported multiple trees down and on power lines due to thunderstorm winds in Salisbury.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A very warm and humid air mass was in place across northwestern Connecticut on Tuesday, May 21st. A slow moving frontal boundary was situated just north of the area across the Saint Lawrence River Valley along the United States-Canadian border. During the day, a wave of low pressure moved along this boundary, allowing the boundary to slowly push southward towards the area. With strong wind shear aloft and plenty of low level moisture in place, thunderstorms developed during the afternoon hours across eastern New York and moved towards western Connecticut by the early evening hours .||Thunderstorms initially formed as single cells and supercells, but eventually organized into several broken lines, which moved from west to east across the area. Many of these storms produced wind damage to trees and power lines. In addition, some thunderstorms produced hail, with hailstones as large as golf ball size.||As the surface wave of low pressure moved away and with the loss of daytime heating, thunderstorms eventually ended during the late evening hours.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A member of the public reported nickel size hail from a thunderstorm in Litchfield.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: High south winds preceding a strong cold front resulted in areas of damage and disruptions to power.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A wind gust to 73 mph was measured at 5:20 am in Madison by a mesonet station. In East Haven, wind gusts of 68 mph were reported at 4:07 am by a skywarn spotter. In New Haven, wind gusts up to 61 mph were measured at New Haven Airport, along with sustained winds of 40 mph around 4:30 am. Scattered power outages were reported throughout the area.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong southerly winds in the morning ahead of a cold front shifted to the west.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Strong winds knocked a tree down onto a car in the town of Orange. This occurred around 715 am. Wind gusts up to 45 mph were reported at Tweed New Haven Airport around that time.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An area of low pressure tracked from the Gulf Coast through New England bringing several inches of rain to the Tri-State Area.  This resulted in isolated flash flooding in Fairfield County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: South Compo Rd. was closed in Westport due to flooding.  Total reported rainfall amounts in Fairfield County ranged from 1.81 inches at Sikorsky Airport in Bridgeport to 3.77 inches in Danbury.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An area of low pressure moved off the mid Atlantic coast Tuesday night, January 15th, and passed just south of Cape Cod Wednesday afternoon the 16th. Snow associated with this low overspread northwestern Connecticut during the early morning hours Wednesday. Some warmer air worked into the area by early in the afternoon resulting in some sleet, freezing rain and freezing drizzle. The bulk of the precipitation occurred in the morning in the form of snow and impacted the commute resulting in some accidents. Total snowfall reports across Litchfield County ranged from 4 to 6 inches.

High south winds preceding a strong cold front resulted in areas of damage and disruptions to power.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A skywarn spotter reported a wind gust to 78 mph at 5:20 am in Westbrook. Another skywarn spotter reported a wind gust up to 65 mph at 5:48 am in Old Saybrook. Scattered power outages were reported throughout the area.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: On the morning hours of Thursday, Februrary 8th, an area of low pressure rapidly developed off the mid-Atlantic coast. The development of this storm was aided by the phasing with another strong upper level disturbance moving towards the coast from the Great Lakes region. As this developing storm moved northeast off the Northeast coast from the late morning of February 8th and into the overnight hours, a large amount of Atlantic moisture was pulled westward, producing a widespread heavy snowfall. ||The snow fell heaviest during the evening and into the overnight hours, with snowfall rates of one to three inches per hour. In addition, strong northeast winds, gusting over 35 mph, allowing for blowing and drifting of snowfall.  Visibility was reduced to less than one-quarter mile, producing blizzard conditions.  Snowfall amounts across Northwestern Connecticut ranged from around one foot in the northwest corner of the Litchfield County to two and a half feet across eastern parts of Litchfield County.  ||The snowfall tapered off during the morning hours, although blowing and drifting continued through the day on Saturday, February 9th.||Travel was significantly affected through the entire state of Connecticut.  All roads were ordered closed for nearly a day.  Statewide, about 38,000 homes and businesses were without power at the storm's peak.

Strong and gusty northwest winds occurred behind a cold front.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: In the town of Orange, a tree was reported down due to strong winds. The tree knocked down power lines which blocked Dogburn Road. This occurred around 12:49 pm.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong and gusty northwest winds occurred behind a cold front.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: At 1:50 pm, traffic lights were knocked down due to the strong winds in the town of Westport. The traffic lights blocked the Sherwood Island Connector. Winds gusted up |to 49 mph at Bridgeport Sikorsky Airport around that time.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: High south winds preceding a strong cold front resulted in areas of damage and disruptions to power.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several trees were reported knocked down in Montville shortly after 5 am. In North Stonington, a tree was knocked down by the high winds and wires were downed as well on Billings Lake Road at 5:32 am. In Franklin, a tree and wires were reported knocked down over Route 187 near Lebanon Road after 6 am. More trees and wires were knocked down in Jewett City at 5:47 am. Trees were downed by the high winds in Franklin on Pleasure Hill Road around 4:52 am.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: High south winds preceding a strong cold front resulted in areas of damage and disruptions to power.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: High winds in Meriden blew off a roof and door of an outdoor shed around 5 am. At around 5:30 am, a tree was knocked down on a house in Ansonia. In Bethany, route 42 was closed from Route 69 to Brooksvalle due to downed trees around 5 am.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: High south winds preceding a strong cold front resulted in areas of damage and disruptions to power.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A wind gust to 61 mph was measured at Bridgeport Airport at 4:15 am. At 4:28 am, sustained winds of 49 mph were measured at Bridgeport Airport. Near Norwalk at 4:15 am, a mesonet measured winds of 64 mph. In Wilton, numerous trees were knocked down at 4:42 am. In Darien, 6 roads were blocked due to downed trees and power lines. This occurred around 4:50 am. A roof was damaged at Ludlow High School in Fairfield at 4:44 am.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: High south winds preceding a strong cold front resulted in areas of damage and disruptions to power.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: At Groton Airport, measured sustained winds of 40 mph were reported at 6 am. The highest gust was 54 mph. At 6:01 am, wires were knocked down in New London on Babcock Road. This was reported by a trained spotter. Scattered power outages were reported throughout the area.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A powerful storm system moved from the Great Lakes region towards southern Canada on the early morning of Friday, November 1st. As the storm's cold front moved across the region during the morning hours, a line of convective heavy rain showers and embedded thunderstorms and gusty winds accompained the boundary. Although the extent of thunder was rather limited, the line produced damaging winds to trees and power lines across portions of Litchfield County. The threat for severe thunderstorms ended by the late morning as the front pushed east of the area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Multiple trees were reported down in Colebrook due to thunderstorm winds.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An area of low pressure moved across the Ohio Valley towards western New York on Saturday, December 14th. At the same time, another area of low pressure began to develop over the mid-Atlantic coast late in the day and rapidly strengthened overnight as it moved up the eastern seaboard. This storm was located off the coast of New England during the day on Sunday, December 15th. ||As a result, snow slowly spread from southwest to northeast during the morning hours on December 14th. With a cold and dry airmass in place, the snow was initially light in intensity and little accumulation occurred during the day. ||However, as the secondary low began to rapidly develop, a steadier and heavier snowfall moved across the region during the evening hours.  Snow fell at rates in excess of one inch per hour at times.  During the late evening and into the overnight hours, the snow began to mix with and eventually change over to sleet and freezing rain, which ultimately cut down on snow accumulations.  Precipitation tapered off by shortly before sunrise.  Snow accmulation was generally about 6 to 8 inches across Litchfield County.

A warm front moved northward across southern New England Sunday night (Oct 6) into Monday (Oct 7) creating a warm, moist, unstable atmosphere over the region.  Monday afternoon and evening (Oct 7) a strong cold front brought a line of strong to severe showers and storms through southern New England.  Strong, damaging winds occurred both with the storms and in the tight pressure gradient ahead of the front.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Automated Surface Observing System at Bradley International Airport in Windsor Locks, CT (KBDL) recorded a sustained wind speed of 32 mph.  In Hartford, a tree was downed onto wires on Clark Street.  Power lines were downed on West Mountain Road in Simsbury.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Several upper level shortwave troughs interacting with a warm, moist airmass and a surface trough produced scattered thunderstorms across the area.  Precipitable waters ranged between 2 and 2 1/2 inches, which resulted in heavy rain and flash flooding in Fairfield and New London Counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: There was six to eight inches of flowing water on portions of Rt. 12 from the U.S. Naval Submarine Base south to Groton.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Several upper level shortwave troughs interacting with a warm, moist airmass and a surface trough produced scattered thunderstorms across the area.  Precipitable waters ranged between 2 and 2 1/2 inches, which resulted in heavy rain and flash flooding in Fairfield and New London Counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: South Rd. at the railroad underpass in Groton was closed due to flooding.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Two feet of water accumulated in the parking lot of the Redding Metro-North train station.

Precipitable waters ranged between 2 and 2 1/2 inches, which resulted in heavy rain and flash flooding in Fairfield and New London Counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A portion of Long Ridge Road was closed due to flooding near West Redding.  Additionally, several basements flooded near Long Ridge Rd. and Sidecut Rd. in West Redding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front triggered scattered showers and thunderstorms, with embedded severe thunderstorms, over southeast Connecticut.

A line of showers and thunderstorms, with embedded severe thunderstorms, formed along a cold front as it pushed through the Northeast.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Numerous trees reported down around the town.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A weak short wave trough moved through the upper flow and triggered slow moving heavy showers and thunderstorms that resulted in flash flooding in the town of Ridgefield.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Basement flooding was reported in Ridgefield.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A combination of passing upper level energy and a nearby stationary front yielded severe thunderstorms across Fairfield, New Haven, and Middlesex Counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trees were reported down throughout the town.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A combination of passing upper level energy and a nearby stationary front yielded severe thunderstorms across Fairfield, New Haven, and Middlesex Counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A few trees were reported down on I-691 in Meriden.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A combination of passing upper level energy and a nearby stationary front yielded severe thunderstorms across Fairfield, New Haven, and Middlesex Counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A tree was reported down along Old Branchville Road in Ridgefield.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The combination of a moist airmass and a wave of low pressure tracking north along a cold front just to the east of Long Island resulted in scattered showers and thunderstorms across Southeast Connecticut.  The redevelopment of these showers and storms over the same area led to a period of persistent heavy rain over New London County, which resulted in flash flooding.  The township of Norwich was hit the hardest with WSR-88D Dual-Pol Storm Total Accumulation estimates of 5 to 8 inches, verified by observations received on the ground.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Golden Rd. near Rt. 32 in Norwich was closed due to flooding.

The redevelopment of these showers and storms over the same area led to a period of persistent heavy rain over New London County, which resulted in flash flooding.  The township of Norwich was hit the hardest with WSR-88D Dual-Pol Storm Total Accumulation estimates of 5 to 8 inches, verified by observations received on the ground.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: West Town St. at I-395 in Norwichtown was impassable due to flooding.  In addition, a vehicle was stranded in flood waters at the intersection of While Plains Rd. and Hansen Rd. also in Norwich.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: An office complex at 12 Case St. in Norwich was evacuated due to flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The combination of a moist airmass and a wave of low pressure tracking north along a cold front just to the east of Long Island resulted in scattered showers and thunderstorms across Southeast Connecticut.  The redevelopment of these showers and storms over the same area led to a period of persistent heavy rain over New London County, which resulted in flash flooding.  The township of Norwich was hit the hardest with WSR-88D Dual-Pol Storm Total Accumulation estimates of 5 to 8 inches, verified by observations received on the ground.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: In Norwich, the Yantic River exceeded bankfull at the intersection of Sturtevant St. and Pleasant St., downstream of the river gauge, resulting in flooding. The public reported a storm total rainfall of 7.88 inches.  Mesonets from the neighboring towns of Yantic, Oakdale and Montville reported total rainfall amounts of 5.25 inches, 3.17 inches and 1.96 inches respectively. Additionally, between 1200 and 1215 EST, the mesonet in Yantic reported 1.15 inches of rainfall in 15 minutes.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The combination of a moist airmass and a wave of low pressure tracking north along a cold front just to the east of Long Island resulted in scattered showers and thunderstorms across Southeast Connecticut.  The redevelopment of these showers and storms over the same area led to a period of persistent heavy rain over New London County, which resulted in flash flooding.  The township of Norwich was hit the hardest with WSR-88D Dual-Pol Storm Total Accumulation estimates of 5 to 8 inches, verified by observations received on the ground.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Sholes Ave., Pleasant St., and West Town St. in Norwich were closed due to flooding.  Residents in the area also experienced basement flooding.  Several motor vehicles were stranded in flood waters as well and occupants were rescued by the local fire department.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The combination of a moist airmass and a wave of low pressure tracking north along a cold front just to the east of Long Island resulted in scattered showers and thunderstorms across Southeast Connecticut.  The redevelopment of these showers and storms over the same area led to a period of persistent heavy rain over New London County, which resulted in flash flooding.  The township of Norwich was hit the hardest with WSR-88D Dual-Pol Storm Total Accumulation estimates of 5 to 8 inches, verified by observations received on the ground.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The exit ramp of I-395 at exit 82, West Town St. was closed due to flooding in Norwich.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A line of showers and thunderstorms, with isolated severe thunderstorms embedded, formed along a slow moving cold front pushing through the Tri-State area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A wire was reported down and blocking the intersection of Evergreen Ave. and Compo Rd. North.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level disturbance moved across Pennsylvania and New Jersey during the day on Wednesday, August 28th.  With instability in place due to daytime heating and above normal amounts of moisture present, showers and thunderstorms developed across the mid Atlantic states, eastern New York and southern New England during the afternoon and evening hours.  Winds aloft were very light, which kept these showers and thunderstorms from moving very quickly.  As a slow moving thunderstorm moved across Torrington in Litchfield County, flash flooding occurred.  This caused several roads to be closed due to flooding.  The thunderstorm activity waned later in the evening as the disturbance moved away from the region.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several houses were inundated with water on Prospect Street in Torrington due to flash flooding from heavy rainfall.  Flash flooding also occurred on Franklin Drive as well.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A backdoor cold front pushing south through New England produced isolated severe thunderstorms in north central Connecticut during the afternoon and evening.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Quarter sized hail was reported near Buckland Mall and lasted for just over 10 minutes.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A slow moving cold front was moving towards northwestern Connecticut during the afternoon of June 18th, 2013. With temperatures well into the 80s and high levels of moisture in place, there was plenty of instability available for thunderstorms to develop. A broken line of showers and thunderstorms moved across Litchfield County during the afternoon and strong winds aloft aided in allowing one of these storms to become severe with large hail. By later in the afternoon, the thunderstorms tracked south and east and away from the region, ending the threat for severe weather.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Penny to quarter size hail was reported during a thunderstorm in Washington.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A warm southerly flow allowed for temperatures to reach well into the 80s to near 90 on Wednesday, July 2nd. In addition, it was rather humid with dewpoints nearing 70 degrees. With the warm and humid conditions in place, the atmosphere became quite unstable during the afternoon and evening hours. ||Well ahead of a cold front, a surface trough was in place across upstate New York and western New England. This caused thunderstorms to develop during the afternoon hours. A few of these storms became severe, producing wind damage to trees and homes.||These storms ended by the late evening hours, as nocturnal influences helped wane the development of additional thunderstorms.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A large eight inch diameter tree limb fell on a barn as a result of thunderstorm winds in Falls Village.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Although the day began with clouds, breaks in the clouds during the afternoon hours allowed the atmosphere to become unstable over northwestern Connecticut. As a surface trough and upper level shortwave approached from the Great Lakes, thunderstorms broke out over eastern New York. Although the thunderstorms weren't overly tall, strong winds aloft allowed the storms to rotate and produce damaging wind gusts, mainly to trees, across Ulster and Dutchess Counties during the evening hours. As these thunderstorms moved into northwestern Connecticut, one of the storms produced wind damage across Litchfield County.  With the loss of daytime heating, thunderstorms weakened and ended by the late-evening hours, ending the threat for severe weather.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A tree was reported down due to thunderstorm winds in East Canaan.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A hot and humid air mass was in place on Wednesday, July 23rd, allowing the atmosphere to become quite unstable. As a cold front approached from the west, clusters of thunderstorms developed during the afternoon hours over eastern New York, producing damaging winds and large hail. These thunderstorms moved into western New England during the evening hours.  One of these thunderstorms continued to be severe, producing wind damage in northwestern Connecticut.  Thunderstorms continued to move east and weakened further by the late evening hours, as the cold front crossed the region.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Wires were reported down on Dibble Hill Road in Cornwall due to thunderstorm winds.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A hot and humid air mass was in place on Wednesday, July 23rd, allowing the atmosphere to become quite unstable. As a cold front approached from the west, clusters of thunderstorms developed during the afternoon hours over eastern New York, producing damaging winds and large hail. These thunderstorms moved into western New England during the evening hours.  One of these thunderstorms continued to be severe, producing wind damage in northwestern Connecticut.  Thunderstorms continued to move east and weakened further by the late evening hours, as the cold front crossed the region.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Nickel size hail was reported during a thunderstorm in Goshen.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong upper level disturbance combined with very cold air aloft to produce showers and thunderstorms across much of Southern New England. Many of these storms produced large hail.
As a cold front moved east toward a warm moist unstable air mass, it produced severe thunderstorms that caused damaging winds and flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: High winds downed numerous trees in Fairfield.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front was moving across the region on Saturday, September 6th. Ahead of this front, an unseasonably hot and humid air mass was in place across northwestern Connecticut during the afternoon hours. This allowed for the atmosphere to be quite unstable. As a result, one thunderstorms developed during the afternoon hours, quickly moving from west to east across the region. This storm produced wind damage across several towns in Litchfield County. ||The threat for storms ended in the evening hours with the passage of the cold front, as cooler, less humid and more stable air moved into the region.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trees were downed on Newton Road in Campville as a result of thunderstorm winds.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: In the midst of a long duration snow event, northerly winds transported very cold air into the region from Canada early in the morning hours on Friday, January 3rd.  With winds picking up due to a strengthening area of low pressure off the eastern seaboard, wind chill values became dangerously low. Wind chill values dropped below -15 degrees by Friday morning over much of the region. ||Wind chill values remained very low, even behind the storm through the day on Friday. With very cold temperatures continuing on Friday night, wind chill values continued to be -15 to -30 degrees in many locations. Winds finally became calm by early Saturday morning on January 4th, although the frigid temperatures continued to make for dangerous conditions.

Hot and humid air over southern New England was enough to produce diurnal thunderstorms. A few of these became severe producing both large hail and damaging winds.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A tree and wires were downed by thunderstorm winds on Route 83 near Strawberry Road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front was moving across the region on Saturday, September 6th. Ahead of this front, an unseasonably hot and humid air mass was in place across northwestern Connecticut during the afternoon hours. This allowed for the atmosphere to be quite unstable. As a result, one thunderstorms developed during the afternoon hours, quickly moving from west to east across the region. This storm produced wind damage across several towns in Litchfield County. ||The threat for storms ended in the evening hours with the passage of the cold front, as cooler, less humid and more stable air moved into the region.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trees and wires were reported down in Litchfield as a result of thunderstorm winds.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low pressure developed during the late evening hours on November 25th across northern Florida, and quickly raced along the Eastern seaboard on the 26th, bringing heavy snow along and north of the Interstate 84 corridor of interior Southwest Connecticut, and disrupting travel plans the day before Thanksgiving Day.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snowfall of 4 inches occurred in Wolcott, near the heavily traveled Interstate 84 corridor, per trained spotter report.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low pressure developed during the late evening hours on November 25th across northern Florida, and quickly raced along the Eastern seaboard on the 26th, bringing heavy snow along and north of the Interstate 84 corridor of interior Southwest Connecticut, and disrupting travel plans the day before Thanksgiving Day.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snowfall of 3 to 6 inches occurred across the area, including the heavily traveled Interstate 84 corridor, per broadcast media, trained spotter, and public reports.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system moving into the Ohio Valley on January 2 redeveloped and intensified along the Mid Atlantic coast, bringing heavy snow to Southern Connecticut before moving out to sea on the third of January.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The public and trained spotters reported snowfall of 5 to 10 inches.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system moving into the Ohio Valley on January 2 redeveloped and intensified along the Mid Atlantic coast, bringing heavy snow to Southern Connecticut before moving out to sea on the third of January.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Connecticut DOT and trained spotters reported snowfall of 7 to 10 inches.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An exceptional winter storm impacted all of northwestern Connecticut between Thursday, February 13th and the morning of Friday, February 14th.||A strong area of low pressure across the Deep South moved towards the mid-Atlantic coast on February 13th. This area of low pressure was responsible for a significant snow and ice event across the Gulf Coast and Southeast states. Well ahead of the storm system, a heavy band of snowfall moved from south to north across the region. The snow began in the morning hours and continued through the early afternoon hours. Snow fell at rates of up to three inches per hour, causing significant travel issues across the region.||Much of the region experienced a break in the steady snowfall between the mid-afternoon and early evening hours as the initial band of precipitation shifted north and east of the region and only periods of lighter snowfall occurred. However, the strengthening coastal storm allowed a second round of steady, heavy precipitation in the form of a wintry mix of snow, sleet and freezing rain to begin in the late evening hours. This precipitation moved from south to north across the region for the overnight hours.  In addition, lightning and thunder accompanied the precipitation as well.||The precipitation tapered off from west to east around sunrise on February 14th, as the storm moved northeast towards eastern New England and Atlantic Canada. By the time snow ended, 10 to 15 inches of snow was reported in Litchfield County. Very strong winds, gusting as high as 40 mph, occurred as the storm pulled away. This led to significant blowing and drifting of the snowfall through the entire day on February 14th.

A coastal storm passed just south and east of the area causing strong winds and heavy rain with isolated flooding in portions of Southern Connecticut.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: At Bridgeport Sikorsky Airport, a sustained wind of 32 mph was measured at 1:31 pm, and a gust of 47 mph was measured at 1:36 pm.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A coastal storm passed just south and east of the area causing strong winds and heavy rain with isolated flooding in portions of Southern Connecticut.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: At New Haven Airport, a sustained wind of 36 mph was measured at 3:11 pm, and a gust of 49 mph was measured at 3:00 pm.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A coastal storm passed just south and east of the area causing strong winds and heavy rain with isolated flooding in portions of Southern Connecticut.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: At Groton New London Airport, a sustained wind of 33 mph was measured at 11:28 am, and a gust of 42 mph was measured at 12:04 pm.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A coastal storm passed just south and east of the area causing strong winds and heavy rain with isolated flooding in portions of Southern Connecticut.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The intersection of Plumtress Rd. and Maple Ave. in Bethel was closed due to flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong coastal storm brought wintry precipitation, heavy rain, and strong winds to much of southern New England. A mix of precipitation brought freezing drizzle, snow, and sleet to northwestern portions of the area while heavy rain was widespread across southeastern Massachusetts and Rhode Island, as well as portions of northern Connecticut.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: An eighth of an inch of ice accumulated on exposed surfaces in Southington.  Several exits off Interstate 84 were closed because of the ice.  Numerous car accidents were reported.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An arctic air mass settled over the region during much of the week between Tuesday, January 21st and Thursday, January 23rd. Very cold air in place allowed for daytime high temperatures only in the single digits and teens and readings frequently below zero at night. With a persistent west to northwest breeze, wind chill values dropped to dangerously cold levels in the night time and morning hours. Wind chill values were -10 to -25 degrees over many areas, with wind chill readings as low as -30 degrees over the high terrain of the Litchfield Hills. The most widespread lowest values occurred on the early morning of Wednesday, January 22nd. This long duration period of frigid arctic air resulted in shelters being opened across the region for  the homeless. Temperatures finally moderated and wind became light by the end of the week, ending the dangerously low wind chill values.

This long duration period of frigid arctic air resulted in shelters being opened across the region for  the homeless. Temperatures finally moderated and wind became light by the end of the week, ending the dangerously low wind chill values.

A long lasting snowstorm occurring across all of northwestern Connecticut between the evening of New Years Day and the morning of January 3rd, 2014. ||A slow moving frontal boundary situated over the mid-Atlantic Region was in place on Wednesday, January 1st. An area of high pressure situated over southern Quebec allowed Arctic air to move down into the region. As a weak wave of low pressure developed along the front, moisture moved up and over the frontal boundary into the region. As a result, light snow broke out and gradually spread from southwest to northeast on the evening of Wednesday, January 1st and continued into the early morning hours of Thursday, January 2nd.  During the daytime on January 2nd, there was a break in the steady snowfall, with occasional light snow showers and flurries and it remained quite cold, with temperatures only in the single digits and teens over much of the region. ||On the evening of Thursday, January 2nd, a new area of low pressure began to form of the mid-Atlantic coast. This brought some moisture from the Atlantic Ocean into the region, and a moderate snowfall developed over the entire area. The snow gradually tapered off to light snow and snow showers from west to east overnight as the low pressure area tracked east northeast away from the region. By the morning hours of Friday, January 3rd, a general 4 to 8 inches of snow had fallen in total.  In addition, temperatures remained very cold and with a cold northwest wind, wind chill values were below zero.

An approaching upper level trough allowed an area of low pressure to develop along the New Jersey shore on the morning of Saturday, January 18th.  As this low pressure area rapidly developed, a fast moving area of snowfall moved northeast across western Connecticut, beginning in the late morning hours.  Within this snowfall were localized areas of moderate to heavy snow.  Snow fell at rates in excess of one inch per hour in spots.  Snow tapered off by the late afternoon as the area of snow moved northeast into central and eastern New England, and amounts varied significantly across Litchfield County. Although most areas only saw a few inches, a small area in the higher elevations of northern Litchfield County received 6 to 10 inches of snowfall.  As a result of this snow, local newspaper media reported numerous traffic accidents and motorists stuck on snowy roads.

During the daytime on January 2nd, there was a break in the steady snowfall, with occasional light snow showers and flurries and it remained quite cold, with temperatures only in the single digits and teens over much of the region. ||On the evening of Thursday, January 2nd, a new area of low pressure began to form of the mid-Atlantic coast. This brought some moisture from the Atlantic Ocean into the region, and a moderate snowfall developed over the entire area. The snow gradually tapered off to light snow and snow showers from west to east overnight as the low pressure area tracked east northeast away from the region.
