In addition, temperatures remained very cold and with a cold northwest wind, wind chill values were below zero.
A strong low pressure system passed south then east of Long Island.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A wind gust of 49 mph was measured at Danbury Airport at 7:58 am.  Sustained winds of 32 mph were measured at 10:12 am at the airport.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong low pressure system passed south then east of Long Island.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Two large tree limbs were knocked down across a driveway in Stamford at 8:10 am. |This was reported by a trained spotter.  Nearby, a wind gust of 48 mph was measured at Bridgeport Sikorsky Airport at 12:03 pm.  At 11:55 am, sustained winds of 35 mph were measured at the airport.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong low pressure system passed south then east of Long Island.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A wind gust of 52 mph was measured at Groton New London Airport at 11:10 am.  At 11:03 am, sustained winds of 33 mph were measured at the airport.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong low pressure system passed south then east of Long Island.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A large tree limb was knocked down in North Haven at 2 pm. This was reported by the public.  Nearby, a wind gust of 44 mph was measured at New Haven Airport at 12:46 pm.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong coastal storm moved up the east coast and over Nantucket bringing a heavy wet snow to much of the area.  This resulted in tree damage and scattered power outages across the region.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Three to ten inches of snow fell across Hartford County.  The heavy wet snow brought down wires in Simsbury.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Behind a strong cold front, bitter Arctic air moved into the region beginning in the early morning hours on Tuesday, January 7th. With strong westerly winds in place, this allowed for winds chill values to be as low as -10 to -20 degrees. Strong winds throughout the day on Tuesday, January 7th allowed the dangerously cold wind chill values to continue. Winds started to diminish on Tuesday night, but with continued very cold temperatures of below zero in many areas, the low wind chill values of less than -15 degrees continued. Although temperatures remaining frigid, high pressure over the region allowed for winds to be light on Wednesday, January 8th, ending the dangerously cold wind chill values.

A slow moving coastal storm impacted all of northwestern Connecticut with a variety of winter weather for Tuesday, December 9th through early in the day on Thursday, December 11th. ||An area of low pressure developed off the Mid-Atlantic coast on Tuesday, December 9th. With cold air in place at the surface, the precipitation initially began as freezing rain and freezing drizzle during the early morning hours. Some sleet also mixed in, especially over the higher elevations. ||As surface temperatures slowly warmed above freezing, the precipitation changed to a plain cold rain by the late morning hours.  This rain fell heavily at times for the afternoon and evening. Precipitation mixed with sleet at times, especially for the higher elevations, but the bulk of the precipitation remained as a cold rain. ||On Tuesday night, precipitation continued mainly in the form of light rain. However, with colder air working into the area aloft, precipitation began to change to mainly snow for during the day on Wednesday, especially for the afternoon and evening hours.||Precipitation began to taper off to just snow showers for Wednesday night and ended by Thursday morning. By the end of the storm, snowfall amounts varied between one and four inches across Litchfield County.

Low pressure moving off the mid-Atlantic coast intensified as it moved northeastward over Nantucket.  This spread heavy snow across all of southern New England.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Six to ten inches of snow fell across Windham County.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low pressure moving off the mid-Atlantic coast intensified as it moved northeastward over Nantucket.  This spread heavy snow across all of southern New England.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Eight to twelve inches of snow fell across Hartford County.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A widespread snowfall occurred across all of northwestern Connecticut on Wednesday, February 5th. An area of low pressure moved across the Ohio Valley, bringing a period of moderate to heavy snowfall out well ahead of the storm during the early morning hours. Snow fell at rates in excess of one to two inches per hour, allowing for a messy commute during the morning hours.  The snow changed to sleet and freezing rain, which continued through the morning hours at mainly light rates.||The low pressure area began to reform off the mid-Atlantic coast during the day and moved northeast towards the New England Coast by the evening hours. Some additional mixed precipitation fell into the afternoon hours, before precipitation tapered off completely by the early evening hours. ||By the time the storm finished, the entire region received a widespread 6 to 12 inches of snow.  The heaviest amounts occurred across the northern portion of the county.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Seven to eleven inches of snow fell across Tolland County.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level disturbance moved through Southern New England, igniting showers and thunderstorms across the area. Many of these storms produced small to large size hail thanks to very cold temperatures aloft.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Penney to nickel size hail fell for 15 minutes.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low pressure tracked along an arctic front bringing heavy snow and strong winds to much of southern New England.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Four to twelve inches of snow fell across Windham County.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A significant, rapidly developing coastal storm moved southeast of Southern New England bringing heavy snow, bitter cold temperatures, and strong winds to all of the region.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Four to eight inches of snow fell across Hartford County.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level disturbance moved through Southern New England, igniting showers and thunderstorms across the area. Many of these storms produced small to large size hail thanks to very cold temperatures aloft.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Dime size hail fell from 2:46pm to 2:49pm, then nickel to quarter size hail fell.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An isolated thunderstorm moved southeast across Litchfield County Connecticut during the late afternoon and early evening hours on Tuesday, May 27th.  The thunderstorm strengthened as it reached the southern portion of the county and produced a period of gusty winds, heavy rainfall and frequent cloud to ground lightning. The storm produced wind damage to trees and homes in the town of New Milford.  Several roads were closed a result of downed trees and power lines.  In addition, schools in New Milford were closed on Wednesday, May 28th due to the ongoing cleanup from the storm damage.||A National Weather Service Storm Survey determined that straight line winds produced winds up to 100 MPH with damage sporadic  and intermittent along a 7 mile swath.  Unfortunately, one person in New Milford died due to electrocution as a result of downed wires falling on a vehicle. Up to 13,000 people throughout the area lost power as a result of the thunderstorms.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A National Weather Service storm survey determined straight line winds produced sporadic and intermittent damage along a  7 mile swath across southern Litchfield County. Winds were estimated up to 100 MPH.  The estimated path width was one mile.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: High shear and decent moisture and instability in advance of a cold front allowed showers and thunderstorms to develop. Some of these storms became severe producing damaging winds.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trees and wires were downed by thunderstorm winds.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: High shear and decent moisture and instability in advance of a cold front allowed showers and thunderstorms to develop. Some of these storms became severe producing damaging winds.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A tree on Route 75 in Suffield was downed by thunderstorm winds.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level disturbance moving out of the Great Lakes initiated showers and thunderstorms over New York and New England. Enough instability was present in the region for some of these storms to become severe, producing strong to damaging winds and at least one funnel cloud.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trees and wires on Jonathan Lane were downed by thunderstorm winds.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level low developed in the eastern Great Lakes, providing enough lift and energy for showers and thunderstorms to develop across southern New England. With plenty of moisture, shear and instability in the region, some of these storms became severe, producing strong to damaging winds.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Multiple trees were blown down across Enfield.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level disturbance moving out of the Great Lakes initiated showers and thunderstorms over New York and New England. Enough instability was present in the region for some of these storms to become severe, producing strong to damaging winds and at least one funnel cloud.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Lightning struck a house on Prospect Street, setting it on fire.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A tree was downed onto wires on Jobs Hill Road.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A tree was downed onto wires on Route 320 near the Willington/Mansfield line.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: High pressure moved offshore allowing the environment to become more unstable and allowing afternoon heating to initiate thunderstorms. A few of these storms became severe producing damaging winds along with lightning.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A tree on Route 5 was downed by thunderstorm winds.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level disturbance moving out of the Great Lakes initiated showers and thunderstorms over New York and New England. Enough instability was present in the region for some of these storms to become severe, producing strong to damaging winds and at least one funnel cloud.

An upper level disturbance moving out of the Great Lakes initiated showers and thunderstorms over New York and New England. Enough instability was present in the region for some of these storms to become severe, producing strong to damaging winds and at least one funnel cloud.
A passing warm front and upper level disturbance produced an isolated tornado in New Haven County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A weak EF-0 tornado touched down in Wolcott CT Sunday morning. The path began near the intersection of Minor Road and Center Street where a tree was uprooted and facing west. Convergent, intermittent tree damage continued along a path to the northeast to Wolcott High School. Large fixed sports equipment was thrown across a field and a fence line was blown down to the west. Several trees were also topped. Further to the northeast on Kalko Drive several trees were downed by the tornado and a large tree fell on a trailer. The tornado lifted around Stagecoach Lane where a tree was uprooted and fell to the west onto a home.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A line of thunderstorms formed along and in front of an approaching cold front, with embedded strong to isolated severe thunderstorms that resulted in damaging winds and frequent lightning.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Multiple trees were reported down at the intersection of Glen Road and Cherry Street.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An approaching cold front triggered a line of thunderstorms that produced heavy rain and resulted in flash flooding in New Haven County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Union Ave. near Route 1 in New Haven was closed due to flooding.  Additionally, a car was stranded and being pulled out of flood waters by a tow truck near the Kimberly Ave. and Interstate 95 overpass.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A very moist and unstable airmass triggered showers and thunderstorms on multiple surface boundaries. Several rounds of storms produced heavy rain that resulted in flash flooding in portions of Fairfield County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A vehicle was floating in flood waters on Elm St. at the I-95 overpass in Stamford.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A very moist and unstable airmass triggered showers and thunderstorms on multiple surface boundaries. Several rounds of storms produced heavy rain that resulted in flash flooding in portions of Fairfield County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A car was stuck in high water under an overpass at the intersection of Bishop St. and Connecticut Ave. in Bridgeport.  In Fairfield, Rooster River exceeded bankfull and flooded nearby streets.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A very moist and unstable airmass triggered showers and thunderstorms on multiple surface boundaries. Several rounds of storms produced heavy rain that resulted in flash flooding in portions of Fairfield County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Widespread street flooding with several roads were impassable in Westport. One car was stranded in high water on Myrtle Avenue.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Scattered thunderstorms with isolated severe thunderstorms formed as a slow moving cold front progressed through the Northeast.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Numerous trees were reported down around the town of Newtown.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Scattered thunderstorms with isolated severe thunderstorms formed as a slow moving cold front progressed through the Northeast.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A tree was reported down across Ridgefield Road near the intersection with Scarlet Oak Drive.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Scattered thunderstorms with isolated severe thunderstorms formed as a slow moving cold front progressed through the Northeast.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A downed tree was reported near the intersection of West Prospect Street and Fairfield Street.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A line of thunderstorms with embedded severe thunderstorms formed along a slow moving cold front as it moved and stalled across the Northeast.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several trees and wires were reported down around the town.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A line of thunderstorms with embedded severe thunderstorms formed along a slow moving cold front as it moved and stalled across the Northeast.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A tree fell through the roof of a garage on Baldwin Street.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A line of thunderstorms with embedded severe thunderstorms formed along a slow moving cold front as it moved and stalled across the Northeast.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A tree was reported down across Maple Ridge Road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A line of thunderstorms with embedded severe thunderstorms formed along a slow moving cold front as it moved and stalled across the Northeast.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A large tree was down, blocking Byam Road at West Waterbury Road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A line of thunderstorms with embedded severe thunderstorms formed along a slow moving cold front as it moved and stalled across the Northeast.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A large tree was down, blocking West Johnson Avenue and Knotter Drive.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Scattered thunderstorms with isolated severe thunderstorms formed as a slow moving cold front progressed through the Northeast.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A tree was reported down at the intersection of Dorset Lane and Route 79.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front moving across the area triggered scattered thunderstorms, with embedded isolated severe thunderstorms with damaging winds.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A tree was reported down as a result of strong winds.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A line of thunderstorms formed along and in front of an approaching cold front, with embedded strong to isolated severe thunderstorms that resulted in damaging winds and frequent lightning.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A house was struck on Elona Lane.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An approaching cold front, combined with tropical moisture in advance of Hurricane Arthur, produced two rounds of showers and thunderstorms during the afternoon and evening. The storms in the evening produced wind damage across parts of northern Connecticut.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trees and wires were downed in Southington. In New Britain, a measured wind gust to 63 mph was reported by Amateur Radio.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An approaching cold front, combined with tropical moisture in advance of Hurricane Arthur, produced two rounds of showers and thunderstorms during the afternoon and evening. The storms in the evening produced wind damage across parts of northern Connecticut.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trees and wires were downed on Merrow Road in Tolland.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An approaching cold front triggered a line of thunderstorms that produced heavy rain and resulted in flash flooding in New Haven County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Humphrey St. near James St. as well as Brewery St. in New Haven were closed due to flooding.  Several cars were stranded in flood waters.  Route 34 eastbound was also closed at Interstates 91 and 95 due to flash flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An approaching cold front, combined with tropical moisture in advance of Hurricane Arthur, produced two rounds of showers and thunderstorms during the afternoon and evening. The storms in the evening produced wind damage across parts of northern Connecticut.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trees and wires were downed in Eastford and Thompson.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An area of low pressure over New York City lifted northeast across Southern New England. This worked together with a warm humid airmass to produce heavy downpours and strong wind.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Tree and wires were brought down and blocked the road on Hartford Pike.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level low developed in the eastern Great Lakes, providing enough lift and energy for showers and thunderstorms to develop across southern New England. With plenty of moisture, shear and instability in the region, some of these storms became severe, producing strong to damaging winds.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trees were downed on Field Road, and trees and wires were blown down on Somers Road (Rt. 83) near the town line between Somers and Ellington.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A surface low with its associated warm front approached the area early in the morning before partially lifting through. This boundary provided the focus for very heavy rain in an extremely moist air mass and resulted in flash flooding in New Haven County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several cars were submerged in flood waters on Interstate 95 in Branford.  Storm total rainfall amounts reported in New Haven County ranged from 0.96 inches in Meriden to 4.50 inches in Madison.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: As a cold front slowly moved across the area, moisture from Tropical Cyclone Arthur passing to the south and east converged along the boundary resulting in heavy rain and isolated flash flooding in New London.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The lower Pawcatuck River exceeded bankfull flooding Mechanic St. in Pawcatuck township.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: As a cold front slowly moved across the area, moisture from Tropical Cyclone Arthur passing to the south and east converged along the boundary resulting in heavy rain and isolated flash flooding in New London.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A vehicle became trapped after 4 feet of water accumulated at the intersection of Thames St. and Eastern Point Rd. in Groton, resulting in a water rescue.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A surface low with its associated warm front approached the area early in the morning before partially lifting through. This boundary provided the focus for very heavy rain in an extremely moist air mass and resulted in flash flooding in New Haven County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Route 1 was closed under the railroad tressel in Madison due to flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A broad upper level trough swung through the Northeast, providing enough forcing that in combination with late afternoon heating triggered an isolated severe thunderstorm.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Multiple trees were reported down around town.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A line of strong with embedded severe thunderstorms formed along and right ahead of a cold front slowly moving across the area.
A line of strong with embedded severe thunderstorms formed along and right ahead of a cold front slowly moving across the area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Multiple tree branches were reported down on power lines on West Street.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An early season winter storm impacted all of northwestern Connecticut during the busy Thanksgiving travel period on November 26th-27th, 2014. ||The storm began during the morning of Wednesday, November 26th. Heavy wet snow began between 8 and 9 AM across most of Litchfield County.  Once snow began, it increased in intensity.  With temperatures above freezing for most of the event, the snow mixed with sleet and rain across valley locations in Southern Litchfield County.  Still, the snow and mixed precipitation caused slow and difficult travel, which was noteworthy as this was the day before Thanksgiving. ||The precipitation tapered off during the late evening and overnight hours. By the early morning on Thanksgiving, snow amounts were 8 to 12 inches across the hills of northern Litchfield County. Lighter amounts fell across the far southern parts of the county due to mixing with rain and sleet.

Lighter amounts fell across the far southern parts of the county due to mixing with rain and sleet.
As a cold front moved east toward a warm moist unstable air mass, it produced severe thunderstorms that caused damaging winds and flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: High winds downed numerous trees across the town of Westport.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: As a cold front moved east toward a warm moist unstable air mass, it produced severe thunderstorms that caused damaging winds and flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: High winds downed trees and wires that closed multiple roads throughout the town of Fairfield.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: As a cold front moved east toward a warm moist unstable air mass, it produced severe thunderstorms that caused damaging winds and flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: High winds downed a tree at Filbert and Barbara Road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: As a cold front moved east toward a warm moist unstable air mass, it produced severe thunderstorms that caused damaging winds and flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: High winds downed a tree and wires onto a house roof at Weed Ave. and Gray Squirrel Drive.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: As a cold front moved east toward a warm moist unstable air mass, it produced severe thunderstorms that caused damaging winds and flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Five people were rescued from a vehicle at the railroad underpass on Compo Rd. South in Westport.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Deep low pressure passed to the south and east of the area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: At 11:50 pm EDT, sustained winds of 38 mph were measured at New Haven Airport.  At 1001 am, a measured wind gust of 49 mph was reported.  A mesonet station at Middle Beach reported a wind gust of 50 mph at 11:00 pm EDT.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Deep low pressure passed to the south and east of the area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: At 12:53 am EDT, sustained winds of 33 mph were measured at Bridgeport Sikorsky Airport.  At 12:57 am EDT, a measured wind gust of 48 mph was reported.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An area of low pressure moved from the Ohio Valley towards the mid-Atlantic states on Wednesday, March 12th. Precipitation spread across the region from west to east during the early morning hours. The precipitation initially began as rain, which fell throughout the daytime hours on Wednesday.||The low pressure area moved towards the New York City area by early evening, and strong, northerly winds transported colder air into the region. This allowed for a change over to a brief period of wintry mix, including snow. The low pressure continued to move eastward towards the eastern New England coast for the overnight hours.||Steady precipitation tapered off during the overnight hours. By the time precipitation had ended, snowfall amounts were just a coating, with some light ice accretion occurring as well. In addition, gusty northwest winds occurred in the wake of the storm. These winds, along with unseasonably cold temperatures, allowed for a very cold day, despite it being mid March.
Low pressure moving from the central Appalachians the morning of the 21st intensified off the Mid Atlantic coast and brought heavy snow to southern Connecticut on the 21st and 22nd.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: CT DOT in Haddam and the public in Durham reported total snowfall of 8.5 and 9 inches, respectively.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low pressure moving from the central Appalachians the morning of the 21st intensified off the Mid Atlantic coast and brought heavy snow to southern Connecticut on the 21st and 22nd.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The public reported total snowfall of 9.5 inches in Shelton.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low pressure moving from the central Appalachians the morning of the 21st intensified off the Mid Atlantic coast and brought heavy snow to southern Connecticut on the 21st and 22nd.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trained spotters in North Haven, Wallingford, and Wolcott reported total snowfall of 9.5, 8.3, and 5.8 inches, respectively.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low pressure moving from the central Appalachians the morning of the 21st intensified off the Mid Atlantic coast and brought heavy snow to southern Connecticut on the 21st and 22nd.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trained spotters and CT DOT reported widespread total snowfall amounts of 6 to 8 inches.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low pressure moving from the central Appalachians the morning of the 21st intensified off the Mid Atlantic coast and brought heavy snow to southern Connecticut on the 21st and 22nd.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The public and CT DOT reported widespread total snowfall of 6 to 9 inches.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low pressure moving from the central Appalachians the morning of the 21st intensified off the Mid Atlantic coast and brought heavy snow to southern Connecticut on the 21st and 22nd.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: CT DOT reported 6 inches of snow in Groton.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low pressure moving from the central Appalachians the morning of the 21st intensified off the Mid Atlantic coast and brought heavy snow to southern Connecticut on the 21st and 22nd.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Broadcast media reported 6.7 inches of snow in Clinton. CT DOT reported 5.5 inches of snow in Old Saybrook.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low pressure moving from the central Appalachians the morning of the 21st intensified off the Mid Atlantic coast and brought heavy snow to southern Connecticut on the 21st and 22nd.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The COOP observer in Bridgeport CT reported a total snowfall of 6.7 inches. Elsewhere, the public, CT DOT, and trained spotters reported total snowfalls of 9 to 11 inches.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An area of low pressure moved from the Ohio Valley towards the mid-Atlantic states on Wednesday, March 12th. Precipitation spread across the region from west to east during the early morning hours. The precipitation initially began as rain, which fell throughout the daytime hours on Wednesday.||The low pressure area moved towards the New York City area by early evening, and strong, northerly winds transported colder air into the region. This allowed for a change over to a brief period of wintry mix, including snow. The low pressure continued to move eastward towards the eastern New England coast for the overnight hours.||Steady precipitation tapered off during the overnight hours. By the time precipitation had ended, snowfall amounts were just a coating, with some light ice accretion occurring as well. In addition, gusty northwest winds occurred in the wake of the storm. These winds, along with unseasonably cold temperatures, allowed for a very cold day, despite it being mid March.

A stacked low pressure system passed south and east of southern New England bringing widespread rainfall to much of the region. This system was anomalously moist with precipitable waters two to three standard deviations above normal for late March. Anywhere from two to five inches of rain fell across southern New England with the highest amounts falling along the south coast of Rhode Island and Massachusetts. This resulted in flooding and flash flooding across much of the area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snake Meadow Brook overflowed its banks, flooding and ultimately closing North Sterling Road in Moosup for several hours.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Weak low pressure passing to the south brought a swath of heavy snow to parts of southwest Connecticut on the third.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trained spotters and the public reported 6.5 inches snowfall in Weston and Shelton. Areas farther north received 5 inches snowfall.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Weak low pressure passing to the south brought a swath of heavy snow to parts of southwest Connecticut on the third.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trained spotters and the public reported 6 to 7 inches snowfall in a narrow corridor from Meriden south through Wallingford into North Haven. Areas farther west received 3 to 5 inches snowfall.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Weak low pressure passing to the south brought a swath of heavy snow to parts of southwest Connecticut on the third.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Connecticut DOT in New Haven and the public in West Haven received 6 inches snowfall. Areas farther east received 5 inches snowfall.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Weak low pressure passing to the south brought a swath of heavy snow to parts of southwest Connecticut on the third.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A trained spotter in Westbrook reported 6 inches snowfall. Other areas received 4 to 5 inches snowfall.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Weak low pressure passing to the south brought a swath of heavy snow to parts of southwest Connecticut on the third.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Bridgeport Airport reported 6.7 inches of snow. The Connecticut DOT, the public, and official NWS observations reported widespread 7 to 9 inch snowfall.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A complex low pressure system moving through the Ohio Valley and Mid Atlantic regions brought a quick burst of heavy snow to parts of Southern Connecticut the morning of February fifth.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The public and trained spotters reported widespread 8 to 11 inches snowfall.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A complex low pressure system moving through the Ohio Valley and Mid Atlantic regions brought a quick burst of heavy snow to parts of Southern Connecticut the morning of February fifth.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trained spotters, the public, and Connecticut DOT reported widespread 5 to 10 inches snowfall.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A complex low pressure system moving through the Ohio Valley and Mid Atlantic regions brought a quick burst of heavy snow to parts of Southern Connecticut the morning of February fifth.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The public, Connecticut DOT, and trained spotters reported widespread 6 to 10 inches snowfall.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A complex low pressure system moving through the Ohio Valley and Mid Atlantic regions brought a quick burst of heavy snow to parts of Southern Connecticut the morning of February fifth.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trained spotters and the public reported widespread 5 to 9 inches snowfall.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A complex low pressure system moving through the Ohio Valley and Mid Atlantic regions brought a quick burst of heavy snow to parts of Southern Connecticut the morning of February fifth.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The public reported 6.3 inches of snow in Clinton.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A warm and humid air mass was in place over northwestern Connecticut during the afternoon and evening hours on Monday, July 7th, which allowed the atmosphere to become quite unstable. As an upper level shortwave trough moved towards the area, clusters of thunderstorms developed over eastern New York and moved into western New England by the evening hours. These thunderstorms, although not overly tall, were able to bring very strong winds aloft down to the surface in New Milford, producing damaging wind gusts to tress.   The threat for severe thunderstorms ended by the late evening hours, as the shortwave trough moved east of the region.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trees were reported down in New Milford due to thunderstorm winds.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A wave of low pressure tracked northeast along a stationary frontal boundary from the Tennessee River Valley to the Mid-Atlantic Coast and into the Atlantic Ocean. Several inches of rain fell across Southern Connecticut resulting in flooding on the Yantic River in New London County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Storm total rainfall reported across New London County ranged from 3.20 inches in New London to 4.90 inches in Mystic. The Yantic River at Yantic exceeded its flood stage of 9.0 feet at 7:00 am EST, crested at 10.10 feet at 10:00 am EST and fell back within its banks at 5:45 pm EST. Numerous roads in Norwich were under 2 feet of water as a result.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Deepening low pressure over the western Atlantic Ocean resulted in strong northeast winds across the area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: At 3:37 pm, the public reported a downed tree onto two cars on Cottage Street. This occurred in the city of New Haven. Gusts of 40 to 45 mph were reported at Meriden Airport and New Haven Tweed Airport.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A weak trough across the region triggered late afternoon isolated severe thunderstorms that produced large hail and injured a motor cyclist.
A weak trough across the region triggered late afternoon isolated severe thunderstorms that produced large hail and injured a motor cyclist.
A weak trough across the region triggered late afternoon isolated severe thunderstorms that produced large hail and injured a motor cyclist.
A weak trough across the region triggered late afternoon isolated severe thunderstorms that produced large hail and injured a motor cyclist.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A motorcyclist was injured due to falling hail, resulting in some cuts. The accident occurred near the intersection of Routes 138 and I-395, south of Jewett City. ||Hail size was estimated by nearby reports.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Colder air moving in on the back side of low pressure departing off the East Coast changed rain to locally heavy snow during the morning of the 31st.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Locally heavy snow snarled traffic during the morning rush. Trained spotters reported widespread snowfall of 2 to 3 inches.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Colder air moving in on the back side of low pressure departing off the East Coast changed rain to locally heavy snow during the morning of the 31st.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Locally heavy snow snarled traffic during the morning rush. Trained spotters and the public reported widespread snowfall of 2.5 to 3.5 inches.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A warm and humid air mass was in place over the region on Thursday, July 3rd. As a strong cold front approached from the west, a broken line of thunderstorms developed over upstate New York and moved eastward during the late afternoon hours. Aided by powerful winds aloft, the storms moved from west to east over northwestern Connecticut during the early evening hours. A few of the storms produced strong winds, causing damage to trees and power lines.  In addition, large hail occurred in some of the storms as well.||As the cold front moved through the area by later in the evening, the storms moved east of the region and the threat for severe weather ended.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Ping pong ball size hail was reported during a thunderstorm in Lakeville.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A warm and humid air mass was in place over the region on Thursday, July 3rd. As a strong cold front approached from the west, a broken line of thunderstorms developed over upstate New York and moved eastward during the late afternoon hours. Aided by powerful winds aloft, the storms moved from west to east over northwestern Connecticut during the early evening hours. A few of the storms produced strong winds, causing damage to trees and power lines.  In addition, large hail occurred in some of the storms as well.||As the cold front moved through the area by later in the evening, the storms moved east of the region and the threat for severe weather ended.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trees were reported down in New Milford due to thunderstorm winds.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A warm southerly flow allowed for temperatures to reach well into the 80s to near 90 on Wednesday, July 2nd. In addition, it was rather humid with dewpoints nearing 70 degrees. With the warm and humid conditions in place, the atmosphere became quite unstable during the afternoon and evening hours. ||Well ahead of a cold front, a surface trough was in place across upstate New York and western New England. This caused thunderstorms to develop during the afternoon hours. A few of these storms became severe, producing wind damage to trees and homes.||These storms ended by the late evening hours, as nocturnal influences helped wane the development of additional thunderstorms.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Numerous trees were reported down in Winsted due to thunderstorm winds.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong southerly winds ahead of a cold front occurred in southern Connecticut.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A trained spotter reported a measured wind gust up to 46 mph in North Haven. The spotter also reported a tree down. Nearby wind gusts of 35 to 36 knots were reported by the ASOS sites at Bridgeport Connecticut, and Meriden Connecticut around that time.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system developed along the northern Gulf Coast on February 12th, and moved to near Cape Hatteras and the Virginia capes by the morning of the 13th. The intensifying low then headed northeast, passing east of Long Island and into the Gulf of Maine early the morning of the 14th, bringing heavy snow and ice to southern Connecticut.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The public and Connecticut DOT reported snowfall of 8 to 11 inches. Freezing rain accretion of up to 3 tenths of an inch also occurred per observations from surrounding areas.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system developed along the northern Gulf Coast on February 12th, and moved to near Cape Hatteras and the Virginia capes by the morning of the 13th. The intensifying low then headed northeast, passing east of Long Island and into the Gulf of Maine early the morning of the 14th, bringing heavy snow and ice to southern Connecticut.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Connecticut DOT, trained spotters and the public reported widespread snowfall of 11 to 17 inches. Freezing rain accretion of 2 to 3 tenths of an inch also occurred per observations from surrounding areas.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system developed along the northern Gulf Coast on February 12th, and moved to near Cape Hatteras and the Virginia capes by the morning of the 13th. The intensifying low then headed northeast, passing east of Long Island and into the Gulf of Maine early the morning of the 14th, bringing heavy snow and ice to southern Connecticut.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trained spotters and Connecticut DOT reported widespread snowfall of 8 to 13 inches. The Meriden ASOS and a trained spotter in Naugatuck also reported freezing rain accretion of 3 tenths of an inch.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A trough of low pressure lingering across the Tri state area triggered multiple rounds of showers and thunderstorms, resulting in damage from a lightning strike.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Lightning struck a tree, which resulted in damage to a garage and portion of the associated house.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system developed along the northern Gulf Coast on February 12th, and moved to near Cape Hatteras and the Virginia capes by the morning of the 13th. The intensifying low then headed northeast, passing east of Long Island and into the Gulf of Maine early the morning of the 14th, bringing heavy snow and ice to southern Connecticut.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The public, trained spotters, and an NWS cooperative observer reported widespread snowfall of 12 to 16 inches. Freezing rain accretion of 2 to 3 tenths of an inch also occurred per observations from surrounding areas.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system developed along the northern Gulf Coast on February 12th, and moved to near Cape Hatteras and the Virginia capes by the morning of the 13th. The intensifying low then headed northeast, passing east of Long Island and into the Gulf of Maine early the morning of the 14th, bringing heavy snow and ice to southern Connecticut.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Connecticut DOT reported snowfall of 9.5 inches in New Haven. Freezing rain accretion of 2 to 3 tenths of an inch also occurred per observations from surrounding areas.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system developed along the northern Gulf Coast on February 12th, and moved to near Cape Hatteras and the Virginia capes by the morning of the 13th. The intensifying low then headed northeast, passing east of Long Island and into the Gulf of Maine early the morning of the 14th, bringing heavy snow and ice to southern Connecticut.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Nearby observations from Connecticut DOT, an NWS cooperative observer, and trained spotters, indicate snowfall of 6 to 8 inches, plus freezing rain accretion of up to 2 tenths of an inch.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system developed along the northern Gulf Coast on February 12th, and moved to near Cape Hatteras and the Virginia capes by the morning of the 13th. The intensifying low then headed northeast, passing east of Long Island and into the Gulf of Maine early the morning of the 14th, bringing heavy snow and ice to southern Connecticut.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Connecticut DOT reported snowfall of 6 to 7 inches.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A warm front lingered just north of the region while a cold front approached the region from the west during the day.  This resulted in a severe thunderstorm that caused wind damage in Middlesex County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Multiple trees were reported down across the town.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system developed along the northern Gulf Coast on February 12th, and moved to near Cape Hatteras and the Virginia capes by the morning of the 13th. The intensifying low then headed northeast, passing east of Long Island and into the Gulf of Maine early the morning of the 14th, bringing heavy snow and ice to southern Connecticut.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trained spotters and nearby observations from Connecticut DOT indicate snowfall of 5 to 7 inches.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front was moving across the region on Saturday, September 6th. Ahead of this front, an unseasonably hot and humid air mass was in place across northwestern Connecticut during the afternoon hours. This allowed for the atmosphere to be quite unstable. As a result, one thunderstorms developed during the afternoon hours, quickly moving from west to east across the region. This storm produced wind damage across several towns in Litchfield County. ||The threat for storms ended in the evening hours with the passage of the cold front, as cooler, less humid and more stable air moved into the region.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Wires were downed on Litchfield Street in Torrington as a result of thunderstorm winds.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level disturbance moving out of the Great Lakes initiated showers and thunderstorms over New York and New England. Enough instability was present in the region for some of these storms to become severe, producing strong to damaging winds and at least one funnel cloud.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A microburst occurred with winds 80-90 mph downing numerous trees and wires on Interstate 195, Goose Lane, and Cedar Mill, Reed and Mile Hill Roads.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A frontal system associated with a large cutoff low pressure system over the Midwest and Lower Great Lakes region caused periods of heavy rain, which resulted in isolated flooding in New Haven County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The on ramp from Interstate 91 south to Interstate 95 in New Haven was closed due to flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An isolated severe thunderstorm formed along and ahead of an approaching cold front moving south across New Haven County.  A down burst resulted with maximum peak wind gusts of 100 mph and property damage.  This storm also produced very heavy rain resulting in flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: An NWS storm survey was conducted by WFO Albany that concluded the occurrence of a down burst. The event began at the Southbury Training School and ended at the Southbury Police Department, resulting in a length of about 2.5 miles. The width was inconclusive. There was extensive tree damage reported of hardwoods and softwoods, with numerous trees reported as snapped and/or uprooted. The damage suggests maximum winds of around 100 mph.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An isolated severe thunderstorm formed along and ahead of an approaching cold front moving south across New Haven County.  A down burst resulted with maximum peak wind gusts of 100 mph and property damage.  This storm also produced very heavy rain resulting in flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Campbell Ave. was impassable from Clark St. to George St. in West Haven due to flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An isolated severe thunderstorm formed along and ahead of an approaching cold front moving south across New Haven County.  A down burst resulted with maximum peak wind gusts of 100 mph and property damage.  This storm also produced very heavy rain resulting in flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The local fire department responded to a car submerged in flood waters at the intersection of Washington Ave. and Wood St. in West Haven.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A warm and humid air mass was in place during the early morning hours on Wednesday, June 18th. A strong cold front moved across the region from west to east shortly after midnight during the early morning hours. Along and just ahead of this boundary, a line of severe thunderstorms in the form of a squall line raced from west to east across the area. These storms produced significant wind damage across eastern New York. The thunderstorms weakened somewhat as they reached the border with western New England as instability started to wane, but still caused damage to a tree, which fell on a house in Winsted. The threat for thunderstorms ended with the passage of the cold front by the late night hours, as drier and less humid air worked into the region.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A tree was reportedly downed due to thunderstorm winds in Winsted. The tree fell on a house and caused some minor damage.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level disturbance moving out of the Great Lakes initiated showers and thunderstorms over New York and New England. Enough instability was present in the region for some of these storms to become severe, producing strong to damaging winds and at least one funnel cloud.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trees and wires on Westwood Road and Codfish Falls Road were downed by thunderstorm winds.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Rapidly intensifying low pressure moved northeast from the southern mid Atlantic coast on the morning of the 15th, to near Nova Scotia the morning of the 16th. This storm brought heavy snow to parts of southeast Connecticut during the afternoon and evening of the 15th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Connecticut DOT and a trained spotter reported 5.8 inches of snowfall in Groton and Stonington, respectively.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A significant winter storm brought six to twelve inches of snow across much of southern New England.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Seven to thirteen inches of snow fell across Hartford County.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A significant winter storm brought six to twelve inches of snow across much of southern New England.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Seven to twelve inches of snow fell across Tolland County.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A significant winter storm brought six to twelve inches of snow across much of southern New England.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Seven to nine inches of snow fell across Windham County.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level disturbance moving out of the Great Lakes initiated showers and thunderstorms over New York and New England. Enough instability was present in the region for some of these storms to become severe, producing strong to damaging winds and at least one funnel cloud.

A strong cold front combined with an upper level disturbance to produce showers and thunderstorms across southern New England during the early morning hours of October 8th. One of these storms produced a microburst in the town of Easthampton in western Massachusetts where numerous trees were downed on the west side of Mount Tom. Scattered wind damage occurred elsewhere across southern New England.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trees and wires on Liberty Street were downed by thunderstorm winds.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A warm and humid air mass was in place over the region on Thursday, July 3rd. As a strong cold front approached from the west, a broken line of thunderstorms developed over upstate New York and moved eastward during the late afternoon hours. Aided by powerful winds aloft, the storms moved from west to east over northwestern Connecticut during the early evening hours. A few of the storms produced strong winds, causing damage to trees and power lines.  In addition, large hail occurred in some of the storms as well.||As the cold front moved through the area by later in the evening, the storms moved east of the region and the threat for severe weather ended.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trees were reported down in Torrington due to thunderstorm winds.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An isolated thunderstorm moved southeast across Litchfield County Connecticut during the late afternoon and early evening hours on Tuesday, May 27th.  The thunderstorm strengthened as it reached the southern portion of the county and produced a period of gusty winds, heavy rainfall and frequent cloud to ground lightning. The storm produced wind damage to trees and homes in the town of New Milford.  Several roads were closed a result of downed trees and power lines.  In addition, schools in New Milford were closed on Wednesday, May 28th due to the ongoing cleanup from the storm damage.||A National Weather Service Storm Survey determined that straight line winds produced winds up to 100 MPH with damage sporadic  and intermittent along a 7 mile swath.  Unfortunately, one person in New Milford died due to electrocution as a result of downed wires falling on a vehicle. Up to 13,000 people throughout the area lost power as a result of the thunderstorms.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Broadcast Media reported that downed power lines resulted in a man exiting a vehicle to be electrocuted.  The man died as a result of the injuries.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Despite being behind a cold front, the region remained in a warm and humid air mass. This allowed the atmosphere to become quite unstable. ||As a cold front approached the region during the afternoon and early evening hours, clusters of thunderstorms developed across eastern upstate New York.  These thunderstorms moved into northwestern Connecticut during the late evening hours and produced damaging winds, mainly to trees and power lines. ||The threat for storms ended as the storms moved eastward and the cold front moved across the area and into central New England for the overnight hours.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A tree and wires were reported down in the town of Warren due to thunderstorm winds.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A warm front approached the region from the south during the late evening hours on Monday, December 28th. Initially, precipitation began as a quick burst of snow, but with warmer air moving into the region aloft, the precipitation quickly changed to a wintry mix of sleet and freezing rain for much of the overnight hours. After sunrise, the precipitation became light in intensity and fell mainly as freezing rain during the morning hours before temperatures warmed up above freezing by the afternoon hours and precipitation ended.||Most areas saw 1 to 2 inches of snow and sleet with a light glaze of ice on top.  As a result of the wintry precipitation, slippery travel resulted in many car accidents throughout the region, especially during the morning commute on Tuesday, December 29th.

After sunrise, the precipitation became light in intensity and fell mainly as freezing rain during the morning hours before temperatures warmed up above freezing by the afternoon hours and precipitation ended.||Most areas saw 1 to 2 inches of snow and sleet with a light glaze of ice on top.  As a result of the wintry precipitation, slippery travel resulted in many car accidents throughout the region, especially during the morning commute on Tuesday, December 29th.
An arctic cold front associated with a clipper low pressure system moving through the northeast resulted in light snow across much of southern New England.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Two to five inches of snow fell across Tolland County.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A clipper low moved across southern Quebec on February 7.  This was followed by low pressure moving east from the Great Lakes on February 8.  On February 9 & 10, low pressure moved off the mid-Atlantic coast becoming a noreaster as it approached southern New England.   This all resulted in a long duration snow storm that dumped up to a foot and a half of snow across southern New England.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Five to thirteen inches of snow fell across Hartford County.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Six to ten inches of snow fell across Tolland County.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Four to eight inches of snow fell across Hartford County.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: During the afternoon on Saturday, February 21st, a storm system began to approach the region from the Ohio Valley. As a warm front stretched towards northwestern Connecticut, a band of steady snowfall developed and moved northward across the area. The snowfall fell locally moderate at times through the late afternoon and into the evening hours. ||As the storm lifted across the region, snowfall tapered off to snow showers and flurries during the overnight hours into the morning of Sunday, February 22nd. By sunrise on Sunday morning, about 5 to 8 inches of snow fell across Litchfield County, with the highest amounts across the high terrain areas.

Behind a departing snowstorm, Arctic air moved into the region between February 2nd and February 3rd. Overnight low temperatures dropped to around zero in many areas, with a few spots in the Litchfield Hills as low as 6 below zero.  With gusty northwest winds in place, wind chill values dropped to 10 to 20 below zero across northern Litchfield County during the overnight hours.  Winds became light during the morning hours and although temperatures remained frigid, wind chill values improved for during the day on February 3rd.

In the wake of a departing storm system, strong northwest winds brought yet another frigid Arctic air mass into the region during the evening on Thursday, February 19th. With winds gusting over 25 MPH and temperatures dropping below zero, wind chill values were as low as 10 to 25 degrees below zero during the overnight hours and into the morning on Friday, February 20th.  With a nearly month long stretch of very cold weather, there were many reports of bursts pipes and water mains.||By the late morning hours on Friday, February 20th, diminishing winds and rising temperatures allowed wind chill values to improve. However, it remained rather cold through the remainder of the day.

In the wake of a departing storm system, strong northwest winds brought yet another frigid Arctic air mass into the region during the evening on Thursday, February 19th. During the afternoon on Saturday, February 21st, a storm system began to approach the region from the Ohio Valley. As a warm front stretched towards northwestern Connecticut, a band of steady snowfall developed and moved northward across the area. The snowfall fell locally moderate at times through the late afternoon and into the evening hours. ||As the storm lifted across the region, snowfall tapered off to snow showers and flurries during the overnight hours into the morning of Sunday, February 22nd. By sunrise on Sunday morning, about 5 to 8 inches of snow fell across Litchfield County, with the highest amounts across the high terrain areas.

A cold front approached southern New England bringing rain to the region. A low level jet brought warmer air into the area just above the surface and temperatures remained below freezing at the surface. This resulted in freezing rain occurring across much of western Massachusetts and northern Connecticut. Icing on the roads ended up resulting in many accidents. Thankfully, only one injury was reported.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Multiple accidents occurred throughout Hartford County, including on Interstate 84.  In addition, Bradley International Airport closed from noon to 1pm due to icing.  Incoming flights were diverted to nearby airports.  About a tenth of an inch of ice accreted on roads and other surfaces.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An area of low pressure impacted the region between the afternoon on Saturday, January 3rd and the morning of Sunday, January 4th. Precipitation associated with the storm's warm front initially began as snow across all of Northwestern Connecticut. However, as warmer air aloft moved into the area, the precipitation changed to sleet and freezing rain by the evening hours. ||As low pressure passed to the west over the Great Lakes, light precipitation continued through the overnight hours, mainly in the form of a plain light rain.  A few spots within the higher elevations continued to see periods of freezing rain through the overnight hours.  Precipitation tapered off to drizzle during the morning hours, with temperatures rising above freezing across the entire area.||Mainly light accumulation of snow occurred, with about 1 to 3 inches in most locations. Light ice accretion from freezing rain of about a tenth to a quarter of an inch also occurred. The combination of snow and ice led to hazardous travel across much of the region.
A low pressure system developed off the North Carolina coast and moved up the east coast of the United States, bringing snow to much of southern New England.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Four to six inches of snow fell across Tolland County.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold air mass was in place over the region on Sunday, February 1st. During the late evening hours, an area of low pressure over the Ohio Valley began moving eastward towards the mid-Atlantic states. With plenty of moisture streaming up from the south, precipitation spread across the region in the form of snow. This snowfall picked up intensity during the overnight hours and continued through much of the day on Monday, February 2nd, as the low pressure area passed to the south of Long Island, New York. ||Snowfall tapered off to snow showers by the evening hours and ended. Most areas received 8 to 14 inches of snowfall.

A strong cold front combined with a remnant of an elevated mixed layer (EML) and a significant amount of deep layer shear and instability to produce showers and thunderstorms across southern New England.  Many of these thunderstorms became severe, producing strong to damaging winds.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trees, utility poles, and wires were downed at the intersection of Russell Road and Route 10.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong cold front combined with a remnant of an elevated mixed layer (EML) and a significant amount of deep layer shear and instability to produce showers and thunderstorms across southern New England.  Many of these thunderstorms became severe, producing strong to damaging winds.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trees and wires were downed on Chestnut Hill Road, Maston Hill Road, and Clark Hill Road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A moist and unstable air mass ahead of an advancing cold front led to the developing of thunderstorms during the early afternoon hours on Tuesday, June 9th across eastern New York. As the thunderstorms organized into small lines, some of the thunderstorms produced wind damage, mainly to trees and power lines.   These thunderstorms reached northwestern Connecticut by the mid afternoon hours and produced a report of wind damage in Torrington. ||Thunderstorms ended over the region by the late afternoon, as the cold front crossed the region from west to east.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Wires were reported down due to thunderstorm winds in Torrington via Twitter.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front moving across southern New England combined with high precipitable waters and weak flow aloft to initiate showers and thunderstorms that produced flooding and pockets of flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Route 189 was blocked by flood waters that were not draining.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Ahead of an approaching cold front, a warm and humid air mass was in place over northwestern Connecticut on Tuesday, May 19th.  As the cold front approached during the early evening hours, a few scattered showers and thunderstorms developed and moved from west to east across the region.  Some of the thunderstorms became severe, producing damaging winds to trees and power lines.  In addition, two of the thunderstorms produced damaging lightning strikes as well.  ||The threat for thunderstorms ended by the late evening hours, as the cold front passed through the region and drier air moved into the area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A lightning strike started a fire at a home on Weed Road in Torrington during a thunderstorm.  Although firefighters were initially hampered due to the ongoing thunderstorm, they were able to contain the fire to the attic on the front side of the house.  They had the fire under control within in an hour and a half.  The family was able to go back into the home once the fire was put out.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front produced showers and thunderstorms across much of southern New England.  Deep moisture and slow moving storms combined to produce heavy rain with some of these storms.  This resulted in some minor street flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain produced flooding on Trout Brook Drive.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: In the wake of a frontal system, gusty northwest winds developed due to a strong pressure gradient between the departing storm and an area of high pressure building into the Great Lakes region during the day on Tuesday, March 17th.  Winds frequently gusted over 30 MPH across Litchfield County with a few gusts recorded between 40 and 43 MPH in the late afternoon hours.||These winds downed trees and power lines, causing some power outages across the region.  In addition, one tree fell onto a truck in Torrington.  A man inside the truck was injured due to fallen tree and was trapped inside the vehicle.||As the storm continued to pulled away and nocturnal effects began to take over, winds subsided by the late evening hours.

In the wake of a frontal system, gusty northwest winds developed due to a strong pressure gradient between the departing storm and an area of high pressure building into the Great Lakes region during the day on Tuesday, March 17th.  Winds frequently gusted over 30 MPH across Litchfield County with a few gusts recorded between 40 and 43 MPH in the late afternoon hours.||These winds downed trees and power lines, causing some power outages across the region.  In addition, one tree fell onto a truck in Torrington.  A man inside the truck was injured due to fallen tree and was trapped inside the vehicle.||As the storm continued to pulled away and nocturnal effects began to take over, winds subsided by the late evening hours.

Behind an Arctic cold front, a frigid air mass moved into northwestern Connecticut on the late evening of Thursday, February 12th into the early morning hours of Friday, February 13th. This very cold air was also accompanied by gusty northwest winds of up to 35 mph. ||During the late night hours, winds continued to be very gusty. With these strong winds and temperatures dropping between zero and -10 degrees, wind chill values were as low as 10 to 30 below zero at times. ||With these cold temperatures and low wind chill values, some schools were delayed on the morning of Friday, February 13th. With the persistent cold weather in place, many towns and cities continued to keep warming shelters open for residents. There were also some reports of frozen pipes and burst water mains, especially in the areas that contained older infrastructure.

An historic winter storm brought heavy snow to southern New England with blizzard conditions to much of Rhode Island and eastern Massachusetts, beginning during the day on Monday, January 26 and lasting into the early morning hours of Tuesday, January 27.  The highest snowfall totals, averaging two to three feet, extended from extreme northeast Connecticut and northwest Rhode Island into much of central and northeast Massachusetts, including greater Boston.  Some of the highest totals reported include Hudson, MA (36 inches), Acton, MA (34 inches), Thompson, CT (33.5 inches), and Methuen, MA (31.5 inches).  Much of southeast Massachusetts and the rest of Rhode Island received one to two feet of snow.  Totals dropped off dramatically west of the Connecticut River Valley where totals of 4 to 8 inches were observed.  ||The storm was well-forecast, with Blizzard Watches and Winter Storm Watches issued 2 days before the snow began.  Low pressure tracked northeast from the Carolinas and strengthened rapidly as it slowly passed southeast of Nantucket on Monday evening, January 26.  All of the precipitation fell as snow with this storm.  At its peak, snowfall rates of 2 to 3 inches per hour were common.  In Massachusetts, blizzard conditions were officially reported in Marshfield (14 hours), Hyannis (13 hours), Nantucket (11 hours), Boston (9 hours), Chatham (9 hours), Worcester (7 hours), and Beverly (3 hours).  In Rhode Island, blizzard conditions were officially reported in Westerly (5 hours), Newport (4 hours), and at T.F. Green State Airport in Warwick (3 hours).  Several other locations fell just short of the required criteria (3 consecutive hours of blizzard conditions) including Fitchburg, New Bedford, Falmouth, and Martha���s Vineyard in Massachusetts and Smithfield in Rhode Island.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snow amounts varied widely across Hartford County, with reports of anywhere from four to twenty-two inches.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Warm air overriding a stationary front along the coast, while a shallow Arctic air mass remained entrenched over land, led to light freezing rain through the morning and into the afternoon. Freezing rain continued even as air temperatures warmed above freezing due to very cold ground temperatures.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The public reported freezing rain accumulation up to 0.1 inch in Norwalk. The freezing rain led to widespread motor vehicle accidents, and numerous falls and injuries. Police discouraged travel until late afternoon.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Warm air overriding a stationary front along the coast, while a shallow Arctic air mass remained entrenched over land, led to light freezing rain through the morning and into the afternoon. Freezing rain continued even as air temperatures warmed above freezing due to very cold ground temperatures.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Freezing rain accumulated nearly 0.2 inches at Danbury Airport. The freezing rain led to widespread motor vehicle accidents, and numerous falls and injuries. Police discouraged travel until late afternoon.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Warm air overriding a stationary front along the coast, while a shallow Arctic air mass remained entrenched over land, led to light freezing rain through the morning and into the afternoon. Freezing rain continued even as air temperatures warmed above freezing due to very cold ground temperatures.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Freezing rain accumulated nearly 0.1 inch at Meriden Markham Airport. The freezing rain led to widespread motor vehicle accidents, and numerous falls and injuries.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Freezing rain led to widespread motor vehicle accidents, including a multi-car accident on Interstate 95 in New London, and numerous falls and injuries.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Freezing rain led to widespread motor vehicle accidents, including 1 fatality, and numerous falls and injuries.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An historic winter storm brought heavy snow to southern New England with blizzard conditions to much of Rhode Island and eastern Massachusetts, beginning during the day on Monday, January 26 and lasting into the early morning hours of Tuesday, January 27.  The highest snowfall totals, averaging two to three feet, extended from extreme northeast Connecticut and northwest Rhode Island into much of central and northeast Massachusetts, including greater Boston.  Some of the highest totals reported include Hudson, MA (36 inches), Acton, MA (34 inches), Thompson, CT (33.5 inches), and Methuen, MA (31.5 inches).  Much of southeast Massachusetts and the rest of Rhode Island received one to two feet of snow.  Totals dropped off dramatically west of the Connecticut River Valley where totals of 4 to 8 inches were observed.  ||The storm was well-forecast, with Blizzard Watches and Winter Storm Watches issued 2 days before the snow began.  Low pressure tracked northeast from the Carolinas and strengthened rapidly as it slowly passed southeast of Nantucket on Monday evening, January 26.  All of the precipitation fell as snow with this storm.  At its peak, snowfall rates of 2 to 3 inches per hour were common.  In Massachusetts, blizzard conditions were officially reported in Marshfield (14 hours), Hyannis (13 hours), Nantucket (11 hours), Boston (9 hours), Chatham (9 hours), Worcester (7 hours), and Beverly (3 hours).  In Rhode Island, blizzard conditions were officially reported in Westerly (5 hours), Newport (4 hours), and at T.F. Green State Airport in Warwick (3 hours).  Several other locations fell just short of the required criteria (3 consecutive hours of blizzard conditions) including Fitchburg, New Bedford, Falmouth, and Martha���s Vineyard in Massachusetts and Smithfield in Rhode Island.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Eighteen to thirty-three inches of snow fell across Windham County.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A rapidly developing area of low pressure moved from just off the mid-Atlantic coast towards southern New England on Saturday, January 24th, 2015. With the storm remaining far enough south of the region, it only brought a glancing blow to the area. Snowfall began during the early morning hours on Saturday, January 24th and diminished during the afternoon hours. During this time, about 3 to 7 inches of snow fell across Litchfield County, with the heaviest amounts in the far southeastern corner of the county.

During this time, about 3 to 7 inches of snow fell across Litchfield County, with the heaviest amounts in the far southeastern corner of the county.

A potent Alberta Clipper low moved from southwestern Canada on January 24th to the Plains states and Ohio Valley on the 25th. The low then redeveloped off the Mid Atlantic coast on the 26th and rapidly intensified into a strong nor'easter, bringing heavy snow and strong winds to Southern Connecticut, with blizzard conditions in New London County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A trained spotter reported 22 inches of snowfall in Haddam. North winds gusted up to 39 mph at Chester Airport, with blowing and drifting of snow.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A potent Alberta Clipper low moved from southwestern Canada on January 24th to the Plains states and Ohio Valley on the 25th. The low then redeveloped off the Mid Atlantic coast on the 26th and rapidly intensified into a strong nor'easter, bringing heavy snow and strong winds to Southern Connecticut, with blizzard conditions in New London County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trained spotters and the public reported snowfall of 6 to 7 inches. North winds gusted up to 35 mph at Danbury Airport, with blowing and drifting of snow.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A potent Alberta Clipper low moved from southwestern Canada on January 24th to the Plains states and Ohio Valley on the 25th.
