EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trained spotters, Connecticut DOT, and the public reported snowfall of 9 to 17 inches. North winds gusted up to 44 mph at New Haven Airport, with blowing and drifting of snow.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A potent Alberta Clipper low moved from southwestern Canada on January 24th to the Plains states and Ohio Valley on the 25th. The low then redeveloped off the Mid Atlantic coast on the 26th and rapidly intensified into a strong nor'easter, bringing heavy snow and strong winds to Southern Connecticut, with blizzard conditions in New London County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trained spotters and Connecticut DOT reported snowfall of 6 to 13 inches. North winds gusted up to 38 mph at Meriden Markham Airport, and northeast winds gusted up to 39 mph at Waterbury-Oxford Airport, with blowing and drifting of snow.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: In the wake of another Arctic cold front, gusty northwest winds ushered in a frigid air mass into the region on Monday, February 23rd. Although winds started to diminish on Monday night, wind chill values continued to range between 10 and 24 degrees below zero into the early morning hours on Tuesday, February 24th. ||Although it remained rather cold, wind chill values rose rose above dangerous levels during the day on Tuesday, February 24th.

Behind a rapidly developing coastal storm, an extremely frigid Arctic air mass pour into the region from the north, beginning during the late morning hours on Sunday, February 15th. With the developing storm just east of the region, a strong pressure gradient allowed for very strong winds. Northwest winds frequently gusted over 30 MPH, with some gusts as high as 47 MPH through the evening hours. ||Temperatures fell quickly through the day and dropped below zero for Sunday night into the morning of Monday, February 16th. Some temperatures were as cold as 18 degrees below zero. With winds continuing to be gusty during the overnight and morning hours, wind chill values dropped as low as 15 to 30 degrees below zero. ||With much of the month experiencing cold temperatures, many towns and cities continued to keep warming shelters open. There were many reports of bursts water mains and pipes due to the frigid temperatures penetrating deep into the ground. This was especially true in areas where the infrastructure was older. ||By the afternoon hours on Monday, February 16th, wind chill values finally rose above dangerous levels, although it remained rather cold through the remainder of the day.

Behind a rapidly developing coastal storm, an extremely frigid Arctic air mass pour into the region from the north, beginning during the late morning hours on Sunday, February 15th. With the developing storm just east of the region, a strong pressure gradient allowed for very strong winds. Northwest winds frequently gusted over 30 MPH, with some gusts as high as 47 MPH through the evening hours. ||Temperatures fell quickly through the day and dropped below zero for Sunday night into the morning of Monday, February 16th. Some temperatures were as cold as 18 degrees below zero. With winds continuing to be gusty during the overnight and morning hours, wind chill values dropped as low as 15 to 30 degrees below zero. ||With much of the month experiencing cold temperatures, many towns and cities continued to keep warming shelters open. There were many reports of bursts water mains and pipes due to the frigid temperatures penetrating deep into the ground. This was especially true in areas where the infrastructure was older. ||By the afternoon hours on Monday, February 16th, wind chill values finally rose above dangerous levels, although it remained rather cold through the remainder of the day.

Behind an Arctic cold front, very cold temperatures moved into the region from Canada for the overnight hours between Friday, January 30th and Saturday, January 31st. Temperatures dropped to around zero in many locations, with a few spots in the Litchfield Hills reaching 3 to 7 degrees below zero. ||With gusty northwest winds in place, wind chill values dropped to 10 to 25 degrees below zero during the early morning hours. However, with gusty winds diminishing during the day on Saturday, January 31st, wind chill values improved, although temperatures remained rather frigid through the day.

Behind an arctic cold front, bitter cold air moved into Northwestern Connecticut for the night of Wednesday, January 7th. Overnight lows were between zero and -10 degrees, with the coldest temperatures across high terrain areas in northern parts of Litchfield County. ||With strong northwesterly winds in place, this allowed for winds chill values to be as low as -10 to -30 degrees during the late night hours into the morning hours on Thursday, January 8th.  Many school districts delayed the start of school due to the extremely cold temperatures and low wind chill values.||Although temperatures remained frigid through the day, winds became light, allowing for wind chill values to improve by the late morning hours on Thursday, January 8th.

Behind an Arctic cold front, a frigid air mass moved into northwestern Connecticut on the late evening of Thursday, February 12th into the early morning hours of Friday, February 13th. This very cold air was also accompanied by gusty northwest winds of up to 35 mph. ||During the late night hours, winds continued to be very gusty. With these strong winds and temperatures dropping between zero and -10 degrees, wind chill values were as low as 10 to 30 below zero at times. ||With these cold temperatures and low wind chill values, some schools were delayed on the morning of Friday, February 13th. With the persistent cold weather in place, many towns and cities continued to keep warming shelters open for residents. There were also some reports of frozen pipes and burst water mains, especially in the areas that contained older infrastructure.

Behind an arctic cold front, bitter cold air moved into Northwestern Connecticut for the night of Wednesday, January 7th. Overnight lows were between zero and -10 degrees, with the coldest temperatures across high terrain areas in northern parts of Litchfield County. ||With strong northwesterly winds in place, this allowed for winds chill values to be as low as -10 to -30 degrees during the late night hours into the morning hours on Thursday, January 8th.  Many school districts delayed the start of school due to the extremely cold temperatures and low wind chill values.||Although temperatures remained frigid through the day, winds became light, allowing for wind chill values to improve by the late morning hours on Thursday, January 8th.

A three day period of snowfall impacted all of northwestern Connecticut between February 7th and 9th, 2015. ||The snowfall began on the late morning of Saturday, February 7th, as an Arctic cold front dropped south across the region. Light steady snow fell into the early afternoon hours before tapering off as the front drifted south of the area. Just a coating of snow fell in most areas.||With the frontal boundary stalled just south of the region for Saturday night, a weak disturbance moving along the boundary allowed for some additional snowfall between Saturday night into the early morning of Sunday, February 8th. An additional coating to an inch or two fell across the region.||After a lull in the snowfall for Sunday morning, a steadier and heavier snowfall developed for late Sunday afternoon into Sunday night, as a stronger wave of low pressure moved along the frontal boundary. This snowfall continued through the day Monday, February 9th as the wave of low pressure passed south of the region across the mid-Atlantic states. Snowfall tapered off between late Monday afternoon into Monday evening. ||By the time all of the snow ended, amounts ranged between 6 and 13 inches across the area, with the heaviest amounts in the higher terrain of northern Litchfield County.

A significant and powerful coastal storm impacted the Northeast states on Monday, January 26th through Tuesday, January 27th. Despite the impressive strength of this storm, it remained just far enough away from the region to avoid having a major impact on northwestern Connecticut. While parts of Long Island, New York and eastern New England saw a major blizzard, much of northwestern Connecticut only saw a moderate snowfall. ||Light snowfall began during the afternoon hours on Monday, January 26th. Snowfall lifted from south to north across the Litchfield County and accumulate an inch or two by evening. ||During the overnight hours, a steady light snowfall occurred, especially in eastern parts of Litchfield County, although only a light accumulations occurred by morning. With the forecast calling for a significant event, many school and businesses were closed for Tuesday, January 27th. ||During the daytime on Tuesday, January 27th, a light to moderate snowfall built into the region from the east. Snowfall was even briefly heavy at times. Although traffic was already light due to people avoiding the roadways due to the forecast, many accidents were reported across the region. Snowfall tapered off by the evening hours. ||Snowfall amounts ranged from about 6 to 12 inches across Litchfield County, with the heaviest amounts in far southeastern areas.

An area of low pressure tracked east from the Ohio Valley the night of February 1 to just south of Long Island the afternoon of February 2.  The close proximity of the low with arctic air to the north resulted in snow at the onset, which transitioned to a wintry mix during the morning hours before going back to snow by early afternoon.  Some interior locations remained all snow.  Much of southern Connecticut received 8 to 14 inches of snowfall along with up to two tenths of an inch of ice along the coast.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snowfall ranged from 8 to 12 inches.  The highest amount of 12 inches was reported in New Fairfield.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An area of low pressure tracked east from the Ohio Valley the night of February 1 to just south of Long Island the afternoon of February 2.  The close proximity of the low with arctic air to the north resulted in snow at the onset, which transitioned to a wintry mix during the morning hours before going back to snow by early afternoon.  Some interior locations remained all snow.  Much of southern Connecticut received 8 to 14 inches of snowfall along with up to two tenths of an inch of ice along the coast.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snowfall ranged from 8 to 14 inches along with some light icing along the coast.  The highest amount of 14.3 inches was reported in Weston.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A line of showers and embedded thunderstorms moved across northwestern Connecticut during the early morning hours of Tuesday, April 21st.  Although the thunderstorms weren't considered severe, cloud to ground lightning struck a home built in the 1800s in the town of Cornwall.  The lightning appeared to hit a nearby tree and then traveled through a trench into an addition on the home.  As a result of the strike, a fire occurred and much of the home was damaged before fire fighters could extinguish the fire.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A lightning strike during an early morning thunderstorm struck a home.  The lightning initially hit a nearby tree, with the strike traveling through a trench and into an addition on the home.  A fire occurred, damaging much of the home.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A three day period of snowfall impacted all of northwestern Connecticut between February 7th and 9th, 2015. ||The snowfall began on the late morning of Saturday, February 7th, as an Arctic cold front dropped south across the region. Light steady snow fell into the early afternoon hours before tapering off as the front drifted south of the area. Just a coating of snow fell in most areas.||With the frontal boundary stalled just south of the region for Saturday night, a weak disturbance moving along the boundary allowed for some additional snowfall between Saturday night into the early morning of Sunday, February 8th. An additional coating to an inch or two fell across the region.||After a lull in the snowfall for Sunday morning, a steadier and heavier snowfall developed for late Sunday afternoon into Sunday night, as a stronger wave of low pressure moved along the frontal boundary. This snowfall continued through the day Monday, February 9th as the wave of low pressure passed south of the region across the mid-Atlantic states. Snowfall tapered off between late Monday afternoon into Monday evening. ||By the time all of the snow ended, amounts ranged between 6 and 13 inches across the area, with the heaviest amounts in the higher terrain of northern Litchfield County.

A storm system moved up the eastern seaboard on Sunday, January 18th. Although the precipitation fell in the form of rain, the ground remained very cold due to recent bitter cold, arctic air. With surface air temperatures around the freezing mark, the rain froze on contact with the ground, producing a thin layer of slippery, black ice. Most areas only saw a tenth of an inch of ice accretion, but this ice was very hazardous to travelers. According to local newspapers, numerous accidents were reported, especially in the early morning hours. With the ground extremely cold, freezing rain was even occurring when surface air temperatures were above freezing. ||It took until the mid-afternoon for temperatures to finally warm up enough for freezing rain not to occur. Precipitation also was tapering off by late in the day as well.

An area of low pressure tracked east from the Ohio Valley the night of February 1 to just south of Long Island the afternoon of February 2.  The close proximity of the low with arctic air to the north resulted in snow at the onset, which transitioned to a wintry mix during the morning hours before going back to snow by early afternoon.  Some interior locations remained all snow.  Much of southern Connecticut received 8 to 14 inches of snowfall along with up to two tenths of an inch of ice along the coast.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snowfall ranged from 8 to 12 inches along with some light icing along the coast.  The highest amount of 12 inches was reported in New Haven.

The close proximity of the low with arctic air to the north resulted in snow at the onset, which transitioned to a wintry mix during the morning hours before going back to snow by early afternoon. EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low pressure moved out of the northern Gulf of Mexico on the morning of the 23rd, to the Mid Atlantic coast on the morning of the 24th, then rapidly intensified on its way northeast to the Canadian Maritimes the following day. This low brought heavy snow to most of southwest Connecticut on the 24th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The public and trained spotters measured snowfall of 6 to 7 inches.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low pressure moved out of the northern Gulf of Mexico on the morning of the 23rd, to the Mid Atlantic coast on the morning of the 24th, then rapidly intensified on its way northeast to the Canadian Maritimes the following day. This low brought heavy snow to most of southwest Connecticut on the 24th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Connecticut DOT, the public and trained spotters measured snowfall of 5 to 8 inches. A cooperative observer in Bridgeport measured 5.5 inches of snow.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low pressure moved out of the northern Gulf of Mexico on the morning of the 23rd, to the Mid Atlantic coast on the morning of the 24th, then rapidly intensified on its way northeast to the Canadian Maritimes the following day. This low brought heavy snow to most of southwest Connecticut on the 24th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Connecticut DOT, the public and trained spotters measured widespread snowfall of 6 to 7 inches.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong northwest winds and frigid air in the wake of an intense storm over the Canadian Maritimes combined to produce dangerous wind chills across parts of interior southern Connecticut.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Wind chills fell to 28 degrees below zero at 3 AM at Waterbury-Oxford Airport.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low pressure moving east from the Ohio Valley along a cold front passing slowly to the south brought a long duration winter weather event to interior southern Connecticut.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A trained spotter reported 7 inches of snow in New Fairfield.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low pressure moved out of the northern Gulf of Mexico on the morning of the 23rd, to the Mid Atlantic coast on the morning of the 24th, then rapidly intensified on its way northeast to the Canadian Maritimes the following day. This low brought heavy snow to most of southwest Connecticut on the 24th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The public measured snowfall of 6.3 inches in Middletown.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An arctic cold front moving into southern New England brought rain and snow showers to the region, followed by strong, damaging winds.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Automated Surface Observing System at Bradley International Airport in Windsor Locks (KBDL) recorded sustained winds of 44 mph and gusts of 58 mph.  A tree was downed onto Steele Street near the Lincoln School in New Britain.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An area of low pressure deepened as it tracked to the northeast of the local region resulting in high winds.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A mesonet station around 1 mile east southeast of Neptune Park reported sustained winds of 41 mph at 8:10 am.  At the USCG Academy mesonet station, a wind gust to 54 mph was reported at 11:15 am.  At Groton New London Airport, sustained winds of 38 mph were measured at 10:47 am.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Weak low pressure moving across from the southwest brought locally heavy snow and some ice to parts of southwest Connecticut.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trained spotters, the public, and Connecticut DOT reported snowfall of 5 to 6 inches.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Weak low pressure moving across from the southwest brought locally heavy snow and some ice to parts of southwest Connecticut.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trained spotters, Connecticut DOT, the public, and a cooperative observer in Bridgeport reported snowfall of 4 to 6 inches, plus ice accumulation of 1 to 2 tenths of an inch.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Weak low pressure moving across from the southwest brought locally heavy snow and some ice to parts of southwest Connecticut.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trained spotters and Connecticut DOT reported snowfall of 4 to 7 inches.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low pressure moving east from the Ohio Valley along a cold front passing slowly to the south brought a long duration winter weather event to interior southern Connecticut.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Connecticut DOT reported snowfall of 5.5 inches in Colchester.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low pressure moving east from the Ohio Valley along a cold front passing slowly to the south brought a long duration winter weather event to interior southern Connecticut.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Connecticut DOT, an NWS cooperative observer and a trained spotter reported 6 to 10 inches of snow in the far northern and eastern portions of northern New Haven County, including Waterbury, Wolcott, Meriden, and North Haven. Most of the county however received lesser amounts of 3 to 5 inches.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An area of low pressure deepened as it tracked to the northeast of the local region resulting in high winds.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The public reported a wind gust of 63 mph at 1145 am in the town of Norwalk. The ASOS at Bridgeport Sikorsky Airport measured sustained winds of 36 mph at 1145 am.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An area of low pressure deepened as it tracked to the northeast of the local region resulting in strong winds.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A mesonet station around 2 miles south southeast of New Haven reported a wind gust to 54 mph at 8:36 am.  The ASOS at New Haven Tweed Airport measured a wind gust to 50 mph at 10:37 am.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Weak low pressure moving across from the southwest brought locally heavy snow and some ice to parts of southwest Connecticut.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Connecticut DOT and trained spotters reported snowfall of 4 to 6 inches. New Haven ASOS also reported 0.05 inches of ice accumulation.

Most areas only saw a tenth of an inch of ice accretion, but this ice was very hazardous to travelers. According to local newspapers, numerous accidents were reported, especially in the early morning hours. Weak low pressure approaching from the Ohio Valley brought heavy snow to much of Southern Connecticut.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trained spotters and the public reported 5 to 8 inches of snow.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trained spotters, Connecticut DOT, and the public reported snowfall mostly between 4 and 5 inches. Some areas, including North Haven, Hamden, Oxford and Southbury, received 6 to 7 inches of snow.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Connecticut DOT reported 6.5 inches of snow in Haddam.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Most Connecticut DOT and trained spotter observations indicated snowfall of 4 to 5 inches, with the highest amount of 5.5 inches in Colchester.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Ahead of an approaching cold front, a warm and humid air mass was in place over northwestern Connecticut on Tuesday, May 19th.  As the cold front approached during the early evening hours, a few scattered showers and thunderstorms developed and moved from west to east across the region.  Some of the thunderstorms became severe, producing damaging winds to trees and power lines.  In addition, two of the thunderstorms produced damaging lightning strikes as well.  ||The threat for thunderstorms ended by the late evening hours, as the cold front passed through the region and drier air moved into the area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Wires were reported down at the intersection of Amenia Road and Sharon Valley Road in Sharon due to thunderstorm winds.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Ahead of an approaching cold front, a warm and humid air mass was in place over northwestern Connecticut on Tuesday, May 19th.  As the cold front approached during the early evening hours, a few scattered showers and thunderstorms developed and moved from west to east across the region.  Some of the thunderstorms became severe, producing damaging winds to trees and power lines.  In addition, two of the thunderstorms produced damaging lightning strikes as well.  ||The threat for thunderstorms ended by the late evening hours, as the cold front passed through the region and drier air moved into the area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A tree was reported down on Amenia Union Road in Sharon due to thunderstorm winds.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low pressure off the Delmarva peninsula intensified rapidly as it moved northeastward.  Its path just southeast of Nantucket brought heavy snow to all of southern New England and blizzard conditions and coastal flooding to coastal areas.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Two to five inches of snow fell across Hartford County.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low pressure off the Delmarva peninsula intensified rapidly as it moved northeastward.  Its path just southeast of Nantucket brought heavy snow to all of southern New England and blizzard conditions and coastal flooding to coastal areas.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Four to nine inches of snow fell across Tolland County.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Five to nine inches of snow fell across Windham County.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Ahead of an approaching cold front, a warm and humid air mass was in place over northwestern Connecticut on Tuesday, May 19th.  As the cold front approached during the early evening hours, a few scattered showers and thunderstorms developed and moved from west to east across the region.  Some of the thunderstorms became severe, producing damaging winds to trees and power lines.  In addition, two of the thunderstorms produced damaging lightning strikes as well.  ||The threat for thunderstorms ended by the late evening hours, as the cold front passed through the region and drier air moved into the area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trees were reported down on Cornwall Bridge Road near Butter Road in Sharon due to thunderstorm winds.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Rain associated with a wave of low pressure moving along a cold front to the south changed to snow before sunrise on March 5, and became heavy across portions of Southern Connecticut.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: An emergency manager, the public, broadcast media, and Connecticut DOT all reported snowfall of 5 to 7 inches.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Rain associated with a wave of low pressure moving along a cold front to the south changed to snow before sunrise on March 5, and became heavy across portions of Southern Connecticut.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trained spotters reported snowfall of 8 inches in Gales Ferry, and 9 inches in Ledyard Center. Connecticut DOT reported snowfall of 5.4 inches in Norwich.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Rain associated with a wave of low pressure moving along a cold front to the south changed to snow before sunrise on March 5, and became heavy across portions of Southern Connecticut.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trained spotters reported snowfall of 7 to 8 inches.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong northwest winds occurred behind a cold front.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A 33 mph sustained wind was measured at Bridgeport Sikorsky Airport at 2:52 pm.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong northwest winds occurred behind a cold front.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A 32 mph sustained wind was measured at Groton New London Airport at 1:56 pm.  A trained spotter in New London reported a light pole snapped and wires were downed at the corner of Route 184 and Packer Road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong winds were observed behind a cold front.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A wind gust of 53 mph was observed at Groton New London Airport at 5:57 pm.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low pressure and a cold front moved across Southern New England. This drew strong gusty northwest winds across the region during the late morning and afternoon.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Automated Surface Observation System at Bradley International Airport (KBDL) recorded sustained winds of 38 mph and gusts to 49 mph.  A tree fell on two cars in a driveway on Russet Lane in Southington. Another tree fell on a car on West Mountain Road in Simsbury.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Rain associated with a wave of low pressure moving along a cold front to the south changed to snow before sunrise on March 5, and became heavy across portions of Southern Connecticut.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A trained spotter measured 6.4 inches of snowfall in New Canaan. Connecticut DOT also measured 6.3 inches of snow in Darien.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Rain associated with a wave of low pressure moving along a cold front to the south changed to snow before sunrise on March 5, and became heavy across portions of Southern Connecticut.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: While most of the area received 3 to 5 inches of snow, 5.5 inches of snowfall was measured in Milford.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A potent Alberta Clipper low moved from southwestern Canada on January 24th to the Plains states and Ohio Valley on the 25th. The low then redeveloped off the Mid Atlantic coast on the 26th and rapidly intensified into a strong nor'easter, bringing heavy snow and strong winds to Southern Connecticut, with blizzard conditions in New London County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Nearby Willimantic Airport experienced blizzard conditions, with 1/4 mile visibility in heavy snow and north winds gusting frequently over 35 mph, from about 630 AM until about 930 AM.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A fast moving low pressure system skirted the south coasts of Massachusetts and Rhode Island, bringing accumulating snow to much of southern New England.  The greatest snow amounts fell in these areas, though snow overspread much of the region.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Two to five inches of snow fell across Hartford County.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A fast moving low pressure system skirted the south coasts of Massachusetts and Rhode Island, bringing accumulating snow to much of southern New England.  The greatest snow amounts fell in these areas, though snow overspread much of the region.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Four to seven inches of snow fell across Tolland County.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: With high pressure situated just off the eastern seaboard, a southerly flow allowed for a very warm and humid air mass to move into northwestern Connecticut. Temperatures reached well into the 80s F with dewpoint temperatures into the 60s F as well. An approaching upper level disturbance, aided by a surface pre-frontal trough, allowed thunderstorms to develop in the afternoon over eastern New York and spread into Litchfield County Connecticut during the early evening hours. Although instability was limited due to areas of cloud cover in place, thunderstorms were able to organize into lines. As a result, one of these thunderstorms became severe, producing damaging winds.||As the upper level disturbance and surface trough moved away, the threat for thunderstorms ended later in the evening, as thunderstorm pushed further east into New England.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Wires were reported down one mile north of West Cornwall due to thunderstorm winds.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A potent Alberta Clipper low moved from southwestern Canada on January 24th to the Plains states and Ohio Valley on the 25th. The low then redeveloped off the Mid Atlantic coast on the 26th and rapidly intensified into a strong nor'easter, bringing heavy snow and strong winds to Southern Connecticut, with blizzard conditions in New London County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The public, trained spotters, Connecticut DOT, and NWS cooperative observers reported snowfall of 6 to 14 inches. North winds gusted up to 43 mph at Sikorsky Airport in Bridgeport, with blowing and drifting of snow.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A potent Alberta Clipper low moved from southwestern Canada on January 24th to the Plains states and Ohio Valley on the 25th. The low then redeveloped off the Mid Atlantic coast on the 26th and rapidly intensified into a strong nor'easter, bringing heavy snow and strong winds to Southern Connecticut, with blizzard conditions in New London County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trained spotters, Connecticut DOT, and the public reported snowfall of 14 to 21 inches. North winds gusted up to 45 mph at nearby Groton-New London Airport, with blowing and drifting of snow.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A potent Alberta Clipper low moved from southwestern Canada on January 24th to the Plains states and Ohio Valley on the 25th. The low then redeveloped off the Mid Atlantic coast on the 26th and rapidly intensified into a strong nor'easter, bringing heavy snow and strong winds to Southern Connecticut, with blizzard conditions in New London County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trained spotters reported snowfall of 16 to 24 inches. North winds gusted up to 45 mph at Groton-New London Airport, with blowing and drifting of snow.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front moving across southern New England combined with high precipitable waters and weak flow aloft to initiate showers and thunderstorms that produced flooding and pockets of flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Lower Lane area of Berlin experienced localized flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A warm front moved northward across northwestern Connecticut during the morning hours on Tuesday, June 23rd. Behind this front, a warm and humid air mass moved into the region. As clouds gave way to partial sunshine, the atmosphere became unstable for the afternoon hours. As an advancing cold front moved towards the region from upstate New York, some scattered thunderstorms developed between the late afternoon and early evening hours. A few of these thunderstorms became severe, producing wind damage to trees.  In addition, one of the thunderstorms produced a funnel cloud in Litchfield. ||As the cold front moved across the region, the threat for thunderstorms ended later in the evening, as a cooler and less humid air mass moved into the area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A trained spotter reported a funnel cloud during a thunderstorm in Litchfield.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trees were reported down and on wires on Blue Street in Winchester due to thunderstorm winds.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A fast moving low pressure system skirted the south coasts of Massachusetts and Rhode Island, bringing accumulating snow to much of southern New England.  The greatest snow amounts fell in these areas, though snow overspread much of the region.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Four to six inches of snow fell across Windham County.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An arctic cold front moving into southern New England brought rain and snow showers to the region, followed by strong, damaging winds.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Wires were downed on Valley View Road in Woodstock.  In Putnam, Route 44 was closed at Route 21 because of a tree downed onto wires.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Nearby Groton-New London Airport experienced blizzard conditions, with 1/4 mile visibility in heavy snow and north winds gusting frequently over 35 mph, from about 4 AM until about 9 AM.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An approaching cold front triggered a cluster of severe thunderstorm producing multiple macrobursts that impacted Southern Connecticut.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A tree fell and crushed a car on West Wooster Street in Danbury.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An approaching cold front triggered a cluster of severe thunderstorm producing multiple macrobursts that impacted Southern Connecticut.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several trees were reported down on Park Avenue near the Danbury Field Mall.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An approaching cold front triggered a cluster of severe thunderstorm producing multiple macrobursts that impacted Southern Connecticut.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A 61 mph wind gust was measured by the Stonington Outer Breakwater Mesonet Location.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An approaching cold front triggered a cluster of severe thunderstorm producing multiple macrobursts that impacted Southern Connecticut.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A tree fell on a car along Flanders Road, near U. S. Route 1. The driver, and sole occupant of the vehicle, was killed.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A passing cold front triggered multiple severe thunderstorms across the entirety of Southern Connecticut.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Multiple trees and power lines were reported down along Pool Road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A passing cold front triggered some isolated severe thunderstorms, bringing damaging wind gusts and large hail to Fairfield County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Numerous trees were reported down in the town of Ridgefield.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A warm front moved north across southern New England resulting in showers and a few thunderstorms. One of these storms caused some tree damage in Simsbury.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A tree on Hopmeadow Street was downed by thunderstorm winds.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A passing triple point low triggered a gustnado over Milford.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A gustnado moved onshore near Milford.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A wave of low pressure riding along a cold front stalled just south of Long Island.  It  brought heavy rain and isolated flash flooding to New London County, Connecticut.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Cars were stranded on Water Street in New London due to flash flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A wave of low pressure riding along a cold front stalled just south of Long Island.  It  brought heavy rain and isolated flash flooding to New London County, Connecticut.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Bank Street was closed due to flash flooding in New London.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A wave of low pressure riding along a cold front stalled just south of Long Island.  It  brought heavy rain and isolated flash flooding to New London County, Connecticut.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A roadway collapse was reported on Mullen Hill Road between Ellen Ward Road and Gallup Lane in Manitock Spring.  Storm total rainfall from the Groton Airport ASOS was 2.53 inches.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong cold front passed through northwestern Connecticut during the early evening hours on Tuesday, July 21st.  A line of showers and thunderstorms accompanied this front as it moved from west to east across the region.  One of these thunderstorms became severe, producing damaging winds in the town of New Milford.  A downed tree fell on a car, injuring the two occupants.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A tree was downed due to thunderstorm winds on Still River Drive in New Milford.  The downed tree fell on a car, injuring the two occupants, who had to be extricated from the vehicle.  The road was closed for a brief time due to the downed tree as well.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: High pressure over Quebec allowed for cold air to move into southern New England at the surface.  At the same time, low pressure passed south of southern New England, allowing warm air to move in above the surface.  This did not occur in the timing ideal for a significant ice storm, but instead produced a mix of snow, sleet, freezing rain, and rain across southern New England.  The most significant of this was some light icing that occurred mostly in the Connecticut and Merrimack River valleys.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Less than a tenth of an inch of ice accretion was reported in Somers with a mix of snow, sleet, and freezing rain.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: High pressure over Quebec allowed for cold air to move into southern New England at the surface.  At the same time, low pressure passed south of southern New England, allowing warm air to move in above the surface.  This did not occur in the timing ideal for a significant ice storm, but instead produced a mix of snow, sleet, freezing rain, and rain across southern New England.  The most significant of this was some light icing that occurred mostly in the Connecticut and Merrimack River valleys.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Freezing rain and freezing drizzle occurred intermittently at Bradley International Airport during this time, mixing with sleet at times.  An eighth of an inch of ice accretion occurred on exposed surfaces during this time.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: On the morning of Saturday, August 13th, a warm front lifted northward across the region. This allowed a very warm and excessively humid air mass to be in place over the area. As temperatures rose through the 80s and into the 90s, dewpoints were unusually high in the mid to upper 70s. By the afternoon hours, this produced heat index values over 100 degrees in many valley areas, with some spots in southern Litchfield County seeing heat index values over 105 degrees.||Ahead of an advancing cold front, an organized line of thunderstorms moved from west to east across all of eastern Upstate New York late in the day.   This line of thunderstorms crossed northwestern Connecticut during the late evening hours, producing damaging winds.||In addition to the gusty winds, the thunderstorms also produced a significant amount of cloud-to-ground lightning. Numerous power outages were reported throughout the region. ||Thunderstorms ended with the passage of the cold front during the overnight hours.

With a southerly flow in place, a warm and humid air mass continued to be in place on Sunday, August 14th.  With temperatures well into the 90s and dewpoints reaching around 70 degrees, heat index values exceeded 100 degrees during the afternoon and early evening hours across southern Litchfield County.

Daytime temperatures were well into the 90s and dewpoints reached into the low to mid 70s. As a result, heat index values reached around 100 degrees for valley areas during the afternoon and early evening hours.

On the morning of Saturday, August 13th, a warm front lifted northward across the region. This allowed a very warm and excessively humid air mass to be in place over the area. As temperatures rose through the 80s and into the 90s, dewpoints were unusually high in the mid to upper 70s. EPISODE_NARRATIVE: In December, rainfall throughout much of northern Connecticut was below normal. This ranged from near normal at Storrs in Tolland County to near three-quarters of an inch below normal at Windsor Locks in Northern Hartford County.  Most places were between four-tenths and five-tenths below normal.||The Connecticut Department of Public Health (DPH) continued a Drought Watch for Hartford and Tolland Counties in Northern Connecticut and a Drought Advisory for Windham County. Voluntary water conservation and adherence to any local water restrictions were encouraged.  The DPH indicated the average percent of usable|storage within the State���s reservoirs was at 68.9 percent. This was below normal, but an improvement from November.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The U.S. Drought Monitor had Hartford County under Extreme Drought (D3) conditions through the month.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An arctic cold front moved across New England Thursday afternoon and evening followed by strong northwest winds and cold air.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Winds brought a tree down on a house in Granby.  Shortly before this, winds at Bradley Airport in Windsor Locks gusted to 38 mph.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong low pressure in the Gulf of Maine combined with approaching high pressure to develop a very strong pressure gradient over southern New England.  This resulted in strong, sometimes damaging winds across the region.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Route 12 was closed in Killingly between Attawaugan Crossing Road and Soap Street due to downed wires.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low pressure intensified as it moved off the coast of North Carolina and tracked northeastward, passing south of southern New England.  This brought accumulating snow to areas south of Interstate 90 in Massachusetts, including Connecticut and Rhode Island.  In addition, strong, damaging winds accompanied the snow.  With bare trees, there was remarkably little damage associated with winds that gusted near hurricane force at times.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: One to nine inches of snow fell across Hartford County with the highest amounts across the southern portion of the county.

This brought accumulating snow to areas south of Interstate 90 in Massachusetts, including Connecticut and Rhode Island.  In addition, strong, damaging winds accompanied the snow. EVENT_NARRATIVE: Two to ten inches of snow fell across Tolland County with the highest amounts falling in the southern portion of the county.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Three to ten inches of snow fell across Windham County with the highest amounts falling across the southern portion of the county.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low pressure traveling along a cold front stalled south of southern New England brought heavy rain, which changed over to heavy snow as temperatures dropped.  This snow was extraordinarily wet and heavy, bringing down trees and wires across portions of southern New England.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Five to ten inches of snow fell across Hartford County.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low pressure traveling along a cold front stalled south of southern New England brought heavy rain, which changed over to heavy snow as temperatures dropped.  This snow was extraordinarily wet and heavy, bringing down trees and wires across portions of southern New England.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Nine to thirteen inches of snow fell across Tolland County.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low pressure traveling along a cold front stalled south of southern New England brought heavy rain, which changed over to heavy snow as temperatures dropped.  This snow was extraordinarily wet and heavy, bringing down trees and wires across portions of southern New England.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Six to thirteen inches of snow fell across Windham County.  In addition, the heavy snow downed numerous trees throughout Killingly and Plainfield.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A very powerful low pressure system tracked up the east coast, passing southeast of Southern New England.  This storm brought heavy snow and gusty winds, resulting in blizzard conditions along the Massachusetts east coast.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Three to five inches of snow fell across Hartford County.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A very powerful low pressure system tracked up the east coast, passing southeast of Southern New England.  This storm brought heavy snow and gusty winds, resulting in blizzard conditions along the Massachusetts east coast.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Three to five inches of snow fell across Tolland County.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A very powerful low pressure system tracked up the east coast, passing southeast of Southern New England.  This storm brought heavy snow and gusty winds, resulting in blizzard conditions along the Massachusetts east coast.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Three to eight inches of snow fell across Windham County.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A powerful area of low pressure was located well off the eastern seaboard on the morning of Monday, February 8th.  As this storm lifted northeast, the steadiest and heaviest snowfall from this system impacted much of eastern New England. However, some of the snowfall extended back into parts of western New England for the afternoon and evening hours.  Three to 6 inches of snow occurred across Litchfield County, before snowfall tapered off by the late evening hours.

Low pressure tracked north through New York bringing a warm front through southern New England.  Unseasonably deep moisture accompanied this front.  This was a very complicated weather situation as a strong low level inversion was in place over the area with a very strong low level jet just above the inversion.  As showers and thunderstorms developed, the storms and heavy rain allowed the stronger winds to mix down to the surface.  In other areas, temperatures warmed enough at the surface to break the inversion and allow the stronger winds to mix down.  This resulted in a complicated combination of severe thunderstorm winds and high winds.  To add to the historical nature of this event, it occurred in February all during the overnight hours.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A tree and wires on the George Washington Turnpike were downed by thunderstorm winds.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Multiple trees and wires were downed on Turnpike Road and Deerfield Road in Somers.

This resulted in a complicated combination of severe thunderstorm winds and high winds.  To add to the historical nature of this event, it occurred in February all during the overnight hours.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Automated Surface Observing System at Hartford-Brainard Airport (KHFD) recorded sustained wind speeds of 44 mph and gusts to 68 mph.  These winds were associated with a passing thunderstorm.  No damage was reported.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low pressure tracked north through New York bringing a warm front through southern New England.  Unseasonably deep moisture accompanied this front.  This was a very complicated weather situation as a strong low level inversion was in place over the area with a very strong low level jet just above the inversion.  As showers and thunderstorms developed, the storms and heavy rain allowed the stronger winds to mix down to the surface.  In other areas, temperatures warmed enough at the surface to break the inversion and allow the stronger winds to mix down.  This resulted in a complicated combination of severe thunderstorm winds and high winds.  To add to the historical nature of this event, it occurred in February all during the overnight hours.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trees and wires were downed throughout South Windsor.  Several roads were closed due to this damage, including:  Ellington Road between Pierce Road and Deming Street and Niederwerfer Road at the East Windsor town line.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A powerful area of low pressure was located well off the eastern seaboard on the morning of Monday, February 8th.  As this storm lifted northeast, the steadiest and heaviest snowfall from this system impacted much of eastern New England. However, some of the snowfall extended back into parts of western New England for the afternoon and evening hours.  Three to 6 inches of snow occurred across Litchfield County, before snowfall tapered off by the late evening hours.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low pressure developed and intensified along the east coast of the United States, passing well southeast of Nantucket.  This resulted in heavy, wet snow overspreading much of southern New England.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: One to five inches of snow fell across Hartford County.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low pressure developed and intensified along the east coast of the United States, passing well southeast of Nantucket.  This resulted in heavy, wet snow overspreading much of southern New England.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Three to seven inches of snow fell across Tolland County.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low pressure developed and intensified along the east coast of the United States, passing well southeast of Nantucket.  This resulted in heavy, wet snow overspreading much of southern New England.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Two to four inches of snow fell across Windham County.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level disturbance coupled with cold air aloft and moving into southern New England set off a complicated mix of showers and thunderstorms and non-convective winds. All efforts were made to separate out the non-convective winds from the thunderstorm winds.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Wires and a transformer were downed on Stoughton Road in East Windsor.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level disturbance coupled with cold air aloft and moving into southern New England set off a complicated mix of showers and thunderstorms and non-convective winds. All efforts were made to separate out the non-convective winds from the thunderstorm winds.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: An oak tree was snapped on Robin Circle in Tolland.  Large pine trees were downed on Anderson and Goose Lane in Tolland.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Arctic high pressure brought strong northwest winds and extremely cold wind chills to southern New England. Many locations reported wind chills between 25 and 35 degrees below zero.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Wind chills as low as 32 below zero were reported at Bradley International Airport in Windsor Locks.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong area of low pressure was located over the Ohio Valley on Wednesday, February 24th and the storm headed northeast towards the region. A warm front extended out of this storm, allowing for periods of rainfall during the day Wednesday, February 24th and into the evening hours. As the warm front passed through the region during the overnight hours, temperatures became quite mild for late February reaching into the 50s and 60s, despite it being in the middle of the night. In addition, thunderstorms ahead of the storm's cold front moved from the mid-Atlantic states up towards northwestern Connecticut. ||The thunderstorms produced a period of very heavy rainfall during the late evening and into the overnight hours. Rainfall fell at rates exceeding one inch per hour at times. This rainfall, combined with a frozen ground in places and some snow melt in mountainous areas, allowed for widespread flooding of urban, poor drainage and low lying areas. Some main stem rivers reached minor flood stage as well.||In addition, the narrow line of thunderstorms became severe over the Litchfield Hills, producing damaging wind gusts.||The passage of the storm's cold front during the early morning hours of Thursday, February 25th ended the threat for severe thunderstorms and heavy rainfall. Some additional rainfall during the day on Thursday, February 25th allowed the receding of water of flooded areas to be slow to occur.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trees and wires were downed on Forest Avenue in Winchester due to thunderstorm winds.  The downed trees and wires were blocking the roadway..

Some additional rainfall during the day on Thursday, February 25th allowed the receding of water of flooded areas to be slow to occur.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A tree was downed on West Wakefield Boulevard due to thunderstorm winds in Winsted.  The tree was blocking the roadway.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An area of low pressure moved northeast along the mid Atlantic Coast towards the coast of Cape Cod on the morning of Friday, February 5th.   Although this system tracked well east of the region, the back side of the storm system allowed for a period to light to moderate snowfall to occur across northwestern Connecticut during the morning hours.  Two to 5 inches of snowfall occurred across Litchfield County, with the highest amounts in eastern areas.

Behind an Arctic cold front, very cold temperatures poured into the region upon brisk northwesterly winds.  Temperatures dropped through the day on Saturday, February 13th, reaching lows of 5 to 20 degrees below zero across northwestern Connecticut on Saturday Night.  Along with winds gusting 20 to 35 MPH, wind chill values reached 15 to 40 degrees below zero Saturday Night into Sunday morning.||With temperatures warming up and winds diminishing, the threat for dangerously cold temperatures and low wind chills ended on the afternoon hours of Sunday, February 14th.

Behind an Arctic cold front, very cold temperatures poured into the region upon brisk northwesterly winds.  Temperatures dropped through the day on Saturday, February 13th, reaching lows of 5 to 20 degrees below zero across northwestern Connecticut on Saturday Night.  Along with winds gusting 20 to 35 MPH, wind chill values reached 15 to 40 degrees below zero Saturday Night into Sunday morning.||With temperatures warming up and winds diminishing, the threat for dangerously cold temperatures and low wind chills ended on the afternoon hours of Sunday, February 14th.

An upper level disturbance coupled with cold air aloft and moving into southern New England set off a complicated mix of showers and thunderstorms and non-convective winds. All efforts were made to separate out the non-convective winds from the thunderstorm winds.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A large tree limb was downed onto Higley Street in Granby by thunderstorm winds.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low pressure approaching from the west brought warm air advection over an anomalously cold air mass at the surface.  This resulted in another round of early April snow across much of southern New England.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Three to six inches of snow fell across Tolland County.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low pressure approaching from the west brought warm air advection over an anomalously cold air mass at the surface.  This resulted in another round of early April snow across much of southern New England.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Three to seven inches of snow fell across Windham County.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low pressure approaching from the west brought warm air advection over an anomalously cold air mass at the surface.  This resulted in another round of early April snow across much of southern New England.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Two to six inches of snow fell across Hartford County.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low pressure moving across the deep South on Thursday January 21st and Friday January 22nd intensifed and moved off the Mid Atlantic coast on Saturday January 23rd, bringing heavy snow and strong winds to all of southern Connecticut, and blizzard conditions to some coastal locations.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Bridgeport ASOS (KBDR) reported blizzard conditions for 3 consecutive hours.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low pressure moving across the deep South on Thursday January 21st and Friday January 22nd intensifed and moved off the Mid Atlantic coast on Saturday January 23rd, bringing heavy snow and strong winds to all of southern Connecticut, and blizzard conditions to some coastal locations.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trained spotters, the public, and Connecticut DOT reported heavy snowfall totals ranging from 9 to 16 inches. Winds gusted to 52 mph in New Haven ASOS (KHVN), with near blizzard conditions from 9 AM until 9 PM.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low pressure moving across the deep South on Thursday January 21st and Friday January 22nd intensifed and moved off the Mid Atlantic coast on Saturday January 23rd, bringing heavy snow and strong winds to all of southern Connecticut, and blizzard conditions to some coastal locations.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The public and Connecticut DOT reported snowfall ranging from 7 to 8 inches. Groton ASOS (KGON) reported near blizzard conditions from 9 AM until 5 PM, where winds also gusted to 45 mph. The U.S. Coast Guard Academy in New London reported strong northerly winds sustained at 39 mph and gusting to 50 mph between 9 PM and 10 PM. An automated weather station at Stonington also reported strong northeast winds,  sustained at 33 mph at 10:10 AM, and gusting to 45 mph at 12:40 PM.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low pressure moving across the deep South on Thursday January 21st and Friday January 22nd intensifed and moved off the Mid Atlantic coast on Saturday January 23rd, bringing heavy snow and strong winds to all of southern Connecticut, and blizzard conditions to some coastal locations.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trained spotters, and Connecticut DOT reported heavy snowfall totals ranging from 6 to 14 inches. Near blizzard conditions occurred at Oxbury ASOS (KOXC) from 9 AM until 8 PM, and at Meriden ASOS (KMMK) from 12 PM until 9 PM.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low pressure moving across the deep South on Thursday January 21st and Friday January 22nd intensifed and moved off the Mid Atlantic coast on Saturday January 23rd, bringing heavy snow and strong winds to all of southern Connecticut, and blizzard conditions to some coastal locations.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trained spotters and amateur radio operators reported snowfall ranging from 7 to 16 inches. Chester ASOS (KSNC) reported near blizzard conditions from 9 AM until 10 PM.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low pressure moving across the deep South on Thursday January 21st and Friday January 22nd intensifed and moved off the Mid Atlantic coast on Saturday January 23rd, bringing heavy snow and strong winds to all of southern Connecticut, and blizzard conditions to some coastal locations.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Connecticut DOT reported 6.7 inches of snow at Old Saybrook. Nearby Chester ASOS (KSNC) reported near blizzard conditions from 9 AM until 10 PM.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low pressure moving across the deep South on Thursday January 21st and Friday January 22nd intensifed and moved off the Mid Atlantic coast on Saturday January 23rd, bringing heavy snow and strong winds to all of southern Connecticut, and blizzard conditions to some coastal locations.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The public and Connecticut DOT reported snowfall ranging from 5 to 14 inches. Nearby Groton ASOS (KGON) reported near blizzard conditions from 9 AM until 5 PM.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An intensifying clipper low pressure system passed north of southern New England, bringing an arctic cold front through the area. This resulted in snow across much of the region and strong, damaging winds near the coast. Unseasonably cold weather then spread across southern New England.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A 24-30 inch diameter tree was downed by strong winds onto wires on Russwin Road in New Britain.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low pressure developed along the southern mid atlantic coast on the evening of the 23rd and then rapidly intensified as it slowly tracked northeast, south of Long Island, through the night of the 24th. The resulting surge from 36 hours of gale to storm force north to northeast winds, combined with high astronomical tides, resulted in areas of minor to localized moderate coastal flooding along western Long Island Sound during the morning of January 23rd.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Minor to moderate flooding was reported in coastal Westport, Connecticut on Saturday morning January 23rd. The Saugatuck River peaked at 6.39' NAVD88, which was about 3 feet of surge above the tide.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: High winds occurred behind a warm front and ahead of a cold front.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A wind gust up to 58 mph was measured at Bridgeport Sikorsky Airport at 1059 pm.|In the town of Greenwich, a trained spotter reported construction fencing was blown across the road at the intersection of Mason Street and Havemeyer Place at 1113 pm.|Near Norwalk, a WeatherFlow station measured a wind gust up to 61 mph at 1225 am on the 25th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong winds occurred behind a warm front and ahead of a cold front.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: In Danbury at 1124 pm, wires were knocked down on Shelter Rock Road between Jansen Street and Cross Street. Around 1126 pm in Bethel, there were multiple reports of trees and wires down along Walnut Hill Road, Putnam Park Road, South Street and Chestnut Street according to emergency management.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong winds occurred behind deepening low pressure.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: An oak tree was reported down in a front yard of a home near North Street and Minosa Circle in Ridgefield at 9 pm. At 1229 am, a wind gust up to 53 mph was measured near Stamford at a mesonet site.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low pressure moving across the deep South on Thursday January 21st and Friday January 22nd intensifed and moved off the Mid Atlantic coast on Saturday January 23rd, bringing heavy snow and strong winds to all of southern Connecticut, and blizzard conditions to some coastal locations.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The public reported heavy snowfall totals ranging from 13 to 16 inches. Connecticut DOT in New Canaan measured 15 inches, and Bridgeport Airport measured 9.5 inches.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low pressure moving across the deep South on Thursday January 21st and Friday January 22nd intensifed and moved off the Mid Atlantic coast on Saturday January 23rd, bringing heavy snow and strong winds to all of southern Connecticut, and blizzard conditions to some coastal locations.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The public, trained spotters, and Connecticut DOT reported heavy snowfall totals ranging from 6 to 14 inches. Danbury ASOS (KDXR) reported near blizzard conditions from 9 AM to 1 PM.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An intensifying clipper low pressure system passed north of southern New England, bringing an arctic cold front through the area. This resulted in snow across much of the region and strong, damaging winds near the coast. Unseasonably cold weather then spread across southern New England.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: One to five inches of snow fell across Hartford County.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low pressure tracking toward southern New England tapped into a plume of tropical moisture and produced torrential rainfall over northeast Connecticut and especially across adjacent portions of central Massachusetts in the matter of a few hours. This resulted in flooding in parts of Windham County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Two to three inches of rain fell within a few hours time and produced significant urban flooding in parts of Windham County. In Woodstock, the basement of Woodstock Elementary School was flooded with about a foot of water. In Plainfield, Railroad Avenue at Church Street was flooded and impassable. Sections of Cemetery Road and South Street were closed due to flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An intensifying clipper low pressure system passed north of southern New England, bringing an arctic cold front through the area. This resulted in snow across much of the region and strong, damaging winds near the coast. Unseasonably cold weather then spread across southern New England.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Two to six inches of snow fell across Tolland County.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An intensifying clipper low pressure system passed north of southern New England, bringing an arctic cold front through the area. This resulted in snow across much of the region and strong, damaging winds near the coast. Unseasonably cold weather then spread across southern New England.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Three to five inches of snow fell across Windham County.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A passing cold front triggered severe thunderstorms across Southern Connecticut.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A tree was reported down on a house on Lockwood Road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A passing cold front triggered severe thunderstorms across Southern Connecticut.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Multiple tree limbs and power lines were reported down across the Town of Middletown.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A passing cold front triggered severe thunderstorms across Southern Connecticut.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Multiple trees and power lines were reported down throughout Durham.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A passing cold front triggered severe thunderstorms across Southern Connecticut.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A gust of 61 mph was measured at the Norwalk Light mesonet location.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A passing cold front triggered severe thunderstorms across Southern Connecticut.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Multiple trees and power lines were reported down throughout the city of New Haven.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A passing cold front triggered severe thunderstorms across Southern Connecticut.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Multiple trees and power lines were reported down in the town of Salem.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong winds occurred ahead of an area of low pressure and associated frontal boundary.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A trained spotter reported a tree down across wires in Reservoir Road in Yantic. A wind gust to 52 mph was measured at Groton Airport at 412 pm.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong winds occurred ahead of an area of low pressure and associated frontal boundary.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trained spotters reported trees and wires down on Main Street Route 138 in Voluntown at 315 pm, and trees and wires down on Hemlock Road near Pachaug at 357 pm.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong winds occurred ahead of an area of low pressure and associated frontal boundary.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A measured wind gust to 52 mph occurred at Bridgeport Sikorsky Airport at 352 pm. A mesonet reported a wind gust of 50 mph near Norwalk at 250 pm, and 52 mph near Fairfield at 346 pm.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low pressure developing along a cold front moving through the region on Thursday February 4th moved off the southern Mid Atlantic coast on Friday February 5th, bringing heavy snow to southern Connecticut on the fifth.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Connecticut DOT and trained spotter reports indicated 5 to 8 inches of snowfall.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An intensifying offshore storm passed close enough on Monday February 8th to bring locally heavy snow to parts of southern CT.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trained spotters and the public reported a widespread 4 to 5 inch snowfall, with locally up to 7 inches at New Fairfield.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An intensifying offshore storm passed close enough on Monday February 8th to bring locally heavy snow to parts of southern CT.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trained spotters, Connecticut DOT, and the public reported a 4 to 6 inch snowfall.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An intensifying offshore storm passed close enough on Monday February 8th to bring locally heavy snow to parts of southern CT.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trained spotters and Connecticut DOT, and the public reported a widespread 3 to 5 inch snowfall, with locally up to 6 inches in New Haven.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: In December, rainfall throughout much of northern Connecticut was below normal. This ranged from near normal at Storrs in Tolland County to near three-quarters of an inch below normal at Windsor Locks in Northern Hartford County.  Most places were between four-tenths and five-tenths below normal.||The Connecticut Department of Public Health (DPH) continued a Drought Watch for Hartford and Tolland Counties in Northern Connecticut and a Drought Advisory for Windham County. Voluntary water conservation and adherence to any local water restrictions were encouraged.  The DPH indicated the average percent of usable|storage within the State���s reservoirs was at 68.9 percent. This was below normal, but an improvement from November.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The U.S. Drought Monitor had most of Tolland County in Severe Drought (D2) through the month, with Extreme Drought (D3) in the far northwest portion of the county.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: In December, rainfall throughout much of northern Connecticut was below normal. This ranged from near normal at Storrs in Tolland County to near three-quarters of an inch below normal at Windsor Locks in Northern Hartford County.  Most places were between four-tenths and five-tenths below normal.||The Connecticut Department of Public Health (DPH) continued a Drought Watch for Hartford and Tolland Counties in Northern Connecticut and a Drought Advisory for Windham County. Voluntary water conservation and adherence to any local water restrictions were encouraged.  The DPH indicated the average percent of usable|storage within the State���s reservoirs was at 68.9 percent. This was below normal, but an improvement from November.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The U.S. Drought Monitor had the western one-third of Windham County in Severe Drought (D2) through the month.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A passing cold front triggered an isolated severe thunderstorm in Fairfield County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Multiple trees were reported down throughout town.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low pressure developing along a cold front moving through the region on Thursday February 4th moved off the southern Mid Atlantic coast on Friday February 5th, bringing heavy snow to southern Connecticut on the fifth.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Public and trained spotter reports indicated snowfall of 5 to 9 inches.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A tree was downed on North Street, blocking the road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A mild and humid air mass was in place over northwestern Connecticut during the early morning hours on Sunday, September 11th. A cold front was crossing through the region around sunrise and a potent line of thunderstorms accompanied the passage of this boundary. Some of these storms were severe, producing damaging winds to trees and power lines across northern parts of Litchfield County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trees and wires were downed in Salisbury due to thunderstorm winds.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A mild and humid air mass was in place over northwestern Connecticut during the early morning hours on Sunday, September 11th. A cold front was crossing through the region around sunrise and a potent line of thunderstorms accompanied the passage of this boundary. Some of these storms were severe, producing damaging winds to trees and power lines across northern parts of Litchfield County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trees and wires were downed in Torrington due to thunderstorm winds.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Below normal monthly precipitation that began in March of 2016, continued through September. In September, rainfall throughout northern Connecticut was below normal.||The Connecticut Department of Public Health issued a drought advisory for the state on June 27th. Soil moisture (measured by the Climate Prediction Center) was much drier than normal. Groundwater conditions (measured by the United States Geological Survey) were found to be below to well below normal. River and streamflow conditions were below to well below normal with 16 gage sites in southern New England at record low levels. ||Farmers have had to irrigate their crops much more than normal for September.  A few communities in northern Connecticut were encouraging voluntary water conservation, only one community had imposed mandatory water restrictions.  Three counties in Connecticut (two in the Taunton CWA) were declared primary disaster counties due to the drought. They include: Litchfield, Hartford, and Tolland Counties. Farms in these counties are eligible for assistance from the Farm Service Agency and the Livestock Forage Disaster Program.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The U.S. Drought Monitor expanded the Severe Drought (D2) designation into Hartford County on September 13th.

Soil moisture (measured by the Climate Prediction Center) was much drier than normal. Groundwater conditions (measured by the United States Geological Survey) were found to be below to well below normal. River and streamflow conditions were below to well below normal with 16 gage sites in southern New England at record low levels. ||Farmers have had to irrigate their crops much more than normal for September.  A few communities in northern Connecticut were encouraging voluntary water conservation, only one community had imposed mandatory water restrictions.  Three counties in Connecticut (two in the Taunton CWA) were declared primary disaster counties due to the drought. They include: Litchfield, Hartford, and Tolland Counties. Farms in these counties are eligible for assistance from the Farm Service Agency and the Livestock Forage Disaster Program.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Hermine was named on August 31st as it intensified to a tropical storm in the Gulf of Mexico. She meandered about in the eastern Gulf of Mexico before moving northeastward across the Florida panhandle, through Georgia and then along the coast of North and South Carolina. She was a hurricane as she made landfall in Florida, then weakened to a tropical storm and finally a tropical depression as she moved off the coast of North Carolina. After moving off the coast of North Carolina, Hermine moved northeast, then north, then west, meandering south of southern New England for several days in early September. ||While classified as a tropical system, Hermine's effects on southern New England were rather minimal. Rainfall added up to less than an inch for most locations and winds were generally below tropical storm force. Because trees were still fully leaved and we had higher wind gusts, there was some wind damage. Storm surge was highest during low tide so we had minimal coastal flooding impacts.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A tree was downed onto power lines at the intersection of Killingly Road and Bosworth Road in Pomfret.  A tree was downed onto Murdock Road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: In October, rainfall throughout much of northern Connecticut was below normal. Rainfall near the Rhode Island border was above normal.||During late October, a Drought Watch was issued for central and western portions of the State, including Tolland and Hartford Counties. This was a deterioration from the previously issued Drought Advisory. Windham County in northeastern Connecticut  remained in a Drought Advisory.  ||As part of Connecticut���s Drought Advisory, voluntary water conservation and adherence to any local water restrictions were encouraged. In addition, a report from the Connecticut Department of Heath indicated that a number of communities and water suppliers within the State had voluntary or mandatory water restrictions in effect during October.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The U.S. Drought Monitor continued the Severe Drought (D2) designation for most of Tolland County through the month of October. The exception was the far eastern portion of Tolland County from Union to Storrs, which was under a Moderate Drought (D1) designation for the month.

This was a deterioration from the previously issued Drought Advisory. Windham County in northeastern Connecticut  remained in a Drought Advisory.  ||As part of Connecticut���s Drought Advisory, voluntary water conservation and adherence to any local water restrictions were encouraged. In addition, a report from the Connecticut Department of Heath indicated that a number of communities and water suppliers within the State had voluntary or mandatory water restrictions in effect during October.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The U.S. Drought Monitor had a small portion of Windham County in Severe Drought (D2) during the month of October, although the vast majority of Windham County was only in a Moderate Drought (D1) category.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: In Killingly, the intersection of Mechanic Street and Westfield Avenue was flooded and impassable.  Two cars were stuck in flood waters at the Interstate 395 and Route 6 interchange.  The Interstate 395 connector (Governor John Davis Lodge Turnpike) from Route 6 on the CT/RI border was closed due to flooding. Several cars became stuck on the turnpike because of the closure.  In Danielson, an apartment complex on Cottage Street was flooded, resulting in an evacuation of all residents.  Finally, five cars were stuck in flood waters on West Road or Route 97 in Pomfret.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A trough of low pressure helped trigger an isolated severe storm, which impacted New Haven County. This storm produced a tornado.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Based on doppler weather radar data, information provided by|local broadcast media and emergency management, the National|Weather Service confirmed that a weak EF0 tornado occurred across|Southern New Haven County during Wednesday afternoon as a severe |thunderstorm moved east across Southern New Haven County, a |small weak tornado briefly touched down just south of North Haven.||Wind damage occurred on a line from about 1/4 mile west of I-91, to Quinnipiac Avenue near the Montowese section of North Haven east to Barberry Road. |Locations of wind damage included: Quinnipiac Avenue, Village Street, Fitch|Street, Governors Drive, Montowese Avenue by Cloudland, Montowese|Avenue, and Nettleton Avenue.  On Village Street, an 8 by 10 foot|shed was lifted about 15 feet up in a tree.||Damage was mainly limited to trees that fell onto power lines and|cars with only minor structural damage.||Based on this limited damage, this tornado is classified as an EF-0|with wind gusts up to 70 mph.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A few afternoon showers and thunderstorms developed in the deep moisture across northern Connecticut.  Several of these storms produced wind damage, flooding, and numerous lightning strikes.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Lightning struck a shed, lighting it on fire.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Below normal monthly precipitation that began in March of 2016, continued through August.  In August, rainfall through northern Connecticut was below normal except for portions of Tolland and Windham Counties where rainfall was actually above normal.  Unfortunately, the additional rainfall did little to dispel the drought conditions.  ||While northern Connecticut remained in a moderate drought (D1) designation (U.S. Drought Monitor) through much of August, the Connecticut Department of Public Health issued a drought advisory for the state on June 27th.  Soil moisture (measured by the Climate Prediction Center) was abnormally dry.  Groundwater conditions (measured by the United States Geological Survey) were found to be below to well below normal.  River and streamflow conditions were below to well below normal with 27 gage sites in southern New England at record low levels.||Farmers have had to irrigate their crops much more than normal for August.  Many sweet corn crops were not marketable due to drought.  Pumpkins and winter squash matured early due to the combination of drought and heat.  A few communities in northern Connecticut were encouraging voluntary water conservation, only one community had imposed mandatory water restrictions.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The U.S. Drought Monitor expanded the Severe Drought (D2) designation into Windham County from August 9th to August 16th.
