EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A powerful coastal storm impacted the region Friday through Sunday with North to Northeast Gale to Storm force winds. This resulted in several tidal cycle of minor to  coastal flooding Friday morning through Sunday morning, with locally moderate impacts occurring during the Saturday morning and Saturday night high tidal cycles.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The NOS tidal gauge at New Haven recorded a peak water level of 9.5 ft. MLLW at 1224 pm EST. This exceeded the moderate coastal flood threshold of 9.2 ft. MLLW between 1148am to 1254 pm. EST.

The building was located on Myrtle Avenue in Stamford per social media reports. Around 3 pm in Stamford, a section of a roof was torn off an apartment building on Myrtle Avenue per social media reports. At the same time, one person was injured in the town of New Cannaan due to another downed tree onto a pickup truck on Canoe Hill Road. The driver was rescued by first responders.

A winter storm brought mixed wintry precipitation to western Connecticut. Precipitation began as snow during the morning hours but changed to a mix of sleet, freezing rain and snow during the afternoon hours. Precipitation transitioned back to snow during the evening hours before exiting the region northwest to southeast. Snowfall and sleet totals ranged from 1 inch to 3 inches.
A deep area of low pressure passed off the coast.

Social media reported a large tree down onto Mitchell Drive in New Haven at 140 pm. In West Haven, media reports of many trees down across the town were received at 325 pm. Law Enforcement in the town of Hamden reported a tree and wires down at Circular Avenue and Gilbert Avenue at 325 pm.

Snowfall rates ranged from 1 to 3 inches per hour at times in the heaviest snow bands.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trained spotters, CoCoRaHS observers, and Amateur Radio reported 1 to 2 feet of snow. The highest totals were reported in New Fairfield and Newtown with 26.8 and 24.3 inches respectively.  Trees and wires were brought down across the town of Ridgefield due to heavy wet snowfall and strong winds.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A surface trough in a very warm and humid airmass triggered thunderstorms across the region.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A Tree down on wires on Swamp Road in Newtown, CT.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: After a frigid end of December and beginning of January, an unseasonably warm airmass was pumped into western New England on January 12th on southerly winds. The temperatures reached the 50s and 60s during the day. Showers also developed in the warm airmass ahead of a cold front and were heavy at times, with some locations receiving one to three inches of rainfall. The combination of warm temperatures and heavy rainfall caused river ice to dislodge and resulted in ice jams in spots. Flooding occurred due to a combination of ice jam movement and heavy rainfall. Several roads were closed or damaged and a few residences had to be evacuated. After the strong cold front passed, many ice jams and their associated flooding froze back in place, resulting in road closures continuing for several days in some areas.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Two ice jams on the Housatonic River spanning a mile caused flooding in Kent beginning on the morning of January 13th. The flood waters first went over Skiff Mountain Road and into the Kent School campus. The waters surrounded parked cars and an indoor ice rink on the campus. Students were sent home as flood waters rendered the campus inaccessible. Waters continued to rise during the afternoon, surrounding houses and necessitating technical rescues of residents on Johnson Road and South Main Street. A total of 12 people in four homes were evacuated. US Route 7, the main north-south route through Kent, was closed between Bulls Bridge Road and Route 341. Schaghticoke Road and River Road were also closed due to flooding. Frigid temperatures resulted in the jam and associated flooding freezing in place, extending the road closures for around a week. A state of emergency was declared for the Town of Kent.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Sodom Road was closed between Allyndale Road and Old Turnpike Road due to encroaching water and ice.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The development of the blizzard/winter storm began along the southeast coast on Wednesday January 3, 2018. An amplifying upper level trough spawned the development of low pressure off the coast of Florida. The low pressure rapidly intensified on Wednesday night through Thursday January 4, 2018 as it moved north-northeast along the coast. The low passed just east of the 40��N 70��W benchmark Thursday afternoon. The central pressure when the storm developed was around 1004 millibars at 1 pm Wednesday. 24 hours later, the central pressure fell to around 950 mb, approximately a 54 millibar drop. The rapid intensification of the storm led to heavy snow, strong winds, and blizzard conditions across Fairfield and New London Counties. Near-blizzard conditions occurred in New Haven and Middlesex counties due to the heaviest snow bands setting up to the east and west.  Thundersnow was also observed across southeast Connecticut. ||System-wide delays and cancellations occurred on the Metro North Railroad. Thousands of homes and businesses also lost power. ||There were numerous other accidents across southern Connecticut.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: CoCoRaHS observers and trained spotters reported 8 to 12 inches of snow. A COOP observer in Success Hill reported 9 inches of snow. The Igor I. Sikorsky Memorial Airport ASOS (Bridgeport, CT) measured a 52 MPH wind gust at 3:23 PM. Winds frequently gusted 40 to 50 MPH during the peak of the event. A jackknifed tractor trailer shut down Interstate 95 southbound in Darien, Connecitcut.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Igor I. Sikorsky Memorial Airport ASOS (Bridgeport, CT) observations showed blizzard conditions, with visibility less than one quarter mile in heavy snow and frequent wind gusts over 35 mph during the morning on January 4th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: CoCoRaHS observers and trained spotters reported 8 to 13 inches of snow. The Danbury Municipal Airport ASOS (Danbury, CT) measured a 40 MPH wind gust at 3:23 PM. Winds frequently gusted 30 to 40 MPH during the peak of the event.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low pressure developed along the North Carolina coast during the afternoon of January 29, 2018. The low moved off the coast to a location east of the 40��N/70��W benchmark during the morning of January 30, 2018. Heavy snow bands were able to develop well north and west of the low pressure system across southeastern Connecticut due to a strong upper level jet.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Social media reported 3 to 5 inches of snow.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A deep upper level trough swept across the southern US and turned northeastward offshore of the east coast from the morning of January 3 through the morning of January 4, 2018. The interaction between the cold upper trough and the relatively warmer Atlantic waters resulted in tremendous intensification of a surface low pressure system that tracked from around Miami, FL to just offshore of Cape Cod on January 3 and 4. A good deal of moisture wrapped into this system and was lifted across much of the East Coast, resulting in a broad area of moderate to heavy snowfall. A heavy band of snow impacted northwest Connecticut from the late morning through the afternoon hours of January 4, resulting in snowfall rates up to 3 per hour and total snowfall amounts mainly in the 7 to 15 inch range. Gusty northerly winds occurred with this system as well, with gusts of 30-45 mph recorded. The winds and falling snow contributed to reduced visibility and blowing and drifting of snow. The snowfall tapered off in the evening of January 4. ||As the system pulled away, brutally cold Arctic air rushed southward into Connecticut, resulting in an extended period of extremely cold conditions from January 5 through January 7. The coldest wind chills occurred during the mornings of January 6 and 7, when frigid air combined with westerly winds gusting to 30-40 mph resulted in widespread wind chills as low as 15 to 30 degrees below zero. High temperatures on January 6 were mainly in the single digits and lower teens. Many warming shelters were opened across the state as a result of the cold weather.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An approaching warm front brought temperatures into the 50s on the 23rd along with a batch of showers. Additional showers occurred in the evening along a cold front, bringing rainfall totals to a half inch to an inch across Litchfield County. The mild temperatures and rainfall caused the Housatonic River to rise in the vicinity of a long-lived ice jam near Kent, resulting in flooding, road closures, and evacuations of houses along the river.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flooding occurred in the vicinity of an ice jam on the Housatonic River as mild temperatures and rainfall caused the river to rise. Water was over Route 7 in spots, resulting in its closure between Route 341 and Bulls Bridge Road. Several homes were evacuated. Water was also over Schaghticoke Road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: After a frigid end of December and beginning of January, an unseasonably warm airmass was pumped into western New England on January 12th on southerly winds. The temperatures reached the 50s and 60s during the day. Showers also developed in the warm airmass ahead of a cold front and were heavy at times, with some locations receiving one to three inches of rainfall. The combination of warm temperatures and heavy rainfall caused river ice to dislodge and resulted in ice jams in spots. Flooding occurred due to a combination of ice jam movement and heavy rainfall. Several roads were closed or damaged and a few residences had to be evacuated. After the strong cold front passed, many ice jams and their associated flooding froze back in place, resulting in road closures continuing for several days in some areas.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: An ice jam resulted in water over a roadway.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An area of light freezing rain moved across Connecticut during the morning rush hour, causing numerous traffic accidents and a few road closures due to icing.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: At 656 AM EST, a multiple vehicle accident was reported on Hampden Road in Chaplin. At 702 AM EST, several accidents due to icing were reported in Willimantic with some roads closed.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure developed along a frontal boundary along the southeast coast on the evening of Saturday, February 17, 2018.  This low gradually became better organized as it moved up the coast towards the 40��N/70��W benchmark early Sunday, February 18, 2018. This system brought heavy snow to southwest Connecticut and light to moderate snowfall across central and eastern Connecticut. Warmer temperatures across the southeastern portion of the state limited snowfall accumulation.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: CoCoRaHS observers, trained spotters, and the public reported 3 to 6 inches of snowfall.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Nearby CoCoRaHS observers and trained spotters in northern New Haven and Northern New London counties reported 3 to 6 inches of snowfall.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A coastal storm passed offshore of Nantucket on January 30, while a surge of colder air moved in from the Great Lakes. This brought several inches of snow to Eastern Connecticut during the night of the 29th and the day of the 30th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: From three to six inches of snow fell on Windham County.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: CoCoRaHS observers, trained spotters, and the public reported 6 to 8 inches of snowfall. The heavy, wet snow also brought down wires on Boston Avenue at Bishop Avenue in Bridgeport.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system tracked southeast of New York, spreading moderate to heavy snowfall across Litchfield county, Connecticut. The snowfall primarily fell Saturday night into early Sunday morning, with reports of up to 7.5 inches in Litchfield county.

A storm moved out of the Gulf of Mexico, crossing Southern New England on the night of the 7th. This brought a period of snow changing to freezing rain across Northern Connecticut.  One-quarter inch of ice accumulation was reported.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: At 3 PM EST, several automobiles in Wethersfield suffered accidents due to icing on road surfaces.  At 315 PM EST, wires were reported down in the downtown area of Granby due to icing.  At 607 PM EST, multiple automobile accidents were reported in New Britain due to icing.  At 617 PM EST, multiple automobile accidents were reported in South Windsor, including one on West Street where a car crashed into a utility pole and caused a power outage.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A wave of low pressure developed across the southeastern states and tracked towards the northeast on February 7, 2018. The low brought a mixture of light snow and light freezing rain. The low pressure tracked a long a warm front which lifted across portions of the region helping to change any snow to freezing rain.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Danbury Airport ASOS reported 0.06 inches of freezing rain. The public reported 1.5 inches of snow in Wilton.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure developed along a frontal boundary along the southeast coast on the evening of Saturday, February 17, 2018.  This low gradually became better organized as it moved up the coast towards the 40��N/70��W benchmark early Sunday, February 18, 2018. This system brought heavy snow to southwest Connecticut and light to moderate snowfall across central and eastern Connecticut. Warmer temperatures across the southeastern portion of the state limited snowfall accumulation.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: CoCoRaHS observers, trained spotters, and the public reported 6 to 7 inches of snowfall.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure developed along a frontal boundary along the southeast coast on the evening of Saturday, February 17, 2018.  This low gradually became better organized as it moved up the coast towards the 40��N/70��W benchmark early Sunday, February 18, 2018. This system brought heavy snow to southwest Connecticut and light to moderate snowfall across central and eastern Connecticut. Warmer temperatures across the southeastern portion of the state limited snowfall accumulation.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trained spotters, amateur radio, CoCoRaHS, and the public reported 6 to 6.5 inches of snowfall.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low pressure over New York City early in the morning on November 3rd rapidly intensified as it moved northeastward across New England. Heavy rain occurred in the early morning hours, with generally 1.50 to 2.50 inches in eastern sections of southern New England and up to 3.66 inches in the slopes of the Berkshires. A few severe thunderstorms moved from Rhode Island into eastern Massachusetts around daybreak. As the strong low passed to our north, strong to damaging westerly winds developed during the afternoon.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: At 418 PM EDT in the Westford portion of the town of Ashford, a tree fell onto a house on Plain Street.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An area of low pressure rapidly intensified off the coast of Long Island on March 2nd, 2018. A large swath of tropical moisture was fed into the storm, resulting in a period of moderate to heavy precipitation throughout the day. The precipitation type was highly dependent on elevation, with lower elevations remaining mainly rain, while higher elevations saw a significant amount of snow. Snowfall accumulations ranged from around an inch up to nine inches over the higher terrain. In addition to the snow, strong winds gusting up to 45 mph resulted in scattered power outages.

Shortly after midnight on Tuesday, March 13th, a rapidly developing area of low pressure was off the mid-Atlantic coast. Light snow began to overspread the region in association with this system and began to increase in intensity towards daybreak. The snow became heavy through the mid-morning hours with snowfall rates of one to three inches per hour in the heaviest band. This low pressure continued to strengthen as it lifted northeast during the day, tracking well east of Cape Cod. Despite the storm taking a rather far easterly track, snowfall continued into the afternoon and evening hours with additional light accumulation. Snowfall totals ranged mainly from 8 to 16 inches, although far southwestern parts of Litchfield County saw only a few inches. This was the third heavy snowfall event in the first half of March 2018.

Shortly after midnight on Tuesday, March 13th, a rapidly developing area of low pressure was off the mid-Atlantic coast. Light snow began to overspread the region in association with this system and began to increase in intensity towards daybreak. The snow became heavy through the mid-morning hours with snowfall rates of one to three inches per hour in the heaviest band. This low pressure continued to strengthen as it lifted northeast during the day, tracking well east of Cape Cod. Despite the storm taking a rather far easterly track, snowfall continued into the afternoon and evening hours with additional light accumulation. Snowfall totals ranged mainly from 8 to 16 inches, although far southwestern parts of Litchfield County saw only a few inches. This was the third heavy snowfall event in the first half of March 2018.

A weakening low pressure system brought some light snow to northwestern Connecticut during the early to mid-morning hours of March 7th, 2018. Meanwhile, a Nor'easter strengthened rapidly along the Atlantic Coast, which resulted in increasing snow intensity during the afternoon and evening hours. Heavy snow bands rotated northwestward and stalled across the area, resulting in one to two feet of accumulation in most areas by the morning of March 8th. The snow led to very difficult travel conditions and resulted in numerous school closures. This event was the second major winter storm in less than a week.

A coastal storm moved up from the Carolinas, bringing snow and rain to Southern New England on March 7th and 8th.  This was primarily a snow event for Connecticut.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: From eight to fifteen inches of snow fell on Tolland County. At 8:05 PM EST a tree was down on wires on Westwood Road and Eastwood Road in Mansfield. At 8:13 PM EST a tree and wires were down on Stebbins Road in Somers. Also at 8:13 PM EST trees and wires were down on Old Stafford Road and on Susan Drive in Tolland. At 8:22 PM EST a tree was down on wires on Wheeling Road in Andover.At 8:44 PM EST a tree was down on a house on Spring Hill Road in Mansfield. At 8:52 PM EST a tree and wires were down on Prospect Street in Vernon.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A coastal storm moved up from the Carolinas, bringing snow and rain to Southern New England on March 7th and 8th.  This was primarily a snow event for Connecticut.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: From eight to sixteen inches of snow fell on Hartford County.  At 8:33 PM EST a tree was down on wires on Sutton Road in Rocky Hill. At 8:43 PM EST a tree was down blocking Treeborough Drive in West Hartford.  At 8:45 PM EST a tree and wires were down on Silo Road in Bristol. At 8:53 PM EST a large tree and wires were down across Meadow Gate Road in Granby. At 9:10 PM EST wires were down on Jordan Lane in Wethersfield. At 9:35 PM EST wires were down on New Britain Avenue between Willard Avenue and Main Street.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low pressure along the Carolina coast March 12 moved up the coast and passed offshore of Southern New England on March 13, moving off through the Maritimes on March 14. The storm brought snow accumulations of up to twenty inches in Northeast Connecticut and up to twelve inches in the Connecticut River Valley.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: From three to eleven inches of snow fell on Hartford County.

The storm brought snow accumulations of up to twenty inches in Northeast Connecticut and up to twelve inches in the Connecticut River Valley.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: From five to thirteen inches of snow fell on Tolland County.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: From five to eleven inches of snow fell on Windham County. At 12:35 AM EST trees and wires were reported down along Bungay Hill Road, State Route 171, and Beaver Dam Road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An early-season nor'easter moved from the Mid-Atlantic coast to southeastern Massachusetts on the 15th and away from the region on the 16th. A quick thump of heavy snow occurred on the front end of the storm, with most accumulations over with by or shortly after midnight on the 16th. Snowfall amounts averaged 5 to 9 inches across Hartford, Windham, and Tolland Counties in northern CT.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: CoCoRaHS, trained spotter, airport, and amateur radio observations measured an average of 7 inches across Hartford County.  Totals ranged from 4.5 inches in Enfield to 9.3 inches just to the northwest of Canton. Bradley International Airport in Windsor Locks recorded 7.9 inches.

Snowfall amounts averaged 5 to 9 inches across Hartford, Windham, and Tolland Counties in northern CT.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: CoCoRaHS, trained spotter, CoOp, and amateur radio observations measured an average of 7 inches across Tolland County.  Totals ranged from 5.0 inches in Storrs to 8.5 inches in Coventry.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An area of low pressure rapidly intensified off the coast of Long Island on March 2nd, 2018. A large swath of tropical moisture was fed into the storm, resulting in a period of moderate to heavy precipitation throughout the day. The precipitation type was highly dependent on elevation, with lower elevations remaining mainly rain, while higher elevations saw a significant amount of snow. Snowfall accumulations ranged from around an inch up to nine inches over the higher terrain. In addition to the snow, strong winds gusting up to 45 mph resulted in scattered power outages.

Heavy rainfall developed across the area on the morning of April 16th ahead of a slow moving warm front. This rain developed in an environment with precipitable water values greater than 1.25 inches, well above normal for mid April. Rainfall totals generally ranged from 2.0 to 4.0 inches across southern Connecticut, with the majority of the rain falling in a 3-4 hour period. This resulted in flash flooding across the region.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Quinnipiac River at Wallingford rose above its flood stage of 10.0 feet at 5:30pm EDT, crested at a height of 10.07 feet at 6:30am EDT, and fell below flood stage at 7:45pm EDT.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low pressure organized over the Ohio Valley on April 14th, swept to the Mid Atlantic coast on the 15th, and moved along the New England coast on the 16th.  This brought rain and some heavy downpours to Connecticut on the 16th, preceded by a mixture of snow, freezing rain, and rain.  The storm moved off through the Canadian Maritimes the night of the 16th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: At 12:59 PM EST, Trout Brook Road in Elmwood was reported flooded.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A powerful low pressure system and a trailing cold front passed through the region on Wednesday, April 4th. Strong, damaging winds occurred both with the frontal passage but also behind it as northwest flow ensued. This resulted in multiple reports of trees and wires down across Litchfield county.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Multiple reports of trees down on burning wires.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Waves of low pressure moved along a stalled frontal boundary across the Middle Atlantic. Moderate to heavy snow fell during the morning commute across southern Connecticut. Snowfall rates reached 1 inch per hour at times. A daily record snowfall for April 2nd of 6 inches was set at the Bridgeport Airport.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trained spotters, CoCoRaHS, and the public reported 6 to 8 inches of snowfall.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trained spotters and the public reported 4 to 6 inches of snow with locally higher amounts around 7 inches in Wallingford.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strengthening coastal low pressure system moved along the Atlantic shoreline November 15th and 16th, bringing 5 to 10 inches of snow and mixed precipitation to northwestern Connecticut. The snow spread in during the evening rush hour with one to three inches per hour accumulation, snarling traffic and resulting in numerous accidents. The snow tapered off overnight but resumed again during the morning hours of the 16th before ending.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong winds occurred ahead of deep low pressure and associated warm front.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: In the town of Stamford, law enforcement reported downed wires, which closed Newfield Drive from Newfield Avenue to Shadow Lane around 1037 am.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Showers and thunderstorms developed along a stationary front draped across southern Connecticut during the afternoon of September 12th. The 8am sounding from Upton, NY recorded a precipitable water value of 2.16 inches, a record for the date based on the Storm Prediction Center's sounding climatology. This resulted in very heavy downpours and flash flooding over southeast Connecticut. A cooperative observer in Norwich reported 4.62 inches of rain with these storms, the bulk of which fell over a period of 2-3 hours.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Water was inside the Octane Cafe at the corner of Tilley Street and Bank Street in New London.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A hot and humid air mass was in place across the region.  This provided an unstable environment for strong to severe thunderstorms to form ahead of a cold front passage during the afternoon and evening hours of June 18th. The storms caused numerous trees and power lines to be knocked down.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A tree was knocked down across a roadway.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Convection developed out ahead of an approaching cold front in a high precipitable water environment (around 2 inches based on the 12Z 6/28 OKX sounding), leading to isolated flash flooding across parts of coastal Fairfield County, CT. Rainfall amounts from CoCoRaHS gauges in the area ranged from 1-1.5 inches, the majority of which fell in a short period of time.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Numerous roads closed due to flooding in Darien including Heights Road, Post Road at Tokeneke Road, Post Road at Thorndal Circle, and Hoyt Street at Briar Brae Road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Convection developed out ahead of an approaching cold front in a high precipitable water environment (around 2 inches based on the 12Z 6/28 OKX sounding), leading to isolated flash flooding across parts of coastal Fairfield County, CT. Rainfall amounts from CoCoRaHS gauges in the area ranged from 1-1.5 inches, the majority of which fell in a short period of time.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A hot and humid airmass brought excessively high heat indices to northwestern Connecticut from the beginning of July through the Independence Day holiday. Temperatures soared as high as 99 degrees on July 1st, the hottest day of the stretch. Combined with dewpoints in the mid-70s, heat indices reached near 110 degrees in the warmest areas. In addition to the hot daytime temperatures, overnight low temperatures only falling into the 70s was common, which exacerbated heat-related problems. The extensive heat prompted the opening of many cooling centers across the region.

A hot and humid airmass brought excessively high heat indices to northwestern Connecticut from the beginning of July through the Independence Day holiday. Temperatures soared as high as 99 degrees on July 1st, the hottest day of the stretch. Combined with dewpoints in the mid-70s, heat indices reached near 110 degrees in the warmest areas. In addition to the hot daytime temperatures, overnight low temperatures only falling into the 70s was common, which exacerbated heat-related problems. The extensive heat prompted the opening of many cooling centers across the region.

Showers and thunderstorms developed along a stationary front draped across southern Connecticut during the afternoon of September 12th. The 8am sounding from Upton, NY recorded a precipitable water value of 2.16 inches, a record for the date based on the Storm Prediction Center's sounding climatology. This resulted in very heavy downpours and flash flooding over southeast Connecticut. A cooperative observer in Norwich reported 4.62 inches of rain with these storms, the bulk of which fell over a period of 2-3 hours.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several roads were closed due to flooding in New London including Broad Street at Ledyard Street, Bank Street between Howard Street and Tilley Street, Bank Street at Truman Street, Pequot Avenu at Green Harbor Beach, and Garfield Avenue at Elm Street.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Showers and thunderstorms developed along a stationary boundary during the morning of the 12th. The rainfall was locally heavy with isolated spots receiving two to four inches of rain. The rain resulted in isolated flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Old Mount Tom Road, a dirt road, was washed out due to flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A coastal storm moved to the east of the area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Around 10 am, three large trees were reported down in the lower section of Painter Park in West Haven.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A coastal storm moved to the east of the area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Social media reported a tree and wires down on Round Hill Road, which blocked the road at 1250 pm. This was in the town of Salem.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Showers and thunderstorms developed in a moist and unstable airmass ahead of an approaching cold front, leading to isolated flash flooding across parts of Fairfield County. Precipitable water values during the afternoon were around 2 inches, and rainfall totals in Fairfield County ranged from 1.00 in Stamford to 2.75 reported by a trained spotter in Trumble. The majority of the rain fell within a 2-3 hour period.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A vehicle was trapped in flood waters under the railroad overpass on West Broad Street between Knowlton Street and Linden Avenue in Stratford.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front crossed northwest Connecticut on the 6th, bringing and end to a four-day heat wave. This front sparked a broken line of thunderstorms during the afternoon as it interacted with the hot and humid airmass. Some of these storms became severe, resulting in scattered reports of wind damage.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A tree was downed onto wires.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A Bermuda high pumped in heat and high humidity across the area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The AWOS at Chester reported heat indices of 105 to 109 during the afternoon hours.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A Bermuda high pumped in heat and high humidity across the area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The AWOS at Chester reported heat indices of 105 to 109 during the afternoon hours.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low pressure approached from the south, and gusty easterly winds were observed ahead of it.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Around 2 am, the Fire Department reported trees and power lines down in Stratford. This occurred on Barnum Avenue. A CO-OP observer reported tree limbs down on a transformer on Pearl Street in Success Hill. This occurred at 230 am and resulted in a power outage.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low pressure moved north from the Florida coast and deepened, passing southeast of Nantucket on Thursday January 4.  The storm reached its lowest pressure and strongest pressure gradient as it passed Southern New England. This brought heavy snow and damaging winds to Connecticut.  The storm moved off through the Maritimes on January 5.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Six to fifteen inches of snow fell across Hartford County.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front moved into very warm humid air over Connecticut on September 6th. This brought showers and strong thunderstorms to the region during the afternoon and evening.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: At 3:20 PM EST, wind brought a tree and wires down on Skungamaug Road in Tolland.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A warm front approached from the south on Sept 25 and stalled just north of Massachusetts on Sept 26. This brought periods of heavy rain to Connecticut with 3 to 6 inches observed over Northeast Connecticut and 1 to 3 inches in Hartford County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: At 7:15 PM EST, Main Street in Willimantic was flooded and impassable.  A laundromat on Main Street reported water coming into the store.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A warm front approached from the south on Sept 25 and stalled just north of Massachusetts on Sept 26. This brought periods of heavy rain to Connecticut with 3 to 6 inches observed over Northeast Connecticut and 1 to 3 inches in Hartford County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: At 8:58 PM EST, Ash Street in Willimantic, near the Kingswood Apartments, was flooded, impassable, and had a road washout.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front crossed northwest Connecticut on the 6th, bringing and end to a four-day heat wave. This front sparked a broken line of thunderstorms during the afternoon as it interacted with the hot and humid airmass. Some of these storms became severe, resulting in scattered reports of wind damage.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A tree was downed onto wires.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low pressure moved north from the Florida coast and deepened, passing southeast of Nantucket on Thursday January 4.  The storm reached its lowest pressure and strongest pressure gradient as it passed Southern New England. This brought heavy snow and damaging winds to Connecticut.  The storm moved off through the Maritimes on January 5.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Eight to seventeen inches of snow fell across Tolland County.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low pressure moved north from the Florida coast and deepened, passing southeast of Nantucket on Thursday January 4.  The storm reached its lowest pressure and strongest pressure gradient as it passed Southern New England. This brought heavy snow and damaging winds to Connecticut.  The storm moved off through the Maritimes on January 5.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Eight to thirteen inches of snow fell across Windham County.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A slow-moving cold front crossed New England from the afternoon of January 12 to the morning of January 13. Strong southerly winds ahead of the front drew mild and humid air north over Southern New England. This helped generate heavy downpours before the front moved through.  Rainfall amounts ranged from one to three inches, except in Southeast Massachusetts where amounts ranged up to four inches.  Maximum wind gusts ranged from 45 to 65 mph.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: At 336 PM EST in Newington, Willard Avenue at Garfield Street was reported closed due to flooding. Rainfall between 1.5 inches and 3.0 inches was reported in Hartford County.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A late-season heat wave impacted northwestern Connecticut during the first week of September. A persistent warm and moist airmass characterized by daytime highs in the 90s and dewpoints in the 70s resulted in heat index values reaching 95-105 degrees during the afternoon hours. This heat wave coincided with the first week of school for many, and the heat prompted some schools to cancel or dismiss classes early and postpone or cancel sports practices.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front interacting with an unseasonably warm and humid airmass sparked an area of showers and thunderstorms during the evening of the 26th. These storms produced heavy rain, resulting in a few reports of flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Multiple washouts were reported along Route 44 near Salisbury with debris and rocks in the road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front crossed northwest Connecticut on the 6th, bringing and end to a four-day heat wave. This front sparked a broken line of thunderstorms during the afternoon as it interacted with the hot and humid airmass. Some of these storms became severe, resulting in scattered reports of wind damage.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A tree was downed onto wires.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front over the Great Lakes moved through Southern New England during the late afternoon and early night of May 15th.  The air mass over Connecticut was very warm and humid, and as the cold front moved into this air it generated numerous thunderstorms. Some thunderstorms produced damaging wind gusts, large hail, and heavy downpours.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: At 3:45 PM EST trees were reported down on both Duncaster Road and Hopkins Road in Bloomfield.

A tree was down across the road at U.S. Route 44 and Firetower Road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Rain developed across the area ahead of an approaching warm front, consolidating into a slow-moving band of heavy rain west of New York City that advanced eastward across southern Connecticut during the afternoon and evening. Precipitable water values increased from 1.84 on the morning sounding from Upton, NY to 2.13 by evening. Both of these values are above the 90th percentile based on a sounding climatology, with the 2.13 precipitable water value on the evening of the 25th a record for the date. Widespread rainfall amounts of 4 inches or more were reported across southern Connecticut with flash flooding resulting in numerous water rescues. A trained spotter in Trubmull received 7.32 inches of rain during the event, while a HAM radio operator in Lebanon received 6.79 inches. Automated stations near Durham and Hamden reported 7.24 and 8.59 inches of rain, respectively.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: All lanes were closed on Route 9 southbound between Exit 16 and Exit 1 in Middletown due to flooding.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: At 8:33 PM EST, Indian Hollow Road in Windham was reported flooded and impassable with debris in the road.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: An EF1 tornado struck the northeast side of Winsted, CT. The tornado moved west to east across eight city blocks, shearing and uprooting trees, and producing some minor structural damage to homes. Many homes and power lines were damaged by fallen trees. A member of the local community witnessed the tornado.

Both of these values are above the 90th percentile based on a sounding climatology, with the 2.13 precipitable water value on the evening of the 25th a record for the date. Widespread rainfall amounts of 4 inches or more were reported across southern Connecticut with flash flooding resulting in numerous water rescues. A trained spotter in Trubmull received 7.32 inches of rain during the event, while a HAM radio operator in Lebanon received 6.79 inches. Automated stations near Durham and Hamden reported 7.24 and 8.59 inches of rain, respectively.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Yantic River at Yantic rose above its flood stage of 9.0 feet at 12:00am EDT September 26th. It continued to rise and exceeded its moderate flood stage of 9.5 feet at 12:15am EDT and then its major flood stage of 11.0 feet at 1:00am EDT before cresting at a height of 12.53 feet at 2:45am EDT. This marks the sixth highest crest ever on the river at this location. The river fell back below flood stage at 3:30pm EDT on the 26th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A warm front approached from the south on Sept 25 and stalled just north of Massachusetts on Sept 26. This brought periods of heavy rain to Connecticut with 3 to 6 inches observed over Northeast Connecticut and 1 to 3 inches in Hartford County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: At 8:00 PM EST, Jennings Lane in Windham was flooded, impassable, and closed due to a possible washout.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Severe thunderstorms impacted portions of Litchfield County during the afternoon of May 15th. A supercell thunderstorm crossed northern portions of the county, resulting in hail up to two inches in diameter, two confirmed tornadoes, and straight-line wind damage. Later in the afternoon, a severe thunderstorm resulted in wind damage across far southern portions of the county. Numerous power outages and several road closures occurred as a result of the storms.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Public video confirmed a tornado over the Barkhamsted Reservoir. A National Weather Service damage survey team found no damage between Winsted, CT, and the reservoir. No damage was reported over the reservoir.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Rain developed across the area ahead of an approaching warm front, consolidating into a slow-moving band of heavy rain west of New York City that advanced eastward across southern Connecticut during the afternoon and evening. Precipitable water values increased from 1.84 on the morning sounding from Upton, NY to 2.13 by evening. Both of these values are above the 90th percentile based on a sounding climatology, with the 2.13 precipitable water value on the evening of the 25th a record for the date. Widespread rainfall amounts of 4 inches or more were reported across southern Connecticut with flash flooding resulting in numerous water rescues. A trained spotter in Trubmull received 7.32 inches of rain during the event, while a HAM radio operator in Lebanon received 6.79 inches. Automated stations near Durham and Hamden reported 7.24 and 8.59 inches of rain, respectively.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several streets flooded in Old Greenwich including Lockwood Avenue, Sound Beach Avenue, and Benjamin Street with at least two feet of standing water making roads impassable.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Hazy, hot and humid conditions enveloped the region from Tuesday, August 28th through Wednesday, August 29th. This prompted a heat advisory to be issued both days for all locations below 1000 feet. Maximum heat index values ranged from the low 90's to the low 100's.

A series of disturbances ahead of a cold frontal boundary brought rounds of heavy rainfall and strong to severe thunderstorms to the region during the afternoon and evening hours of Friday, August 17th. As a result of these disturbances, numerous trees and wires were downed across the region. Rainfall from the event ranged from 1 to 3 inches.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A large tree, wires and transformer were down on Robbins Road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A moist, tropical environment was in place across southern New England on the morning of August 4th.  A short-wave trough was approaching, along with a cold front.  The main concern was for flash flooding, but early morning sunshine destabilized the atmosphere and contributed to the development of the tornado, which also touched down again in Massachusetts.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: An EF-0 tornado, with wind speeds estimated at 80 mph, touched down on Redhead Hill Road in northern Woodstock and traveled just over 5 miles on a discontinuous path before lifting up in the Quinebaug portion of Thompson.  It was only 8 yards wide.  It sliced a single, healthy oak tree in half and flattened small portions of two separate corn fields on Redhead Hill Road in Woodstock.  The corn was laid down in differenet directions. A woman saw swirling of trees and other debris as it occurred, despite it being enshrouded in rain.  Isolated tree damage also was spotted on Watson Road, near Green Acres Lane, in Quinebaug.  The tornado lasted from 936 AM EDT to 945 AM EDT.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front over the Great Lakes moved through Southern New England during the late afternoon and early night of May 15th.  The air mass over Connecticut was very warm and humid, and as the cold front moved into this air it generated numerous thunderstorms. Some thunderstorms produced damaging wind gusts, large hail, and heavy downpours.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: At 4:35 PM EST trees and wires were reported down on Snow lane at Kennerson Reservoir Road in Ashford.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: At 8:50 PM EST, three feet of water was reported on Walts Hill road in North Bloomfield.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A tornado touched down near the intersection of Bethany Road and|Bonna Street in Beacon Falls, destroyed a barn in Bethany, and|continued on to just west of Sleeping Giant State Park in Hamden,|where the damage path broadened and became more straight-line in|nature. The tornado left a path of numerous uprooted and snapped |hardwood and pine trees. Based on this information, this tornado |is classified as an EF1 with maximum winds of 110 mph.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A warm front approached from the south on Sept 25 and stalled just north of Massachusetts on Sept 26. This brought periods of heavy rain to Connecticut with 3 to 6 inches observed over Northeast Connecticut and 1 to 3 inches in Hartford County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: At 7:50 PM EST, State Route 66 near Columbia Motorsports in Columbia was closed due to flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An approaching cold front triggered numerous severe thunderstorms over southern Connecticut. These storms produced 2 tornadoes in the Lower Hudson Valley, as well as microbursts and macroburts.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Numerous trees and wires down around town.  Roads impassable.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An approaching cold front triggered numerous severe thunderstorms over southern Connecticut. These storms produced 2 tornadoes in the Lower Hudson Valley, as well as microbursts and macroburts.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Tree fell on truck in Candlewood Lake area killing a man.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A storm passing west of Connecticut brought strong south winds to northern Connecticut on Friday December 21. The same storm also brought one to four inches of rain.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: At 2:05 PM EST, multiple cars were trapped in eighteen inches of flood waters at junction of School Street and Prestige Park Road in East Hartford.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level shortwave and surface cold front moved across the region during the early evening hours of December 17th. Snow showers organized into a band of moderate to heavy snow with occasional squalls that impacted the region throughout the evening. Snow squall warnings were issued for some of these bands of heavy snow and gusty winds. Snowfall accumulations of up to an inch were reported from these squalls. Strong winds ensued behind the cold frontal passage with several wind reports up to 40 mph.
An approaching cold front triggered numerous severe thunderstorms over southern Connecticut. These storms produced 2 tornadoes in the Lower Hudson Valley, as well as microbursts and macroburts.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trees fallen into two homes on Danenberg Place in West Haven.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A storm passing west of Connecticut brought strong south winds to northern Connecticut on Friday December 21. The same storm also brought one to four inches of rain.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: At Noon EST, a tree was reported down on Orchard Road in West Hartford.  At 1:37 PM EST power lines were reported down across a driveway on Curtis Street in Bristol.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A deepening low pressure system moved up the spine of the Appalachians into New York, spreading moderate to heavy rainfall into New England from Thursday, December 20th into Friday, December 21st, 2018. Total rainfall amounts ranged from an inch up to almost 4 inches in Litchfield county. This rainfall prompted several river flood warnings as well as areal flood warnings and advisories to be issued. ||Behind the departing low pressure system, winds became strong, with gusts up to 40 mph recording in Litchfield county, Connecticut.

This rainfall prompted several river flood warnings as well as areal flood warnings and advisories to be issued. ||Behind the departing low pressure system, winds became strong, with gusts up to 40 mph recording in Litchfield county, Connecticut.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Route 317 in Woodbury was closed due to a downed tree.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Severe thunderstorms impacted portions of Litchfield County during the afternoon of May 15th. A supercell thunderstorm crossed northern portions of the county, resulting in hail up to two inches in diameter, two confirmed tornadoes, and straight-line wind damage. Later in the afternoon, a severe thunderstorm resulted in wind damage across far southern portions of the county. Numerous power outages and several road closures occurred as a result of the storms.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several large trees were snapped or uprooted. Some roads were impassable. Shingles were torn off of New Milford High School.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Severe thunderstorms impacted portions of Litchfield County during the afternoon of May 15th. A supercell thunderstorm crossed northern portions of the county, resulting in hail up to two inches in diameter, two confirmed tornadoes, and straight-line wind damage. Later in the afternoon, a severe thunderstorm resulted in wind damage across far southern portions of the county. Numerous power outages and several road closures occurred as a result of the storms.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Twenty residences in the town of Bridgewater were damaged due to falling trees. One lane of Curtis Road was closed between Route 67 and Hat Shop Hill Road due to fallen wires.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low pressure moving up the spine of the Appalachians resulted in widespread heavy rainfall and reports of flash flooding across portions of southern Connecticut. A record high precipitable water value of 1.66 inches was recorded on the 12Z sounding from Upton, NY. Rainfall amounts across the region ranged from 1.5 to 4.5. A CoCoRaHS observer near Bedford reported 4.33 inches of rain from this event, while a CoCoRaHS observer near Prospect reported 4.02 inches. The ASOS at Bridgeport Airport recorded 1.97 inches of rain.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Route 15 was closed northbound at Exit 68W in Meriden due to flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Intensifying low pressure moving up the spine of the Applachians on December 21st and into southern Quebec the morning of the 22nd produced strong southeast winds.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A mesonet station in the town of Stamford reported a wind gust of 50 mph at 753 am.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front moved east from the Great Lakes and crossed Connecticut the night of the 17th.  A pre-frontal trough preceded the front mid-afternoon of the 17th.  This brought thunderstorms with damaging winds and downpours.  This also caused a tornado in Ashford, crossing Ashford Lake during mid afternoon.  Two to three inches of rain fell in local downpours.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: At 2:45 PM EST, a thunderstorm over Stafford Springs brought a tree down on wires on Diamond Ledge Road.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: At 3:19 PM EST, a thunderstorm over Pomfret brought a small tree down and left other debris on Quasset Road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An area of high pressure over the Eastern USA brought hot and very humid air to Southern New England on July 1st. Heat Index values of 105 to 109 occurred in parts of Northern Connecticut, while the remainder of the region had values around 100.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Automated Surface Observing System platform at Hartford-Brainard Airport observed a heat index of 108 on July 1st from 1 PM to 2 PM EST and again from 5 to 6 PM EST.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An area of high pressure over the Eastern USA brought hot and very humid air to Southern New England on July 1st. Heat Index values of 105 to 109 occurred in parts of Northern Connecticut, while the remainder of the region had values around 100.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Automated Surface Observing System platform at Windham Airport rose to 109 from 1 PM to 6 PM EST on July 1st.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front moved east from the Great Lakes and crossed Connecticut the night of the 17th.  A pre-frontal trough preceded the front mid-afternoon of the 17th.  This brought thunderstorms with damaging winds and downpours.  This also caused a tornado in Ashford, crossing Ashford Lake during mid afternoon.  Two to three inches of rain fell in local downpours.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: At 3 PM EST, an EF-0 tornado touched down west of Ashford Lake and moved generally east for about one minute. Damage was confined to a narrow area bounded by North Road to the west and Ashford Lake to the east, and by Birchwood drive to the north and Westview Drive to the south. Numerous large trees were uprooted in this area. While the tornado was over the lake, a local resident observed water from the lake was lifted fifty to sixty feet into the air.  The tornado then lifted off the surface over the east end of Ashford Lake.  Overall, the tornado had maximum winds of 85 MPH.  Numerous trees were uprooted by the tornado along its path. Path length was 0.4 miles and width was 225 yards.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: At 2:05 PM EST, a thunderstorm crossing Farmington Connecticut brought a tree and wires down on Colton Street, and a tree was brought down on Reservoir Road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low pressure over upstate New York moved east-southeastward across Southern New England during the afternoon and early evening. A warm front boundary extending eastward from the low, combined with strong mid-level wind shear, provided the focus for thunderstorms in Connecticut.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Penny-size hail fell on Union.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low pressure from the Gulf of Mexico moved up the East Coast on October 27th and 28th, bringing rain and strong winds to mainly the eastern half of southern New England.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: In Chaplin, a tree was down on wires on Tower Hill Road at 336 PM EDT.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An approaching cold front triggered severe thunderstorms across southwestern Connecticut, including one tornado in Fairfield County.
An approaching cold front triggered severe thunderstorms across southwestern Connecticut, including one tornado in Fairfield County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Large tree down on West Norwalk Road near Stony Lane.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An approaching cold front triggered severe thunderstorms across southwestern Connecticut, including one tornado in Fairfield County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Tree down on West Norwalk Road and Ravenwood Road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An approaching cold front triggered severe thunderstorms across southwestern Connecticut, including one tornado in Fairfield County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A National Weather Service (NWS) Storm Survey of damage was conducted with|Connecticut Emergency Management and Homeland Security and the New Canaan|and Norwalk Offices of Emergency Management in the area from New Canaan to Norwalk. Based on the results of this survey and NWS Doppler Radar data the following information has been determined. The tornado began near the intersection of Weed Street and Marshall Ridge Road in New Canaan and lifted near the intersection of Scribner Avenue and Orlando Road in Norwalk. Extensive tree damage was observed, and some of the trees fell on parked cars. The most significant damage was in New Canaan, where multiple trees were both uprooted and snapped. This damage is consistent with maximum wind speeds of around 100 mph, making this an EF-1 tornado. The tornado had a maximum path width of around 100 yards and was on the ground for around three and three-quarter miles.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Cool northeast flow was in place across the region but a warm front attempted to move north through Connecticut just as a mid-level short wave trough was approaching. Low pressure from the Midwest moved along the boundary, crossing New England at night. Instability and unseasonably high moisture generated damaging thunderstorms and downpours. A brief tornado also touched down in Mansfield, CT during the early evening.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: At 4:43 PM EST, a car was reported trapped in flood waters on Lyme Street near the Breakthrough II Magnet School.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level disturbance associated with an upper level low in Southeastern Canada, along with a surface trough of low pressure approaching from the west resulted in a line of severe thunderstorms which produced a tornado over Fishers Island, NY.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The EF0 tornado touched down on North Anguilla Road about |three tenths of a mile south of Miner Pentway, then tracked northeast |towards North Anguilla Road at Miner Pentway. Across the properties of |5 homes, over 30 large oak trees were uprooted and downed in a |convergent pattern, as well as numerous large tree limbs broken.||The tornado briefly lifted and then touched down again near the |intersection of Route 184 and Route 2 with a few large oak trees downed |around the traffic circle. The tornado continued east-northeast along |Route 184 for about 350 yards, before turning northeast over Surrey Rd. |Clusters of tree damage, including uprooted oak trees in a convergent |pattern and snapped branches, were noted along this path.||The tornado appears to have briefly lifted before finally touching down and then |dissipating about 800 yards to the northeast of Surrey Rd. This is in |the vicinity of the intersection of Route 49 and Babcock Road, where |numerous trees were uprooted and downed on both sides of the road. |The uprooting and downing of trees from wet grounds and the |nature of tree branch damage was consistent with estimated maximum |winds speeds of 85 mph.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Cool northeast flow was in place across the region but a warm front attempted to move north through Connecticut just as a mid-level short wave trough was approaching. Low pressure from the Midwest moved along the boundary, crossing New England at night. Instability and unseasonably high moisture generated damaging thunderstorms and downpours. A brief tornado also touched down in Mansfield, CT during the early evening.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The National Weather Service in Norton confirmed that a weak EF-0 tornado touched down in Mansfield, CT. This was based on a number of sources, including an eyewitness account, information from the Mansfield Emergency Management Agency Director, aerial drone footage provided by the media, and a weak tornado debris signature seen on Doppler radar. ||Trees were downed, in a chaotic pattern, starting from just west of Storrs Road (Route 195) between Cemetery Road and Bassetts Bridge Road, continuing east-northeastward across Cemetery Road, and ending just to the east of the southernmost portion of Echo Road. Several shingles were blown off a roof on Storrs Road and were found 500 yards downwind. A person living on Centre Street, just west of Echo Lake observed a swirling mass of leaves and sticks passing to his southeast, some of which were hitting his house. The Mansfield Emergency Management Agency Director walked the path and found that downed trees north of Cemetery Road were facing the southwest while they were mainly facing northeast just to the south of Cemetery Road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A Nor'easter tracked northward along the east coast Friday night into Saturday and brought strong winds, rain and mountain snow to western New England on Saturday, October 27th, 2018.  This storm resulted in reports of trees and wires down across Litchfield county, with wind gust reports up to 40 mph.
An approaching cold front triggered severe thunderstorms across southwestern Connecticut, including one tornado in Fairfield County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trees reported down across Merritt Parkway at Exit 37.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A wave of low pressure developed along the Middle Atlantic coast during Thursday November 15, 2018. The low was associated with a closed upper level trough across the Midwest. As the trough translated eastward into Friday November 16, 2018, the low pressure moved up the northeast coast. The antecedent air mass ahead of the low was cold and dry for the middle of November with temperatures during the morning and afternoon of November in the upper 20s and low 30s.  The moisture associated with the trough and low pressure was able to produce moderate to heavy bands of snow as the precipitation began across the entire Tri-State area due to the cold air in place. Once the low drew warmer air from the south, the precipitation gradually changed to a wintry mix and then plain rain, especially for coastal Connecticut.  The moderate to heavy wet snowfall impacted the evening rush hour with 1-2 inch per hour snowfall rates. Numerous accidents were reported in Southern Connecticut and many motorists were stranded on roads until the early morning hours the next morning. Many tree limbs and branches being brought down by the weight of the snow, which also caused power outages.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: An Emergency Manager in Bethel reported 8 inches of snow. A trained spotter in New Fairfield reported 12 inches of snow. Trained spotters, Amateur Radio, CoCoRaHS, and the public reported 6 to 9 inches of snow.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A wave of low pressure developed along the Middle Atlantic coast during Thursday November 15, 2018. The low was associated with a closed upper level trough across the Midwest. As the trough translated eastward into Friday November 16, 2018, the low pressure moved up the northeast coast. The antecedent air mass ahead of the low was cold and dry for the middle of November with temperatures during the morning and afternoon of November in the upper 20s and low 30s.  The moisture associated with the trough and low pressure was able to produce moderate to heavy bands of snow as the precipitation began across the entire Tri-State area due to the cold air in place. Once the low drew warmer air from the south, the precipitation gradually changed to a wintry mix and then plain rain, especially for coastal Connecticut.  The moderate to heavy wet snowfall impacted the evening rush hour with 1-2 inch per hour snowfall rates. Numerous accidents were reported in Southern Connecticut and many motorists were stranded on roads until the early morning hours the next morning. Many tree limbs and branches being brought down by the weight of the snow, which also caused power outages.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trained spotters, amateur radio, CoCoRaHS, and the public reported 4 to 7 inches of snow. There were major travel disruptions on the Metro North during the evening commute.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Easterly Gale to Storm force winds resulted in tidal departures |of 3-5 ft above astronomical high tides around the times of high |tide overnight into early Friday morning.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The water level at the New Haven NOS tidal gauge reached a peak of 9.6 ft MLLW between 05:27 AM EST and 05:51 AM EST on the 16th.||The moderate coastal flood threshold of 9.2 ft MLLW was exceeded between 04:57 AM EST and 06:21 AM EST.
